corn millet muffin.review: So we took a Cousin here during a 12 hr layover. We had seen the vids on YouTube about it and we were pleasantly surprised. Sunday morning about 9am the wait was about 45min. But worth it. I had "The Plow" plate which incl. two eggs, some really delicious Rosemary country potatoes, awesome sausage pattys, and to finish off, what I came for, Lemon Ricotta Pancakes!  If you visit for the pancakes alone it's worth it. They were fluffy , light and just lemony enough to not be overpowering and the ricotta, well let's just say I'm adding ricotta to my pancake mix from now on. Also delish was the corn millet muffin.

excerpts: so we opted for corn millet muffin which was good.
corn millet muffin.author: T L.
corn millet muffin.review:
(See pics) Review #1192. Great all local purveyors ingredients brunch that brightens up any gloomy day or energizes a sunny day.

The day we visited, they were out of monkey bread so we opted for corn millet muffin which was good.

The Plow with the two eggs, Nueske bacon, chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes was a total brunch that had everything you need and desire. The bacon and sausage were good salty, sweet and meaty, while the pancakes definitely were the highlight. Eggs were prepared perfectly to my likeness.

As mentioned many times in my other reviews, I love locally roasted beans. Equator coffee was earthy and was happily light roasted.

My friend had the fried egg on Acme bun that was hearty and freshly tasted.

Mimosa was nice but more orange juice than sparkling wine.

Many had wondered about the San Francisco style long wait and yes even on a rainy weekend we we visited. However, the server was extremely helpful and actually told us not to go get coffee up the street because there would be a table coming up shortly and if those who were not there while called, they would lose the spot. Amazing enough, we only waited for 10 minutes. While the place was completely packed, service was super friendly and perky, we were never rushed to finish, though we were considerate to not hold up the tables.

Do wish they were closer to public transit stops.

excerpts:
We had:

- Corn Millet Muffin with sweet butter
corn millet muffin.author: Cathy K.
corn millet muffin.review:
If I could design my dream neighborhood, Plow would be in it. I dig its modern, clean lines, natural wood furnishings, high ceiling, big windows, sunlight, and its local, organic, sustainable offerings Their amiable staff are like a well oiled machine - efficient and reliable. I was impressed by how quickly they turned the tables to greet its waiting patrons. 

We had:

- Corn Millet Muffin with sweet butter * - my sharp-eyed friend noticed that the asterisked items are 'until it's gone' ~  the law of supply & demand bumped them up as a priority to consider. The muffin had a nice texture, flavor and a dash of warmth. On the other hand, its butter sidekick was cold & hard, making it awkward to spread on the delicate muffin ~ if I had a lighter, I could've softened it a bit.

- Coffee Cake * - Although it didn't stand out, it was a good, sweet compliment to our meal. 

- Pork Chops (a bit too briny for my palate, but cooked to a nice doneness). Came with crispy potatoes and eggs prepared your way - we chose scrambled.

- Eggs Benedict with Spinach and Mushrooms - My favorite. Eggs poached perfectly with a deliciously flavorful hollandaise sauce and crispy potatoes with caramelized onions (same potatoes that accompanied the Pork Chops).

Our meal was delightful ~ I couldn't stop eating. I was tempted to call the local wheelbarrow company to cart me out.

excerpts: The basket featured a corn millet muffin, a currant scone and a buttermilk biscuit, all of which were exceptional with oh-so-good perfect crunchiness on the top.
corn millet muffin.author: Stephanie W.
corn millet muffin.review:
When they tell you that the wait is going to be an hour and twenty minutes, they're not joking. Really. If you're not keen on waiting, I'd recommend arriving right when they open at 8am, not at 11am like normal Sunday brunchers. 

After an hour and a half chilling on the sidewalk, needless to say we were starving. In fact, I was so hungry I could barely hold a conversation. Luckily, our waitress was super sweet and took our order right away. We decided to start with the bakery basket, which came out promptly and steaming hot and fresh. There's nothing like pastries baked that morning to start a day off right, and these were no exception. The basket featured a corn millet muffin, a currant scone and a buttermilk biscuit, all of which were exceptional with oh-so-good perfect crunchiness on the top. (We might, of course, have been slightly biased by how hungry we were.)

Despite the wait to be seated, once we ordered our food it actually came out pretty quickly. The portions were the perfect size, and everything was wonderful, from the different kinds of eggs to the crispy potatoes to the pancakes to the biscuits and gravy. Oh, and not to mention the creme brulee our waitress talked us into for dessert. Even though we were stuffed, my friends and I were still nearly licking the ramekin. 

Other lovely things:
- Even though the place is tiny, there are high ceilings and big windows so it feels airier and larger than it is
- Service was delightful. There were also enough people working to keep everything moving quickly (except table turnover...)
- The kitchen is entirely open, so you can see everything as it's happening. 
- The menu is full of a million things I'd love to try, and all the ingredients are sourced fresh from local farms.

Unfortunately, because of the hour and a half wait, I don't think we'll be heading back here any time soon. I just can't wait that long for my breakfast, at least not without getting something to eat first.

excerpts: The breakfast basket had a warm, savory corn millet muffin that melted in my mouth.
The jams were particularly tasty as well.
corn millet muffin.author: Annie F.
corn millet muffin.review:
Ah, I am so glad breakfast spots like this exist!  I was tired of greasy spoons that serve overcooked eggs in pools of canola oil.  Sometimes, you want to wake up and have some clean, fresh breakfast eggs and potatoes and you don't want to carry it around with you all day!

I went here with a big group of 8 last weekend and considering how small plow is, they were quite happy and willing to accommodate us as soon as they could (which on a beautiful Sunday took about 20 minutes).

The food is delicious.  We tried almost everything.  The breakfast basket had a warm, savory corn millet muffin that melted in my mouth.  The jams were particularly tasty as well.  The orange scone and buttermilk thingy had just the right amount of sweetness - I hate overly sugary scones!

We also got quite a few salads - now somewhere in the review list a person was freaking out about rotten greens.  In my experience, we got EVERY kind of salad and there was NO ROTTEN greens.  The arugula had dressing on it, but it was fantastic and complemented the persimmons perfectly.

Other highlights - the fried egg sandwich. It's huge, and when you bite into it, the yolk pours out.  Mmmmm.  The french toast and market omelette were fresh and tasty.  The housemade sausage patties were perfectly cooked.  And the pumpkin pancakes made me want to do a backflip.  Of course, our plow dish was filling and fun.  I love eating eggs, potatoes, and pancakes all in one!  And they're mini-pancakes so you're not overly stuffed.

Finally, we got this pumpkin cheesecake at the end. Normally, I don't like cheesecake because it's too rich and sweet, but this one had cream and pumpkin spice that blended just right.  It was all, I'll say it again, delicious.

My final say is that if you're looking for a greasy spoon, this is not the place for you.  But if you're looking for a clean, fresh breakfast/brunch with top-of-the-line ingredients (they even list the farms/food places they get their ingredients from at the bottom of the menu), then go to plow!  It feels great to leave brunch and not have a rock in your stomach.

almond flour pancakes.review:
Plow is a pretty good place to get standard brunch fare. If you come early, the wait is really worth it! 

I've always come at opening time around 8 AM and probably wouldn't wait more than 30 min for it, so I highly recommend coming early. 

The menu consists of options like Soft Scrambled Eggs, Sausage & Eggs, Eggs Benedict, etc. It seems like the more popular dishes are the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and The Plow.

The Plow ($17.5) - Two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes with choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I ended up getting the Annie's Almond Flour Pancakes since it was GF which tasted great! The chicken apple sausage was also pretty good too. I had a side of fruit which cost a little more, but also tried the potatoes and they were really delicious

Plow stands out because of it's simple, yet delicious and quality ingredients. It does run on the expensive side though.

almond flour pancakes.review:
We've been coming to plow for a couple of years and always bring our friends who are visiting from out of town to plow. The best times to go there to avoid the long wait is during the week.otherwise, expect a minimum of an hour wait. 
As you are waiting, you can visit the neighborhood, grab some coffee and enjoy a nice quiet walk.

We have pretty much ordered everything on the menu and our all time favorite is the plow and the egg sandwich. The plow contains of two lemon ricotta pancakes, wedge potatoes, a choice of bacon, pork belly bacon or sausage and 2 eggs. If you don't eat meat, you can substitute the bacon or sausage with avocado or salad. If you are gluten intolerant, you can substitute the ricotta pancakes with almond flour pancakes. But please know that there's cross contamination as all of their gluten items are cooked in the same fryer. 

You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. The long wait is always worth it for me!

almond flour pancakes.review:
As a native, I've tried a variety of brunch spots ranging from the most Instagram Famous all the way down to the cheapest hole in the wall spots in San Francisco.  What I've learned is to not let all places with 1-2 hour waits prove themselves worthy based on how esthetically  pleasing their decor looks or how well their food photographs. With that being said, Plow is easily one of the few places in SF that is NOT worth the 1-2 hour wait, money or camera space. If you're going to wait anywhere for a table during brunch, do yourself a favor and play the waiting game at better restaurants like Kitchen Story, Sweet Maple or Mission Beach Cafe. Luckily service was nice and attentive which is always the more important everlasting impression anyways. 

The Breakfast Sandwich with Bacon- the best part about this sandwich was the cheddar cheese, aioli and frisée. The eggs are supposed to be served soft, but mine in particular came out hard. Bacon was soggy. 

The Plow- basically Plow's version of a Denny's Grand Slam. I hate lemon but love ricotta. I gave the lemon ricotta pancakes a try but if you're anything like me then definitely skip out on these. I overheard another customer sub out these pancakes for the almond flour pancakes instead. House made pork sausage patties tastes like Italian sausage by the brand New York Style Sausage Company that you can buy at Safeway. 

Buttermilk Biscuit with honey butter- best thing we ordered! It was a hybrid of a cornbread and biscuit.

almond flour pancakes.author: Patricia A.
almond flour pancakes.review:
Went here for brunch on a Sunday afternoon. It was packed. Of course. The wait turned out to be a two hour wait, but I mean what do you expect? The brunch scene in SF is legit crazy! 

The overall restaurant was really small. Groups bigger than 5-6 I think would be hard to accommodate. There's outside seating also. There is only 1 bathroom, so there's usually another wait to go to the bathroom. However, the bathroom is big and clean.

I ordered the almond flour pancakes, side of fruits, and strawberry lemonade. The pancakes were so fluffy and aaaaamazing! I highly recommend it. Although, the fruits and strawberry lemonade was not really anything special. I also do think it was a bit overpriced. ($7 or so for a small plate of fruits). 

The wait is ridiculous, so I definitely would take that into account when you come here! The food was good, although some items on the menu I would recommend not getting since it is a bit overpriced. 

I do recommend checking this place out.

excerpts: But the menu also has chia seed pudding and a plate of gluten free, almond flour pancakes.
almond flour pancakes.author: Nicole C.
almond flour pancakes.review:
If you reside in San Francisco and do not live under a rock, chances are you've heard of Plow. This may be because the food is delicious. It is equally possible you know them only for their ridiculous wait times (a problem that has become emblematic of any metropolitan area with a love of basic, bougie, boozy brunch). 

Brief summary of why the food is great. Any Google search will yield that it is "comfort" and "rustic style." What this means in practice is an almost southern amount of decadence with all of the artisanal perks of any bay area establishment. You have your all inclusive brunch platter called "The Plow." But the menu also has chia seed pudding and a plate of gluten free, almond flour pancakes. 

More on The Plow. It's probably the best option on the menu, especially for a first timer. Eggs are prepared to your liking, and you get the choice between pork sausage, chicken apple sausage, and bacon. However the main attractions are the potatoes (so popular they are named "plow potatoes"). These little guys are perfectly crispy on the outside but ultimately melt on your tongue. Anyone on a diet--please evacuate immediately. To add insult to carbaphobic injury, the lemon ricotta pancakes are delicious. They are smaller than you'd expect, which is both a curse and a blessing.

The great food isn't the only reason this place is so busy. The interior of the restaurant is tiny, as if it is trying to spite you and your hungry stomach. There is ample outdoor seating for those who are waiting to be seated, but I'd also recommend exploring the surrounding area, or even walking all the way to the Mission, like one Yelper did. You will literally have enough time to walk several miles and back (if you can bear the hill, that is). Especially if you're trying to score brunch on a Sunday (but why would you do that to yourself). Alternatively, ordering a grapefruit mimosa is another good way to kill time.

If you plan on wandering--which I highly suggest--make sure you call them periodically or come back by the suggested time. When they invite people to come in, they do not call said people on the phone. If you aren't there, your spot is lost to the next people in line. I'm pretty sure they do this on purpose as a form of line management. Every time someone is called and doesn't show up, everyone waiting outside cheers.

I only eat here once a year, because that's about how long it takes for me to no longer feel disenchanted by the wait time. A year out, and the memory of the line suddenly feels less sharp. "Maybe this time will be different," I think to myself. 

It never is.

excerpts: For 3, we ordered the plow (they substitute avocado instead of meat if you're vegetarian), summer melon salad, almond flour pancakes, and the cornbread muffin.
My favorites were the plow and the summer melon salad.
The plow was the perfect dish for breakfast: 2 eggs, plow potatoes, and 2 mini lemon ricotta pancakes.
If I were to go back again and get a dish solely for me, I would get this.
The eggs were cooked perfects, the potatoes were just the right amount of crispy and had great seasoning, and the pancakes were soft, fluffy and just melted in your mouth.
If you can't tell already, order this dish!
There's definitely a reason it's named after the restaurant itself.
The summer melon salad was beyond fresh and tasty.
It had many crunchy melon pieces alongside lettuce, onions, cheese, and corn.
The almond flour pancakes were just ok
- they tasted more like regular pancakes to me and there wasn't really anything special about them.
Same goes for the muffin, we honestly just ordered this because they told us they were running out of them and there was only a limited quantity
so we had some high hopes.
almond flour pancakes.author: Malika R.
almond flour pancakes.review:
It's no joke that you usually have to wait 1.5-2 hours to get a spot at this small but delicious brunch spot in potrero. It's just something that most San Franciscans do on a weekend morning, wait in line for one of the famous brunch places in the area. I've done it before and I'll do it again - although the wait seems far too long, Plow is mouth-watering good! 

Right on the 2-hour mark, our name was called and we were so excited to finally sit down and eat! For 3, we ordered the plow (they substitute avocado instead of meat if you're vegetarian), summer melon salad, almond flour pancakes, and the cornbread muffin. It was a LOT of food! 

My favorites were the plow and the summer melon salad. The plow was the perfect dish for breakfast: 2 eggs, plow potatoes, and 2 mini lemon ricotta pancakes. If I were to go back again and get a dish solely for me, I would get this. The eggs were cooked perfects, the potatoes were just the right amount of crispy and had great seasoning, and the pancakes were soft, fluffy and just melted in your mouth. If you can't tell already, order this dish! There's definitely a reason it's named after the restaurant itself. The summer melon salad was beyond fresh and tasty. It had many crunchy melon pieces alongside lettuce, onions, cheese, and corn. I loved the combination of all these ingredients, but this is probably a supplement to your meal, I don't think this would fill you up.

The almond flour pancakes were just ok - they tasted more like regular pancakes to me and there wasn't really anything special about them. Same goes for the muffin, we honestly just ordered this because they told us they were running out of them and there was only a limited quantity so we had some high hopes. I didn't really like the texture of the muffin and the taste was just ok as well. 

Service is great even though they're busy for at least 7 hours straight (7am-2pm). If you're willing to wait, go here! It's some good quality, hearty, delicious brunch food. I wish there was a shorter wait so I could keep going back again and again.

almond flour pancakes.review:

Service: We did wait about an hour or so and were one of the last to be seated (it stops taking patrons at 2 pm).  The waitress did seem a bit pushy but she took our orders and everything came out as asked.

Food: Incredible!!! I never thought a simple order of pancakes could be so delicious! I ordered the almond flour pancakes.  Huge pancakes that filled me up and satisfied my hunger.  My boyfriend ordered "The Plow" and also enjoyed every bite!

almond flour pancakes.author: Angela K.
almond flour pancakes.review:
Plow sits in the up and coming Dogpatch and I'm really loving this area. That being said, I was really excited to try this place. The only catch - it's basically a 2 hour wait.

The food is good, definitely. As all the Yelpers recommend, get the Plow. I agree - it gives you all the breakfast basics: eggs, sausage or bacon, pancakes and crispy potatoes. Everyone comes here for the lemon ricotta pancakes. Being that I'm the stranger person that does not like lemony baked goods, I went with the almond flour pancakes. I was a big fan of the almond flour pancakes and the crispy potatoes. Everything else was made well and overall, it was a fulfilling breakfast.

But it is NOT worth a 2 hour wait. If you're an early riser, then definitely come when they open. Otherwise, plan to put your name down, walk around grab a snack, take your time and come back 2 hours later.

Very crispy outside, and soft on the inside and well seasoned. The sandwich was a delight. It had cheese and a expertly fried egg. The bacon acted as the sprinkles on a good cupcake! Really good! We shared some of the Almond flour pancakes, which were surprisingly light and fluffy. 

I got to try some of "the plow", which had their house made sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.  I really liked the lemon ricotta pancakes, too! They had a little citrus flavor that went well with a little bit of syrup. They don't have an extensive menu, but it is like that for a reason. They do what they do well and that is all you need to know!

almond flour pancakes.review:
I don't usually go on rants in my content, but rather try to pin point the best parts of my 5-star reviews... But this place has sentiment...so here I go.

LOVE LOVE LOVE this spot. A fairly minimal menu, but all unique options. My fiance and I ate here for our first meal as a couple, purely by coincidence. We happened to be staying in Potrero Hill, and found this hidden gem down on the corner. Favorite thing about SF? The constant "serendipities" that I experience! 

So about the food.. well, just trust me, it's some of the best breakfast this city has ever seen. And fear-not you gluten free folks... they have the best almond flour pancakes I've ever tried... and I highly recommend them to wheat eaters as well. Moist... moist...moist. 

I ordered the soft egg scramble with goat cheese.. and my mouth is watering just thinking about it. I'm an egg lover, and consider myself an egg connoisseur if you will.. so believe me when I say- this one's a winner.

If you're into rich breakfast, you will be taken care of here. I tend to stick with my egg dishes, but from what I've seen on other tables, it's not a dissapointment! 

Forget the farm...go "plow" it up over here!

I also couldn't stop eyeing all the egg sandwiches that were being carried out of the kitchen!
Overall had an enjoyable brunch experience at Plow.
Would've been slightly better
had we not spent a good portion of our day waiting and eating.
almond flour pancakes.author: Cathy C.
almond flour pancakes.review:
I looooooove brunch. If I had it my way I would eat breakfast foods all day. Heard about this place from friends so I'm glad I got to stop by as I was visiting from out of town. We got there around noon on a Sunday and of course, the corner was bustling with people waiting for a table. I can't believe we waited almost two hours to get seated, but I'm proud of us for making it through alive. The moment when your name does get called makes you feel like you've just won the lottery, it's great. We got a table outside which was fine because as other reviewers have said, they provide blankets. The outdoor seating can get a bit awkward with hungry folks staring at you and your food, the likelihood increasing exponentially the closer you are to the main door (which we were right beside). The indoor area is a bit small, but love the decor and atmosphere.  

Maybe it was the hunger (or hanger), but I thought the coffee was really good. My friend had the plow while I had the dungeness crab scramble. The food here did not disappoint. The scramble was really good but it seemed to be a bit watery/mushy? Tried friend's pancakes and they were also good, not too flour-y. Definitely pretty heavy on the lemon, whether you are or aren't into that. Seemed like a lot of folks dining around us were substituting in almond flour pancakes. I also couldn't stop eyeing all the egg sandwiches that were being carried out of the kitchen! Overall had an enjoyable brunch experience at Plow. Would've been slightly better had we not spent a good portion of our day waiting and eating.

excerpts: She ordered a side of scrambled eggs with the Almond Flour Pancakes.
almond flour pancakes.author: Melody W.
almond flour pancakes.review:
I came here with a gal pal on a Thursday lunch break (~12:15pm). Parking was easy (say what the what? It's never easy in SF). Since I was in great company, the wait wasn't long at all--probably 10-15 minutes max for first available seating. We got seated outside, which was fine. The weather was amazing, so we didn't mind. 

She ordered a side of scrambled eggs with the Almond Flour Pancakes. I got the Plow breakfast (hey-- when in Rome, right?) which came with two eggs (over-easy for me), 4 things of chicken apple sausage, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes (yes! and yes!), and a big hoppin' load of crispy potato chunks (it's a bit ginger-y, so be advised). Oh-- and a cup of Equator coffee to wash it all down. I loved The Plow (get yer mind outta the gutter...lol). I believe the gal pal loved her pancakes too. I only wish my lemon ricotta pancakes had some blueberry compote (sp?) like the ones in the regular lemon ricotta pancake entree. And, I think the crispy potatoes were a little over-powering with ginger taste. All in all, I loved the dish and the experience. 

This place is worth a visit in my book.

excerpts: The almond flour pancakes are also incredible, my hubs ended up stealing mine because he doesn't like lemon pancakes.
almond flour pancakes.author: Kaitlyn M.
almond flour pancakes.review:
After we got married, we ended up in the heart of San Francisco being the tourists we are. Thankfully we stumbled upon this charming little quarter. It is worth every single second of the wait...odds are there will be a wait! I'll save you some time ordering though -- Get the plow breakfast! You get the best of all worlds. Lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, bacon, eggs, you name it. The almond flour pancakes are also incredible, my hubs ended up stealing mine because he doesn't like lemon pancakes. They make everything fresh and you can see them cutting potatoes or squeezing orange juice when you walk in the door!

See the link below for my top 10 favorite Breakfast Spots//Coast to Coast --

http://www.kaitgmiller.com/healthy-eating/10bestbreakfastspots
kaitgmiller.com

excerpts: I'll definitely be coming back to try the almond flour pancakes and french toast!
almond flour pancakes.author: Shannon L.
almond flour pancakes.review:
SO SO SOO AMAZING! This is my new favorite brunch place. My friend and I came on a Thursday around 12 noon so there was only a five minute wait, but that's probably nothing compared to how long it is on the weekends. I can't even imagine how crazy it is then. As for the food, we both ordered "The Plow" which consists of their:

-silver dollar lemon ricotta pancakes - I'm not normally a fan of pancakes, but these blew my mind! Probably my favorite out of everything on my plate. Eat them slowly and just taste all the flavors in these light and fluffy pancakes! Still thinking about them...so good!
-crispy potatoes - all I can say is crispy and oh-so-delicious, just the way I like it. 
-nueske bacon - can't go wrong with bacon. 
 
I'll definitely be coming back to try the almond flour pancakes and french toast!

excerpts: We are somewhat automatic in what order: lemon ricotta pancakes, almond flour pancakes, and several times the French toast.
almond flour pancakes.author: Al G.
almond flour pancakes.review: My wife have eaten at Plow 8 times in the last 3 years- all breakfasts/brunch on weekends. We are somewhat automatic in what order: lemon ricotta pancakes, almond flour pancakes, and several times the French toast. On two occasions, I  have personally order The Plow. We generally get there early- between 8am to 8:30am, so that we do not have to wait in line. After 9am, you expect to wait in line about 10 mins to 30 mins depending on the size of your party. What we've always enjoyed about Plow is its consistency with how simple and how good their food is. The service is pretty good and fairly quick. Surprisingly enough, we've never had any challenges with finding parking within 2 blocks.

excerpts: I ordered the Annie's almond flour pancakes plus a side of eggs.
SO GOOD!!
almond flour pancakes.author: Cari G.
almond flour pancakes.review: I was visiting from Vegas and researched gluten free restaurants prior to trip and came across Plow. I knew it had a wait because they're very popular! I came as a just one and got to be seated at the bar top area instead of wait 2 hours. I ordered the Annie's almond flour pancakes plus a side of eggs. SO GOOD!!

excerpts: My brother raved about those but the almond flour pancakes were AMAZING too.
Luckily I forgot to ask them to hold the potatoes because the potatoes were nearly worth the trip on their own.
Beautifully tender on the inside and the loveliest, crunchy outside I have ever experienced.
almond flour pancakes.author: Deniz U.
almond flour pancakes.review:
This was, hands down, the best brunch I've ever had in San Francisco. 
We did have a bit of a wait and after coming to check back in at the time we were told, it did get my blood a little heated up that we were passed over several minutes before and ended up having to wait another 15 minutes while they rotated through some other parties that were on the list after us, but . . . . the brunch we had did more than I could ever hope to lift our moods. 
The wife and I had 'The Plow' which they were happy to swap out the lemon ricotta pancakes. My brother raved about those but the almond flour pancakes were AMAZING too. Luckily I forgot to ask them to hold the potatoes because the potatoes were nearly worth the trip on their own. Beautifully tender on the inside and the loveliest, crunchy outside I have ever experienced. The bacon was was absolute perfection too. 

I can't think of a single thing I would change. You can count on us waiting patiently outside at least twice a month. 

Bravo Plow!!!

excerpts: My husband got the almond flour pancakes and he was a bit disappointed.
He was under the impression that they would taste almondy but they didn't at all.
almond flour pancakes.author: Karishma B.
almond flour pancakes.review:
We had brunch at Plow with some friends today. The wait was a little over an hour but we expected that since it was the peak brunch hour. But let me tell you, it was worth the wait!

I got the fried egg sandwich (eggs were cooked perfectly) with crispy potatoes (had a hint of rosemary -- super delicious!). My husband and I split a lemon ricotta pancake, which was on point! And we tried a buttermilk biscuit that just melted in our mouths. My husband got the almond flour pancakes and he was a bit disappointed. He was under the impression that they would taste almondy but they didn't at all. They tasted good but don't get them if you want something that tastes almondy.

We would definitely go back and try other items on the menu. But we'll still get the lemon ricotta pancakes in addition to anything else we get. They.are.amazing!!!

excerpts: I recall having the almond flour pancakes, and they were better than I had expected.
Not grainy, pretty fluffy.
Also had a couple eggs over easy on the side, cooked just right, and not super greasy.
almond flour pancakes.author: Jonathan B.
almond flour pancakes.review:
Can't believe I forgot to review this place, so good.

We sat at the bar, which was a great experience seeing the cooks work the busy kitchen.  We were promptly served some coffee & tea, which was delicious and placed our orders.

I recall having the almond flour pancakes, and they were better than I had expected.  Not grainy, pretty fluffy.  Also had a couple eggs over easy on the side, cooked just right, and not super greasy.  Very nice.

I need to come back here and sample some more of their items, it all looked great as I saw it travelling around the room to other tables.

excerpts: I also love the almond flour pancakes.
I recommend going an hour earlier than you'd like to eat to put your name on the list and walk around the neighborhood to check out it's gorgeous views.
The counter seats are your best opportunities to see the real stars of Plow at work!
almond flour pancakes.author: Ashly O.
almond flour pancakes.review: Very worth the potential 90 minute wait. The crispy potatoes are incredible. You're doing yourself an injustice if you don't get them: crispy, salty rosemary goodness. I also love the almond flour pancakes. I recommend going an hour earlier than you'd like to eat to put your name on the list and walk around the neighborhood to check out it's gorgeous views. The counter seats are your best opportunities to see the real stars of Plow at work!

excerpts: We tried the lemon ricotta and almond flour pancakes and both were absolutely delish!
almond flour pancakes.author: Jennifer I.
almond flour pancakes.review:
One hour wait later...happy tummies!

We sat outside since I brought my little Peanut along (this place is dog friendly).  Everyone in my crew ordered the "plow" so we can sample a bit of everything - 2 eggs, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, sausages (or bacon), and potatoes.  It did not disappoint.  The eggs over easy were definitely on the "easy" side.  Next time I'll know to ask for eggs over medium instead.  We tried the lemon ricotta and almond flour pancakes and both were absolutely delish!  Potatoes were seasoned and done just right!

I will definitely be coming back!  (Another plus is the plentiful parking!)

excerpts: We were especially impressed by the delicious gluten free almond flour pancakes, crispy fried potatoes, and smoked bacon.
almond flour pancakes.author: Rosemary H.
almond flour pancakes.review:
Everything was wonderful . We were especially impressed by the delicious gluten free almond flour pancakes, crispy fried potatoes, and smoked bacon. 

Wandered to Farley's for coffee during our 15 minute wait on a Saturday morning around 9:30am.

excerpts: The almond flour pancakes was delicious.

excerpts: We had the almond flour pancakes and the corned beef hash.
Delicious and totally paleo.
Definitely high quality ingredients prepared well.
And our waitress Katie was so genuinely nice--perhaps the nicest waitress I've ever met in San Francisco.
SF is not known for polite service, and it was great to see a departure from that.
We thoroughly enjoyed sitting in her section.
I definitely recommend this place, but don't order the tea and be prepared to shell out the bucks.
almond flour pancakes.author: Peter S.
almond flour pancakes.review:
Great food and excellent atmosphere. I only had two complaints, so I'll get those out of the way first: my tea was obscenely weak--just warm water really, and the bill was over 50 bucks for two people who just drank coffee and tea. That's pretty pricey for a casual Saturday breakfast.
This place is popular with the early crowd. We arrived at 9 and were seated at 9:45 (on a Saturday). We sat at the center, which turned out to be fun. There's an open kitchen, and everyone in it was totally tapped into their flow, cranking out food to a synchronized rhythm. Everyone seemed to really enjoy working there.  The music was 50's and 60's rock and soul hits, which created a nice atmosphere. The employees were smiling and dancing while they worked their butts off.
The food was excellent. We had the almond flour pancakes and the corned beef hash. Delicious and totally paleo. Definitely high quality ingredients prepared well.
And our waitress Katie was so genuinely nice--perhaps the nicest waitress I've ever met in San Francisco. SF is not known for polite service, and it was great to see a departure from that. We thoroughly enjoyed sitting in her section.
I definitely recommend this place, but don't order the tea and be prepared to shell out the bucks.

excerpts: i wanted to try the almond flour pancakes
but i was craving for eggs
almond flour pancakes.author: Rosalee C.
almond flour pancakes.review:
i've been wanting to try this place for some time but i am rarely in this neighborhood and i don't know why.

my boyfriend and i woke up early and decided to eat here since there's a chance of not waiting so long because it's so early. well, when we drove by the large crowd crowding the entrance almost made us change our minds but decided to stay. the 40min wait didn't seem so long.

we sat at the bar and just watched all the cooks in action. they got skills!

i wanted to try the almond flour pancakes but i was craving for eggs so instead i ordered 'the plow', which consisted of eggs [poached], sausage and lemon ricotta pancakes. i'm not a huge fan of lemon things [exc. lemonade, lemon bundt cake], and i knew these pancakes were risky. they're ok, but i don't love them like everyone else did. 

regardless, i am definitely coming back here to try the almond pancakes, and other things on their menu! it's small but they have large windows that bring all the sunlight in!

excerpts: same problem with the almond flour pancakes.
almond flour pancakes.author: Diana C.
almond flour pancakes.review:
3.5 stars. this place is so cute!  the wait was very long...  love the decor.

ordered The Plow - with scrambled eggs and house made pork sausage patties. waitress came back half an hour later saying they were out of the pork sausage (it was 12:37pm on Sunday - yes, i did check the time) got the chicken apple sausage instead. should have gotten the bacon if i knew that the chicken apple sausages are those little bfast sausage (i like the ones with apple chunks in them instead). however, i really like the scrambled eggs (so runny!!) and CRISPY potatoes. tried that one weird whey orange drink (i wasn't paying a lot of attention when the waitress was describing it, but she mentioned that they made some cheese in-house and extracted protein, add orange juice and tonic... bleh - i didn't like it). lemon ricotta pancakes - first bite had a kick to it, but it's not fluffy. i like fluffy pancakes. same problem with the almond flour pancakes. 

i would totally go back for the eggs and potatoes. the muffin looked good, too. want to try that next time.

excerpts: During my last visit, I ordered the almond flour pancakes, which are perfectly fluffy on the inside, with the right amount of almond flavor so as to deliver a rich taste without being overwhelming.
I've also ordered the french toast with strawberry compote, mascarpone, and syrup, which was tremendous.
I'm a vegetarian
almond flour pancakes.author: Rishi N.
almond flour pancakes.review:
Plow is probably my favorite brunch spot in SF.  The location itself is pretty small and very homely / cozy, with huge windows that allow sunlight to pour in (especially valuable for those who don't enjoy as much sunlight due to living elsewhere in SF...).  If only I could park myself here on weekdays and read a book / eat breakfast every day... (and if only I had unlimited monetary resources...)

The food itself is delightful.  During my last visit, I ordered the almond flour pancakes, which are perfectly fluffy on the inside, with the right amount of almond flavor so as to deliver a rich taste without being overwhelming.  I've also ordered the french toast with strawberry compote, mascarpone, and syrup, which was tremendous.  I'm a vegetarian so I can't comment on meat dishes, but friends whom I have gone to Plow with all rave about the dishes they've gotten (everything from The Plow to the Nicoise salad).  Plow is also one of the few places that serve Equator coffee in SF (especially now that La Boulange is being acquired by Starbucks) - while expensive at $3.75 / cup (unlimited refills), it complements a meal perfectly.  Service is great given how hectic things seem to be every time I visit (which has always been on weekends), as the staff is very friendly.

The main negative aspect, as other folks have noted here, is the wait - it can be absolutely brutal at 1-2 hours on weekends.  That wait will get you a single table for 2 if you're lucky, or perhaps a seat at a table of 4 (typically shared with other people if your party is fewer than 4 people) or at the bar.  If you show up after 10:30am on a weekend, be prepared to wait a while ... with limited breakfast / brunch options nearby if you decide that you can't stand the wait.  Plow is also quite pricey for brunch (even by SF standards) - in my opinion, it's worth it, but coupled with the long wait it's something to keep in mind.

All in all, Plow is definitely worth visiting - and if you can make it work, visit on a weekday to avoid the brutal lines (note that they're closed on Mondays).

excerpts: Chicken apple sausage, crispy potatoes and most of all ALMOND FLOUR PANCAKES were all amazing
almond flour pancakes.author: Nate M.
almond flour pancakes.review: Chicken apple sausage, crispy potatoes and most of all ALMOND FLOUR PANCAKES were all amazing

excerpts: - Almond flour pancakes - Also light and fluffy, but tasted like a regular pancake, not a hint of almond to be found.
almond flour pancakes.author: Snuffles B.
almond flour pancakes.review:
We violated the cardinal rule of Sunday Brunch, which is to be a lazy bum and roll out of bed incoherently to eat at an hour where the rest of the world could have done half a day's work already. Instead we got up at 7:30 so we could avoid the line. So technically, we didn't have brunch, we had breakfast and believe it or not, if you get there at 8:30, you might still have to wait b/c they stagger the first seating (outside and inside). 

The inside has an open but farmy feel, the outside is on the sidewalk on a steep hill - VERY challenging to avoid getting a sunburn and if you are facing up the hill, its a work out just to get your head close enough to the plate to eat your food. Plus the time we got our food, half the block was a waiting area for ravenously hungry Brunch-seekers, so I'd vote to sit inside. The servers are very nice and do a good job.

- Monkey bread - don't be deceived, this is NOT banana bread - its like a cinnamon roll and french toast hybrid - tasty
- Donut - a bit dry but still a good cake donut
- Egg Sandwich - Big, messy, technically challenging to eat, and yummy
- Bacon - Its bacon, you will like it unless there is something wrong with you
- Crispy potatoes - In fact crispy but a bit bland
- Pork Sausage - Pretty light and tasty
- Lemon ricotta pancakes - Light, fluffy, lemony, one of the best pancakes I've had
- Almond flour pancakes - Also light and fluffy, but tasted like a regular pancake, not a hint of almond to be found.

While this place is tasty, its not wait-for-an-hour-and-get-a-sunburn-tasty. And don't get me started about the bathroom line - OY.

excerpts: The almond flour pancakes are overwhelmingly mouthwatering and the chia pudding is so good too.
Everything I've had is just perfect.
I love the ingredients they use and the list of all the local farms they source from.
That's most important to me.
But I don't like to wait in lines
so I don't go on the weekends
almond flour pancakes.author: Cel H.
almond flour pancakes.review: Favorite place for brunch. The almond flour pancakes are overwhelmingly mouthwatering and the chia pudding is so good too. Everything I've had is just perfect. I love the ingredients they use and the list of all the local farms they source from. That's most important to me. But I don't like to wait in lines so I don't go on the weekends

excerpts: The crispy potatoes are very good as are the almond flour pancakes.
The bacon was not crispy, but a bit blackened like it had been cooked over an oven with a lot of burnt grease.
The bacon ruined the experience for me.
I will have to avoid ordering that next time.
I think the seats at the counter are the best seats in the house, since there's a direct view of the action in the kitchen.
almond flour pancakes.author: Jenny K.

The bacon was not crispy, but a bit blackened like it had been cooked over an oven with a lot of burnt grease.  The bacon ruined the experience for me.  I will have to avoid ordering that next time.  I think the seats at the counter are the best seats in the house, since there's a direct view of the action in the kitchen.

excerpts: She got the almond flour pancakes which she loved...
almond flour pancakes.author: kristen k.
almond flour pancakes.review: I was extremely excited to try plow, specifically because my mom has quite a few food allergies and is gluten free. She got the almond flour pancakes which she loved... I got the plow breakfast. The bad started when 3 waters were placed on the table automatically when we had bottled waters in front of us. Water should only be served upon request right now which really made me mad.. Then, I asked for my potatoes without onion so I could share them with my mom, who has a severe onion allergy. Luckily I spotted them in the potatoes before she ate them... I would've let our waitress know if she hadn't disappeared. We didn't see her until she left the check on our table. I might come back for the ricotta pancakes, to go. Might.

excerpts: I highly recommend getting the almond flour pancakes, delicious!!
almond flour pancakes.author: Hayley P.
almond flour pancakes.review: Joel and Maxine are the owners of Plow and are amazing people. They are so kind, they have perfected breakfast. Without a doubt this is the best breakfast place I have been too. I ordered the plow plate and it was a little bit of everything which was perfect! I highly recommend getting the almond flour pancakes, delicious!!

excerpts: Got The Plow with almond flour pancakes.
So good.
BF got the pork chop; equally as good.
Want to go back now.
almond flour pancakes.author: S G.
almond flour pancakes.review: Great restaurant!  Had to wait an hour +, but it was totally worth it.  Got The Plow with almond flour pancakes.  So good.  BF got the pork chop; equally as good.  Want to go back now.

excerpts: Highlights: the plow (nice to try a little bit of everything), almond flour pancakes, corn + cheddar bun.
Cute neighborhood spot.
almond flour pancakes.author: Daisy Y.
almond flour pancakes.review: Came here for weekend brunch with the family.  Arrived around 930a and waited about 25 minutes or so.  Not bad, was expecting a longer wait.  Ordered a bunch of dishes and shared them.  Highlights: the plow (nice to try a little bit of everything), almond flour pancakes, corn + cheddar bun.  Cute neighborhood spot.

excerpts: I ordered " the plow " it came with two small lemon ricotta pancakes.
I have to pause and mention that there is a tight team of 3 guys working and one is making ricotta fresh right there on the line.
Talk about high-end pancakes!
One guy is working on the potatoes, one is working on the meats, it is a friendly, swift and delicious team of chefs.

The plow also comes with crispy Neueske bacon, two eggs (I chose over medium) cooked absolutely perfectly, a hash of deep-fried country potatoes which were still soft and buttery inside but nice and crispy on the outside, caramelized onion and bacon tossed together, it was really a step above the norm.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Kelly T.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I was looking for a quick bite to eat between appointments in the city and in San Rafael and was lucky to find Plow. Breakfast or brunch was on my mind and I saw the positive Yelp reviews at Plow and thought I would check it out and oh my goodness I am happy that I did! 

I ordered " the plow " it came with two small lemon ricotta pancakes. I have to pause and mention that there is a tight team of 3 guys working and one is making ricotta fresh right there on the line. Talk about high-end pancakes! One guy is working on the potatoes, one is working on the meats, it is a friendly, swift and delicious team of chefs. The menu is expansive and they have such unique breakfasts, large portions and such high quality. 

The plow also comes with crispy Neueske bacon, two eggs (I chose over medium) cooked absolutely perfectly, a hash of deep-fried country potatoes which were still soft and buttery inside but nice and crispy on the outside, caramelized onion and bacon tossed together, it was really a step above the norm. 

Everyone works as a friendly well-oiled machine, they all have their pace down and it works wonderfully for all of us. The service is lovely, they don't bother you but they check in with you which is nice, not overt or pushy which many places as packed as this can tend to be. I can't wait to go back.

excerpts: Since I couldn't choose between salty or sweet, I ordered the plow which gives you the best of both worlds (lemon ricotta pancakes, choice of meat, choice of eggs, and potatoes).
You get your choice of eggs and meat
so I went with scrambled eggs and pork sausage.
The scrambled eggs and ricotta pancake were both very light and fluffy, the pork sausages were decent, and the potatoes were straight up delicious.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Julian Y.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
My friend and I knew that the wait would take awhile judging from the crowd of people chilling near the entrance. We arrived at 1:15pm, and got seated at 2pm. Luckily, there was a coffee shop a few stores down which was very convenient for us to get a coffee while we wait.

We had outdoor seating which wasn't bad at all since it was sunny. Since I couldn't choose between salty or sweet, I ordered the plow which gives you the best of both worlds (lemon ricotta pancakes, choice of meat, choice of eggs, and potatoes). You get your choice of eggs and meat so I went with scrambled eggs and pork sausage. The scrambled eggs and ricotta pancake were both very light and fluffy, the pork sausages were decent, and the potatoes were straight up delicious. A combo of food put into one delicious dish.

The servers are really attentive and your glass of water will never be empty. The friendly servers were a big plus on a Sunday afternoon to finish off my weekend.

I can't wait to explore the other items on the menu next time!

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes were also delicious.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Sara T.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Long wait but delicious! Shared a combination plate called "The Plow" and an order of their seasonal french toast (peaches), and it was definitely a good amount of food. I really like their potatoes! I don't know what they do to it, but it was sooo delicious! I don't usually choose potatoes as the highlight of a dish but for this sampler plate, the potatoes definitely were my favorite part. The lemon ricotta pancakes were also delicious. 

We sat at the outdoor seats, which was fine on a nice day but I would definitely bundle up or dress in layers since SF weather is sometimes unpredictable. It wasn't difficult to flag a server down. Everyone was very friendly!

Would definitely come back to try the rest of the menu or to just order the Plow again. Definitely thinking about the potatoes again...

excerpts: Ordered the Plow which comes with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes, and
I got the chicken apple sauage which I really liked and the plow potatoes are SOOOO good.
The lemon ricotta pancakes were also SOOOOOO good.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Carol L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Oh, Plow... how I waited and waited and waited and wanted so badly to love you. My friends and I came around 10:30am on a Saturday as a party of 5 and waited WAY OVER 2 hours. We were quoted 1.5 hours - 2 hours and called pretty frequently to check in on our table. 

This is the part that irks me the most about my experience.. at one point maybe 1.5 hours in, they told us to come back in 15 minutes. We came back in around 10 minutes and they told us "oh sorry, we just gave your table away". Sorry, but WHAT???? You would think that a place this popular can figure out their reservations and their waiting system but NOPE. So if you come here, you better just wait right outside the restaurant....... They call your name once or twice and if you're not there they just skip right over you even if they tell you to come back at a certain time. Truly unlike anything else I've ever experienced before, but maybe I'm spoiled after being in Chicago and NY for a while now as they have their lines and reservation systems all figured out..

Service was good from one person, but rude from another. Honestly, at this point I was pretty hangry though. So maybe the service wasn't THAT bad, it just came across as horribly rude when we asked for more water and were ignored. Also the host just wasn't pleasant to my party at all. 

Ordered the Plow which comes with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes, and your choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I got the chicken apple sauage which I really liked and the plow potatoes are SOOOO good. The lemon ricotta pancakes were also SOOOOOO good. (But was it because I was starving after waiting close to 2.5 hours for a table and the food?) 

I would come back, but I would never wait more than 30 minutes for the food. 3 stars because this restaurant needs to work on their service and their queue, but the food is pretty good.

TL;DR: Wait outside the restaurant otherwise your table will be given away and you'll wait outside forever and be even more starving than you already were.

Also their place is tiny, so if you want to get seated as quickly as possible then come by yourself or with one other person. They have like one or two tables that can accommodate parties over 4 people.

excerpts: I can't wait over 1 hour for those lemon ricotta pancakes and home made pork sausages no matter how delicious they are and how harmoniously they go together.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Kathleen S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
This place is one of my favorite brunch places in the city! However, it must be on the list of every one else too as the wait here is ridic and I can't do it any longer. I can't wait over 1 hour for those lemon ricotta pancakes and home made pork sausages no matter how delicious they are and how harmoniously they go together.

How do you eat at Plow and not agonizingly have to wait for grub on a weekend? Start waiting in line before they open. I unexpectedly had to work a graveyard shift and would miraculously be in the city semi-awake at 7am on a Saturday so to Plow we went. They don't open until 8am on the weekends (Yelp hours were wrong) so we walked over to Farley's a half block away to get some caffeine and lined up around 7:40 am and managed to get in on the first seating. If you come at 8am, I think that might be too late.

The Plow was just as yummy as I remembered. Their pastry apple bread was solid and a nice prelude to our breakfast. Unfortunately I always get the same thing when I come here so I can't speak for much of the rest of the menu.

excerpts: A hearty plate filled with two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, choice of protein (I chose pork sausage patties), and eggs!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Catherine T.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
"The Plow" is the obvious go-to brunch meal. A hearty plate filled with two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, choice of protein (I chose pork sausage patties), and eggs! Everything was delicious and service was quick and attentive. 

We waited for two hours and I honestly wouldn't wait again. Looking at the menu it doesn't look like anything else was enticing either. Also sitting at the counter there was this pungent smell that was bothersome.

Luckily we had a pre-snack before eating here so if I was really hangry this rating would've been lower lol.

In concloosh- if you can avoid a long wait time, come here and order The Plow!

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes....
they were incredibly fluffy and just the right amount of sweet to balance out the savory aspects of the dish.
The eggs and apple sausage were also good.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: April L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I went here for brunch with my friend on a Saturday morning at around 10:30 am. We had heard a lot of hype about this place so we decided to check it out. We were quoted a 1 hour and 30 minute wait time, but we ended up waiting about an hour. I would not come here super hungry (maybe grab a coffee while waiting). 

We both got The Plow ($17.50)- which basically comes with a little bit of everything! The potatoes were SO SO good and perfectly seasoned and crispy. The lemon ricotta pancakes....they were incredibly fluffy and just the right amount of sweet to balance out the savory aspects of the dish. The eggs and apple sausage were also good. I do wish they added a couple more sausages to finish off the dish. 

We also got the Buttermilk Biscuit ($5) while we were waiting for our main dishes, which was a bit dry but the the honey butter helped. 

Overall, I would come here again, but maybe on a weekday when it's not as busy.

excerpts: I order the "Plow Breakfast " which came with the lemon ricotta pancakes , organic fresh eggs cooked to order , Plow potatoes and choice of bacon , house made pork sausage patties or apple sausage.
I opted for the house made pork sausage patties and they were great .
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Elizabeth B.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
You must make Plow a staple brunch spot while visiting SF . After researching reviews we decided on going to Plow for breakfast as I read great reviews and also heard they had the "best potatoes " in the city . The reviews were all spot on .
I dined here on a Tuesday around 9:30am in Oct and while the place was small and packed we managed to sit down right away outside but there was also counter seating where you can watch the Chefs perform their magic . 

I order the "Plow Breakfast " which came with the lemon ricotta pancakes , organic fresh eggs cooked to order , Plow potatoes and choice of bacon , house made pork sausage patties or apple sausage. I opted for the house made pork sausage patties and they were great . If I would of changed anything about them o would of made them a little more seasoned . 

The pancakes were light but flavorful and a nice lemon touch but not over the top. They were a nice size .The maple syrup was authentic and complemented the pancakes nicely . They also had pumpkin pancakes as a choice as well . 
We enjoyed one of the home made biscuits with butter ($5) . You can tell they are made with love and from scratch . 

The highlight of the entire breakfast were the potatoes though . They were perfectly seasoned , crispy and crunchy on the outside and light on the inside . I never quite had breakfast potatoes like this but I can see why people line up for this country style breakfast spot. Hey there early though because around 10 or so when we were leaving there was a line starting to form .

The staff here was very friendly , patient and accommodating . I even saw one of the waitresses bring a table a ricotta pancake on the house just because they had ordered pumpkin pancakes . Food was fresh , hot and fairly quick to arrive . The meal was quite filling and I left a very satisfied customer .

excerpts: Eggs, choice of meat (I had chicken apple sausage), crispy potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes.
Their lemon ricotta pancakes are smol, light, and fluffy -- finally, a pancake that doesn't weigh you down!
The sausages were v flavorful and juicy, but not at all greasy -
*praise*.
Best of all the parts were so well proportioned to each other!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Joyce C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
IT'S SO WORTH IT.  Do not doubt, believe and be blessed!  Got here at 8:30am on a Sunday and there was already an hour wait.  We went to a neighboring cafe for some coffee while we waited, but the large mug of black coffee on an empty stomach set me up with raging anxiety and nausea by the time we got back (woohoo! Adventure...)

Even with all the shenanigans besetting my poor bod, this meal is by far the best brunch I've had in a looong time.  I ordered **The Plow ** ($17.50), recommended to me by my breakfast bud as a sampling of Plow's hit items.  Eggs, choice of meat (I had chicken apple sausage), crispy potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes.  Sounds standard, but oh my god - they are out of this world.

I identify as a huge tater lover, and I was still intrigued by this hype over their potatoes.  Best way to describe it: you know the crispy skin on peking duck?  These potatoes had that kind of delicate crisp to them!  HNGH.  Nom nom.

Their lemon ricotta pancakes are smol, light, and fluffy -- finally, a pancake that doesn't weigh you down!  The sausages were v flavorful and juicy, but not at all greasy - *praise*.  Best of all the parts were so well proportioned to each other!  AMAZING.

Keep in mind I felt all these lovey dovey things towards the food while having an anxiety-crippled appetite, so the food really is THAT good. @Plow, TAKE MY MONEY.  I'll be back.  And you should try waiting for and eventually eating at this place too :3

excerpts: It comes with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, Plow potatoes, and your choice of pork sausage, bacon, or chicken apple sausage.
I've heard such good things about their lemon ricotta pancakes, so I knew I *had* to try them out.
Almost everything was perfect about this platter: the eggs were perfectly scrambled, the potatoes were roasted just right, and OMG THE PANCAKES.
They were so light with a nice lemon flavor that wasn't overpowering.
The pancakes themselves aren't too sweet so you can control the sweetness with the syrup.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Dianna H.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Another solid spot for brunch in SF, as long as you're willing to wait. Food is 5 stars but I'm taking away one star for the perpetually long wait.

I've tried to come once before, but when we were told the wait would be around 1.5 hours, my friend and I bounced and ate at a place nearby with a much shorter wait. One year later, I decide to challenge the wait at Plow again.

My friend came around 10:15 on a Saturday to put her name down and was told to check back in 2 hours or so. When the three of us came back around noon, they had already called our name but bumped us to the top of the list. We were seated shortly after that.

I can see why they have such a long wait; it's a small space with seating for maybe 30 people? Definitely don't recommend coming here with a big group.

As a first timer, I knew I had to get their namesake dish: The Plow ($17.50). It comes with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, Plow potatoes, and your choice of pork sausage, bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I don't know why more brunch places don't offer this, but it's the person brunch platter for people who prefer mostly savory dishes with a small bit of sweet on the side.

I've heard such good things about their lemon ricotta pancakes, so I knew I *had* to try them out. Almost everything was perfect about this platter: the eggs were perfectly scrambled, the potatoes were roasted just right, and OMG THE PANCAKES. They were so light with a nice lemon flavor that wasn't overpowering. The pancakes themselves aren't too sweet so you can control the sweetness with the syrup. The Plow platter comes with two mini pancakes, but I might need to order a whole side of these to myself next time! My only complaint was that the pork sausage wasn't that great.

It was so nice to come here with my girlfriends and catch up on life. So glad I finally got to check this place out, and I will be back!

excerpts: and....lemon ricotta pancakes.
I will try the homemade sausage patty next time since the chicken apple sausage was fairly ordinary.
I will come back to this place just for the lemon ricotta pancakes and breakfast potatoes.
Though the pancakes are small, they're just lovely - fragrant and fluffy with a little bit of crispy edge.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Aileen C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
After hearing about this place for years as a not-to-miss SF brunch experience, my curiosity of their "amazing" potatoes overcame my weariness of SF lines. There were over 20 tables ahead of me when I put my name down but luckily not everyone is as willing to wait and we were seated after about 45 minutes of waiting. We ordered the Plow, which comes with chicken sausage/homemade sausage patty, eggs, breakfast potatoes and....lemon ricotta pancakes. I will try the homemade sausage patty next time since the chicken apple sausage was fairly ordinary. I will come back to this place just for the lemon ricotta pancakes and breakfast potatoes. Though the pancakes are small, they're just lovely - fragrant and fluffy with a little bit of crispy edge. The breakfast potatoes are amazing - the seasoning is spicy and earthy and they're crunchy on the outside and tender on the inside.

I really enjoyed the smoked salmon eggs benedict - the eggs were perfectly poached and the hollandaise sauce was creamy but not overly heavy. I also appreciated that they toasted the english muffin so the muffin didn't dissolve to mush as we broke open the egg yolk. I was tempted to lick the plate. One interesting thing was that I tasted the vinegar flavour from the cooked egg, which my boyfriend didn't notice so I'm curious if that was a one-off experience.

excerpts: Lemon ricotta pancakes
- I've had this version a few places before this, but non have I enjoyed more.
In my previous experience, they tend to be heavy on the ricotta and light on the lemon.
There's no hiding the lemon here!
Plow has achieved the perfect balance.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Donald S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
In the wise words of one Oprah Winfrey....Yeeeeees! Potrero Hill strikes again!(Oprah didn't make the strikes again reference...that's all me) And to think I almost skipped this one. Breakfast at Plow is bomb.com

These guys are not inventing the wheel here, but there is something to be said about the finest execution of fresh ingredients. 

FOOD

Breakfast sandwich - the perfect example of simple but great. I can eat this for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. A sandwich featuring eggs, avocado, cheese, bacon, and frisée. The acme bun absolutely puts this over the top. Actually I've never heard of acme before this, but it seems identical to a brioche. Is there a better sandwich bread than a soft warm brioche? No....no there is not my friend.

Lemon ricotta pancakes - I've had this version a few places before this, but non have I enjoyed more. In my previous experience, they tend to be heavy on the ricotta and light on the lemon. There's no hiding the lemon here! Plow has achieved the perfect balance. These melt in your mouth pancakes are perfection.

Plow potatoes - get.this.NOW! This is the potato mountaintop. If these are not the best breakfast potatoes you've ever had, I would really appreciate it if you would inbox me the name of one better. That's like finding out there's a second heaven! 

I swear there's something in the air in this neighborhood. Another one of my breakfast favs, which shall remain unnamed, just so happens to be a few blocks away. Plow is an instant catapult into my go to places. Already plotting my return....

excerpts: I ordered the plow, which comes with eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, rosemary potatoes, and your choice of chicken apple sausage or pork sausage patties (but you already knew that) for $17.
I was pleasantly surprised with the lemon ricotta pancakes and the potatoes!
I fell in love with both of those.
The lemon ricotta pancakes were so creamy with a hint of lemon, and the potatoes were super crunchy and had the perfect amount of seasoning.
I never finish my potatoes bc
they are so filling, but I almost finished these!
The thing I was most disappointed in was the meat...
I ordered the pork sausage patties after seeing many yelp photos and I was sad to bite into a dry, flavorless sausage patty!
Maybe next time i'll try the chicken apple sausage.
I also thought the price point was a little high, but hey, we're in San Francisco so anything goes!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Tara A.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Finalllly tried Plow and it is a solid 3.5 stars from me! I came for a Monday brunch at 12 pm and there was a 45 minute wait for a party of 3. Parties of 2 definitely get seated faster than parties of 3-4.

I ordered the plow, which comes with eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, rosemary potatoes, and your choice of chicken apple sausage or pork sausage patties (but you already knew that) for $17. I was pleasantly surprised with the lemon ricotta pancakes and the potatoes! I fell in love with both of those. The lemon ricotta pancakes were so creamy with a hint of lemon, and the potatoes were super crunchy and had the perfect amount of seasoning. I never finish my potatoes bc they are so filling, but I almost finished these! The thing I was most disappointed in was the meat... I ordered the pork sausage patties after seeing many yelp photos and I was sad to bite into a dry, flavorless sausage patty! :( Maybe next time i'll try the chicken apple sausage. I also thought the price point was a little high, but hey, we're in San Francisco so anything goes!

excerpts: About the lemon ricotta pancakes, I love lemon ricotta desserts/pancakes in general.
I found these kind of a letdown.
The hype isn't real in my opinion, but I seem to be the outlier.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Sophia L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I sat at the bar for brunch and like that you can watch them cook.

Of course the wait was long. I believe I waited just under an hour since it was a little less crowded during Christmas weekend.

I got the plow so I can have my mix of savory and sweet. The savory items were fine. Nothing special... pretty much things you can find anywhere. About the lemon ricotta pancakes, I love lemon ricotta desserts/pancakes in general. I found these kind of a letdown. The hype isn't real in my opinion, but I seem to be the outlier.

excerpts: The one thing that was delicious were the lemon ricotta pancakes.
Now those were awesome.
They were fluffy, light, and not too sweet.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Sierra R.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I'm really not sure what the hoopla was about because this place is O.K. Like, there was nothing special about it.

I went for a farewell brunch for our fantastic summer intern. Plow does not take reservations so two people went early to get our name and larger party in for a table. It took about twenty minutes which is wonderful for a table of six of you ask me.

We had heard that we should get their biscuits with honey butter so we ordered three biscuits to split amongst our group. They came and were warm. But yo....they were dense AF. Like, I was curious if it was a brick or a biscuit. It needed all the butter.

I opted for the breakfast sandwich. It was not great. It was quite bland. My potatoes were clearly ones from the bottom as they were mostly scraps and wayyyyy overcooked.

The one thing that was delicious were the lemon ricotta pancakes. Now those were awesome. They were fluffy, light, and not too sweet. I was quite impressed.

Overall, I'm not sold on the hype for Plow and wouldn't say don't go there but it wouldn't be an enthusiastic "eat there" from me.

excerpts: I ordered the plow, which is two eggs, potatoes, meat and two of their lemon ricotta pancakes.
Boy
oh boy, those pancakes stole the entire show.
They melted in your mouth with twangs of lemon and notes of sweet, melt-in-your-mouth savory flavors which I can only assume is the ricotta.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Emily R.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Absolutely delicious. This was my first time here and because it is a Thursday and I went at 8am, it wasn't busy at all. I was told by a friend that there is usually a line out the door, and I'm not surprised. 

The general atmosphere fits perfectly with the farm to table vibe, it feels relaxed and familiar. The servers were super friendly and nice. It reminded me of going to a hip friends house for breakfast. I sat at the breakfast bar and was able to see the kitchen staff preparing food, which also gave the sense of cleanliness because I could see any missteps made. 

The food was delicious, it all tasted homemade and fresh. The eggs were creamy and moist. The potatoes had a crisp to them that made me keep going back for me. The pork sausage was slightly spicy, which I am not a fan of, but I was able to try my friend's chicken sausage which had a maple syrup aftertaste to them which was just delicious. I ordered the plow, which is two eggs, potatoes, meat and two of their lemon ricotta pancakes. Boy oh boy, those pancakes stole the entire show. They melted in your mouth with twangs of lemon and notes of sweet, melt-in-your-mouth savory flavors which I can only assume is the ricotta. Combined with the syrup served on the side and a small pat of butter on top, it was heavenly. 

I would absolutely check this place out again and suggest you do the same.

excerpts: I ordered the Plow which consists of two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, two eggs, and your choice or bacon/sausage.
It's essentially a sampler.
It was admittedly pretty good.
I especially enjoyed the flavorful, buttery pancakes and the runny eggs.
The potatoes were very well seasoned and the sausage was also delicious.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Alicia L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Plow's notoriously long wait coupled with their slow af service makes me not want to come here again.

I ordered the Plow which consists of two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, two eggs, and your choice or bacon/sausage. It's essentially a sampler.
It was admittedly pretty good. I especially enjoyed the flavorful, buttery pancakes and the runny eggs. The potatoes were very well seasoned and the sausage was also delicious. They do their basics pretty well, but I kept biting into something hard with the potatoes.

My friend ordered the Vietnamese pork chop and it was absolutely terrible. I don't know if the chef just messed up but it was so overly salty we could not eat it. I'm pretty sure it was a mishap though because there's no way they'd still be in business delivering this kind of food.

The service isn't good either as there is very limited seating, so you have to wait a looooong time. Additionally, it takes forever to get your food. Set aside a really long dining time slot if you wanna eat here.

Price is 2/5
Food is 3/5
Wait is 2/5
Service is 2/5

excerpts: I was really excited for the famous lemon ricotta pancakes, but surprisingly it was my least favorite thing that I tried; the lemon flavor was good and they were pretty fluffy/soft but still not good enough to justify 3 pancakes for $16 in my opinion.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Melissa H.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Finally got to try Plow! I came in around 8:40 on a weekday and was seated immediately, which was lucky. The interior is so small, I can definitely see why the wait is insane on weekends. 

I was really excited for the famous lemon ricotta pancakes, but surprisingly it was my least favorite thing that I tried; the lemon flavor was good and they were pretty fluffy/soft but still not good enough to justify 3 pancakes for $16 in my opinion. 

By far the standout of the meal was the BUTTERMILK BISCUIT! I love baked goods of all types and I've had more than my fair share of biscuits but this is definitely leagues above any other biscuit I've ever eaten in my life. It's SO flakey and buttery and delicious and pairs AMAZINGLY with the honey butter for an ultra decadent experience. The outer crust is so perfect and the inside is so soft and warm; next time I come to Plow I'm literally just ordering like 5 of these biscuits and calling it a day.

I also tried the prosciutto & gruyere toast which was a solid savory option! The Plow potatoes are delicious, but I wish there was a bit more prosciutto. 

Overall, really solid brunch. Definitely get one (or ten) of the buttermilk biscuits.

excerpts: The potatoes are some of the best breakfast potatoes I've had - well seasoned - and the sausage, the lemon ricotta pancakes, and the eggs were all amazing!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Michele L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Solid 4.5 stars for brunch. 

This place is great for brunch, though the waits can be horrendous. The few times we actually got through the wait we ended up wandering around dogwatch for a couple hours, getting coffee at a nearby coffee shop, browsing the nearby market, walking to the nearby park, and debating whether we should maybe eat somewhere else with a shorter wait (like Aina). We have never regretted holding out though!

My go-to dish is The Plow, which seems to come with all their top hits. The potatoes are some of the best breakfast potatoes I've had - well seasoned - and the sausage, the lemon ricotta pancakes, and the eggs were all amazing!

I forgot what the other dishes are like since I just get the plow for now, but someday I will venture past this dish! Also, please start using yelp waitlist!!! Waiting around dogwatch is so painfully especially at 8am when nothing is open!

excerpts: It seems like the more popular dishes are the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and The Plow.
The Plow ($17.5) - Two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes with choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage.
The Plow ($17.5) - Two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes with choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Chelsea W.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Plow is a pretty good place to get standard brunch fare. If you come early, the wait is really worth it! 

I've always come at opening time around 8 AM and probably wouldn't wait more than 30 min for it, so I highly recommend coming early. 

The menu consists of options like Soft Scrambled Eggs, Sausage & Eggs, Eggs Benedict, etc. It seems like the more popular dishes are the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and The Plow.

The Plow ($17.5) - Two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes with choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I ended up getting the Annie's Almond Flour Pancakes since it was GF which tasted great! The chicken apple sausage was also pretty good too. I had a side of fruit which cost a little more, but also tried the potatoes and they were really delicious

Plow stands out because of it's simple, yet delicious and quality ingredients. It does run on the expensive side though.

excerpts: The food was incredible- everyone at my table ordered "The Plow" - lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes (highlight of the meal!!), eggs, and choice of meat.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Hannah O.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Came here on a Sunday morning with 4 friends- had roughly an hour wait but there are cute shops nearby to peruse while waiting. The food was incredible- everyone at my table ordered "The Plow" - lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes (highlight of the meal!!), eggs, and choice of meat. I subbed my pancakes for the seasonal pumpkin spice pancakes.

Beautiful atmosphere, incredible food, and lovely service. Will definitely be back here anytime I'm back in SF!

excerpts: The house made sausage was a bit bland, the lemon ricotta pancakes were okay, and the eggs were simply eggs.
I will say the potatoes are pretty good.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Shannon G.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
The first thing I will say is be prepared for a long wait. We went in Sunday (aka brunch day) so the 90 minute wait wasn't a surprise. Based on the glowing meal reviews seemed like it would be worth it. The place itself is small, but very nice. The staff is very pleasant and attentive. I gave three stars because the food is average. The house made sausage was a bit bland, the lemon ricotta pancakes were okay, and the eggs were simply eggs. I will say the potatoes are pretty good. Also, the fresh squeezed orange juice was perfection!
