All in all, an okay brunch location. If I were with someone who suggested Plow as the brunch spot I wouldn't object; however, it would not be on my list of suggestions if I were to pick the location.

excerpts: Unique smokehouse flavor in the bacon, home fries with a nice subtle addition of rosemary, and unbelievably good lemon ricotta pancakes.
Coffee on point too.
Two thumbs way up.
But - be vigilant on that wait list: we almost got passed up and we were literally standing right there.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Adrian C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: Yes, the wait on weekends is long, but the outstanding flavors of the food made it worth it. Perfection can be achieved in scrambled eggs, and it was here. Unique smokehouse flavor in the bacon, home fries with a nice subtle addition of rosemary, and unbelievably good lemon ricotta pancakes. Coffee on point too. Two thumbs way up. But - be vigilant on that wait list: we almost got passed up and we were literally standing right there.

excerpts: I would highly recommend the Plow ($17) where you are able to experience this savory delight w/ bacon (also fried super well), your choice of eggs and sweeten your taste buds with the lemon ricotta pancakes.
These pancakes live up to its hype and is worth getting.
If you're looking for something sweet stick to the lemon ricotta pancakes.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Christina G.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Pro tip: if you come here for brunch on a weekend be prepared to wait 1-2 hrs. Bring a coat because it's SF weather and you'll freeze waiting outside (the sun shines on the opposite side of the street) and so you can opt to eat outside and expedite your wait time. 

If you love breakfast potatoes this quite possibly may be the best in town. The potatoes here are roasted and I'm guessing flash fried to create an extra crispy texture. 

I would highly recommend the Plow ($17) where you are able to experience this savory delight w/ bacon (also fried super well), your choice of eggs and sweeten your taste buds with the lemon ricotta pancakes. These pancakes live up to its hype and is worth getting. They have a strong lemon taste and are extra fluffy. 

We also got the French roast and I WOULD NOT recommend this dish. The French toast wasn't sweet, it was soggy in all the bad ways and the stuffing inside of it was bland. Even when we tried to drench the French toast in maple syrup it did not taste good. If you're looking for something sweet stick to the lemon ricotta pancakes.

excerpts: My favorites are the lemon ricotta pancakes and their homemade sausage.
They definitely do well when it comes to getting your carbs in.
Oh and their potatoes!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Maria S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
When I'm looking for breakfast during the week, I immediately think of Plow.  I give up going on the weekends as I just can't wait or find parking.  Luckily, I almost always get a seat quickly when I go during the middle of the week.  

My favorites are the lemon ricotta pancakes and their homemade sausage.  They definitely do well when it comes to getting your carbs in.  Oh and their potatoes!  Absolutely fried to perfection.  

On my last visit, I was especially impressed with their service.  The host saw that I had a cane and was nice enough to ask if I would want to sit at the counter on a stool or wait a little longer to sit at a table so I would be more comfortable.  That really was so thoughtful!  

If you're like me, sit at the counter and watch the magic of the cooks in front of you.  I love seeing them work and also love to see the other menu items made.  Makes me want to order the entire menu.

This is the comfort breakfast place you always wanted.  Go now!

excerpts: It also comes with lemon ricotta pancakes; they were very interesting
and I know there's a lot of hype around it
but I wouldn't go crazy.
However, the pancakes w/ everything else on the plate was delicious.
Also, try the strawberry lemonade.
They give it to you in a small cup smh but it does taste good.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Angela L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
BE PREPARED TO WAIT 1-2 HRS!

I just had to come here because everyone in SF talks about this place. This place did not let down. I got the plow dish and it was amazing. Instead getting one of the meats, I got avocado. They were able to do a free vegetarian substitution. The avocado itself was the softest, richest avocado I'd ever had. The plow potatoes amazing, they are seasoned so well. It also comes with lemon ricotta pancakes; they were very interesting and I know there's a lot of hype around it but I wouldn't go crazy. However, the pancakes w/ everything else on the plate was delicious. 
Also, try the strawberry lemonade. They give it to you in a small cup smh but it does taste good.

excerpts: As for the food -- I ordered the Plow -- it comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, potatoes, and
I substituted avocado for the meat.
I opted for scrambled eggs, which were so fluffy and light.
The potatoes were crispy on the outside and smooth, and not overly herb-y.
I'm usually put off when there's excessive rosemary on breakfast potatoes.
The real star of the show would have to be the pancakes.
Which, perfectly lemony and fluffy and creamy all at once, are the reason I will be back.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Pooja K.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
So this place has always popped up in conversations with friends, and I happened to try it out for brunch. Luckily the wait was only about 20 min, but since it's a really intimate/homey space I've heard it can be a while. Personally I believe it's worth it! The decor inside is adorable, and everything is accented with this lovely yellow color that complements the Potrero Hill location amongst all the beautiful homes. 

As for the food -- I ordered the Plow -- it comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, potatoes, and I substituted avocado for the meat. I opted for scrambled eggs, which were so fluffy and light. The potatoes were crispy on the outside and smooth, and not overly herb-y. I'm usually put off when there's excessive rosemary on breakfast potatoes. The real star of the show would have to be the pancakes. Which, perfectly lemony and fluffy and creamy all at once, are the reason I will be back.

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes were also delicious.
They were light and fluffy with a hint of sweetness, it's one of the best pancakes I've had.
I wish there were more than just two small ones.
I ordered pork sausages and scrambled eggs.
The sausages were nothing special, actually tasted a little dry.
The scrambled eggs were nicely cooked to a soft scramble.
For my husband's order, the pork chop is a decent size, but the marinade was overwhelmed with fish sauce.
I understand that the pork chop is Vietnamese style, but all I can taste is fish sauce and nothing else.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Linda L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Heard a lot about this place and was warned about the wait. Unfortunately, I did not wake up early enough and arrived at 11am on Saturday for a brunch. The food was good, but definitely not worth the two hour wait for a party of two. When we arrived, there were about 4-5 parties waiting outside; however, when I put my name down, I was told there was about 1.5 pages of parties ahead of us. We were told to expect a 45min to 1hr wait and decided to just wait outside. The host and hostess had called several parties without any response, so we thought it will probably be quick. After about 45 minutes of waiting and noticing that people arrived after us got seated first. Later, my husband went in and found out that, many of the parties showed up after they were called and placed back on the waitlist in their original orders; therefore, they were being seated before us. I have no problem waiting for good food, but I feel their system flawed. Usually you would have to go to the back of the line if you missed your name, but not at Plow. So, if you want to eat here, drop by and put your name down and return at the time convenient to you. 

After about 1.5hr wait, we were finally seated at the bar right in front of the kitchen area. Not only is their seating system flawed, their waitresses were not efficient either. We were seated for about 10-15 minutes until someone finally came to offer water and coffee, then we were told that she would come back to take our order even though we said we were ready to place our orders. While we were waiting again, we noticed that the kitchen had a lull, since no orders were being placed, and the person putting all the food orders together was looking at his phone. Once the orders started going in, we saw that he did not wash his hands before starting to handle all the food. In addition, while waiting for our waitress, we saw that the hostess went into the kitchen area, reached in the pile of bacon and grabbed one with her bare hands. She went into the door that goes to the back of the kitchen to eat, which is good, and then came out and washed her hands. Maybe it would've been better to wash her hands before touching food that they will serve to customers. 

Finally, despite the long wait for service and slightly disturbed by the kitchen staff's lack of appropriate hand washing we were glad that we got our food because we were very hungry at that point (about 2 hrs since arrival). I ordered the Plow (the most popular dish), my husband ordered the pork chop and eggs. First, the potatoes are very good. It has a hard crispy outside and very soft center. It is also perfectly seasoned with salt, rosemary, grilled onions, and other herbs. The lemon ricotta pancakes were also delicious. They were light and fluffy with a hint of sweetness, it's one of the best pancakes I've had. I wish there were more than just two small ones. I ordered pork sausages and scrambled eggs. The sausages were nothing special, actually tasted a little dry. The scrambled eggs were nicely cooked to a soft scramble. For my husband's order, the pork chop is a decent size, but the marinade was overwhelmed with fish sauce. I understand that the pork chop is Vietnamese style, but all I can taste is fish sauce and nothing else. For his order, he also got scrambled eggs, and it also came with potatoes. 

Overall, I would give the food a four star, I would deduct a star because I don't think the food is good enough to worth that much wait, also for the slow service and poor hygiene.

excerpts:
It was clear what their signature dish is that all tourists and locals like to order alike ...

the plow - two eggs sunny side up, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes with house made pork sausage.
And now the lemon ricotta pancakes: WERE THE ABSOLUTE BEST!
Perfectly fluffy and soft with that great blend of lemon flavors woven within.
Not too strong nor tangy, but perfectly sweeet!
Here for some more lemon ricotta pancakes and maybe try their almond pancakes next!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Cuc N.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
On the second attempt, the boyfriend and I finally got to try this brunch restaurant called Plow. Why? Not only because it was a suggestion from a local San Franciscan, but my boyfriend finds fun and giddiness in the name itself. Weird. It's all about cows!!

Even on a Friday morning, this place has a wait for the inside, which is warm and cozy and the Christmas spirit is definitely in the air. With an airplane to catch back home, we opted to sit outside with no wait. This wasn't so bad because I do enjoy sitting on a cup of hot tea while enjoying the crisp cold air through my nose and on my face. What better Christmas spirit?

What we didn't know would be waiting for us was a very kind hostess who not only seated us at our table, but also had her hands filled with two warm and cozy blankets for each of us. I looked around. Every single seated customer had one around their shoulders or on their lap. What nice and thoughtful customer service to provide such amenities for the outside! Now I was really glad to sit outside. Just that small thing added to my cold and crisp winter morning.

I enjoyed the warm blanket. It was perfect!!!

So let's get to food??? We didn't order much because it was just us two and we both don't want to feel overstuffed. But what to order when you can only order one? This was easy to decide! It was clear what their signature dish is that all tourists and locals like to order alike ...

the plow - two eggs sunny side up, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes with house made pork sausage.

Now everything on this plate was scrumptious. The eggs were perfectly yolky and freshly made. The patties were hand made from scratch and you can taste all the fresh flavors and hard work into molding these. The potatoes were crispy, crunchy and hot. And now the lemon ricotta pancakes: WERE THE ABSOLUTE BEST! Perfectly fluffy and soft with that great blend of lemon flavors woven within. Not too strong nor tangy, but perfectly sweeet! Now this is what they were known for!

I would definitely come back here. Here for some more lemon ricotta pancakes and maybe try their almond pancakes next!

excerpts: All of my friends enjoyed their dishes as well, and we shared one of the lemon ricotta pancakes, which was phenomenal.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Kristin W.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I had brunch at Plow the other day and it was fantastic. We had to wait a while to be seated (even though it was noon on a Thursday), but once we had a table service was prompt.

I ordered the Two Egg Breakfast, and though there was nothing particularly unique about the food on my plate, everything was delicious (especially the potatoes!!). All of my friends enjoyed their dishes as well, and we shared one of the lemon ricotta pancakes, which was phenomenal. 

I probably wouldn't come here during the weekend, but if you can get in without a super long wait, go for it! (Also, I didn't partake, but I did see people ordering mimosas while they stood outside waiting...just a tip.)

excerpts: My boyfriend got "the plow" ($17.50), which was two eggs, potatoes, two mini lemon ricotta pancakes, and choice of pork sausage, chicken sausage, and bacon.
This was a pretty unique dish, and the pancakes were amazing - fluffy and sweet and lemony.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Amy C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Came here for lunch with a group of 5. The wait around 10am was a solid 2 hours, so be prepared to wait or put your name down and come back. 

The food was really good, although the prices were pretty high. My boyfriend got "the plow" ($17.50), which was two eggs, potatoes, two mini lemon ricotta pancakes, and choice of pork sausage, chicken sausage, and bacon. This was a pretty unique dish, and the pancakes were amazing - fluffy and sweet and lemony. The pork sausage was house made and also very good.

I got the breakfast sandwich, which came with eggs, bacon, and frise on a bun with potatoes ($15.75). It was pretty good but not unique enough to justify the price. It was a good portion though and filled me up. 

Overall food was about 3.75, but not sure if it's worth the wait if the wait is longer than 30-40 min.

excerpts: Food: we had the plow with lemon ricotta pancakes and pork sausage plus the breakfast sandwich with bacon and avocado.
First off, oh my GOD the lemon ricotta pancakes are not overhyped.
Soft, cakey, dense, and not too sweet-
they were absolutely the best part of the meal.
The sandwich came in next, though I would have appreciated a little more of the aioli and less frisee.
Surprise star were the breakfast potatoes that came with both.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Marissa F.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
My mom and I came here hungry, a bad idea on a Saturday morning with an hour long wait. However, we scored a sweet parking spot and didn't have anywhere to be. So wait we did, and though I probably wouldn't do the wait again, the food was worth it the first time around. 

Service & atmosphere: the place is cozy cute, but honestly I don't remember much of it since I was so starving by the time we sat down. Service was very attentive and quick.

Food: we had the plow with lemon ricotta pancakes and pork sausage plus the breakfast sandwich with bacon and avocado. First off, oh my GOD the lemon ricotta pancakes are not overhyped. Soft, cakey, dense, and not too sweet- they were absolutely the best part of the meal. The sandwich came in next, though I would have appreciated a little more of the aioli and less frisee. Surprise star were the breakfast potatoes that came with both. Crispy, well-seasoned, and just super comforting!

Def come here, preferably not at peak brunch time!

excerpts: Everything was great- the house-made sausages, the Plow potatoes, and especially the lemon ricotta pancakes.
I would definitely return just for these pancakes!
You can definitely taste the lemon flavor and the ricotta and it was even okay to eat without too much syrup.
I did find the scrambled egg a little too soft and soggy, though, which I did not like.
It felt very undercooked.
But other than that, it was a great experience!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Navie N.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: I was really excited to try this place out after reading all the reviews and it did not disappoint. At first, I was afraid to get the Plow because I thought it would be gigantic, but it's definitely a good portion for one person. Everything was great- the house-made sausages, the Plow potatoes, and especially the lemon ricotta pancakes. I would definitely return just for these pancakes! You can definitely taste the lemon flavor and the ricotta and it was even okay to eat without too much syrup. I did find the scrambled egg a little too soft and soggy, though, which I did not like. It felt very undercooked. But other than that, it was a great experience!

excerpts: Lemon ricotta pancakes are also delicious.
The only thing I haven't been impressed with is the housemade sausage...
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Joe M.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Follow the hype and it will lead you to Plow. This place is crowded every day of the week, and for good reason!

FOOD - 5/5
The potatoes are to die for! Fried to a crisp and seasoned with rosemary and plenty of garlic. I could eat these all day! Lemon ricotta pancakes are also delicious. The only thing I haven't been impressed with is the housemade sausage... For some reason it just doesn't taste that great to me.

PRICE - 3/5
$20 per person? Wait, this isn't New York... Oh well. When your brunch game is this strong, you can charge whatever you want!

WAIT - 3/5 on weekdays, 1/5 on weekends
If you're not lined up by 8am on Saturday, don't even bother...

AMBIANCE - 4/5
Nice, clean aesthetic. Love the big windows, which let in plenty of light.

SERVICE - 4/5
Waiters are nice, just busy.

PARKING - 4/5
It's surprisingly easy to find free parking in Dogpatch, add long as you're willing to walk a few blocks.

excerpts: Envision crispy potatoes, perfect lemon ricotta pancakes, and freshly made biscuits, while you are standing in an hour long line.
I got scrambled eggs with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, and chicken apple sausage.
The potatoes were cooked to crispy perfection and I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Emily T.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Envision crispy potatoes, perfect lemon ricotta pancakes, and freshly made biscuits, while you are standing in an hour long line. Its worth the wait. 

Why I was here // I came with two of my buds as we decided to go for a Sunday brunch, we even got there 5 minutes before it opened and there was already a long line down the block. By the time we got our name on the list we were given a 45 minute wait time for the outdoor seats. Sigh....We took a stroll and chit chatted the time away but...tip: sometimes they will call your name early to fit the tables if the party above you is called and not there, I would honestly stick around the restaurant , where you can hear the host because we got called early and missed it. Our wait could have been 20 minutes shorter..

Service // Service is friendly for this bustling restaurant. Since we were sitting in the freezing cold in their outdoor patio area with no heating, they offered us blankets which was nice. 

Food // 
-Buttermilk Biscuit with honey butter // 5.00 // I was so happy I got this magical piece of fluffy goodness. The honey butter was creamy and sweet and meshed well with the light, crispy and warm biscuit
-The Plow // 17.50 // The whole package this one is. I got scrambled eggs with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, and chicken apple sausage. The potatoes were cooked to crispy perfection and I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes! 

Overall // I would definitely come here to this magical palace of brunch. The only issue is that wait time can be pretty bad, so maybe I would try coming on a weekday next time around. 
Also this place is small and doesn't accommodate parties larger than 6, so choose your brunch friends wisely.

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes that comes on this plate are to die for.
Next time I'm just getting that alone.
Overall good atmosphere as well.
Just be prepared to stand and wait around for the food.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Claudio R.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: Was told by a restaurant owner from DTLA to try this place out if I visited SF, went on a Friday and the wait was about 40 min. The chefs are incredible and the way they move is insane, everything is precise. The food reflected that. The breakfast sandwich was so good(add the avocado and bacon for a party in your mouth). The other dish was the signature PLOW which is a platter of food. Bacon is what they're known for from what I've heard so try that. Potatoes are perfectly crisp but so soft on the inside. The lemon ricotta pancakes that comes on this plate are to die for. Next time I'm just getting that alone. Overall good atmosphere as well. Just be prepared to stand and wait around for the food.

excerpts: Well-crisped potatoes accompanied by eggs cooked to order with a side of meat of your choosing - bacon, in my case, all come together to provide a bombardment of savory flavor before you settle in for the reason you came: the lemon ricotta pancakes.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Matthew V.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Another delicious brunch spot in San Francisco. The eponymous item, "The Plow" is an excellent collection of breakfast foods combined for the delight of your taste buds. Well-crisped potatoes accompanied by eggs cooked to order with a side of meat of your choosing - bacon, in my case, all come together to provide a bombardment of savory flavor before you settle in for the reason you came: the lemon ricotta pancakes.

I must confess, they were not to die for, as some have claimed. But they are absolutely worth living for and enjoying. Tasty food, small venue, longer waits than you want: everything you'd expect from a San Francisco brunch place, but in a good way.

excerpts: Their lemon ricotta pancakes are moist and fresh (but you already knew that.
Custard French toast- also bomb (more custard filling needed please).
I would love to see places like this start playing with their syrup flavors to set them apart from competitors creating similar dishes like Sweet Maple.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Tash B.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I LOVED my brunch here this past Saturday. YES it's a 90 minute wait, NO they don't take phone numbers.. but it's worth it . 

They've got seating inside and out. Unfortunately  their outdoor seating doesn't fall in the sun so it can get chilly. 

Their staff, though slammed, was super friendly omitting great vibes, especially the runners. 

Their lemon ricotta pancakes are moist and fresh (but you already knew that. Custard French toast- also bomb (more custard filling needed please). I would love to see places like this start playing with their syrup flavors to set them apart from competitors creating similar dishes like Sweet Maple. Perhaps a rosemary orange peel infused syrup to compliment the ricotta pancakes? 

Breakfast sandwich, prosciutto Gouda toast, bacon - all on point, and it's easy to mess up bacon. Super crispy, and a plenty. The grapefruit mimosa was delicious, though I REALLY was craving a bloody (they only have mimosas, beer and wine:(... )

Will definitely be returning, likely earlier for less of a wait

excerpts: plow: bacon, scambled eggs, plow potatoes, and 2 mini lemon ricotta pancakes.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Michelle N.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I haven't had much luck with the brunch scene in the bay area, but I think I found a winner!!! Plow has been on my bookmark list for years, and my fiance and I finally had a chance to try it! We arrived on a Saturday at 8AM and were met with a massive line. There was ~40 min wait (quoted as 25-30 min), as we missed the first seating of the restaurant.

We tried:
-the plow: bacon, scambled eggs, plow potatoes, and 2 mini lemon ricotta pancakes. The crispy potatoes are just as good as everyone says, and the pancakes were delicious. However, mine felt dense; not as fluffy as others said.
-dungeness crab scrambled: I was a bigger fan of this than my fiance was, but we both agreed it was delicious

So glad to have found a favorite brunch place in the bay, and I can't wait to come back!!

excerpts: (I switched out the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes from The Plow).
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Yoona K.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Visited SF again and apparently this is "one of the best brunch places in SF." Maybe I'm just spoiled with how many amazing brunch places there are in DC but I was pretty underwhelmed with what I ate, especially with the long wait. 

My friend and I came around 11am on a Sunday and had to wait 2 hours before getting seated. There are a lot of cute coffee shops down the block so we put our names down (they only call your name at the door, no text notification) and walked over to work at a nearby cafe. We got seated after 2 hours and were starving at this point so anything would've tasted good. The interior is very cute and had a nice overall vibe with the open kitchen (seating less than 30 people throughout the whole restaurant?). 

I ordered The Plow based on most of the Yelp reviews on here and my friend ordered the Blood Sausage. Both brunch items were tasty but nothing amazing and definitely not worth a 2 hour wait. Everything was pretty standard in terms of taste in my opinion (eggs, sausage, potatoes etc.)... The only thing that is worth mentioning was that the Pumpkin Pancakes were really good (I switched out the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes from The Plow).

excerpts: I ordered the plow which comes with eggs (light, fluffy-no taste of cheap cooking oil), potatoes (well seasoned, cripsy), lemon ricotta pancakes (light with perfectly browned edges).
Even the coffee was superb (French roast).
Welcoming airy environment, love tqpqqhe gray color palet and light scent of fresh flowers.
The waitresses  were super sweet and very attentive.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Sabrina D.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: Seriously impressed! did NOT have one freaking complaint which never happens. I ordered the plow which comes with eggs (light, fluffy-no taste of cheap cooking oil), potatoes (well seasoned, cripsy), lemon ricotta pancakes (light with perfectly browned edges). Even the coffee was superb (French roast). Welcoming airy environment, love tqpqqhe gray color palet and light scent of fresh flowers. The waitresses  were super sweet and very attentive.

excerpts: I did not get a chance to write a review last time I was here, but I was definitely blown away by everything: the aesthetic, the lemon ricotta pancakes, the service.
I also ordered the lemon ricotta pancakes ($16) because I was dying to have my friends try them!
The chorizo scramble itself tasted great, but we were starving and for the price tag of $17, the portions were skimpy.
I ran out of soft tortillas quickly and was left with an large amount of beans showing that the dish wasn't proportionate either.
The lemon ricotta pancakes are always a winner!
However, 3 pancakes for $16 is still a reach, no matter how "pure" the maple syrup was.
Don't get me wrong, I want to love this place and would recommend you try it out at least once for the delicious and fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes.
They are easily the most unique, tasty pancakes I've ever had!
But just be prepared financially and mentally for small portions and high prices.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Alexi G.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I did not get a chance to write a review last time I was here, but I was definitely blown away by everything: the aesthetic, the lemon ricotta pancakes, the service.
This time around, I wanted to be blown away but was taken back by the experience that I had.

My group of 4 arrived at around 11AM on a Monday morning, expecting a not too long wait because it was a weekday. It was about a 30-40 minute which was fine since it gave us some time to browse the surrounding bookstores and enjoy the surprisingly sunny SF weather.

We got seated 30 minutes later (HURRAY for an accurate hostess) and we quickly picked our dishes, eager to get our order in as we were starving. Our food took about 30-35 minutes to come out, but they felt like the longest 35 minutes of my life considering we had already waited an hour and were starving. On top of that, it didn't take long for us to drink all the water in the hopes of tiding our hunger and it wasn't refilled for a while. I eventually chose to order a $4 coffee because the food took so long and I was getting a little "hangry". But OK - maybe it was a little bit of our fault for not preparing ourselves for the wait.

Now, this is where it gets bumpy on Plow's end. 
Our food came out; I got the chorizo scramble ($17), a change from the "plow" combo that I usually get. I also ordered the lemon ricotta pancakes ($16) because I was dying to have my friends try them!
The chorizo scramble itself tasted great, but we were starving and for the price tag of $17, the portions were skimpy. I ran out of soft tortillas quickly and was left with an large amount of beans showing that the dish wasn't proportionate either. The lemon ricotta pancakes are always a winner! However, 3 pancakes for $16 is still a reach, no matter how "pure" the maple syrup was. I was so hungry that I could've probably gone out to another restaurant after but did not want to order more after spending so much on such small portions.

Don't get me wrong, I want to love this place and would recommend you try it out at least once for the delicious and fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes. They are easily the most unique, tasty pancakes I've ever had! But just be prepared financially and mentally for small portions and high prices.

excerpts: Although they weren't as heavenly as the lemon ricotta pancakes, they were as soft and fluffy.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Doruk B.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Plow is the best brunch spot in SF. Yes, the food is as amazing as you heard and, yes, the wait can be deterrent. 

Today was my second visit to Plow. I ordered the Plow. Lemon ricotta pancake is fluffy and you can almost taste the ricotta cheese. You must try it. The plow potatoes are as fascinating. The skin of potatoes was so thin and yet crunchy. I had my eggs sunny side up and that worked great with the homemade sausage. I also tried the pumpkin pancakes. Although they weren't as heavenly as the lemon ricotta pancakes, they were as soft and fluffy. I think SF has plenty decent brunch options but Plow manages to rise above the rest. 

The service is great and polite. Our waitress was great at making recommendations and checked on us a couple of times. 

The wait wasn't too bad this time around. We only waited for about 30 minutes. That could be because it is the Friday after the Christmas break or because we got seated right around 2pm, which is when Plow closes. 

I strongly recommend trying Plow. Decide for yourself whether the food justifies the wait. I think it does.

excerpts: Lemon ricotta pancakes?
Tart and complemented every bite of potato that came after.
The housemade pork patties exploded with juice and delectable flavor, ever so slightly caramelized on the outside by the flattop.
The bacon on the sandwich was pliant, but it was clear that finishing it off on the flat-top really did it crispy justice.
And wow, I hate frisee in every mixed greens
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Gwen W.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I feel bad for anyone who waits more than an hour for this place. Considering that we came at 10 a.m. on a Sunday and waited a whopping 15 minutes (seriously, I timed it from the second we got out of our Lyft). Why? Everyone else wandered away to get coffee or check out the few shops down the street. Just stand around and wait a bit, apparently. Or perch on the wooden slabs affixed to the wall.

Foodies and chefs alike have crowned Plow the best brunch in The City. (See: Dzung Duong of Honeysuckle Catering, J. Kenji Lopez-Alt of the Food Lab, critics at Thrillist, Eater SF, SF Gate, Conde Nast...) And holy hell, I used to think that title belonged to Kitchen Story. Nope.

My significant other went for the Plow breakfast, with two over easy eggs and their housemade pork sausage patties, while I ordered the breakfast sandwich with bacon and a cinnamon roll. Everything we had was phenomenal. The crispy roasted potatoes are the stuff of daydreams, and sitting at the breakfast bar watching cooks in the kitchen toss them with herbs and soft, sweet onions made them so much more satisfying to eat. Imagine a skin that shatters the moment it meets your front teeth. I would deep fry the heck out of my home fries the way that the folks at Plow do.

They've also mastered the art of cooking fluffy eggs, complete with crispy edges and runny yolks. Lemon ricotta pancakes? Tart and complemented every bite of potato that came after. The housemade pork patties exploded with juice and delectable flavor, ever so slightly caramelized on the outside by the flattop. The bacon on the sandwich was pliant, but it was clear that finishing it off on the flat-top really did it crispy justice. And wow, I hate frisee in every mixed greens salad I eat, but the bitter vegetable actually went so well with the fluffy Acme bread, meat, and eggs.

The cinnamon roll was a 9/10 on the indie pastry scale. I found it a little bit dry, but it satisfied a month-long craving for gooey cinnamon buns and it was made quite well.

Service is very friendly here, and despite the hustle and bustle, I was impressed by their professionalism and their ability to work with each other in the kitchen. Cue cooks working together to plate a sandwich, with one guy handling all eggs and another one popping the buns right off the flattop. Plus, our water jug never ran low. If the weekend wait is as bad as it seems, I think I'd pop in on a weekday instead. At the very least, I would come for those fantastically crispy potatoes.

excerpts: Lemon ricotta pancakes are bomb!
They're very soft and the ricotta chunks go so well with the zesty-ness of the lemon.
Potatoes are perfectly seasoned and crispy (SO crispy!)
and the sausage is so full of flavor and spice.
It's also crazy juicy - juice was just oozing out with each bite.
Scrambled eggs are perfectly done - not over cooked like many places do them.
I was very satisfied with my meal.
Also I came around 1:20pm on Sunday and waited maybe 45 minutes for a table for 2, so not bad at all.
I definitely want to come back!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Jeana Y.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: Lemon ricotta pancakes are bomb! They're very soft and the ricotta chunks go so well with the zesty-ness of the lemon. Potatoes are perfectly seasoned and crispy (SO crispy!) and the sausage is so full of flavor and spice. It's also crazy juicy - juice was just oozing out with each bite. Scrambled eggs are perfectly done - not over cooked like many places do them. I was very satisfied with my meal. Also I came around 1:20pm on Sunday and waited maybe 45 minutes for a table for 2, so not bad at all. I definitely want to come back!

excerpts: And my favorite ... the lemon ricotta pancakes are to die for!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Samantha L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Plow understands what a real breakfast should taste like. They have the best, crispiest potatoes. The sausage and bacon are full of flavor without the grease. And my favorite ... the lemon ricotta pancakes are to die for! Give me all the carbs and sugar! 

I usually pick up due to the intimidating wait times but every once in a while it's essential to sit down and casually enjoy a meal here.

excerpts: Lovely links of chicken apple sausage and two lemon ricotta pancakes were enough to satisfy the two of us!
This place definitely does the basics and turns them to indescribably amazing bits of heaven.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Rachel S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
This place is simply darling!! Well worth the hour wait even at 1 pm on a Saturday. (Beware, we came late and they were out of biscuits. They must be something!!) Luckily you can entertain yourself with the views of the city! (They're in between some of the crazy hills) 
My friend and I simply ordered the plow to split and it arrived fairly quickly! Scrambled eggs, perfectly ribboned and melt in your mout. Truly amazing! Crispy hash browns without having to request them that way with a mild dusting of beautifully fresh rosemary. Lovely links of chicken apple sausage and two lemon ricotta pancakes were enough to satisfy the two of us!
This place definitely does the basics and turns them to indescribably amazing bits of heaven.

excerpts: I had The Plow with their house made pork sausage patties, along with two lemon ricotta pancakes and their famous Plow potatoes.
Out of the three items that were on the plate, I probably enjoyed the pancakes the most, with the potatoes coming in a close second.
The sausage patties were good, but maybe just a tad too salty for me.
My husband had the French Toast and we essentially ate in total silence.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Lisa I.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
After living in SF for 7 years, I finally made it to Plow. Don't ask me why it took so long. But I finally did it.

My husband and I braved the experience by queueing up before 7:30AM to ensure that we were in the first wave of seating once they opened. I suppose a true San Franciscan would have braved the epic line later on in the day, but I've got more important things to do than sit around and wait. I had The Plow with their house made pork sausage patties, along with two lemon ricotta pancakes and their famous Plow potatoes. Out of the three items that were on the plate, I probably enjoyed the pancakes the most, with the potatoes coming in a close second. The sausage patties were good, but maybe just a tad too salty for me. My husband had the French Toast and we essentially ate in total silence. Neither of us wanted to share any of our dishes, which usually means it's truly delicious and worth keeping close to the vest.

Do I think waiting for Plow is worth it? No. But if you're an early riser and need something to do early in the morning, this is a great place to check off your SF Must-Eat list.

excerpts: I got two eggs with bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Yvi L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Another SF brunch place to check off my list. We came here on a Friday morning around 11:00 and of course there was already a big crowd of people waiting outside. For just me and my man the estimated wait time was 1.5 hours! 
The crowd dissembled a bit when it started raining, but the wait time ended up still being 1 hour 15 minutes. 

VIBE: very cute homey cafe. Farm to table vibes and super clean 

FOOD: 
The Plow- I got two eggs with bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes. The pancakes were super fluffy and the potatoes were seasoned well without being salty. 

Butcher's steak- my man got this dish and he must have really loved it because it was gone quickly. (Or he was just very hungry from the long wait) 

Both dishes were presented beautifully and did taste good quality. But not sure it was unique enough or THAAAAT good to justify the long wait.

excerpts: Not the best lemon ricotta pancakes, but the breakfast potatoes were very crispy!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Alyssa P.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Came here on a Sunday morning around 9 am, and was told the wait would be a 1-1.5 hours for a party of 4. I agree with other Yelpers in that you should not stray too far from the front door, as they are only shout names and move through the list very quickly. 

Food was good, but not great. I had the signature Plow which I appreciate for offering a combination of both savory and sweet options. Not the best lemon ricotta pancakes, but the breakfast potatoes were very crispy! 

Service was fine to begin with, however as the line outside grew it took a lot longer to get simple things such as more water or the check. 

While Plow has the makings of a fantastic breakfast spot, between the wait for a table and the so-so service, I'm not quite ready to make this a regular go-to.

excerpts: The Lemon Ricotta Pancakes are creamy, fluffy, with a subtle lemon flavor.
Hands down all pancakes should be made with ricotta.
The homemade pork sausage patties are full of flavor.
Lastly, the eggs are cooked perfectly and seasoned well.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Julian L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Wait - 1 Hour @ 13:00

Value - $17 / dish.

Dish Size: Medium

The Plow -  Imagine the best Denny's Grand Slam you every had and times that by 1,000,000 - that's how good this dish is. Every component of the dish is amazing in taste and preparation. The crispy potatoes are probably the best potatoes you'll have in the city. The Lemon Ricotta Pancakes are creamy, fluffy, with a subtle lemon flavor. Hands down all pancakes should be made with ricotta. The homemade pork sausage patties are full of flavor. Lastly, the eggs are cooked perfectly and seasoned well. To put simply, this dish is perfect. 


If you love traditional classic breakfast, Plow is the perfect place. Plow isn't trying to reinvent the wheel, what Plow does it takes the classics and makes the best version of it possible. The food is so refined that it's hard to imagine how Plow could improve upon their dishes. I suppose the price could be a bit lower...

The rustic and refined qualities of the food carries all the way through into the space. Although the interior is small, Plow feels spacious with large operable windows allowing natural light and ventilation to flood the entirety of the space. Plow's interior is minimal with warm accents of rustic decor, must notably the angled dark wood floor. With only a handful of tables and counter seating, it's obvious why the wait can reach upwards of an hour. 

Admittedly, deciding to dine at Plow boils down to one question, "Am I willing to wait over an hour for brunch?" I must say that I wavered a bit while waiting but after the meal I can confidently say that it's worth the wait.

excerpts: I got the plow, which everyone raves about, and I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes.
So heavenly!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Tiffany H.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Best brunch I've had in SF! I did wait an hour and a half, but I guess it really was amazing as everyone else says. 

Their potatoes are bombdotcom- crispy, smooth, and just very potato. Very simplistic and pure. I got the plow, which everyone raves about, and I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes. So heavenly! The chicken apple sausage was delicious as well, and my over medium eggs were cooked up to par.  

My friend got the prosciutto & gruyere toast, and I had a bite. Tasted A+ as well. 

Service was very nice, and they really do try to be efficient.

excerpts: The Plow: comes with the lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, eggs, and choice of sausage or bacon.
The lemon ricotta pancakes are one of my favorite, great flavor and so fluffy!
The potatoes are fried, so you know it's good!
One of my favorite potato places, my other favorite is probably at Kitchen Story.
Prosciutto, Gruyere open sandwich:
Served with a perfect egg on top (great yolk action!)
and on a great hardy slice of bread.
If you like prosciutto and gruyere, order this!
French Toast:
It had warm apples served on it
but it was nothing special.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Lauren S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Brunch is super popular in SF and there are many places to go but Plow is definitely by far my favorite.  It is a small shop and always has a long wait.  But there is a nice coffee shop nearby where you can wait and enjoy a nice coffee.  Or if the line is too long you can venture to Neighbor Bakehouse which is only about a 12 minute walk and one of my favorite bakeries in SF too.  

I have been here on a few occasions and here is what we have ordered:
1. Biscuit, got to get the biscuit!  Just get one to share with the table.  Comes with a homemade jam too.
2. The Plow: comes with the lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, eggs, and choice of sausage or bacon.  The lemon ricotta pancakes are one of my favorite, great flavor and so fluffy!  The potatoes are fried, so you know it's good!  One of my favorite potato places, my other favorite is probably at Kitchen Story.  
3. Prosciutto, Gruyere open sandwich: Served with a perfect egg on top (great yolk action!) and on a great hardy slice of bread.  If you like prosciutto and gruyere, order this! 
4. French Toast: It had warm apples served on it but it was nothing special.  I would not recommend ordering it.

Overall highly recommend and a must try in SF!

excerpts: It comes with two eggs, potatoes, your meat of choice and two lemon ricotta pancakes.
The potatoes are fried with rosemary and the lemon ricotta pancakes are so flavorful, these are definitely my two favorite parts of this dish.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Mallory L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
This is literally my favorite breakfast spot of all time. I dream about Plow and drool just thinking about it. Breakfast is hands down my favorite meal of the day and Plow always does it right. 

If you haven't visited Plow before, I recommend ordering The Plow. It comes with two eggs, potatoes, your meat of choice and two lemon ricotta pancakes. The potatoes are fried with rosemary and the lemon ricotta pancakes are so flavorful, these are definitely my two favorite parts of this dish. 

The fried egg sandwich is another amazing choice. I've never had a better breakfast sandwich in my life. The aioli and the Vermont cheddar make this sandwich give me two thumbs up  

If you're dining with a few others, I highly recommend ordering the French toast for your entire party to share. I'm not a french toast type of gal, but the mascarpone and baked apples make this dish sooooo amazing.

You'll definitely have to wait in order to be seated at Plow. If you're visiting on the weekends, get there early or you might have to wait two hours, BUT it is totally worth it.

excerpts: The plow contains of two lemon ricotta pancakes, wedge potatoes, a choice of bacon, pork belly bacon or sausage and 2 eggs.
If you don't eat meat, you can substitute the bacon or sausage with avocado or salad.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Ghazal P.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
We've been coming to plow for a couple of years and always bring our friends who are visiting from out of town to plow. The best times to go there to avoid the long wait is during the week.otherwise, expect a minimum of an hour wait. 
As you are waiting, you can visit the neighborhood, grab some coffee and enjoy a nice quiet walk.

We have pretty much ordered everything on the menu and our all time favorite is the plow and the egg sandwich. The plow contains of two lemon ricotta pancakes, wedge potatoes, a choice of bacon, pork belly bacon or sausage and 2 eggs. If you don't eat meat, you can substitute the bacon or sausage with avocado or salad. If you are gluten intolerant, you can substitute the ricotta pancakes with almond flour pancakes. But please know that there's cross contamination as all of their gluten items are cooked in the same fryer. 

You can't go wrong with anything on the menu. The long wait is always worth it for me!

excerpts: I got the the plow breakfast which comes with two lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, potatoes, and sausage.
I can't wait to come back and have this meal all over again.
It's all I ever think about.
We went on a Friday and probably got there at 10
we told an hour which was fine and totally worth
the wait wouldn't mind doing again just to taste those fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Sofia V.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: What can I say one of the best breakfast I've ever had. I got the the plow breakfast which comes with two lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, potatoes, and sausage. I can't wait to come back and have this meal all over again. It's all I ever think about. We went on a Friday and probably got there at 10 we told an hour which was fine and totally worth the wait wouldn't mind doing again just to taste those fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes!

excerpts: As for our meals themselves, we shared the Plow with the absolutely scrumptious lemon ricotta pancakes (fluffiness for days!), pork sausage, over medium eggs, and their crispy potatoes, as well as the corned beef hash which tasted almost fajita-y and had really tender corned beef.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Eva C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
As an SF transplant, I'm slowly trying to make my way through the city's top brunch spots, and Plow did not disappoint. 

Location - Parking was surprisingly not too difficult to find, with open street spots here and there.

Wait time - Coming on a Saturday morning around 11am, we were quoted a wait of an hour and a half for a party of 2 so we put our names down and went to a nearby store. We came back ~45 minutes later, and to our surprise were shortly called up! 

FOOD! - Delicious! Relatively standard brunch fare in my opinion, but done really well. We started off with a buttermilk biscuit, which I have to say is probably one of the best biscuits I've had. We also ordered grapefruit mimosas, which were refreshing and the acidity paired well with the heaviness of our meal.

As for our meals themselves, we shared the Plow with the absolutely scrumptious lemon ricotta pancakes (fluffiness for days!), pork sausage, over medium eggs, and their crispy potatoes, as well as the corned beef hash which tasted almost fajita-y and had really tender corned beef. 

Service was friendly and welcoming, and after this experience I would definitely visit Plow again!

excerpts: The first time, I had The Plow breakfast, which comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes (crisp, and tossed with caramelized onions and rosemary),
A friend of mine ordered The Plow, but with poached eggs, and also noticed the overpowering vinegar flavor of the eggs.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Yvonne C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
The breakfast here is pretty delicious, so expect a wait, unless you show up well before 8:30 AM.

I've been here twice now with friends, and have enjoyed both experiences.  The first time, I had The Plow breakfast, which comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes (crisp, and tossed with caramelized onions and rosemary), two eggs any style (I had them over-easy), and a choice of meat.  The potatoes rock, the pancakes are fluffy, and everything else is pretty solid (I had the chicken apple sausage).

The second time I came, I got the benedict.  It was alright...but I wouldn't get it again.  The poached eggs were cooked in water with way too much vinegar, so the eggs essentially tasted like vinegar to the degree that it overpowered the hollandaise sauce.  The English muffin upon which it sat was kind of soggy, either from the spinach and mushrooms, or the vinegary egg.  The potatoes were solid.  A friend of mine ordered The Plow, but with poached eggs, and also noticed the overpowering vinegar flavor of the eggs.  We also got the walnut rosemary cake, which was warm, toasty, and delicious.

Tip: get your eggs any style BUT poached, unless you like the burning acidity of vinegar for breakfast.

excerpts: It included two eggs with your choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, and two (mini) lemon ricotta pancakes with a side of yet again those delicious plow potatoes ($17.50).
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Brittany D.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
This is definitely one of the more upscale brunch joints with average meals $15+, but to be fair, the food is excellent! They deserve to be paid top dollar for the eclectic menu. 

FOOD. My goodness, what I would give for another open-faced prosciutto and gruyere toast this morning?! This magical combo with chili, garlic egg fried up, frisee (a type of endive) and parsley atop a toasted Acme brioche ($15) was heavenly. With a side of plow potatoes, this meal leans on the carb-heavy side of the breakfast food spectrum, but I cannot complain because it was simply amazing. *I do have to warn you, however, that the egg is super runny, so consume with extreme caution* They also serve Equator drip coffee! Although not a seasoned coffee drinker myself, I do appreciate this particular brand of coffee ever since my first tasting at its home base location in Marin County. My two other classmates each ordered the plow signature dish, a tasting platter, if you will, and a good first-timer dish according to the waitress. It included two eggs with your choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, and two (mini) lemon ricotta pancakes with a side of yet again those delicious plow potatoes ($17.50). One of them also ordered fresh grapefruit juice and a warm buttermilk biscuit with honey butter (omg). 

SERVICE. 5 stars. The waitress even knew how to use an instax mini 9. She deserved bonus points for this. Tuesday morning around 10am is also the best time to come if you can. We were seated almost instantly upon arrival-- it took longer for my instax camera to produce an image on the Polaroid film. She was also very accommodating and gave great recommendations. We got pretty good seats by the window, but do be aware that since space is tight, the tables feel communal even though they're separate from each other. So if you're okay with sitting right next to the table next to you, then it should be fine. Get friendly.

I will reiterate: excellent food, excellent service. Can't wait to be back to try the other items on the menu!

excerpts: Got the lemon ricotta pancakes and left a changed man.
The ricotta combined with the lemon, while fully ingrained in the pancakes are beautifully seared.
Drizzle a little maple syrup on it
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Richard Cornelius T.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Got the lemon ricotta pancakes and left a changed man. The ricotta combined with the lemon, while fully ingrained in the pancakes are beautifully seared. Drizzle a little maple syrup on it and you've got a guaranteed food coma. 

Much like any SF restaurant it's lacking in space and unfortunately the wait can go up to 1.5 hours but it's well worth the wait. 

Food: 5/5
Service/Wait: 4/5

excerpts: It comes with your choice of bacon or house made pork sausage, two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and potatoes.
Every element in this dish is done perfectly.
I haven't tried the bacon because their house made pork sausage is so well flavored (they put a lot of herbs inside to balance out the pork).
The lemon ricotta pancakes are softer than normal pancakes because of the ricotta and they have a nice lemon-y taste throughout.
And the POTATOES.
They are always so on point with their potatoes.
I don't know how they make the outside so crispy and the inside so soft.
These are probably the best potatoes I've ever had.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Christine L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I've visited Plow at least 3 times now. You really cannot get any better than ordering "The Plow". It comes with your choice of bacon or house made pork sausage, two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and potatoes. Every element in this dish is done perfectly. I haven't tried the bacon because their house made pork sausage is so well flavored (they put a lot of herbs inside to balance out the pork). The lemon ricotta pancakes are softer than normal pancakes because of the ricotta and they have a nice lemon-y taste throughout. And the POTATOES. They are always so on point with their potatoes. I don't know how they make the outside so crispy and the inside so soft. These are probably the best potatoes I've ever had. Their seasoning is good too.

We've tried the breakfast sandwich and the eggs benedict. They're good too but will forever be in the shadow of "The Plow".

Come early and get in with the first batch of people so you minimize your wait time. Don't fear eating outside even with the cold fog. They provide blankets.

excerpts: The eggs and potatoes are consistent, and the lemon ricotta pancakes are really different.
They look fluffy, but inside is a bit dense.
I don't mind it since I prefer denser pancakes, but others may think differently.
I'm not sure if $17 is completely worth it for the dish, but as long as it is tasty, I really can't complain.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Nick L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I need to preface this by saying that if you aren't willing to wait a decent amount of time for a table, you need to come here early in the morning, especially if it's a weekend. And I don't mean come here when they open, I'm saying line up 30 minutes before they open to make the first seating. I got here right at the open, and still had to wait 30-45 minutes because I didn't make the first seating. 

That said, the food here is pretty good. I get "The Plow" every time, since it is the quintessential breakfast on a large plate. I normally get the house made sausage patties. The eggs and potatoes are consistent, and the lemon ricotta pancakes are really different. They look fluffy, but inside is a bit dense. I don't mind it since I prefer denser pancakes, but others may think differently. I'm not sure if $17 is completely worth it for the dish, but as long as it is tasty, I really can't complain.

excerpts: We ordered The Plow which came with eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, meat, home fries, etc.
We also tried the Breakfast Sandwich and the Biscuit.
ALL ARE AMAZING.
The lemon ricotta pancakes melt in your mouth with a subtle lemon flavor that helps cut through the fat.
I gotta say I couldn't eat a ton of them though because they are ridiculously rich.
The flakey biscuit comes with creamy honey butter -- a must try.
The potatoes really steal the show.
Definitely a top 3 home fry for me -- a strong plus for this place.
Lastly, the breakfast sandwich is heavenly with a fluffy acme bun and delicious melted cheddar.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Deena M.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
My friends tell me this is the best brunch place in SF -- it doesn't disappoint. Definitely try this place out, but come on a weekday if you can (weekend wait times are astronomical) and be prepared to shovel out some cash. Pros: delicious food, quaint atmosphere; Cons: price, over-hype

Food: We ordered The Plow which came with eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, meat, home fries, etc. We also tried the Breakfast Sandwich and the Biscuit. ALL ARE AMAZING. The lemon ricotta pancakes melt in your mouth with a subtle lemon flavor that helps cut through the fat. I gotta say I couldn't eat a ton of them though because they are ridiculously rich. The flakey biscuit comes with creamy honey butter -- a must try. The potatoes really steal the show. Definitely a top 3 home fry for me -- a strong plus for this place. Lastly, the breakfast sandwich is heavenly with a fluffy acme bun and delicious melted cheddar. I must say we were impressed. 

Atmosphere: This place feels very homey and, to me, almost nondescript. The tables and decor are simple and the place is very small so you feel like you're being served at someone's home. It helps that you're in the middle of a cute Portrero Hill neighborhood. 

Value: Now the portions here are huge (as brunch tends to be) but it is definitely pricey. Most main entrees are around $15-17 -- the higher end. I thought the quality of food was justifiable in the end. 

Service: Kind and attentive -- food came pretty quickly. I have to say I'm sure we'd have a slightly different experience if we came on a busy weekend. 

In all a star brunch place. Just don't let the crowds and buzz interfere with your expectations. :)

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes immediately impressed me because it wasn't tarty
but it was a comfortable lemony flavour with a delicious center.
The chicken sausages complimented the eggs.
My breakfast needs were fulfilled.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Liza H.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Plow
 My partner and I came here on a Friday morning and it took about 10 minutes to get seated. We almost ordered 5 minutes after and the food came by really quick. 

Food:
We ordered The Plow and the Smoked Salmon Toast. The waitress assured that our meals will be a pack full and she was right. The Smoked Salmon Toast was very satisfying and included 4 pieces of fried toast, fresh cucumbers, capers, cheese, and pickeled cabbage and a side of salad. It was an food orgy in my mouth. 

The Plow's potatoes were my favourite due to the crispness and richness in spices. The lemon ricotta pancakes immediately impressed me because it wasn't tarty but it was a comfortable lemony flavour with a delicious center. The chicken sausages complimented the eggs. My breakfast needs were fulfilled. We were kind of crazy to order a coconut mochi cake for starters.. 

Service:
We were welcomed by a nice greeting queue lady and our sit down waitress was extremely helpful with helping us pick our orders. She knew which meals could fill us up.

excerpts: Snuggling in, we both ordered the Plow, a combo breakfast platter with potatoes, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, choice of chicken apple sausage, homemade pork sausage, or bacon, and 2 eggs any style.
We got our eggs sunnyside up (the best way!)
and ordered pork sausage with one order, and chicken apple with the other
so we can share.
Chicken apple sausage was the winning protein for me!
The pork sausage was more of a patty, and not as juicy as I would have expected, I'd opt for chicken apple sausage if you're trying to decide!
"The Plow" is like a familiar, warm hug!
My favorite part were the lemon ricotta pancakes.
They were the perfect size so you get a wholesome taste, but not overpowering to the point where you can't finish your meal.
The flavor was refreshing, and I love the creaminess/fluffiness the ricotta gives the pancake.
Though pretty steep at $17.50 a plate, I thoroughly enjoyed the food, and both my boyfriend
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Tina T.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Finally had put aside enough time to try this place out! As commonly known, Plow has a very long wait for brunch on the weekends, and unfortunately, weekends are the only chance I get to have brunch in the city.  But, if you do have a chance to stop by, I'd recommend! It's located in a home-y neighborhood, with small shops down 18th and Farley's coffee shop down the way if you need a place to wait (or some coffee to settle your hunger!). 

My boyfriend and I waited a decent 1.5 hours to get seated, closer to 2 hours to get our food.  We were seated outside, and thankfully it was a beautiful day in SF.  Although there was a slight chill (it's SF in February, expected lol), they provide blankets on the outside seats in case you get cold. Such a sweet touch, and made waiting for our food less uncomfortable.  Snuggling in, we both ordered the Plow, a combo breakfast platter with potatoes, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, choice of chicken apple sausage, homemade pork sausage, or bacon, and 2 eggs any style. We got our eggs sunnyside up (the best way!) and ordered pork sausage with one order, and chicken apple with the other so we can share.  Chicken apple sausage was the winning protein for me!  The pork sausage was more of a patty, and not as juicy as I would have expected, I'd opt for chicken apple sausage if you're trying to decide! 
"The Plow" is like a familiar, warm hug! My favorite part were the lemon ricotta pancakes.  They were the perfect size so you get a wholesome taste, but not overpowering to the point where you can't finish your meal. The flavor was refreshing, and I love the creaminess/fluffiness the ricotta gives the pancake. Though pretty steep at $17.50 a plate, I thoroughly enjoyed the food, and both my boyfriend and I finish our plates clean.  

If you ever have 2-3 hours to spare on a weekend, I'd recommend to stop by~ (if not, try for a weekday as I hear those wait times are much more reasonable).

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes are as good as everyone says they are.
If I remember correctly, they be fluffy and soft and delicious.
(I am lactose intolerant
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Cheri C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Parking: street
Service: pretty good for the amount of people they see (especially because it's so small!)

Experience: Always a wait (even on a Wednesday), so come early, put your name down, grab a coffee from Farley's, and be patient. I'd suggest not to come hungry because then you'll probably become hangry.

I have to say the last time I was here, I was slightly disappointed in the plow potatoes, as they were different than before. Previously, they were more crispy, but I guess they changed how they make them now? Still tasty though. I just really like them crispy carbs you know?

The lemon ricotta pancakes are as good as everyone says they are. If I remember correctly, they be fluffy and soft and delicious. (I am lactose intolerant so I paid for it later, but it was worth it).

And refillable coffee (a bit expensive IMO), but it's strong and bold so if you aren't too sensitive, drink up!

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing.
They are petite in size, but big in flavor.
The potatoes are so perfectly seasoned and crispy.
They are everything that baby spud dreams about becoming.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Kim W.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Is it overhyped? Maybe. Are the lines ridiculous? Yes. Is it cheap? Unfortunately, no. But do they have spot on pancakes and potatoes? You bet! Carbs are life and so I will continue to dream about Plow's brunch fare. 

Came here in a group of 3 on a Monday at around 11:30. They estimated a wait time of 45 minutes, so we did a little bit of window shopping down the block. We came back 20 minutes later just as they were calling our name. Phew. Don't wander too far and miss your name, or it was all for naught.

I got The Plow because why compromise? I wanted a little bit of sweet and a little bit of savory and they absolutely delivered. The lemon ricotta pancakes are amazing. They are petite in size, but big in flavor. The potatoes are so perfectly seasoned and crispy. They are everything that baby spud dreams about becoming. My eggs (over easy) and the chicken apple sausage were cooked well. 

All the food was delicious, but my experience wasn't perfect. The seating is cramped. We sat at a table that was clearly meant for two. It was a tight squeeze. They ran out of three items on the menu, mostly sad about the biscuits though. And the wait for the food was really long. No tables were getting food, so I guess they had some sort of a hangup in the kitchen. Definitely great food, but not worth waiting more than half an hour.

excerpts: The Plow plate has two eggs, meat of choice, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and plow potatoes.
The eggs were perfectly over easy.
The meat was the perfect savory complement to the LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES, which were so fluffy and soft that they melted in your mouth.
You didn't even need to chew.
I'm not the biggest fan of pancakes, but I really would get a plate of just these.
Don't let their size fool you!
They are smaller, but they are really dense.
Their potatoes are garlicky and well seasoned with the perfect crisp around the edges!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Sophie P.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
OKAY GUYS HONESTLY, BEST BRUNCH. HANDS DOWN. 

We didn't have to wait, so I'm not sure if I would wait 2 hours for brunch, but out of all other brunch options out there Plow definitely takes the cake. The actual restaurant, ambiance, and location is nothing special, but the food here is really unique from other brunch spots.

+ THE PLOW ($17): You have to get the works if you come here. The Plow plate has two eggs, meat of choice, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and plow potatoes. The eggs were perfectly over easy. The meat was the perfect savory complement to the LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES, which were so fluffy and soft that they melted in your mouth. You didn't even need to chew. I'm not the biggest fan of pancakes, but I really would get a plate of just these. Don't let their size fool you! They are smaller, but they are really dense. Their potatoes are garlicky and well seasoned with the perfect crisp around the edges! This plate has everything you need for a full breakfast or brunch!

+ CHIA SEED PUDDING ($9.25): I also got this because I wanted to feel good about myself, and this is a solid option if you have a sensitive stomach or are not that hungry! The chia seeds are soaked in almond milk and topped with coconut, blood orange, raw almonds, bee pollen, hemp seeds, and honey. It is the perfect blend of sweet, sour, and savory. 

I normally wouldn't like to sit at the bar for brunch, but we did not regret it. The kitchen is completely open, and you see all of the chefs making each breakfast plate and it truly is a work of art! They are working nonstop, constantly cooking eggs, sausage or bacon, and dollops of pancake batter on the grill. It made our meal so much more enjoyable!

excerpts: The plow:  the plow has two eggs (any style you want), two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes or sausages (don't get the pork sausage).
This was a pretty decent size order.
However, i wasn't completely impressed by this dish because i was disappointed in the pork sausage.
it was a little too chewy for me.
The Lemon Ricotta pancakes were ok
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Belinda C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Talk about the early bird gets the worm.  Well, let's apply that phrase to Plow.  We got here around 10 am and we had to wait an hour for a table.  They print a new menu everyday, so it's great to see how they change things up.  So after waiting for an hour my friend and I studied the menu inside out and already knew what we were going to order when they seated us.   So here's what we ordered

The plow:  the plow has two eggs (any style you want), two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes or sausages (don't get the pork sausage).   This was a pretty decent size order. However, i wasn't completely impressed by this dish because i was disappointed in the pork sausage. it was a little too chewy for me. The Lemon Ricotta pancakes were ok, it did have a lot of lemon flavor, but it wasn't as fluffy as i hoped for.   

Prosciutto and gruyere toast-  this dish came with potatoes.  My friend loved the potatoes, but i felt it was too dry.   We actually found a hair in this dish, but we just took it off and let it go, we waited an hour for food, we didn't want to wait anymore for it to be sent back to the kitchen.  This dish turned out pretty good.  I loved prosciutto, so anything with prosciutto is perfect. 

Overall,the service was great, next time i'll get here early so that we didn't have to wait until noon for food.  I did hear that if you have a group of 6 they can't seat you, so you have to break up your group.

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes are the go to.
Homemade sausage is just okay
, i'd just get stacks of that pancake! -
@joeyngoy
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Joey N.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: The plow platter, so delicious. The lemon ricotta pancakes are the go to. Homemade sausage is just okay, i'd just get stacks of that pancake! - @joeyngoy

excerpts: Also the lemon ricotta pancakes which are a staple and the soft scramble.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Sophie S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Finally made it here for brunch and it was really good! 

Be prepared for a wait, that's a given for brunch even on a week day. We shared a biscuit---unbelievable. One of the best I've ever had. Also the lemon ricotta pancakes which are a staple and the soft scramble. I loved the potatoes that came with the eggs, although I felt mine was lacking goat cheese compared to the one my friend ordered.

Overall Plow was solid, but I'm not sure how soon I'll be dying to wait in line all the way in Potrero again!

excerpts: I always order the Plow, which comes with two eggs, choice of proteins, potatoes, and the lemon ricotta pancakes.
I think this is just the perfect amount of food and on the borderline of feeling bloated for me.
Seriously everything they make though is amazing, especially the pancakes.
I absolutely love lemon-y things
so it's so bomb.
I know the pancake and potato recipe is online so
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Janet H.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Oh, Plow... my favorite brunch spot in SF.

Even though it's my favorite, solid brunch spot, I rarely eat here because of long lines and I value my precious sleep time on weekends. No matter what, it's always at least an hour wait, unless you get here at opening (I assume).

I always order the Plow, which comes with two eggs, choice of proteins, potatoes, and the lemon ricotta pancakes. I think this is just the perfect amount of food and on the borderline of feeling bloated for me. Seriously everything they make though is amazing, especially the pancakes. I absolutely love lemon-y things so it's so bomb. I know the pancake and potato recipe is online so one day I shall make it!

Also, you know when Plow is delicious when people wait in the rain, with no overhang. That's commitment.

excerpts: but The Plow with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, homemade sausage, and two sunny side eggs were exactly the way I wanted to start off my Sunday.
My friend's eggs benedict with spinach and mushrooms was also super delicious.
I will definitely come again!
Especially since that 18th st strip is hustlin and bustlin with up and coming restaurants.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Annie L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Not sure what else I can do to add to the stellar reviews, but damnnnnn Plow potatoes are out of this world. These made the 7x7 list a couple years ago, and while I was determined to finish that list, I never made it to Plow due to the inconvenience of its location. But now, I've discovered 22nd st Caltrain, which is only 15 minutes walking distance away. I came around 12PM and got seated around 1:30PM. 

The wait is ridiculous.... they dont accept parties larger than 6, primarily because of their small space, but also because that party of 6 would wait FOREVER. I suggest coming in small groups of 1 or 2, 3 or 4 are max but you'd probably be waiting awhile. 

Though, the food here was delicious. There is a Philz quite close by, but of course you could make it easy on yourself and just order some coffee from Plow while waiting. It was worth it to me, not sure if I was starving but The Plow with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, homemade sausage, and two sunny side eggs were exactly the way I wanted to start off my Sunday. My friend's eggs benedict with spinach and mushrooms was also super delicious. I will definitely come again! Especially since that 18th st strip is hustlin and bustlin with up and coming restaurants.

excerpts: We ordered: Lemon Ricotta Pancakes, French Toast, Blood Sausage, Mochi cake
I agree with most others; the lemon ricotta pancakes are a must, even coming from me (I generally don't like lemon bars, key lime pie, etc).
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Sheewon B.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
We ordered: Lemon Ricotta Pancakes, French Toast, Blood Sausage, Mochi cake

This is my favorite brunch spot in SF, although I'm kind of biased since it's within walking distance from my house. 

I agree with most others; the lemon ricotta pancakes are a must, even coming from me (I generally don't like lemon bars, key lime pie, etc). The lemon is executed subtlety enough so your lips don't pucker as you eat them, and the pancake is light and savory which makes the food a whole-mouth experience.  

French toast is really good but I think that SF restaurants in general are really good at French toast, so I don't think it's necessarily a standout. 

Blood sausage is an interesting item to serve. I personally can't get over the idea that I'm eating blood, but my more adventurous brother assures me that it's a well made, delicious breakfast item. 

Mochi cake was also interesting but not my cup of tea. 

Go really really early or be prepared to wait. Last time we waited 2.5 hours to get seated, so this morning we arrived at 8:10am, but people were already seated and the line was about 20 people deep. We didn't get seated until around 9:15am.

excerpts:
THE PLOW 5/5
Their signature plate with 2 eggs, meat (choice of pork sausage patties, bacon, or chicken apple sausage), potatoes, and 2 small but amazing lemon ricotta pancakes!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Poy W.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
A delicious place for brunch in SF! It's American with a hint of Chinese influence. You can see it in their menu with specialities like Chinese breakfast and Hong Kong Style brick toast.

I came here on a Wednesday at 10:15 am and the place was already packed for brunch. It's very small - no wonder the wait is over an hour on weekends. Luckily, my group of 4 only waited maybe 15-20 minutes for a table outside. Although it's chilly outside at this time of year, they offer blankets to keep you warm (but no heaters). The waiters are friendly and despite being outside, they came out often to see if we needed anything and to fill our waters. 

THE PLOW 5/5
Their signature plate with 2 eggs, meat (choice of pork sausage patties, bacon, or chicken apple sausage), potatoes, and 2 small but amazing lemon ricotta pancakes! It's a great choice if you're looking for a taste of their famous pancakes but want a heartier breakfast. 

OPEN-FACED PROSCITTO + GRUYERE TOAST 3.5/5
I love anything with proscuitto so this was a must try, but it didn't quite live up to expectations. It's more on the healthy side, with a perfectly runny egg atop lot of frisee, parsley, one slice of proscuitto, and cheese. In my opinion, it could have used more meat to balance out the greens. I would probably pass on this next time. 

HONG KONG STYLE TOAST 1/5
It's $4 for brioche bread covered with condensed milk which just feels like a trap for non-Asian people LOLOL. Just find a dessert place with brick toast next time. 

Overall, the ambiance and food was good. I would come here again!

excerpts: - Lemon ricotta pancakes:
The right amount of lemon/tartness.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Charlene E.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Plow wasn't anything mind blowing, but pretty tasty nonetheless!
