excerpts: Everything on the menu sounded delicious - we decided on the buttermilk biscuit, crab scramble, breakfast sandwich with avocado, lemon ricotta pancakes, a side of bacon and mimosas.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Roshni B.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Totally worth the wait - as long as you order the right things. It's tempting to opt for The Plow and get your classic American breakfast fix, but the rest of the menu is just so good. 

My friend and I arrived at 8:10am on Sunday and waited about an hour for a table inside. They offer blankets if you are ok with sitting outside, but we didn't mind waiting the extra 15 min or so on top of the overall wait time to be warm. Everything on the menu sounded delicious - we decided on the buttermilk biscuit, crab scramble, breakfast sandwich with avocado, lemon ricotta pancakes, a side of bacon and mimosas. 

We couldn't decide which item we liked most because it was all just so good. The biscuit was just perfection and a great item to share as an appetizer. The scramble and sandwich were perfect as entrees and the order of pancakes were a great idea to share so you get both savory and sweet. 

At the end of the meal we both agreed that the wait was worth it. I think you just have to be mentally ready for it and you'll be fine.

excerpts: : The Plow - comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, choice of sausage meats, eggs, and potatoes (I would highly recommend subbing the potatoes for fruit - you get fresh mango, berries, grapefruit super unique for a brunch place), the Chinese breakfast (pork shoulder with some spicy sauce), and others.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Kunal T.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I felt #basic one day so I walked in wanting to try it with few of my coworkers. I would value this brunch place at a max wait of 45 minutes - usually on weekends it could be a 1.5-2 hour wait.

Things I would recommend: The Plow - comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, choice of sausage meats, eggs, and potatoes (I would highly recommend subbing the potatoes for fruit - you get fresh mango, berries, grapefruit super unique for a brunch place), the Chinese breakfast (pork shoulder with some spicy sauce), and others.

In terms of drinks the grapefruit mimosa has a fresh fruit and is pretty strong (if you're trying to have a turnt up day then go for it). 

Service is good. Comparable to Mission beach cafe, Sweet Maple, and all those other brunch giants.

excerpts: The plow had lemon ricotta pancakes which were probably the highlight of that dish.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Rohenne L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Good? Yeah sure. Worth the weekend wait? Unfortunately not.

I was super excited to finally come to plow, I plowed myself out of bed at 7am just to make it to plow by 7:55am right before opening. At that point, there was already a long line! Omg, crazy! (It must be amazing for everyone to be lining up like they line up for new iphone releases). We didn't make it to the first seating, so ended up going to a near by coffee shop to wait for 30min, came back and there was an available table for us. Woohoo.

The staff, though super busy was attentive and very friendly. We ordered a coconut mochi cake, The Plow, breakfast sandwich and French toast. 

My favorite was probably the mochi cake and everything else was pretty good but nothing mind blowing. The French toast and breakfast sandwich were both decent but the way it's made feels like you can do it yourself at home. The plow had lemon ricotta pancakes which were probably the highlight of that dish. 

Coffee was subpar :(, id just get coffee next door. 

Overall, good experience and if there weren't a line, I'd definitely go more often since it is that comfort brunch food that you'd want on a Sunday morning. 

I've heard from others that their weekday lunch menu is better and dishes are more special, maybe that's what I'm missing from this review. I'll have to try it again on a weekday.

excerpts: Lemon ricotta pancakes - the most memorable!
Soft and fluffy (albeit a bit burnt), with a refreshing lemon zest balanced by an attenuated sweetness and a touch of creamy ricotta.
House made sausage - a close second.
The patties were wonderfully juicy without being too greasy, and I especially liked the extra dimension from the boldly heavy use of pepper and caraway.
Potatoes - quite a bit of hype, but I found it to be just okay.
It did have a nice crisp and aromatic tones from the rosemary, though I found the outer crunchy coating too thick, causing the potatoes to be too dry.
Eggs - Scrambled eggs pretty on point.

lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Edna C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Plow sure does plow a hole in my wallet! 

The Plow is famous for their brunch and notorious for the wait, which is usually at least an hour on weekends. TL;DR is it worth the wait? No, it's not worth the horrendous weekend wait; however, it is worth the hassles of going early on a weekday. 

The menu is always changing, with some staples such as the plow, the breakfast sandwich, some type of French toast, and the buttermilk biscuit. It seemed like some of the specialties could be hit-or-miss (I saw someone next to me get something that looked fancy but small.) I'm also usually a fan of French toast, but in a lot of pictures it was surprisingly burnt here. Thus, I went with their signature plow. 

The Plow plate is the epitome of perfection on classic brunch items. In fact, I was almost going to pass on Plow because it seemed so commonplace, yet so professionally crafted. It seemed as if so much thought had been put into every detail, you could perform mindful eating with your otherwise mundane sausage/bacon, eggs, potatoes, and pancakes. My thoughts:

1. Lemon ricotta pancakes - the most memorable! Soft and fluffy (albeit a bit burnt), with a refreshing lemon zest balanced by an attenuated sweetness and a touch of creamy ricotta.
2. House made sausage - a close second. The patties were wonderfully juicy without being too greasy, and I especially liked the extra dimension from the boldly heavy use of pepper and caraway. 
3. Potatoes - quite a bit of hype, but I found it to be just okay. It did have a nice crisp and aromatic tones from the rosemary, though I found the outer crunchy coating too thick, causing the potatoes to be too dry.
4. Eggs - Scrambled eggs pretty on point. The texture, consistency, and taste were all well executed. It used less butter than some of the more indulgent scrambles I've had, making it a lighter version.

I had expected portions to be bigger for the $17 pricetag on the bouge equivalent of a McDonald's big breakfast. If you eat it slowly, you'll enjoy it more and it the portion size turns turns out to lie within the narrow window of satisfaction without a debilitating food coma. Plow was memorable, delicious, and Instagram-worthy, but for a total of over $20 for a breakfasty plate, I don't think it's worthwhile to return after the one-time dining experience to cross it off my bucket list.

I arrived just after 7am on a weekday, and by the time I left around 8am the place was nearly full o_O Sometimes I feel like SF brunch is a encephalopathic pandemic.

The combination with farmer's cheese, pickled red onion, caper, dill, Acme levain, and simple green salad served only to complement the dish even better. As for the Plow, I loved the potatoes because of the seasoning that the chefs use on it, which is most stellar & left my mouth most happy. The lemon ricotta pancakes were just as soft, moist, and their tartiness was just perfect & not too overpowering. Eggs & sausage were also done well. Overall, a most pleasant place to come for brunch & I would definitely recommend it to others. Don't be surprised if there is a wait (there usually is).

lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
All the food was tasty. If you put your name down, go get a coffee, bring a snack and catch up with friends during the wait, then, the wait doesn't seem horrendous. If I was coming truly just for food because I was hungry, though, it is pretty absurd. I think the best strategy to minimize wait time on a weekend is to go right before 2pm. There will still be a wait, but most people are going to think they are closing. They do a final wait list call at 2pm (so you have to be present), but if you are there, you will be seated. 

Food came out fast once you are seated and order. I had the plow. Love the lemon ricotta pancakes, and potatoes were deliciously prepared. House made sausage was eh...I would get the bacon instead.

excerpts: I often choose the Plow, which is eggs, those devilishly good crispy potatoes, choice of meat (try the new-ish bacon confit, which is basically   a roasted piece of pork belly -- so yummy!), and a couple of those luscious mini lemon ricotta pancakes.
It really is way too much food for one meal, so you might try my trick of eating no more than half of each item and taking the rest with me.

I also love the french toast, which I had on today's visit, along with a side of that irresistible bacon confit (I just have to remember to rescue the remainder from the office fridge later today...).
The dungeness scramble is also very good, with eggs that are cooked just a tolerable bit past runny.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Teresa D.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Every couple of weeks or so I sneak in here at 7 a.m. for a solo pre-work breakfast feast at the counter, and have never been disappointed with the food. I often choose the Plow, which is eggs, those devilishly good crispy potatoes, choice of meat (try the new-ish bacon confit, which is basically   a roasted piece of pork belly -- so yummy!), and a couple of those luscious mini lemon ricotta pancakes. It really is way too much food for one meal, so you might try my trick of eating no more than half of each item and taking the rest with me. I also love the french toast, which I had on today's visit, along with a side of that irresistible bacon confit (I just have to remember to rescue the remainder from the office fridge later today...). The dungeness scramble is also very good, with eggs that are cooked just a tolerable bit past runny. I'm freaked out by gross undercooked eggs, so this works for me.

The only down side for me is the coffee, which is a very bitter roast. I know that a lot of people seem to favor that over-roasted, super-bitter thing, but I'm not one of them. Give me a bitter cocktail any day (please!), but you can keep the bitter coffee. Really, I don't expect such a small kitchen to keep more than one type of roast on hand, so I do understand they have to pick something that a lot of people like. 

I've found the service to be attentive and oblivious at the same time. I'm pretty sure I was the very first person to put in my order this morning, but I saw a lot of food come out of the kitchen headed to tables that hadn't even settled on the menu before my order went in. When my food finally arrived about 16 minutes later, it didn't include the bacon confit side -- that was another 8 to 10 minutes in coming. None of this is a big deal if the server addresses the delay with a cheerful explanation, showing the customer that they haven't been forgotten. My server didn't say anything about any of it. Pretty disappointing. 

But make no mistake: this is a very good place. I don't think I'd try it on a weekend since I hear the wait is way over the top.

lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Jessica N.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
3 words: Lemon Ricotta Pancakes!!

I came here one morning with a friend alll the way from Castro Valley just to try Plow. It's been on my Yelp bookmarks for soo long! The wait was about 30 minutes once I put my name down. The indoor seating is a little limited and crowded; my friend and I were seated outside. Good thing it was a nice day out in SF. Not too cold and or too windy. 

I knew I wanted to order their Lemon Ricotta Pancakes for sure and although everyone recommended The Plow which comes with eggs, sausage, potatoes, and pancakes, I knew that would be too much food for me so I just planned on getting them as a side order. However, my friend said I could just take one of her pancakes so I did that instead and ordered the Coconut Chia Seed Pudding which came with seasonal fruit, bee pollen, and honey. The chia pudding was delicious and light and the pancake was probably the best lemon ricotta pancake I've ever tasted. It was super fluffy and you could actually taste the lemon! 

I would definitely recommend Plow to a friend or anyone looking for a nice brunch place in SF. And I would definitely recommend those pancakes! I'd probably come back just for the pancakes next time!

excerpts: Comes with everything, two eggs, choice of protein, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Sandy B.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Finally got my seat at plow this passed Saturday. Been waiting to come here for awhile. The week before I got to plow at 11:30am and it was a 2.5 hour wait for a party of 3. We couldn't wait because we were hungry. Came back this Saturday at 10:30am and it was 1.5 - 2 hour wait for a party of 2. WOW!!! I know, the wait is crazy long. Instead of just waiting outside, my friend and I decided to get coffee 2 blocks away to kill time. Also you can order coffee, drinks and baked goods from Plow as you wait for your table. 

It was slightly over 1.5 hour wait and got a seat at the counter. We ordered **Equator coffee $3.75. Unlimited refills. We started with their **Hong Kong style toast  buttered brioche + sweetened condensed milk. I was super excited because its been forever since I had condensed milk. The brioche we had was super dry. Was a bit disappointed with that. We had one piece and let the milk soak in to soften up the brioche. My friend had their famous **"The Plow". Comes with everything, two eggs, choice of protein, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes. She got the house made pork sausage patties. I thought it was super yummy. I got to try everything she had. I really like their triple fried plow potatoes. Must have!! I got their special **Cornbeef hash on poached eggs. I really like it. Wasn't too heavy. This dish is smaller in portion size but I thought it was perfect for me. 

Not my favorite in the city but it has became my TOP 5 BRUNCH in SF. Service was good, staff was friendly, especially the chefs.

Finally got to eat here! 
We avoided the ridic long wait by coming on a weekday around 12:30. We were told the wait was 20 minutes and were seated at a communal table in about 15 min.

Food was AMAZING! I don't know if I would wait any longer than 45 min for a meal in SF but this place blows many hyped brunch places out of the water in terms of quality and deliciousness (*cough cough* Zazie). 

I ordered the Plow since I don't know when I'll be here again and it's got a little bit of everything. I was disappointed that they didn't have any of their biscuits (though at $4 each, that was probably a good thing). The best thing on the plate BY FAR were the potatoes. Breakfast potatoes can go so wrong and these were perfectly crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Pale, limp potatoes are such a travesty and Plow has mastered the art of frying/baking this humble vegetable. 

Second best thing were those lemon ricotta pancakes---sooooo good! Flavorful and lite. You don't really need the maple syrup at all on them!

Scrambled eggs and bacon were above average and quality was there. Entire plate was $17 which I thought was fair given the quality of ingredients and the portion size.

Would love to say "I'll be back" but the wait times are just silly so I probably won't be back again unless it's another random time on a weekday.

lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Pooja M.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I came for brunch and stayed for Kanye.

If you want to feel pumped up and ready to party while you enjoy your delicious brunch, Plow is definitely the place to be in the city. 

The restaurant is small, but the vibe is 'popping' as the staff is all super friendly and fun and the music blasting through the restaurant will get you grooving in your seat (or up and about the restaurant if you're brave enough). 

I was in the mood for a bit of everything that day, so I decided to order the restaurant's namesake, The Plow, which is an all in one dish that consists of two eggs served in any style, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and a choice of pork, bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I asked for my eggs poached and I substituted a salad for the meat options.

The eggs were perfectly poached, but had no seasoning to them otherwise, and the salad was fresh and crispy, but again, bland. The standouts of the dish were the crispy potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes. The potatoes were so expertly seasoned and full of flavor -- they could quite easily be some of the best potatoes I've ever had. And those lemon ricotta pancakes were out of this world! The lemon is very present in the pancakes and is balanced nicely by the ricotta, and the syrup with the pancakes added a nice sweetness that wasn't overbearing. The pancakes were light and fluffy and don't sit heavy in your stomach. I'll definitely be coming back for those pancakes!

Something to keep in mind: Plow is one of the most popular brunch restaurants in SF, so expect a long wait time (at least 1.5 hours) on the weekend. However, if you're a brunch queen like me who's trying to catch 'em all, you are an expert on surviving the brunch hunger pains and boredom of long wait times, and having to wait no longer affects you. 

If you are not on a brunch quest like I am and you are willing to endure the long wait, bring a friend to keep you company, eat something light beforehand, and try to come as close to opening hours as you can, and you'll be brunching down in no time.

There is a lovely cafe across the street called Farley's that has plenty of indoor and outdoor seating and serves tea and light pastries where you can keep yourself from starving as you wait to be called. In general, the neighborhood where The Plow is located is really lovely and has a stunning view of the city skyline, so even if the wait is long, the environment is inviting. 

I'm putting The Plow on my list of brunch places to return to, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an exciting brunch spot!

lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Tiffany P.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
My favorite underrated brunch place in SF! I feel like there isn't enough hype around Plow, but there is still always a wait. The wait on weekends can be about an hour; I came on my own on a weekday this time and had to wait ~20 minutes.

I had the dungeness crab scramble a while ago and remember loving it. I was really looking forward to getting more of it this recent time but it wasn't on the menu anymore, so I tried a couple new things instead.

1) Buttermilk biscuit with honey butter (5/5) - AMAZING. The biscuit is large, golden brown on the edges, and fluffy inside. The honey butter is essentially butter mixed lightly with honey, but the balance of the creamy saltiness of butter with the sweet was so good.

2) The plow - Combination plate that allowed me to try a lot of different components. Crispy potatoes (5/5) - YES, so crispy on the outside, really well seasoned, but still buttery on the inside. Two overeasy eggs (4/5) - no complaints on the eggs themselves, wish they could have salted it a bit more though. House-made pork sausage (5/5) - really flavorful, it tasted like they mixed in little pieces of onions and herbs into it. Lemon ricotta pancakes (4/5) - actually not quite what I expected, for all that I hear about these pancakes, I was a little disappointed. The pancakes tasted really good, with just a hint of lemon that wasn't overpowering. However, because of the ricotta, the texture of the pancakes is a lot more dense, and I prefer my pancakes fluffier and airy.

A bit out of the way over in Potrero, but the trek is worth it!

excerpts: I got signature "plow" breakfast plate with their house-made sausage patties, two eggs, the ridiculous rosemary and seat salt potatoes, and of course their famous lemon ricotta pancakes.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Caddy M.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Let's get this out of the way: There will be a wait....now if you don't want to wait, get your ass out of bed earlier, dude! It's not that hard, especially for a place as fantastic as this.

The food really is something special here. When I went for the first time, I was alone so I sat the counter, which gave me an opportunity to watch their skillful cooks work their magic. It is a really intimate space, and everyone on staff is really adept at working together to make the operation run smoothly, especially considering the volume of patrons they serve each day.

I got signature "plow" breakfast plate with their house-made sausage patties, two eggs, the ridiculous rosemary and seat salt potatoes, and of course their famous lemon ricotta pancakes. Everything was superb, and as I sat there enjoying my meal, I saw several other dishes being prepared that also looked to die for, so I will be back.  

and if you're feeling the need to walk off the food coma that will most certainly fall into once you are done, they are located at the base of a nice long hill that provides a great view from the top.

excerpts: The Plow breakfast was the perfect size, potatoes are perfect and the lemon ricotta pancakes are so delicious.
Will definitely return next time I visit San Francisco!

lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Took my mom here for a birthday breakfast on Thursday March 23rd. 
The place is a little small so there was a bit of a wait for a table inside for 5 of us; there was no wait for the tables outside. One of the employees (Juan) went the extra mile and offered us coffee while we waited.
Our server was friendly as well as the rest of the staff. 
The Plow breakfast was the perfect size, potatoes are perfect and the lemon ricotta pancakes are so delicious. 
Will definitely return next time I visit San Francisco!

excerpts: We ended up sharing the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and the Scrambled Eggs.
Both tasted very light and healthy.
Would recommend.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Stefanie C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I enjoyed yet another brunch adventure with Nina Y. even though she had been here before. We waited for about 45 minutes in the freezing cold weather. For some reason I never seem to check the weather before I head to brunch in my maxi dress... #BRUNCH.

We were seated at the countertop facing the chefs. It's always fun to see them prepare each meal. I like that the menu is short and simple. For such a small place, patrons needs to make quick decisions! We ended up sharing the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and the Scrambled Eggs. Both tasted very light and healthy. Would recommend. The service was also wonderful.

Overall I felt like we spent longer waiting in line than actually eating and sipping our coffee, but it's definitely worth coming here to get a taste of those pancakes!

excerpts: We shared two Plows (with delectable twice fried potatoes & lemon ricotta pancakes that are quite different, in a good way, than the ones at MyMy in Nob Hill) and a Gruyere Prosciutto plate (with an Instagram/porn-worthy garlic chili egg running overtop of the open-faced toast - WOW) and were treated warmly and with care from the moment we walked in the front door.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Andy L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
About as warm and friendly of a neighborhood restaurant as you could ask for. We were lucky enough to be the last 3 seated (at the kitchen counter, highly recommended) for a Saturday breakfast once it opened up at 8. We shared two Plows (with delectable twice fried potatoes & lemon ricotta pancakes that are quite different, in a good way, than the ones at MyMy in Nob Hill) and a Gruyere Prosciutto plate (with an Instagram/porn-worthy garlic chili egg running overtop of the open-faced toast - WOW) and were treated warmly and with care from the moment we walked in the front door.

We ordered a cinnamon bun, which came out hot and fresh towards the end of the meal, and was simply orgasmic. The orange zest that's baked in is an incredibly palatable yet subtle addition to the already-near-perfect bun. 

Maxine, the owner, is one of the nicest people I've met in the industry of late, and I really appreciated her talking to us for quite some time during our meal and sharing stories with us. The chefs were hard working and communicated well to knock out ticket after ticket during the morning rush - they were fun to watch! Our service was outstanding throughout the meal. Can't wait to dine again in the friendly confines of Plow. It's worth the trip to Potrero in and of itself!

that have wow'd me and made me want to keep eating even when I was extremely full, but this was just...meh.
It wasn't terrible, but it also didn't make me want to wait on a busy day to come here either because I honestly don't think it'll be worth it.
For the price we payed, the amount of time we waited, and the overall experience, it didn't make me feel this place is as spectacular as the reviews had made it out to be.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Victoria K.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Maybe I had my hopes up too high? 

With the glowing reviews on Yelp of Plow, it has been my mission to come here and try this place out. One day, we decided to head here and make that happen. The wait was long - and was to be expected - like similar brunch places in SF, and especially for a place such as Plow. The place itself is very small. When we (finally) got seated, we were lucky enough to get the window seat of the restaurant, but even our waitress had a difficult time coming to our table to give us our menus/take our orders since there was another table REALLY close to us. I decided to get the Plow so I could get a little taste of everything, including the lemon ricotta pancakes I've been dying to try. The food came out at a reasonable time despite how busy the entire place was, and overall it was just...okay. The food tasted average, and the lemon ricotta pancakes I had were just, okay. I've had lemon ricotta pancakes at other restaurants that have wow'd me and made me want to keep eating even when I was extremely full, but this was just...meh. It wasn't terrible, but it also didn't make me want to wait on a busy day to come here either because I honestly don't think it'll be worth it. For the price we payed, the amount of time we waited, and the overall experience, it didn't make me feel this place is as spectacular as the reviews had made it out to be. I'd give this place 3.5 stars. 

Overall, this probably wouldn't be my first choice to get brunch in San Francisco.

excerpts: If you can't decide between Sweet and savory, order a single side of lemon ricotta pancakes...
I left feeling like I should receive some kind of 'amazing orderer' award!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Brandi C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: Best breakfast ever!! If you can't decide between Sweet and savory, order a single side of lemon ricotta pancakes... I left feeling like I should receive some kind of 'amazing orderer' award!

excerpts: The Plow (two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and side of either bacon or sausages) was delicious.
How did the potatoes stay so crispy the whole time, I will never know.
They were well seasoned too.
I expected the pancakes to be the highlight piece on my plate, as I've had them before.
Sadly, these pancakes weren't as good as I remembered when I came here last.
Yes, the sweet lemon and honey taste was there, but the flavors just wasn't as packed this time around.
The grapefruit mimosa was alright.
Nothing too special and isn't worth $10.5 a glass.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Kevin S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
The plow at the plow.

No matter how early you go, the wait is at least an hour. I came with a couple friends at 9:30am on a Saturday, and we weren't seated until 10:30am. Half the times I've waited before for brunch doesn't take that much time, but the brunch game in SF is always on point. Service here was efficient and welcoming, and street parking is everywhere.

TIP: Drop your friends off to get a spot on the waitlist while you find parking.

All 3 of us ordered the Plow, and I also ordered a grapefruit mimosa along with my meal.

The Plow (two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and side of either bacon or sausages) was delicious. How did the potatoes stay so crispy the whole time, I will never know. They were well seasoned too. I expected the pancakes to be the highlight piece on my plate, as I've had them before. Sadly, these pancakes weren't as good as I remembered when I came here last. Yes, the sweet lemon and honey taste was there, but the flavors just wasn't as packed this time around. The grapefruit mimosa was alright. Nothing too special and isn't worth $10.5 a glass. I'd rather go to Radish for their unlimited grapefruit mimosas ($15/person).

I'd come back just for the pancakes.

excerpts: Based on my buddy's recommendation, I ordered their self-titled brunch speciality: two eggs any style (I went poached), house made pork sausage patties, bacon or chicken apple sausage (I went with the sausage), potatoes and two lemon ricotta pancakes.
I'm usually one to avoid lemon flavored foods, but I have to say these two flapjacks were some of the lightest, fluffiest, tastiest I've had in as long as I can remember.
The eggs were perfectly cooked, the sausage savory and hot.
The other real highlight was the potatoes, which are twice fried.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Alex L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Holy breakfast of the Gods. This place lives up to the hype. You can't find too many traditional breakfasts/brunches anymore. Pop in here and order the aptly named "Plow" breakfast and watch your world change. 

I was a little doubtful of the rave reviews. After all, this is San Francisco and many a popular spot seems to have unusually good reviews based just on how trendy it is at the time. Fortunately, I came on a Wednesday when the wait was minimal and we sat almost immediately at the bar where we could watch the chefs work. Based on my buddy's recommendation, I ordered their self-titled brunch speciality: two eggs any style (I went poached), house made pork sausage patties, bacon or chicken apple sausage (I went with the sausage), potatoes and two lemon ricotta pancakes. I'm usually one to avoid lemon flavored foods, but I have to say these two flapjacks were some of the lightest, fluffiest, tastiest I've had in as long as I can remember. The eggs were perfectly cooked, the sausage savory and hot. The other real highlight was the potatoes, which are twice fried. Throw on a little hot sauce and you're in brunch heaven. 

Some waits are worth it, others are not. I'm here to say this is a brunch worth the wait, and worth coming back for.

excerpts: I got the plow, and the lemon ricotta pancakes + crispy potatoes just blew me away.
I'm generally not a pancake lover, but those were so fluffy and smooth, it was almost like eating a cake.
The potatoes were season so perfectly and had just the right crispiness, so that was honestly beautiful.
I didn't care for the eggs or bacon tho, so
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Diane Z.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
This was actually the first time that I've waited 2.5 hours for a meal... And it was raining too. Gosh that was really an experience I would rather not repeat. (Tip: go grab coffee at Philz while you're waiting!!!) 

The food was amazing! I got the plow, and the lemon ricotta pancakes + crispy potatoes just blew me away. I'm generally not a pancake lover, but those were so fluffy and smooth, it was almost like eating a cake. The potatoes were season so perfectly and had just the right crispiness, so that was honestly beautiful. I didn't care for the eggs or bacon tho, so I ended up just kinda pushing them away. 

Overall it was a great dining experience as the service was also pretty great. However I don't think I'll ever come back just because the wait is way too long and the food is kind of overpriced.

excerpts: The Arugula Salad with Burrata was delicious, but the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes were coarse.
Kitchen Story's are much better.
I've heard the potatoes are the shining star here at Plow, but I don't like potatoes.
Probably wouldn't come back.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Letitia L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: The Arugula Salad with Burrata was delicious, but the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes were coarse.  Kitchen Story's are much better. I've heard the potatoes are the shining star here at Plow, but I don't like potatoes.  Probably wouldn't come back.

excerpts: And I have repeated dreams about their lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes.
I've been here 3 times and it has not disappoint.
I love taking new people here to mold them into fans.
The wait is a bit long, but hey, you can always explore the area.
We walked to the Dogpatch area which is about a 10 minute walk.
We also went next door to Provender Coffee (:
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Jenna L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: The Plow Breakfast is a must! It can be shared amongst 2 people or 1 FA.  :) I've done both. The homemade sausage is pretty bomb, the apple chicken sausage is also great.. and can't go wrong with bacon.. (so those are what you get to choose besides how you like yo eggs). And I have repeated dreams about their lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes. I've been here 3 times and it has not disappoint. I love taking new people here to mold them into fans. (: The wait is a bit long, but hey, you can always explore the area. We walked to the Dogpatch area which is about a 10 minute walk. We also went next door to Provender Coffee (:

excerpts: lemon ricotta pancakes with.
House made sausage .
If you come on a weekend expect a line up
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Vivian C.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: I almost don't want to post this. Plow is the best brunch in the world. Order the farmers plow- lemon ricotta pancakes with. House made sausage . If you come on a weekend expect a line up

excerpts: The Plow the restaurant's go-to: two eggs, choice of meat, in this case chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and plow potatoes.
Nice snappy sausage with full flavor, the potatoes again were crispy and soft at the same time, but the pancakes def stole the show.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Jurem F.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
If there is any restaurant that can serve as the example for all other restaurants to follow, it's Plow. Yes this place is a fabulous place to get breakfast/brunch, but what amazed me is the service. My wife and I didnt have many needs this afternoon, but our server Andrea got to us quickly and super efficiently, never skipping a beat with greeting us, taking our orders, running our food, and dropping the check. Thanks so much!

But the true unsung hero is the guy without a name on a receipt. You can tell this guy has been here for a long time because of how efficient he is, with clearing plates, setting up tables, seating guests from the waitlist, polishing silverware, and even with the breakdown of the outside patio seating. This dude completely blew me away with how every move he made was calculated and done very swiftly. I wish he worked for me!



ON TO THE FOOD. Mimosas, both grapefruit and OG, were served in wine glasses, which was greatly appreciated lol. I got the breakfast sandwich with bacon and my wife got the Plow with chicken apple sausage. 

The breakfast sandwich is your traditional egg sandwich with frisee, cheddar, and aioli. Done perfect and just what I was looking for. The yolks were runny, which is just bliss, the potatoes were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, and the acme bun was soft and tasteful. 

The Plow the restaurant's go-to: two eggs, choice of meat, in this case chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and plow potatoes. Nice snappy sausage with full flavor, the potatoes again were crispy and soft at the same time, but the pancakes def stole the show. You NEED THESE in your life!

BOOKMARKED. WILL RETURN FOR MOAR.

excerpts: As soon as the server came over, I completely scrambled (pun intended) and went with the soft scrambled eggs BUT added an order of the lemon ricotta pancakes on the side.
Could I BE any more excited?
The answer is no.
Plus I also ordered an iced chai.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Ilana B.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Hmmm what to say about Plow....

Heard amazing things about this place and have been dying to try it! My friend and I finally ventured out to Petrero Hill (10 min car ride from my apt...) to try Plow and boy did it live up to the hype. We had been looking over the menu in the uber ride there and already knew what we wanted...The Plow. Of course. It had everything you could ever want...eggs, meat, pancakes, AND potatoes. YUM. I was ready to take on The Plow. 

We knew the line was going to be long and we'd probably be waiting for over an hour but it would be worth it. The second we walked in, we told the hostess we had two people and she said we can either put you on the list for inside or seat you outside right away. My friend and I both looked at each other and said outside at the same time. We could not believe it! Note: It was a little chilly outside but who cares...we were getting seated RIGHT AWAY! Anyone who lives in SF and eats brunch on a weekend knows how rare this is. So outside it was! They even provided each customer with their own blanket!! Incredible. Is there anything they don't think of?!

As soon as we sat down, I started looking over the menu. The Plow still looked amazing but on the other hand, the soft scrambled eggs looked heavenly as well. I mean...shitake mushrooms and goat cheese in my soft scrambled eggs? I think yes. Plus I've been told they are known for both these dishes. It was going to be a game time decision. As soon as the server came over, I completely scrambled (pun intended) and went with the soft scrambled eggs BUT added an order of the lemon ricotta pancakes on the side. Could I BE any more excited? The answer is no. Plus I also ordered an iced chai. It was so tasty. 

I could not have been happier with my decision to get the soft scrambled eggs. it was everything I could have hoped for and more. Much more. 

Plow, you have my heart.

excerpts: Those lemon ricotta pancakes.
Dang.
I could eat 50 of those.
Everything on the plate was just so well made with great ingredients, and it was easy to see why the waits are constantly long.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Stefanie S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I've only been here once but it made quite an impression. I went way back when the Giants won the World Series in 2014, thinking that it wouldn't be crowded and I could avoid the long waits. Wrong lol seems like a lot of people had the same idea. 

It was roughly a 30 min wait for two people. It's a pretty small space so it'll be cozy but don't worry, the food will make it all okay. My boyfriend and I both ordered the plow plates. Those lemon ricotta pancakes. Dang. I could eat 50 of those. Everything on the plate was just so well made with great ingredients, and it was easy to see why the waits are constantly long. I will not wait till the Giants win (even year tho heyyy) to come back!

Free street parking, but it's pretty hilly because duh San Francisco. Bring a jacket for the wait outside haha

excerpts: My friend got the lemon ricotta pancakes, which were soft and not too sweet.
They refilled my coffee generously.
The waitress was nice and there was definitely a rushed vibe.
We wanted to order takeout to bring to a friend that was not with us
and they don't do that apparently.
Generally the food is very good and the atmosphere is great for catching up and talking.
At the same time the waiting and the feeling rushed is the reason it doesn't get 5 stars.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Anne S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: Met a friend here for lunch on a friday noon time. Got there around 11am. We had to wait an hour before being seated. There is no where to wait. A few benches or stools would make the experience better. We then got seated around noon. The decor has a lot of natural light and high ceilings which makes it feel bigger than it is. The decor is like your grandmothers kitchen and dining room with a bar that faces into the kitchen. The vibe is nice so you can see the staff preparing your food...which looks fantastic and makes you want everything.  I got an omelette. It was good, the potatoes that accompanied it were delicious and fed made me fall off the no carb band wagon. My friend got the lemon ricotta pancakes, which were soft and not too sweet. They refilled my coffee generously. The waitress was nice and there was definitely a rushed vibe. We wanted to order takeout to bring to a friend that was not with us and they don't do that apparently. Generally the food is very good and the atmosphere is great for catching up and talking. At the same time the waiting and the feeling rushed is the reason it doesn't get 5 stars.

excerpts: My friend and I also split the lemon ricotta pancakes.
These were incredible!
The lightness/ fluffiness from the ricotta.. paired with the blueberry compote.
Absolutely delicious.
If you have a few house to wait, I would say this spot is worth it.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Mariel P.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: Plow was one of the best breakfasts I've had in San Francisco. The only reason for a 4 star was that the wait gets extremely long from the moment it opens. Service was impeccable, but we got there at 9:15 and had a 45 minute wait. By 10:00 they were telling people it went up to 2 hours. I highly recommend the eggs Benedict with salmon. Definitely one of the best I've had (and I try that at every breakfast spot I go to). My friend and I also split the lemon ricotta pancakes. These were incredible! The lightness/ fluffiness from the ricotta.. paired with the blueberry compote. Absolutely delicious. If you have a few house to wait, I would say this spot is worth it.

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes and the French toast were outta this world!!!
I got the one with coffee to go with my French toast, a little too strong for me but still delicious.
Service was great the waitress was super nice always kept an eye on us to see if we needed help with anything.
Definitely coming and recommending people.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Enjoy S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: Came here to have breakfast with my brother and nephew and I must say wow this place blew my mind!!! The lemon ricotta pancakes and the French toast were outta this world!!! I got the one with coffee to go with my French toast, a little too strong for me but still delicious. Service was great the waitress was super nice always kept an eye on us to see if we needed help with anything. Definitely coming and recommending people.

excerpts: Comes with 2 eggs, choice of sausage (we took Apple chicken), potatoes and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes.
The pancakes were my favorite.
Everything else was good and perfectly cooked.
2) Mochi: was excellent.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Anjali A.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Checked in on May 31st, 2016.

First time to San Francisco, searched on Yelp for breakfast place and found Plow.  Very impressed!
Rating:
1) Food - 5/5
2) Service - 5/5
3) Ambiance - 4/5

We ordered:
1) The Plow: was very good.  It was a big order, can easily be shared between 2 people with big appetite, or 3 people with small appetite.  Comes with 2 eggs, choice of sausage (we took Apple chicken), potatoes and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes.  The pancakes were my favorite.  Everything else was good and perfectly cooked.
2) Mochi: was excellent.  
3) Cold brewed Iced coffee: did not care much for it.

Service was efficient and timely.  I have taken off one star due to the cramped setup.  I would like to see them move to a larger location with more space between 2 tables.

excerpts: I ordered the French toast with strawberries, mascarpone, and pure maple syrup while the mister ordered the Plow breakfast with two eggs, house made pork sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.
No complaints!
All the components on the Plow were nicely cooked and the two fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes truly had a pleasant lemon essence.
All the components on the Plow were nicely cooked and the two fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes truly had a pleasant lemon essence.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Merica S.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Good food, but not feeling the approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes wait on the weekends. 

I'm not going to lie---the food just wasn't worth the unbearably long wait. Didn't blow my mind. 

I ordered the French toast with strawberries, mascarpone, and pure maple syrup while the mister ordered the Plow breakfast with two eggs, house made pork sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.  No complaints! All the components on the Plow were nicely cooked and the two fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes truly had a pleasant lemon essence. I thought my French toast appeared relatively burnt, though it didn't taste like it. 

+ Can only accommodate parties of 6 or fewer due to the small size of the venue 
+ No reservations
+ Indoor and outdoor seating

excerpts: Hubby and I split a biscuit (comes with honey butter) - that was sooo good, great texture - and "the plow" which is your choice of eggs, your choice of meat, breakfast potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes.
The plow was soooo delicious but also sooo much food
so I'd def recommend splitting it.

The eggs were phenomenal, the chicken apple sausage and bacon (Hubby requested an extra meat side) were good but greasy, the breakfast potatoes were amazing (especially those small crunchy bits, but the star of the show was the pancakes!
Such great flavor, not too heavy, great texture because of the ricotta.
I just wish I had gotten to eat more of the pancakes
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Xenia P.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: What a great spot for breakfast! We went on a weekday and it was full, so I can only imagine how packed it gets on the weekend. Hubby and I split a biscuit (comes with honey butter) - that was sooo good, great texture - and "the plow" which is your choice of eggs, your choice of meat, breakfast potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes. The plow was soooo delicious but also sooo much food so I'd def recommend splitting it. The eggs were phenomenal, the chicken apple sausage and bacon (Hubby requested an extra meat side) were good but greasy, the breakfast potatoes were amazing (especially those small crunchy bits, but the star of the show was the pancakes! Such great flavor, not too heavy, great texture because of the ricotta. I just wish I had gotten to eat more of the pancakes

excerpts: Me and my friend both got 'The Plow' which came with 2 eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, homefries and your choice of pork sausage patties (like the kind you get with your sausage mcmuffin), chicken apple sausages (links) or bacon.
Me and my friend decided to get the sausage patties and the chicken apple sausages to share.
Between those two, I would recommend the chicken apple sausages more, but they were both moist and juicy.
The pancakes were fluffy and with the right amount of lemon in it (yums.)
The homefries potatoes were extra crispy (they actually fry them @___@) and seasoned just the right amount.
I was lucky enough to be seated at the bar, meaning I had the pleasure to see the cook season the potatoes
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Jenny N.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I must be on a quest to try every brunch place in the city because that's all I been reviewing lately, and this place happens to win a spot in my list of best brunches in the city. 

I came here on a weekend and for a party of 2, the wait was about 1.5 hours... which is about average in this city. The place seems like a fairly small place and the ambience is pretty fresh and bright because the place was filled with natural sunlight. I took the bus here but parking doesn't seem to be like a big issue in this neighborhood. 

Me and my friend both got 'The Plow' which came with 2 eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, homefries and your choice of pork sausage patties (like the kind you get with your sausage mcmuffin), chicken apple sausages (links) or bacon. Me and my friend decided to get the sausage patties and the chicken apple sausages to share. Between those two, I would recommend the chicken apple sausages more, but they were both moist and juicy. The pancakes were fluffy and with the right amount of lemon in it (yums.) The homefries potatoes were extra crispy (they actually fry them @___@) and seasoned just the right amount. I was lucky enough to be seated at the bar, meaning I had the pleasure to see the cook season the potatoes and she actually tries every batch to make sure they're seasoned enough. 

Overall, I would definitely recommend this place for all brunch lovers.

excerpts: Plow is known for its lemon ricotta pancakes.
Another signature dish is the "plow" which is like a "best-of" dish that includes two lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, homemade sausage, and amazing smashed potatoes.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Hieu H.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Waited over two hours for brunch at Plow.  Best way to kill the time is to wonder around the neighborhood and grab a coffee at one of the nearby cafes.

Plow is known for its lemon ricotta pancakes. I'd say they're good, but not mindblowing.

My favorite dish was the dungeness crab scramble - not skimpy on the crab meat and you end up getting some in every bite. 

Another signature dish is the "plow" which is like a "best-of" dish that includes two lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, homemade sausage, and amazing smashed potatoes.

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes are by far my favorite
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Laura T.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: This place is one of my favorites in the city. If you can swing it, I'd recommend going early during the weekdays, then you really won't get much of a wait. On the other hand, I've come at 10:30 on a Sunday and been told that we won't be seated until 1pm, soooo take that as you will. While the wait is long, I think it can be so worth it though!  The lemon ricotta pancakes are by far my favorite and I think the Plow breakfast is just overall delicious and awesome. This is one of my favorites as a SF local!

excerpts: My friend and I split The Plow, which consists of lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, a meat, and eggs.
We went with the house made sausage and over medium eggs.
I loved the potatoes, which were soft on the inside and super crispy on the outside.
The portions were just big enough that we felt satisfied, not bloated like we usually do after brunch.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Anna H.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
We dropped by last minute on a Friday afternoon and were pleasantly surprised by the relatively quick 20 minute wait. My friend and I split The Plow, which consists of lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, a meat, and eggs. We went with the house made sausage and over medium eggs. I loved the potatoes, which were soft on the inside and super crispy on the outside. The portions were just big enough that we felt satisfied, not bloated like we usually do after brunch. The meal was quite expensive - $17 + tax and tip for a very simple meal, excluding the potatoes (which as I mentioned before, were extraordinary).

Service was attentive and the atmosphere is great. I'm not sure if I would make a trip back just for the potatoes because Plow is definitely on the pricey end but it's worth trying if you're in the area!

excerpts: It came with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, bacon, sausage.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Jaime F.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Hipster spot. I don't usually go out for brunch, but this place is certainly an experience. 

Got in, the waitress told our party of two the wait was about 30 minutes. They did seem very busy. We went walking around and looked around. We come back after 10 minutes, the waitress seemed to be looking for us. She said the table was almost ready. Sure enough, we were seated after a short wait. 

I ordered the plow breakfast and coffee. It came with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, bacon, sausage. The waiter was very friendly and very attentive to coffee and water refills and kept checking on us.

It's very easy to find parking here. Definitely recommend this spot if you are on Potrero Hill!

excerpts: lemon ricotta pancakes bear repeating.
Salmon toast light and flavorful
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Dawn G.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review: Great food! Homemade sausage, yum, lemon ricotta pancakes bear repeating. Salmon toast light and flavorful

excerpts: Probably the best lemon ricotta pancakes I've ever had.
Just by ordering the "Plow" you get to experience what they're known for which are the lemon ricotta pancakes and amazing crispy potatoes
(super hot so watch your tongue
but oh so good); in addition you get a side of eggs and choice of sausage or bacon.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Kathy L.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Probably the best lemon ricotta pancakes I've ever had. Not enough for me to come back and wait almost 2 hours for though...which was how long my friends and I waited.

Just by ordering the "Plow" you get to experience what they're known for which are the lemon ricotta pancakes and amazing crispy potatoes (super hot so watch your tongue but oh so good); in addition you get a side of eggs and choice of sausage or bacon.

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes are supposed to be a huge hit here
but I personally didn't favor them.
The dense ricotta made it too heavy for me to finish both.
But it seems to be exactly what a ricotta pancake should be.
I would definitely come back next time for brunch again!
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Paulina N.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Came here in a Monday afternoon, for a group of 5 our wait was about 30-35 minuets. Not too bad because a couple of parties before us didn't show up.
Our servicer was nice she got our orders in as soon as we were ready. 
We ordered 2 buttermilk biscuits to start off our lunch. The butter was sweet and seems like it was house made. 
I got the plow with pork sausage, and soft scrambled eggs. My plate turned out exactly what i thought it would. The lemon ricotta pancakes are supposed to be a huge hit here but I personally didn't favor them. The dense ricotta made it too heavy for me to finish both. But it seems to be exactly what a ricotta pancake should be. 
I would definitely come back next time for brunch again!

excerpts: The lemon ricotta pancakes.
AMAZING.
SO GOOD.
HOW.
WHY.
Country style potatoes and eggs.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Steph D.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
I have tried to eat here three times. THREE TIMES. The wait is usually around an hour, and all the people standing outside can be intimidating, but it's absolutely worth it. 

I went at 9am to put our name in for a group of 4, and our table was ready about 45 mins later. Opted for inside seating cause it was cold, but would have been happy to sit outside just to finally be able to eat at this place. Limited seating, so I don't think a party bigger than 5 or 6 would be a good idea.

Ordered the plow so I could try a little bit of everything. The lemon ricotta pancakes. AMAZING. SO GOOD. HOW. WHY. Country style potatoes and eggs. Definitely the perfect hearty size after a late Friday night.

I would suggest ordering the grilled cheese. A friend ordered it and as soon as they brought the food, the entire table was jealous. 

I would eat here every weekend this wasn't San Francisco and I didn't have to wait an hour to sit at a fabulous restaurant.

excerpts: My friend ordered the plow dish, and I ordered the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes with a side of bacon.
lemon ricotta pancakes.author: Taylor M.
lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
Pretty good! 

Came here for brunch on a Tuesday morning around 11, and was surprised to see that it was busy! Had to wait less than 10 minutes for a table, and the hostess seated us at a two-top right next to a four-top that was within breathing room of us. It felt awkward being a bit close, so we scooted the table over a bit. 

With that said, Plow is a small restaurant. Be prepared to get comfortable with your table neighbors! 

My friend ordered the plow dish, and I ordered the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes with a side of bacon. 

Our food came out in about 15 minutes, and it was good! My bacon was greasy, fatty, and most importantly, crispy. It added the salt needed to the sweetness of the pancakes. The pancakes were delicious. I could taste the lemon without it being overpowering, and the ricotta was present as well. The blueberry compote that comes along is a great addition, as it adds a bit of tartness to the pancakes. Plus, the purple-blue of the blueberries on top of the lemon pancakes look so colorful and fun! 

My friend seemed enjoyed her dish, she ate the whole thing! 

The service was great. Our server made sure our coffee mugs were filled, and took good care of us. 

I'd recommend this place to a friend for sure. I'll come back in the future and order those pancakes again!

I don't really understand what the hype is all about. 

My friend and I came on a Saturday morning around 10:30am and the wait was 1-1.5 hours for a party of 2. We went for a stroll across the street to grab some coffee and toast while we waited, but I saw others order coffee and mimosas from Plow while waiting. The staff seemed super nice and accommodating, considering how busy it was.

We finally got seated after about an hour and 15 mins. We both ordered The Plow, which comes with eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, and your choice of pork sausage/bacon/chicken apple sausage. I went with the classic bacon option while my friend opted for the pork sausage.

Being seated outside, I noticed that we were not given a jug of water that we could use to fill our own glasses, while people sitting inside were. It didn't matter too much because our waitress was pretty good about refilling our waters. Just wish they kept it consistent with the tables, though.

Onto the food... Honestly I was very disappointed. My over medium eggs came with a perfect runny yolk (yay!) but overall were extremely bland. They tasted like they were barely seasoned with any salt or pepper. The bacon was terrible. It was waaay too salty and was not crispy at all. It was actually pretty soggy. The lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes, on the other hand, were the redeeming factors of the dish. The pancakes were fluffy and had a good balance of lemon flavor. The potatoes were pretty good as well, but not remarkable enough for me to say they were amazing. I tried some of my friend's pork sausage and thought it was pretty average. The worst part was when I found a piece of hair at the bottom of my plate. Definitely know it's not my own since it was short and black instead of long and ombré. It's too bad I had already eaten a majority of the plate when I found it...

I also noticed that they printed the menu specific for that day. I'm not sure if they print the menu everyday, but I sure hope not because that would be such a waste of paper.

Overall, Plow was definitely overhyped. It wasn't worth it to me to wait 1+ hour and pay $17 for a mediocre plate of food that had a hair in it... But maybe I just had a bad experience? I'd give it a try again maybe if the wait weren't so long.

***This neighborhood breakfast spot utilizes high quality ingredients and a well-run kitchen to churn out delicious and satisfying breakfast and brunch dishes***

Plow is located in Dogpatch, an up-and-coming neighborhood that will probably introduce several more destination restaurants in the next few years.  Plow is a weekday and weekend breakfast and brunch eatery.  The restaurant is small and casual though the décor is nicely done featuring homey but still contemporary notes.  The counter is nice and provides an excellent view of the short order counter where the team of chefs here efficiently crank out breakfast dishes like a well-run greasy spoon.

The food at Plow is not greasy spoon staples though.  You will see more upscale ingredients here like prosciutto and frisee as well as some great looking bread from a prestigious San Francisco bakery.  I had The Plow, which is their signature breakfast plate.  It is a hearty plate featuring two eggs, crispy fried potatoes with onions, choice of meat (chicken apple sausage, pork sausage patties or bacon), and two lemon ricotta pancakes.

With the exception of the lemon ricotta pancakes, this breakfast veered more towards fairly classic interpretations.  I had the eggs sunny side up, and they were quite good.  I would have liked the egg yolk a little less done, but the flavor was great.  The crispy potatoes were quite delicious.  The caramelized onions provided a mild sweet flavor while the potatoes combined a satisfying crispy exterior with a hot and soft center.  I also had their bacon, which was Nueske's bacon, a popular Midwestern bacon from Wisconsin.  The bacon had a smoky flavor as well as an appetizing pork flavor from the crispy fat.

The bacon was not as thick as Niman Ranch bacon, but the flavor was definitely memorable.  I also ordered their pork sausage patties, and these were good though I probably did prefer the bacon.  The center of the sausage was moist while the outside was well seared and crispy.  They get a little more adventurous with the seasoning so you get more herb and fennel notes with their sausage than you would experience at most breakfast spots.

The kitchen gussied up the pancakes a little more than they did with the other breakfast items in The Plow.  The pancakes featured both lemon and ricotta.  The lemon was nice.  It provided a noticeable lemon flavor as well as a lot of freshness.  I felt though that the ricotta probably hurt the pancake more than it helped it.  The pancakes had a great color and the smell of the pancake was very inviting.  Unfortunately, the pancake could have been sweeter.  The center was also a tad on the dry side and did not have that light and fluffy cake-like texture you would expect in an excellent pancake.

Service was fairly quick given how busy this restaurant gets (even on weekdays).  Prices are higher than your standard breakfast spot, but the ingredients at Plow are definitely high quality and the portions are surprisingly generous.

I enjoyed The Plow at Plow though I felt the savory items were far superior to the disappointing lemon ricotta pancakes.  Part of me really loved the breakfast here, and, in some ways, Plow would rival my favorite breakfast restaurants--Matt's Big Breakfast in Phoenix or Huckleberry in Santa Monica, which features an excellent fried egg sandwich with bacon.  I would definitely go back and give Plow's other dishes a shot.  If you are a big breakfast fan, Plow is a must visit if you live in San Francisco or are just visiting.

I believe free street parking is available in the nearby residential area though parking spaces are probably hard to find around here.

lemon ricotta pancakes.review:
With over a thousand reviews, you've probably gleaned that there is a ridiculous wait for a delicious breakfast. 

I finally got to come here on a Saturday with a party of three and was quoted a 1.5 hour wait. While pretending to be a flowerpots sitting on the sills outside, we decided to imbibe some self serve coffee (very strong - solid flavors). 

Upon being seated a little over an hour later, I noticed how once again new San Francisco the place is with a minimalist look, lots of natural lighting and light woodsy interior. It was also very cramped inside, but we did not want to wait extra for al fresco dining. 

Of course I ordered the Plow which came with the lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes and opted for the pork sausage and my eggs over medium. I also had a camellia iced tea on the side. I thoroughly enjoyed the fluffly sweetness of the pancakes but the CRISPY POTATOES were the star of the show; I now have a much higher standard for my brunch potatoes. The eggs were cooked perfectly (over medium is not really a thing so basically over easy). However the pork sausage was a huge letdown as it was very dry and had whole cumin seeds in it. It was remediable with dashes of Youk's hot sauce, but it was really just tough and dry. I had a bite of my friend's fried egg sandwich with avocado and it was stellar (though this is something rather difficult to not succeed in). The camellia iced tea was blase but refreshing.

Service was wonderful and our waters and teas were refilled regularly. I was a little miffed because the self serve coffee was ~$4 and there was no real sign or warning from the hostess who merely said "help yourself." I guess it is San Francisco and people no longer bat an eye at a $4 cup of coffee. The area is definitely different now than it was when I drove through to lifeguard at UCSF in my high school days. 

On the whole, a solid brunch place, but a little pricey ($30 after tax and tip for myself). I would come back if the wait abates.

Overall the food is solid. But you have to mentally prepare yourself to wait over an hour in the SF cold (or sit at the coffee shop down the street). If you're up for it, go for it!
