soft scrambled eggs.author: Victoria J.
soft scrambled eggs.review:
Yes, the wait here is ridiculous, there's no pleasant place to sit and you can't sit inside because it's a small place. That's just how it is. If you come with this mindset, you'll be okay waiting, if not, then you'll probably be miserable. Although, a few times when I've come and I know the wait will be more than 30 minutes, I'll just leave and go to Farley's to hang out there for a while and come back with a hot cup of coffee in hand. 

The potatoes here are always amazing. I love how they fry them, I love how they come with beautiful sprigs of rosemary, and sometimes when I come here I get a side order with my meal because the amount of potatoes that come with the dish just aren't enough! I usually get something with eggs here (eg. soft scrambled eggs) and I've always loved what I order. The last time I visited plow my boyfriend ordered the crab scramble and he said he didn't like it at all though. He described it as too watery and the taste was lackluster. He usually gets the plow and is always satisfied with that, so I think for him it was matter of ordering. I've tried their monkey bread, which was just okay and tasted more like a cinnamon roll. I've also tried their pop tart, which was pretty good, but I feel like I could home make pop tarts just as good and not for $5 a piece. 

I like plow a lot and is my go to breakfast place, but just there is a ridiculous wait, but the food is very solidly good. The waitstaff is alright, nothing to really say about them. Some people find them rude, but they're usually attentive and that's all I care about.

excerpts: The "soft scrambled eggs - asparagus, stinging nettles, oyster mushrooms, goat cheese, crispy potatoes + toast", sounds fancy but is pretty average fare.
The potatoes were tasty,
the scrambled eggs also ok.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Mar L.
soft scrambled eggs.review:
Pretty underwhelmed, particularly based on the glowing reviews I've read. 

Wait was quoted on a Friday for an hour, which was pretty much right on.

Were seated next to other people. I don't mind, but I think servers should always ask the party if that's ok first.

The entrance door was open and sitting next to the door was frigid cold. I asked if the door could be closed, but after 5 minutes the staff were too lazy to close it again.

The general decor is ok. Nice, basic, but pleasant.

The service is basic, a bit short staffed. I saw the waitress roll her eyes while walking away from a request of another table, which I don't particularly like to see.

I had the gluten free almond pancakes $13. Honestly again, BASIC. Slightly burnt on one side. Taste is below average, grainy, very little taste. It's literally just three small pancakes on a barren plate with a *speck* of butter. Kinda sad. It could use some fruit, or bananas, walnuts, berries, anything to make it more presentable. I've had pretty gnarly gluten free pancakes before (friggin Swingers in LA, for example), and for $13 this leaves a bit to be desired. 

The "soft scrambled eggs - asparagus, stinging nettles, oyster mushrooms, goat cheese, crispy potatoes + toast", sounds fancy but is pretty average fare. The potatoes were tasty, the scrambled eggs also ok. I would eat it again, but not particularly worth $15.

Just upon leaving, I was asked to leave the table because other people were waiting, and the waitress mumbled something about promising people a table for too long. I was offered a "glass of water" for my gesture.

Decent place, BUT:

NOT worth the wait.
NOT worth the price.

excerpts: While the soft scrambled eggs were excellent, the sausage was too dry and i didn't finish it.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Jack K.
soft scrambled eggs.review:
Plow slipped a little in this outing.  While the soft scrambled eggs were excellent, the sausage was too dry and i didn't finish it.  

This is a really crowded, relatively small place.  The hostess is really nice, however, and comes outside to find you when its your time to eat.  They'll set you up with coffee while you wait, as well.

excerpts:
we ordered: 
- soft scrambled eggs - this dish sounds so normal but is so good.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Jen S.
soft scrambled eggs.review:
wow got here before 9am and the wait is an hour and a half? are you kidding me? luckily my friend lived close by and so we ran some errands and came back just in time for our name to be called. we ordered: 
- soft scrambled eggs - this dish sounds so normal but is so good. i'll take it over normal scrambled eggs any day 
- the plow - eggs, bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes - everything on this dish was amazing! pancakes i normally don't like but these ones were amazing. i even wished they were bigger. and the potatoes - so crispy and yum!
- smoked salmon toast - it was good cause i love smoked salmon but wasn't anything special, if you have to chose the first two are better. 
i just wish they had bloody mary's on the menu. but i guess i'll settle for a mimosa ;) not sure if i would come often since the wait is soo long but if the occasion calls for it, i would. the food IS good!

excerpts: The soft scrambled eggs were the turning point for me, where I switched from liking Plow to loving Plow.
Of course we've all read about the proper way to slowly scramble eggs, slow and over low heat a la Julia Child or Jacques Pepin, and I thought I had it right before.
I was wrong.
These eggs were so, so silky.
Not runny, but perfectly silky, highlighted by fava greens, chanterelles, and goat cheese.
Anyway, of course you can't go wrong with gingery braised pork shoulder over rice, but the soft scrambled eggs are really where it's at.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Candice L.
soft scrambled eggs.review:
For a year and a half, I have been hearing my Potrero friends rave about Plow. Actually, I've been hearing raves about Plow from friends, the blogs, and pretty much anybody who had been and weathered the wait for their tasty breakfasts. Truth be told, I am not enamored with Mission Beach Cafe or Boogaloos and didn't think that breakfast at Plow would wow me.

The breakfast wowed me. 

We started with a corn and millet muffin, freshly baked and still warm from the oven. The muffin was crumbly and a bit hard to eat but the crust on the muffin top was crunchy and the millet added crispy bits to the slightly sweet corn muffin. Seriously though, all muffins should be eaten fresh and warm from the oven. 

Next up were a la carte orders of an almond pancake (gluten-free!) and a pumpkin pancake. The pumpkin pancake was fine, similar to what I make at home, but the almond pancake was really interesting. I didn't believe it was actually gluten-free at first b/c the texture was so spot on and it wasn't heavily almond flavored. I dislike marzipan, so I was quite pleased at the neutral flavor profile of the pancake. We asked the server and she informed us that it was made with almond, oat, and coconut flour. An excellent option for the g-f people out there.

The soft scrambled eggs were the turning point for me, where I switched from liking Plow to loving Plow. Of course we've all read about the proper way to slowly scramble eggs, slow and over low heat a la Julia Child or Jacques Pepin, and I thought I had it right before. I was wrong. These eggs were so, so silky. Not runny, but perfectly silky, highlighted by fava greens, chanterelles, and goat cheese. The much lauded crispy potatoes and some levain toast (well buttered with butter you could actually taste) were also there. I don't even like eggs and I kept going back to them, passing over the crispy fried potatoes!

We also tried the Chinese Breakfast whose name manages to simultaneously bring to mind my family and Humphry Slocombe's Secret Breakfast. Anyway, of course you can't go wrong with gingery braised pork shoulder over rice, but the soft scrambled eggs are really where it's at.

All the ingredients used were obviously quality; seasoning levels and ingredient ratios were also well balanced. Loved the clean yet rustic vibe of the naturally sunny dining room. Also loved our server who understood that we were there to sample some different dishes vs eating at a traditional pace. She brought things out at a comfortable rate and was there to answer questions as needed. I can't imagine this perfect vision of what breakfast at Plow is ruined by the hoards on weekends so I guess I'll just save it for an occasional 7am weekday treat.

excerpts: My friend and I ordered the soft scrambled eggs, the cherry tomatoes and goat cheese for me, and the oyster mushrooms and cheddar for her.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Thi D.
soft scrambled eggs.review: Came here on a weekday at 1pm.  There was plenty of seating outdoors, but we opted for inside since it was a little chilly.  We had to wait about 20 minutes for a table.  I definitely dig the ambiance inside.  My friend and I ordered the soft scrambled eggs, the cherry tomatoes and goat cheese for me, and the oyster mushrooms and cheddar for her.  The mister ordered the plow.  My eggs were cooked perfectly and had a lot of flavor.  I can see why people rave about the crispy potatoes because they were very good.  I tried the lemon ricotta pancakes from the mister's plate, which made me wish I ordered them.  Overall, very tasty food and good, friendly service.

excerpts: The soft scrambled eggs were good, but nothing fancy.
But... the potatoes.
Yes, they are mighty fine and
just so... dang....
soft scrambled eggs.author: Solomon W.
soft scrambled eggs.review:
Potato, potahto, however you say the name of this tuberifous vegetable, you must eat them at Plow if you are in San Francisco. Yes, the wait on any given day is pretty crazy--odd that it is in such a residential area--but I assure you that it is worth your time.

The restaurant is small and quaint, so they are really consistent at cranking out good grub to a few people at a time. I believe that they take care in each dish, and it comes out in the offerings, primarily the potatoes.

The lemon ricotta pancake was fluffy and creamy; it boasted just a touch of sweetness balanced with a hint of lemon, to boot. The duckfat cornmeal pancake possessed this tartness from possibly buttermilk? It was just rich and fluffy, with a touch of crispness. The coffee crumbcake was just OK, unfortunately. Lots o' blueberry, but sort of a mealy texture and light flavor.

Onto the actual food. The crispy potatoes are the best I have ever had in the "roasted" category, bar none. Honestly just outrageously delicious potatoes. The soft scrambled eggs were good, but nothing fancy. But... the potatoes. Yes, they are mighty fine and just so... dang.... GOOD.

Plow falls into that category "sleek" eatery with one word with only a few letters like "Cow" or "Meat" or "Brunch." Does it match up to all of the like? 100%, yes.

excerpts: My girlfriend loved her soft scrambled eggs with merguez sausage and even conceded to the home fry perfection, quite an accomplishment given that ambivalence is generally the best a breakfast potato can hope for from her.
We both loved the fresh squeezed orange juice, too, an item I can safely say we hold to nearly-impossibly-high standards.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Derek W.
soft scrambled eggs.review:
Picking a favorite brunch spot in San Francisco is a little like deciding which of your children you love the best.  There are many worthy contenders, hence the significance of my ordination of Plow as personal  favorite was a choice well considered.

I was primed to love this place when we drove up and saw expectant diners waiting patiently on every corner adjoining the restaurant, sipping delicious coffee on the house.  A second indication of the fine feast to come was the plump, perfectly contented pig which graces each menu and serves as the restaurant's icon.   I studied the menu carefully and greedily as we waited.

Ordering a 1/2 "appetizer" portion of the French Toast with caramelized apples, mascarpone, and maple syrup seemed like the right thing to do, and it was a good call indeed, every bite moist, rich and delightful.  

The next course for me was a combination plate that sounded and tasted too good to be true:  a festival of flavors including extraordinary lemon ricotta pancakes, perfectly crispy home fried potatoes and housemade fennel sausage.  Paired with eggs, this terrific trio took me on a non-stop flight to gastro-paradise.   

My girlfriend loved her soft scrambled eggs with merguez sausage and even conceded to the home fry perfection, quite an accomplishment given that ambivalence is generally the best a breakfast potato can hope for from her.  We both loved the fresh squeezed orange juice, too, an item I can safely say we hold to nearly-impossibly-high standards.
 
The open layout, simple decor and beautiful photography created a pleasant ambiance, and our server was a picture of attentiveness and calm amidst the bustling scene.

There will be many return visits.

excerpts: I had the lemon ricotta pancakes and my boyfriend had the soft scrambled eggs with the most delicious breakfast potatoes ever!
The place was a bit cramped, we shared a table with another couple which was fine.
The pancakes were to die for and the service was great.
Love Plow.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Denisse R.
soft scrambled eggs.review: Best breakfast/brunch place in the city. I met up with my boyfriend on a Saturday around just before noon. Be prepared to wait a good hour for a table in this tiny little spot. Once we tasted the food, it was no wonder there was a line. I had the lemon ricotta pancakes and my boyfriend had the soft scrambled eggs with the most delicious breakfast potatoes ever! The place was a bit cramped, we shared a table with another couple which was fine. The pancakes were to die for and the service was great. Love Plow.

excerpts: We also decided upon the hash, soft scrambled eggs, and french toast.
As a side, we ordered the heirloom tomato salad.
After ordering, we waited another likely 45 minutes to be served.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Lily R.
soft scrambled eggs.review:
So...Where do I start? My two girlfriends and I came on a Sunday afternoon, expecting the wait. We showed up around 11, and were told it would be an hour and a half wait. Yikes. Luckily, we had a lot to catch up on and the weather was absolutely perfect for spending walking around the area. An hour passed and we managed to swipe a spot on a planter nearby to sit upon. An hour and a half passed and there was still one more party of 3 to be seated before us. Just short of two hours passed and we were seated at the bar facing the open kitchen.

The three of us knew Plow was known for their lemon ricotta pancakes and made sure we ordered those. We also decided upon the hash, soft scrambled eggs, and french toast. As a side, we ordered the heirloom tomato salad. After ordering, we waited another likely 45 minutes to be served. They were busy and there were just two cooks preparing the food for all the patrons. 

It was far too much food for three rather small women, but we gladly forced ourselves to finish it all. Our brunch wasn't cheap (all that food plus drinks for each of us), but was WELL worth it, as was the wait. I will gladly return at the next opportunity that arises. Although, hopefully that will happen earlier in the morning so as to reduce that impressive wait.

excerpts: My friend ordered the soft scrambled eggs and I ordered the chicken apple sausage and eggplant toast - caramelized onions and eggplant on toasted French bread with a side of greens.
Pretty good.
Worth returning, but still don't quite get the high ratings.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Vivian W.
soft scrambled eggs.review: 3.5 stars.  Been here twice.  Thought it was only okay the first time, but liked my food better the 2nd time.  Cute place with easy parking.  My friend ordered the soft scrambled eggs and I ordered the chicken apple sausage and eggplant toast - caramelized onions and eggplant on toasted French bread with a side of greens.  Pretty good.  Worth returning, but still don't quite get the high ratings.

excerpts: Eggs Benedict had great flavor and some of the best I've tried and the soft scrambled eggs with wild mushrooms, goat cheese and spinach was tasty and the potatoes were nice and crispy.
I would however wait for a table inside because the outdoor tables are cramped and far from being level.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Chadwick C.
soft scrambled eggs.review:
Everything ordered for brunch was spot on! Eggs Benedict had great flavor and some of the best I've tried and the soft scrambled eggs with wild mushrooms, goat cheese and spinach was tasty and the potatoes were nice and crispy. 
I would however wait for a table inside because the outdoor tables are cramped and far from being level.

excerpts: It looks heavy but was actually pretty light with soft scrambled eggs.
Thank you for not charging SF health tax.
I would go back.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Fatty A.
soft scrambled eggs.review: Solid brunch spot.  The wait here is cray.  Egg whites for $5.50 is cray.  The food is good but on the expensive side.  The homemade sausage patty was delicious.  I was expecting the lemon ricotta pancakes to blow me away.  They were just good.  The chicken tinga was also pretty good.  It looks heavy but was actually pretty light with soft scrambled eggs.  Thank you for not charging SF health tax.  I would go back.

excerpts: Just had the best breakfast ever- the soft scrambled eggs were killer.
We showed up at 10:30 on a Friday and were seated at the counter immediately.
Great service, great food, great coffee.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Tatiana N.
soft scrambled eggs.review: Just had the best breakfast ever- the soft scrambled eggs were killer. We showed up at 10:30 on a Friday and were seated at the counter immediately. Great service, great food, great coffee.

excerpts: Soft scrambled eggs w/goat cheese: Solid dish.
Tastes exactly like you'd imagine but better.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Julie C.
soft scrambled eggs.review:
Very cute place. Took a day off from work so I came on a weekday morning. 

Everything looked great on the menu and it was a hard decision but we settled on the following:

1) Lemon Ricotta Pancakes: So good. Soft and fluffy with little bits of ricotta throughout. 

2) Soft scrambled eggs w/goat cheese: Solid dish. Tastes exactly like you'd imagine but better. Simple and comforting.

3) Blood sausage: The best dish we had that morning. Everyone loved it.

The crispy potatoes that came with most dishes were great too. Still dreaming about the blood sausage... and all the cute little piggy artifacts throughout the restaurant!

excerpts: I'm still thinking about the soft scrambled eggs I had that were completely delicious.
Without a doubt the best brunch I have ever had.
soft scrambled eggs.author: Angie F.
soft scrambled eggs.review: Fantastic find. Really cool spot in Potrero Hill with great service, nice atmosphere and phenomenal food. I'm still thinking about the soft scrambled eggs I had that were completely delicious. Without a doubt the best brunch I have ever had.

excerpts: I had the soft scrambled eggs with spinach, shallots and goat cheese-y goodness and those potatoes..
THOSE POTATOES!
Boiled then fried then tossed with seasoning and onions... so delicious.
Definitely worth a trip if you're in the area.
Also, who doesn't appreciate a neighborhood spot that serves quality brunch M-F?
The world needs more of it!!
soft scrambled eggs.author: Alexandra N.
soft scrambled eggs.review: Thanks, Ashley for the tip on this place!  Booked a last minute tour at Anchor Brewery this morning and met some nice people who knew the area--they introduced me to this gem which is basically around the block.  I had the soft scrambled eggs with spinach, shallots and goat cheese-y goodness and those potatoes.. THOSE POTATOES!  Boiled then fried then tossed with seasoning and onions... so delicious.  Definitely worth a trip if you're in the area.  Also, who doesn't appreciate a neighborhood spot that serves quality brunch M-F? The world needs more of it!!

excerpts: The plow also comes with crispy Neueske bacon, two eggs (I chose over medium) cooked absolutely perfectly, a hash of deep-fried country potatoes which were still soft and buttery inside but nice and crispy on the outside, caramelized onion and bacon tossed together, it was really a step above the norm.
two eggs.author: Kelly T.
two eggs.review:
I was looking for a quick bite to eat between appointments in the city and in San Rafael and was lucky to find Plow. Breakfast or brunch was on my mind and I saw the positive Yelp reviews at Plow and thought I would check it out and oh my goodness I am happy that I did! 

I ordered " the plow " it came with two small lemon ricotta pancakes. I have to pause and mention that there is a tight team of 3 guys working and one is making ricotta fresh right there on the line. Talk about high-end pancakes! One guy is working on the potatoes, one is working on the meats, it is a friendly, swift and delicious team of chefs. The menu is expansive and they have such unique breakfasts, large portions and such high quality. 

The plow also comes with crispy Neueske bacon, two eggs (I chose over medium) cooked absolutely perfectly, a hash of deep-fried country potatoes which were still soft and buttery inside but nice and crispy on the outside, caramelized onion and bacon tossed together, it was really a step above the norm. 

Everyone works as a friendly well-oiled machine, they all have their pace down and it works wonderfully for all of us. The service is lovely, they don't bother you but they check in with you which is nice, not overt or pushy which many places as packed as this can tend to be. I can't wait to go back.

excerpts: Ordered the Plow which comes with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes, and
I got the chicken apple sauage which I really liked and the plow potatoes are SOOOO good.
The lemon ricotta pancakes were also SOOOOOO good.
two eggs.author: Carol L.
two eggs.review:
Oh, Plow... how I waited and waited and waited and wanted so badly to love you. My friends and I came around 10:30am on a Saturday as a party of 5 and waited WAY OVER 2 hours. We were quoted 1.5 hours - 2 hours and called pretty frequently to check in on our table. 

This is the part that irks me the most about my experience.. at one point maybe 1.5 hours in, they told us to come back in 15 minutes. We came back in around 10 minutes and they told us "oh sorry, we just gave your table away". Sorry, but WHAT???? You would think that a place this popular can figure out their reservations and their waiting system but NOPE. So if you come here, you better just wait right outside the restaurant....... They call your name once or twice and if you're not there they just skip right over you even if they tell you to come back at a certain time. Truly unlike anything else I've ever experienced before, but maybe I'm spoiled after being in Chicago and NY for a while now as they have their lines and reservation systems all figured out..

Service was good from one person, but rude from another. Honestly, at this point I was pretty hangry though. So maybe the service wasn't THAT bad, it just came across as horribly rude when we asked for more water and were ignored. Also the host just wasn't pleasant to my party at all. 

Ordered the Plow which comes with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes, and your choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I got the chicken apple sauage which I really liked and the plow potatoes are SOOOO good. The lemon ricotta pancakes were also SOOOOOO good. (But was it because I was starving after waiting close to 2.5 hours for a table and the food?) 

I would come back, but I would never wait more than 30 minutes for the food. 3 stars because this restaurant needs to work on their service and their queue, but the food is pretty good.

TL;DR: Wait outside the restaurant otherwise your table will be given away and you'll wait outside forever and be even more starving than you already were.

Also their place is tiny, so if you want to get seated as quickly as possible then come by yourself or with one other person. They have like one or two tables that can accommodate parties over 4 people.

excerpts: It comes with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, Plow potatoes, and your choice of pork sausage, bacon, or chicken apple sausage.
I've heard such good things about their lemon ricotta pancakes, so I knew I *had* to try them out.
Almost everything was perfect about this platter: the eggs were perfectly scrambled, the potatoes were roasted just right, and OMG THE PANCAKES.
They were so light with a nice lemon flavor that wasn't overpowering.
The pancakes themselves aren't too sweet so you can control the sweetness with the syrup.
two eggs.author: Dianna H.
two eggs.review:
Another solid spot for brunch in SF, as long as you're willing to wait. Food is 5 stars but I'm taking away one star for the perpetually long wait.

I've tried to come once before, but when we were told the wait would be around 1.5 hours, my friend and I bounced and ate at a place nearby with a much shorter wait. One year later, I decide to challenge the wait at Plow again.

My friend came around 10:15 on a Saturday to put her name down and was told to check back in 2 hours or so. When the three of us came back around noon, they had already called our name but bumped us to the top of the list. We were seated shortly after that.

I can see why they have such a long wait; it's a small space with seating for maybe 30 people? Definitely don't recommend coming here with a big group.

As a first timer, I knew I had to get their namesake dish: The Plow ($17.50). It comes with two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, Plow potatoes, and your choice of pork sausage, bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I don't know why more brunch places don't offer this, but it's the person brunch platter for people who prefer mostly savory dishes with a small bit of sweet on the side.

I've heard such good things about their lemon ricotta pancakes, so I knew I *had* to try them out. Almost everything was perfect about this platter: the eggs were perfectly scrambled, the potatoes were roasted just right, and OMG THE PANCAKES. They were so light with a nice lemon flavor that wasn't overpowering. The pancakes themselves aren't too sweet so you can control the sweetness with the syrup. The Plow platter comes with two mini pancakes, but I might need to order a whole side of these to myself next time! My only complaint was that the pork sausage wasn't that great.

It was so nice to come here with my girlfriends and catch up on life. So glad I finally got to check this place out, and I will be back!

excerpts: I ordered the plow, which is two eggs, potatoes, meat and two of their lemon ricotta pancakes.
Boy
oh boy, those pancakes stole the entire show.
They melted in your mouth with twangs of lemon and notes of sweet, melt-in-your-mouth savory flavors which I can only assume is the ricotta.
two eggs.author: Emily R.
two eggs.review:
Absolutely delicious. This was my first time here and because it is a Thursday and I went at 8am, it wasn't busy at all. I was told by a friend that there is usually a line out the door, and I'm not surprised. 

The general atmosphere fits perfectly with the farm to table vibe, it feels relaxed and familiar. The servers were super friendly and nice. It reminded me of going to a hip friends house for breakfast. I sat at the breakfast bar and was able to see the kitchen staff preparing food, which also gave the sense of cleanliness because I could see any missteps made. 

The food was delicious, it all tasted homemade and fresh. The eggs were creamy and moist. The potatoes had a crisp to them that made me keep going back for me. The pork sausage was slightly spicy, which I am not a fan of, but I was able to try my friend's chicken sausage which had a maple syrup aftertaste to them which was just delicious. I ordered the plow, which is two eggs, potatoes, meat and two of their lemon ricotta pancakes. Boy oh boy, those pancakes stole the entire show. They melted in your mouth with twangs of lemon and notes of sweet, melt-in-your-mouth savory flavors which I can only assume is the ricotta. Combined with the syrup served on the side and a small pat of butter on top, it was heavenly. 

I would absolutely check this place out again and suggest you do the same.

excerpts: I ordered the Plow which consists of two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, two eggs, and your choice or bacon/sausage.
It's essentially a sampler.
It was admittedly pretty good.
I especially enjoyed the flavorful, buttery pancakes and the runny eggs.
The potatoes were very well seasoned and the sausage was also delicious.
two eggs.author: Alicia L.
two eggs.review:
Plow's notoriously long wait coupled with their slow af service makes me not want to come here again.

I ordered the Plow which consists of two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, two eggs, and your choice or bacon/sausage. It's essentially a sampler.
It was admittedly pretty good. I especially enjoyed the flavorful, buttery pancakes and the runny eggs. The potatoes were very well seasoned and the sausage was also delicious. They do their basics pretty well, but I kept biting into something hard with the potatoes.

My friend ordered the Vietnamese pork chop and it was absolutely terrible. I don't know if the chef just messed up but it was so overly salty we could not eat it. I'm pretty sure it was a mishap though because there's no way they'd still be in business delivering this kind of food.

The service isn't good either as there is very limited seating, so you have to wait a looooong time. Additionally, it takes forever to get your food. Set aside a really long dining time slot if you wanna eat here.

Price is 2/5
Food is 3/5
Wait is 2/5
Service is 2/5

excerpts: The Plow ($17.5) - Two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes with choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage.
two eggs.author: Chelsea W.
two eggs.review:
Plow is a pretty good place to get standard brunch fare. If you come early, the wait is really worth it! 

I've always come at opening time around 8 AM and probably wouldn't wait more than 30 min for it, so I highly recommend coming early. 

The menu consists of options like Soft Scrambled Eggs, Sausage & Eggs, Eggs Benedict, etc. It seems like the more popular dishes are the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes and The Plow.

The Plow ($17.5) - Two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes with choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I ended up getting the Annie's Almond Flour Pancakes since it was GF which tasted great! The chicken apple sausage was also pretty good too. I had a side of fruit which cost a little more, but also tried the potatoes and they were really delicious

Plow stands out because of it's simple, yet delicious and quality ingredients. It does run on the expensive side though.

excerpts: It was delicious, but definitely not worth waiting 2 hours, and getting treated like you're a beggar, but paying $17 for a plate of two eggs, potatoes, a bit of sausage, and mini pancakes.
two eggs.author: Su Lin Y.
two eggs.review:
Hostess: ABSOLUTELY ATROCIOUS (negative 5 out of 5)
Service/Waitress: 4/5
Food: 4/5

I used to love Plow, and would wake up at 7am to make it here by 7.40 am so I could be in the first group to be seated--such was my dedication!I haven't been in a while, more because of my reluctance to wake up at 7am on a weekend than anything else, but I visited yesterday (Sunday brunch) and was horribly shocked and disappointed by the hostess/front of house service. My friend stopped by around 9.45am to put our names down, and was given ETA of 90-120 minutes. So far, so good. (Honestly, the food in my opinion isn't worth a 2 hour wait, but np, we were going to commit).

We come back in just over 90 minutes (11.20am) to check on our seat. 25 more minutes the hostess says, back to Farleys (coffee shop) we go. We come back in about 20 minutes (11.40) to check again, and are told by a different (VERY sassy hostess) that we were called and weren't here, and so we'll get the next available table. She said it in a really dismissive way, sounding like she was really blaming us for not being here. That being said, I had to clarify and say, 

Me: "well, we were told 25 minu--"--oops before I can finish, I'm interrupted 
Hostess: "Well, we called YOUR NAME, and you WEREN'T HERE, so. We gave it away. You'll get the next table". 
Me: "How long will that be?", 
Hostess: "About 25 minutes". 
Me: "Another 25 minutes? We were just--" interrupted AGAIN 
Hostess: "WELL, we quoted you 2-2.5 hours, so we are STILL WITHIN OUR TIME RANGE we gave you. OKAY?!", 
me: "But--",  
Hostess: "M'AAM, We are still WITHIN The time we gave you SO." (glares at me, aggressive body language throughout--leaning in, glaring)

I can't capture tone here but she was straight up talking DOWN to me, super rude, interrupting me before I could even complete HALF a sentence--all I wanted to say was "is it actually going to be 25 minutes because if so I'm going to go wait in the coffee shop not stand out here in the frigid SF winds since you have no freaking space for your guests to wait indoors".  Also, you MISQUOTED ME. I didn't even get to open my mouth to tell her they quoted us 120 mins on the upper end, i.e. 2 hours, not 2.5 hours. I understand it can be hard to get an accurate quote, but you should NEVER talk down to anyone like that and insult me by not giving me the opportunity to even finish a sentence. I didn't even raise my voice or tone or anything like that, I simply wanted to know if I should wait here or go back to the coffee shop, because lady, you told me 25 minutes, I'm back in 20 and you tell me it's my fault and you gave away my table and refuse to hear me out? This is after I waited close to 2 hours at this point, LADY. 

Never in my LIFE have I been treated so atrociously and been intimidated like this at an eating establishment in America. I am not kidding she talked down AT me (not TO me) and raised her voice and cut me off repeatedly so I couldn't ask any clarifying questions. Incredibly aggressive body language. What a NASTY experience. There was another lady who was kinder, but she was addressing other people. Also, the food was definitely not fantastic enough to warrant such treatment. It was delicious, but definitely not worth waiting 2 hours, and getting treated like you're a beggar, but paying $17 for a plate of two eggs, potatoes, a bit of sausage, and mini pancakes. Only to be seated out in the cold and told that their blankets are all dirty right now.

---

Dear Plow--obviously quality of food comes first, but seriously, front of house staff are very important as well. Especially if you're having lines of people wait for brunch. Maybe consider employing one of those electronic systems that let's you notify customers via texts? Honestly never have I felt so insulted and intimidated.

excerpts:
It was clear what their signature dish is that all tourists and locals like to order alike ...

the plow - two eggs sunny side up, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes with house made pork sausage.
And now the lemon ricotta pancakes: WERE THE ABSOLUTE BEST!
Perfectly fluffy and soft with that great blend of lemon flavors woven within.
Not too strong nor tangy, but perfectly sweeet!
Here for some more lemon ricotta pancakes and maybe try their almond pancakes next!
two eggs.author: Cuc N.
two eggs.review:
On the second attempt, the boyfriend and I finally got to try this brunch restaurant called Plow. Why? Not only because it was a suggestion from a local San Franciscan, but my boyfriend finds fun and giddiness in the name itself. Weird. It's all about cows!!

Even on a Friday morning, this place has a wait for the inside, which is warm and cozy and the Christmas spirit is definitely in the air. With an airplane to catch back home, we opted to sit outside with no wait. This wasn't so bad because I do enjoy sitting on a cup of hot tea while enjoying the crisp cold air through my nose and on my face. What better Christmas spirit?

What we didn't know would be waiting for us was a very kind hostess who not only seated us at our table, but also had her hands filled with two warm and cozy blankets for each of us. I looked around. Every single seated customer had one around their shoulders or on their lap. What nice and thoughtful customer service to provide such amenities for the outside! Now I was really glad to sit outside. Just that small thing added to my cold and crisp winter morning.

I enjoyed the warm blanket. It was perfect!!!

So let's get to food??? We didn't order much because it was just us two and we both don't want to feel overstuffed. But what to order when you can only order one? This was easy to decide! It was clear what their signature dish is that all tourists and locals like to order alike ...

the plow - two eggs sunny side up, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes with house made pork sausage.

Now everything on this plate was scrumptious. The eggs were perfectly yolky and freshly made. The patties were hand made from scratch and you can taste all the fresh flavors and hard work into molding these. The potatoes were crispy, crunchy and hot. And now the lemon ricotta pancakes: WERE THE ABSOLUTE BEST! Perfectly fluffy and soft with that great blend of lemon flavors woven within. Not too strong nor tangy, but perfectly sweeet! Now this is what they were known for!

I would definitely come back here. Here for some more lemon ricotta pancakes and maybe try their almond pancakes next!

excerpts: My hubby ordered The Plow with Pork Patties (as we were told that it is their house specialty) that comes with 2 pancakes, their signature fried smashed potatoes, and two eggs.
Hubby said his was okay.
I got the Soft Scramble Eggs that's with shiitake mushrooms, spinanch and goat cheese mixed in the scramble.
It was good!
It also comes with the fried smashed potatoes and two toasted bread wedges.
The potatoes are good too!
It was a perfect brunch meal for me!
two eggs.author: Abby Q.
two eggs.review:
There's always a long wait especially on weekends (we came on Saturday mornings).  First time we came here, we were told that the wait time is 2 hours.  Since we were hungry, we went to a good french bistro two blocks away.  The second time, we were told that the wait time is 1 hour.  Since we are more determined and have come prepared with a granola for hunger emergencies, we waited it out.  And was surprised that my name was called 30 minutes later (since a lot of people walked away).    

My hubby ordered The Plow with Pork Patties (as we were told that it is their house specialty) that comes with 2 pancakes, their signature fried smashed potatoes, and two eggs.  Hubby said his was okay.  I got the Soft Scramble Eggs that's with shiitake mushrooms, spinanch and goat cheese mixed in the scramble.  It was good! It also comes with the fried smashed potatoes and two toasted bread wedges.  The potatoes are good too!  It was a perfect brunch meal for me!

excerpts: My boyfriend got "the plow" ($17.50), which was two eggs, potatoes, two mini lemon ricotta pancakes, and choice of pork sausage, chicken sausage, and bacon.
This was a pretty unique dish, and the pancakes were amazing - fluffy and sweet and lemony.
two eggs.author: Amy C.
two eggs.review:
Came here for lunch with a group of 5. The wait around 10am was a solid 2 hours, so be prepared to wait or put your name down and come back. 

The food was really good, although the prices were pretty high. My boyfriend got "the plow" ($17.50), which was two eggs, potatoes, two mini lemon ricotta pancakes, and choice of pork sausage, chicken sausage, and bacon. This was a pretty unique dish, and the pancakes were amazing - fluffy and sweet and lemony. The pork sausage was house made and also very good.

I got the breakfast sandwich, which came with eggs, bacon, and frise on a bun with potatoes ($15.75). It was pretty good but not unique enough to justify the price. It was a good portion though and filled me up. 

Overall food was about 3.75, but not sure if it's worth the wait if the wait is longer than 30-40 min.

excerpts: It had two eggs which was nice when we were trying to split it between the two of us.
two eggs.author: Rae A.
two eggs.review:
It's a highly-recommended place to chow for SF Brunch. So many people have told me to check this place out. Just pulling up to it and I could smell something delicious and savory. We were put on the waitlist and walked around a little bit to kill time. 

We were nervous about sitting outside but how nice is it that they provide blankets! That's so unique and thoughtful and definitely appropriate. We overheard the other people around us order the biscuit (which sells out) so we got that + The Plow (with the sausage patties) + Breakfast sandwich. 

Favorite thing I ate during our SF food trip would probably be these biscuits and the Tony's Pizza. They were DELICIOUS. It wasn't dry at all, tasted fresh, and served warm. No wonder the couple next to us each got their own. 

The Plow ($17):
Yummy!! The potatoes are delicious. We asked for them to make it extra crispy which added +10 to taste. Not sure if I loved the sausage, you could really taste the fennel and maybe eating outside made everything too cold for my liking. The Ricotta Pancakes were good because of the actual ricotta you could see scattered in the batter. I also liked how you got to try a little bit of everything they had to offer. 

Breakfast Sandwich:
Arguably better than the Plow. The brioche bread really is a game changer for sandwiches. It had two eggs which was nice when we were trying to split it between the two of us. It was filling even without the additional extras. 

All in all, not sure if the wait would be worth it. The potatoes and biscuits were the highlights for me but I don't know how much I have to be craving it to wait any longer than 30 minutes.

excerpts: I got two eggs with bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes.
two eggs.author: Yvi L.
two eggs.review:
Another SF brunch place to check off my list. We came here on a Friday morning around 11:00 and of course there was already a big crowd of people waiting outside. For just me and my man the estimated wait time was 1.5 hours! 
The crowd dissembled a bit when it started raining, but the wait time ended up still being 1 hour 15 minutes. 

VIBE: very cute homey cafe. Farm to table vibes and super clean 

FOOD: 
The Plow- I got two eggs with bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes. The pancakes were super fluffy and the potatoes were seasoned well without being salty. 

Butcher's steak- my man got this dish and he must have really loved it because it was gone quickly. (Or he was just very hungry from the long wait) 

Both dishes were presented beautifully and did taste good quality. But not sure it was unique enough or THAAAAT good to justify the long wait.

excerpts: It comes with two eggs, potatoes, your meat of choice and two lemon ricotta pancakes.
The potatoes are fried with rosemary and the lemon ricotta pancakes are so flavorful, these are definitely my two favorite parts of this dish.
two eggs.author: Mallory L.
two eggs.review:
This is literally my favorite breakfast spot of all time. I dream about Plow and drool just thinking about it. Breakfast is hands down my favorite meal of the day and Plow always does it right. 

If you haven't visited Plow before, I recommend ordering The Plow. It comes with two eggs, potatoes, your meat of choice and two lemon ricotta pancakes. The potatoes are fried with rosemary and the lemon ricotta pancakes are so flavorful, these are definitely my two favorite parts of this dish. 

The fried egg sandwich is another amazing choice. I've never had a better breakfast sandwich in my life. The aioli and the Vermont cheddar make this sandwich give me two thumbs up  

If you're dining with a few others, I highly recommend ordering the French toast for your entire party to share. I'm not a french toast type of gal, but the mascarpone and baked apples make this dish sooooo amazing.

You'll definitely have to wait in order to be seated at Plow. If you're visiting on the weekends, get there early or you might have to wait two hours, BUT it is totally worth it.

excerpts: My dining partner ordered the two egg breakfast which includes two eggs (duh), a choice of meat (pork sausage, chicken sausage or bacon), plow potatoes and toast.
I must say, the potatoes were some of the best breakfast potatoes I've ever had.
Perfectly crispy on the outside and warm on the inside.
Another must try!
two eggs.author: Kim B.
two eggs.review:
OMG. One word -- biscuit. Seriously one of the best biscuits I've ever had in my life and I'm so glad my dining partner talked me into it. Their breakfasts come with Acme wheat sourdough bread (and I love me some sourdough toast) but the biscuit was SO GOOD!

I also tried the custard french toast. It was good but a little too decadent and rich for me. My dining partner ordered the two egg breakfast which includes two eggs (duh), a choice of meat (pork sausage, chicken sausage or bacon), plow potatoes and toast. I must say, the potatoes were some of the best breakfast potatoes I've ever had. Perfectly crispy on the outside and warm on the inside. Another must try!

excerpts: two eggs any style
(I had them over-easy), and a choice of meat.
The potatoes rock, the pancakes are fluffy, and everything else is pretty solid
two eggs.author: Yvonne C.
two eggs.review:
The breakfast here is pretty delicious, so expect a wait, unless you show up well before 8:30 AM.

I've been here twice now with friends, and have enjoyed both experiences.  The first time, I had The Plow breakfast, which comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes (crisp, and tossed with caramelized onions and rosemary), two eggs any style (I had them over-easy), and a choice of meat.  The potatoes rock, the pancakes are fluffy, and everything else is pretty solid (I had the chicken apple sausage).

The second time I came, I got the benedict.  It was alright...but I wouldn't get it again.  The poached eggs were cooked in water with way too much vinegar, so the eggs essentially tasted like vinegar to the degree that it overpowered the hollandaise sauce.  The English muffin upon which it sat was kind of soggy, either from the spinach and mushrooms, or the vinegary egg.  The potatoes were solid.  A friend of mine ordered The Plow, but with poached eggs, and also noticed the overpowering vinegar flavor of the eggs.  We also got the walnut rosemary cake, which was warm, toasty, and delicious.

Tip: get your eggs any style BUT poached, unless you like the burning acidity of vinegar for breakfast.

excerpts: It included two eggs with your choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, and two (mini) lemon ricotta pancakes with a side of yet again those delicious plow potatoes ($17.50).
two eggs.author: Brittany D.
two eggs.review:
This is definitely one of the more upscale brunch joints with average meals $15+, but to be fair, the food is excellent! They deserve to be paid top dollar for the eclectic menu. 

FOOD. My goodness, what I would give for another open-faced prosciutto and gruyere toast this morning?! This magical combo with chili, garlic egg fried up, frisee (a type of endive) and parsley atop a toasted Acme brioche ($15) was heavenly. With a side of plow potatoes, this meal leans on the carb-heavy side of the breakfast food spectrum, but I cannot complain because it was simply amazing. *I do have to warn you, however, that the egg is super runny, so consume with extreme caution* They also serve Equator drip coffee! Although not a seasoned coffee drinker myself, I do appreciate this particular brand of coffee ever since my first tasting at its home base location in Marin County. My two other classmates each ordered the plow signature dish, a tasting platter, if you will, and a good first-timer dish according to the waitress. It included two eggs with your choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, and two (mini) lemon ricotta pancakes with a side of yet again those delicious plow potatoes ($17.50). One of them also ordered fresh grapefruit juice and a warm buttermilk biscuit with honey butter (omg). 

SERVICE. 5 stars. The waitress even knew how to use an instax mini 9. She deserved bonus points for this. Tuesday morning around 10am is also the best time to come if you can. We were seated almost instantly upon arrival-- it took longer for my instax camera to produce an image on the Polaroid film. She was also very accommodating and gave great recommendations. We got pretty good seats by the window, but do be aware that since space is tight, the tables feel communal even though they're separate from each other. So if you're okay with sitting right next to the table next to you, then it should be fine. Get friendly.

I will reiterate: excellent food, excellent service. Can't wait to be back to try the other items on the menu!

excerpts: It comes with your choice of bacon or house made pork sausage, two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and potatoes.
Every element in this dish is done perfectly.
I haven't tried the bacon because their house made pork sausage is so well flavored (they put a lot of herbs inside to balance out the pork).
The lemon ricotta pancakes are softer than normal pancakes because of the ricotta and they have a nice lemon-y taste throughout.
And the POTATOES.
They are always so on point with their potatoes.
I don't know how they make the outside so crispy and the inside so soft.
These are probably the best potatoes I've ever had.
two eggs.author: Christine L.
two eggs.review:
I've visited Plow at least 3 times now. You really cannot get any better than ordering "The Plow". It comes with your choice of bacon or house made pork sausage, two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and potatoes. Every element in this dish is done perfectly. I haven't tried the bacon because their house made pork sausage is so well flavored (they put a lot of herbs inside to balance out the pork). The lemon ricotta pancakes are softer than normal pancakes because of the ricotta and they have a nice lemon-y taste throughout. And the POTATOES. They are always so on point with their potatoes. I don't know how they make the outside so crispy and the inside so soft. These are probably the best potatoes I've ever had. Their seasoning is good too.

We've tried the breakfast sandwich and the eggs benedict. They're good too but will forever be in the shadow of "The Plow".

Come early and get in with the first batch of people so you minimize your wait time. Don't fear eating outside even with the cold fog. They provide blankets.

excerpts: The Plow plate has two eggs, meat of choice, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and plow potatoes.
The eggs were perfectly over easy.
The meat was the perfect savory complement to the LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES, which were so fluffy and soft that they melted in your mouth.
You didn't even need to chew.
I'm not the biggest fan of pancakes, but I really would get a plate of just these.
Don't let their size fool you!
They are smaller, but they are really dense.
Their potatoes are garlicky and well seasoned with the perfect crisp around the edges!
two eggs.author: Sophie P.
two eggs.review:
OKAY GUYS HONESTLY, BEST BRUNCH. HANDS DOWN. 

We didn't have to wait, so I'm not sure if I would wait 2 hours for brunch, but out of all other brunch options out there Plow definitely takes the cake. The actual restaurant, ambiance, and location is nothing special, but the food here is really unique from other brunch spots.

+ THE PLOW ($17): You have to get the works if you come here. The Plow plate has two eggs, meat of choice, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and plow potatoes. The eggs were perfectly over easy. The meat was the perfect savory complement to the LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES, which were so fluffy and soft that they melted in your mouth. You didn't even need to chew. I'm not the biggest fan of pancakes, but I really would get a plate of just these. Don't let their size fool you! They are smaller, but they are really dense. Their potatoes are garlicky and well seasoned with the perfect crisp around the edges! This plate has everything you need for a full breakfast or brunch!

+ CHIA SEED PUDDING ($9.25): I also got this because I wanted to feel good about myself, and this is a solid option if you have a sensitive stomach or are not that hungry! The chia seeds are soaked in almond milk and topped with coconut, blood orange, raw almonds, bee pollen, hemp seeds, and honey. It is the perfect blend of sweet, sour, and savory. 

I normally wouldn't like to sit at the bar for brunch, but we did not regret it. The kitchen is completely open, and you see all of the chefs making each breakfast plate and it truly is a work of art! They are working nonstop, constantly cooking eggs, sausage or bacon, and dollops of pancake batter on the grill. It made our meal so much more enjoyable!

excerpts: The plow:  the plow has two eggs (any style you want), two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes or sausages (don't get the pork sausage).
This was a pretty decent size order.
However, i wasn't completely impressed by this dish because i was disappointed in the pork sausage.
it was a little too chewy for me.
The Lemon Ricotta pancakes were ok
two eggs.author: Belinda C.
two eggs.review:
Talk about the early bird gets the worm.  Well, let's apply that phrase to Plow.  We got here around 10 am and we had to wait an hour for a table.  They print a new menu everyday, so it's great to see how they change things up.  So after waiting for an hour my friend and I studied the menu inside out and already knew what we were going to order when they seated us.   So here's what we ordered

The plow:  the plow has two eggs (any style you want), two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes or sausages (don't get the pork sausage).   This was a pretty decent size order. However, i wasn't completely impressed by this dish because i was disappointed in the pork sausage. it was a little too chewy for me. The Lemon Ricotta pancakes were ok, it did have a lot of lemon flavor, but it wasn't as fluffy as i hoped for.   

Prosciutto and gruyere toast-  this dish came with potatoes.  My friend loved the potatoes, but i felt it was too dry.   We actually found a hair in this dish, but we just took it off and let it go, we waited an hour for food, we didn't want to wait anymore for it to be sent back to the kitchen.  This dish turned out pretty good.  I loved prosciutto, so anything with prosciutto is perfect. 

Overall,the service was great, next time i'll get here early so that we didn't have to wait until noon for food.  I did hear that if you have a group of 6 they can't seat you, so you have to break up your group.

excerpts: I always order the Plow, which comes with two eggs, choice of proteins, potatoes, and the lemon ricotta pancakes.
I think this is just the perfect amount of food and on the borderline of feeling bloated for me.
Seriously everything they make though is amazing, especially the pancakes.
I absolutely love lemon-y things
so it's so bomb.
I know the pancake and potato recipe is online so
two eggs.author: Janet H.
two eggs.review:
Oh, Plow... my favorite brunch spot in SF.

Even though it's my favorite, solid brunch spot, I rarely eat here because of long lines and I value my precious sleep time on weekends. No matter what, it's always at least an hour wait, unless you get here at opening (I assume).

I always order the Plow, which comes with two eggs, choice of proteins, potatoes, and the lemon ricotta pancakes. I think this is just the perfect amount of food and on the borderline of feeling bloated for me. Seriously everything they make though is amazing, especially the pancakes. I absolutely love lemon-y things so it's so bomb. I know the pancake and potato recipe is online so one day I shall make it!

Also, you know when Plow is delicious when people wait in the rain, with no overhang. That's commitment.

excerpts: I ordered the plow: two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, and chicken apple sausage.
The food came out quick and it was the perfect portion.
The potatoes were well seasoned, eggs were slurped and gone in seconds, and the pancakes were so fluffy.
Def try the pancakes because the hint of lemon got me hooked.
I typically don't like maple syrup because of how sweet and thick it is but the syrup it came with was really good.
The sausage tasted just okay tho.
two eggs.author: Ying Z.
two eggs.review:
LOVED this place!

I ordered the plow: two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, and chicken apple sausage. The food came out quick and it was the perfect portion. The potatoes were well seasoned, eggs were slurped and gone in seconds, and the pancakes were so fluffy. Def try the pancakes because the hint of lemon got me hooked. I typically don't like maple syrup because of how sweet and thick it is but the syrup it came with was really good. The sausage tasted just okay tho. It wasn't anything special. 

The wait was no joke. They gave us a 1.5 wait time at noon and we were seated close to 2pm. But the staff was nice so I can't imagine them turning people away. 

TIP: come early to avoid the long wait

excerpts: With two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes, and bacon, it was a good amount for a weekday breakfast.
two eggs.author: Yi Z.
two eggs.review:
I was so excited for my Tuesday morning breakfast at Plow that I could barely sleep the night before. See, I've had this place bookmarked on Yelp for longer than I can remember and every so often, in some obscure conversation, someone would mention how wonderful the brunch is at Plow. I'd listen with hunger and envy. I'd get motivated to try to find someone who would be willing to get up at the crack of dawn with me. And I'd be disappointed when my friends laughed at my suggestion of eating that early.

Fast forward to today, March 7, 2017. He was willing to meet me at Plow at opening time. He might be a keeper for that reason alone. When I got there, we sluggishly greeted each other; both of us were still in a sleepy daze.

We were one of the first to get seated and we browsed the many tasty options on the menu. He was a good sport about sharing The Plow with me. With two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, plow potatoes, and bacon, it was a good amount for a weekday breakfast. We also ordered the jiggly coconut mochi cake.

It was all excellent. Our eggs over easy were cooked perfectly with beautiful runny yolks. The pancakes had a fluffy texture with a bit of refreshing lemon flavor. The bacon and potatoes were crispy and flavorful. The mochi cake was sticky and filling in a great way.

I'll have to come back another day to try some other items on the menu. Next Tuesday at 7am, anyone?

excerpts: I ordered the breakfast sandwich which came with two eggs fried soft, aioli, cheddar, frisee on a acme bun.
Plow potatoes were served as a side and were fresh and mouth watering.
Bacon or avocado could also be added for an additional charge.
two eggs.author: Kassie C.
two eggs.review:
As a write this review I wish I were back in San Fran just so I could have brunch at Plow again, it was that good! A group of 6 of us visited Plow last Friday for brunch in the early afternoon. We arrived around 45 minutes before closing. We did have to wait a while but understandable with a larger group. We first sat outside but it started raining and the server was very accommodating to move of us indoors. 

As far as the brunch items, everything looked so delicious and everyone in our group loved their food. I ordered the breakfast sandwich which came with two eggs fried soft, aioli, cheddar, frisee on a acme bun. Plow potatoes were served as a side and were fresh and mouth watering. Bacon or avocado could also be added for an additional charge. We also each got a refreshing mimosa where we toasted to my friend's 30th birthday.

The food came out in a timely manner and the service was great. I highly recommend checking out this farm to table restaurant. It is a bit pricey for brunch (around $200 before tip for 6 people) but we all agreed it was well worth it!!

If ever in the San Fran area again, I will be sure to stop here again!!

excerpts: The dish comes with two eggs with choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes.
I asked for scrambled eggs (which is a rarity for me) and bacon.
two eggs.author: Lisa N.
two eggs.review:
What a cute little place for breakfast/brunch. There are hooks along the wall for your coats/bags.

I was forewarned about how long the wait can be, so I planned to come here on a Monday morning during my visit. We showed up not long after they opened and were seated right away. 

I was debating between the Plow, the Dungeness crab scramble, and the open-faced prosciutto + Gruyere toast. But since I was intrigued by the lemon ricotta pancakes, I opted for the Plow.

The dish comes with two eggs with choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes. I asked for scrambled eggs (which is a rarity for me) and bacon. Every element of the dish was really good, the potatoes were very crispy on the outside, and the pancakes had a nice balance of flavors.

Service seemed a bit slow, but I'll just give them the benefit of the doubt that it was busy. It certainly seemed busy, but I noticed the servers standing around and inattentive numerous times throughout our meal.

Overall, I would recommend this place for the food. Service wasn't terrible, but it wasn't fantastic either. Granted, it was early on a Monday morning. If I find my way back to this spot during a future visit, I'll definitely try one of the other dishes that intrigued me.

excerpts: Two eggs, house made pork sausage patties, lemon ricotta pancakes and plow potatoes.
Not sure what to get?
Get this one!
It has everything!
The pork sausage patties was although not quite what I expected, was good.
It tasted healthier than your normal diner pork sausage patty--looks like there are veggies in the mix
and it's not as salty.
I liked it!
The potatoes was probable the main reason why I got this.
It's all so crispy and yummy!
I can have a bowl of this in its own.
As for the lemon ricotta pancakes to fulfill that sweet side, it was great.
two eggs.author: Tu-Anh N.
two eggs.review:
On an early Sunday morning, we came here around 8:30am.  We were told that for a party of 2, it would be a little over an hour wait. And they were right! We got seated outside at 9:45am.  They have blankets if your cold!  What did we do to wait? Walk around! Plow is located in a quaint area with other small shops and cafes to walk by.  Get that walk in so you can fill that belly!

Here's what we had:

Five Mountains organic tea - $4.75
Rolled Jasmine Green
It's tea. Warm. It was cold out so it was fitting. :)

BUTTERMILK BISCUIT - $4.50
This hunk of biscuit was served with a side of honey butter, that was sweet and yummy.  The biscuit itself is shareable and fluffy. I really enjoyed it!

BROWN BUTTER COCONUT MOCHI CAKE - $4.25
This dessert was delicious! Order quick before they run out!  would never expect a mochi cake here!  There's a layer in There that tasted quite custardy.  I recommend getting this even if your full; have it to go!  

FRENCH TOAST - $13  
Brown sugar caramelized apples, blood, mascarpone, pure Vermont maple syrup.
Depending on the season, the fruit may change.  This French toast was amazing.  It was so creamy and you definitely taste quality in every bite. Get it!

THE PLOW - $17 
Two eggs, house made pork sausage patties, lemon ricotta pancakes and plow potatoes.
Not sure what to get? Get this one! It has everything!  The pork sausage patties was although not quite what I expected, was good.  It tasted healthier than your normal diner pork sausage patty--looks like there are veggies in the mix and it's not as salty.  I liked it!  The potatoes was probable the main reason why I got this.  It's all so crispy and yummy!  I can have a bowl of this in its own.  As for the lemon ricotta pancakes to fulfill that sweet side, it was great.  I liked the small portion and the flavors were subtle and wonderful.    

I enjoyed everything here. I can see why it's so popular and I was not annoyed with the wait.  Our server was friendly.  It started to right as we were leaving so freat timing! Don't worry they have a thing they roll out to cover you from getting wet. :)

excerpts:
It comes with two eggs, their famous potatoes, choice of brekky meat and two lemon ricotta pancakes.

The lemon ricotta pancakes were also amazing- light and fluffy and melt in your mouth delicious.
two eggs.author: Elliott W.
two eggs.review:
Pro tip: If you can, go early during a week day. You'll likely get seated without waiting + there will be plenty of time to eat before you need to be at work.

I trekked over from the Mission (dang, those hills will get ya!) early Thursday morning with the boy and got there right at 7 when they open. We were seated right away and then had the difficult time of figuring out what to order.

I'm pretty sure EVERYTHING would be amazing on the menu, and I'm really bummed that I couldn't justify ordering one of everything. The best option in my opinion is getting "the Plow" which satisfies a lot of different tastes. It comes with two eggs, their famous potatoes, choice of brekky meat and two lemon ricotta pancakes.

Guys, their potatoes. I don't know how to do them justice. They are the most crispy delicious things on the planet, and perfectly salted/seasoned as well. I wish I had a mountain of these.

The lemon ricotta pancakes were also amazing- light and fluffy and melt in your mouth delicious.

I really don't think there's a bad option on the menu; it's more of timing your visit right so that you don't get hangry while you wait!

excerpts: Wife got the Plow two eggs and lemon pancakes
and She finished her plate and not normal for her as for the kids
one got the breakfast sandwich and the other got the almond pancakes.

two eggs.review:
Simple menu and full with flavors and chef magic.
I got the chicken sandwich and it worth the wait. Guess what even the kids their nagging changes to plate licking and wow dad thx. Wife got the Plow two eggs and lemon pancakes and She finished her plate and not normal for her as for the kids one got the breakfast sandwich and the other got the almond pancakes.

excerpts: We both ordered "the plow" which came with 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, potatos, two eggs, and your choice of sausage patties, bacon, or chicken apple sausage!
two eggs.author: Alyssa C.
two eggs.review:
Finally got to try this place out... ive had this place bookmarked for a couple years!! Went here for brunch with my bff yesterday we both really enjoyed it here! We both ordered "the plow" which came with 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, potatos, two eggs, and your choice of sausage patties, bacon, or chicken apple sausage! We also got a glass of mimosas which were super refreshing! 

Overall I had a great experience here, it has such a cute ambiance, service was great and the servers were fast. One of the workers even refilled our glasses with more champagne towards the end and offered to take our picture! Definitely coming back!

excerpts: My friend and I shared the breakfast sandwich, which is two eggs fried soft, aioli, cheddar, Acme bread, frisee and of course we added avocado.
The aioli really made the sandwich tasty and they give a lot of avocado!
This entree also came with plow potatoes which are fried, so the texture is crispier than most breakfast potatoes.
I actually forgot to take a picture of my own food but took pictures of everyone else's food...
two eggs.author: Samantha C.
two eggs.review:
A light, delicate, won't leave you feeling stuffed, breakfast place!

Came on a Saturday around 10 and the wait was an hour and a half, but the actual wait was only 45 minutes. 

My friend and I shared the breakfast sandwich, which is two eggs fried soft, aioli, cheddar, Acme bread, frisee and of course we added avocado. The aioli really made the sandwich tasty and they give a lot of avocado! This entree also came with plow potatoes which are fried, so the texture is crispier than most breakfast potatoes. I actually forgot to take a picture of my own food but took pictures of everyone else's food... I must have been too excited to eat. 

I also got to try the chia seed pudding, which was light and delicious! The peaches they used were SUPER sweet and the pudding had a eccentric texture with all those chia seeds incorporated. 

Another preference is that most of my friends preferred the chicken apple sausages over the bacon, if you're ordering the plow, which is what they're named after.

excerpts: Ordered summer succotash and really what you get is 3 beans with some bit of other veg swimming in water and two eggs on top.
Just not wowed considering it's $17!
Other dishes looked more impressive but I feel I've been ripped off.

the plow  - two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes

two eggs.author: Charlton C.
two eggs.review:
Don't think I've ever waited this long for brunch before which was shy of just 2 hours! Was it worth the wait? Find out in my review below. 

This restaurant is located in corner of an intersection. There is a steep hill right next to it, we parked on top of that hill which turned out to be quite the walk.  
Here is what we ordered: 

the plow  - two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes

The lemon ricotta pancakes here were the highlight here, small and fluffy and just the perfect ratio of lemon flavor mixed it. The plow potatoes were quite good too, crunchy and complements the rest of the breakfast plate. Be sure to mix it with the egg yolk for maximum yumminess! 

Beef Hash Skillet - two eggs, beef hash 
Pretty standard here, had better ones 

Overall the food was as expected it to be, I think the reason why the wait times were so long is because the restaurant is so small and cannot accommodate more than let's say 20-30 people at a time. 

The good thing about this place is that parking is easy to find since it is in a neighborhood. All in all, it is a good spot for brunch to cross of the list and onto the next one when I come back to visit!

excerpts: Comes with everything, two eggs, choice of protein, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes.
two eggs.author: Sandy B.
two eggs.review:
Finally got my seat at plow this passed Saturday. Been waiting to come here for awhile. The week before I got to plow at 11:30am and it was a 2.5 hour wait for a party of 3. We couldn't wait because we were hungry. Came back this Saturday at 10:30am and it was 1.5 - 2 hour wait for a party of 2. WOW!!! I know, the wait is crazy long. Instead of just waiting outside, my friend and I decided to get coffee 2 blocks away to kill time. Also you can order coffee, drinks and baked goods from Plow as you wait for your table. 

It was slightly over 1.5 hour wait and got a seat at the counter. We ordered **Equator coffee $3.75. Unlimited refills. We started with their **Hong Kong style toast  buttered brioche + sweetened condensed milk. I was super excited because its been forever since I had condensed milk. The brioche we had was super dry. Was a bit disappointed with that. We had one piece and let the milk soak in to soften up the brioche. My friend had their famous **"The Plow". Comes with everything, two eggs, choice of protein, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes. She got the house made pork sausage patties. I thought it was super yummy. I got to try everything she had. I really like their triple fried plow potatoes. Must have!! I got their special **Cornbeef hash on poached eggs. I really like it. Wasn't too heavy. This dish is smaller in portion size but I thought it was perfect for me. 

Not my favorite in the city but it has became my TOP 5 BRUNCH in SF. Service was good, staff was friendly, especially the chefs.

excerpts: I was in the mood for a bit of everything that day, so I decided to order the restaurant's namesake, The Plow, which is an all in one dish that consists of two eggs served in any style, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and a choice of pork, bacon, or chicken apple sausage.
The standouts of the dish were the crispy potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes.
The potatoes were so expertly seasoned and full of flavor -- they could quite easily be some of the best potatoes I've ever had.
The standouts of the dish were the crispy potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes.
The potatoes were so expertly seasoned and full of flavor -- they could quite easily be some of the best potatoes I've ever had.
And those lemon ricotta pancakes were out of this world!
The lemon is very present in the pancakes and is balanced nicely by the ricotta, and the syrup with the pancakes added a nice sweetness that wasn't overbearing.
The pancakes were light and fluffy and don't sit heavy in your stomach.
In general, the neighborhood where The Plow is located is really lovely and has a stunning view of the city skyline, so even if the wait is long, the environment is inviting.
I'm putting The Plow on my list of brunch places to return to, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an exciting brunch spot!
two eggs.author: Pooja M.
two eggs.review:
I came for brunch and stayed for Kanye.

If you want to feel pumped up and ready to party while you enjoy your delicious brunch, Plow is definitely the place to be in the city. 

The restaurant is small, but the vibe is 'popping' as the staff is all super friendly and fun and the music blasting through the restaurant will get you grooving in your seat (or up and about the restaurant if you're brave enough). 

I was in the mood for a bit of everything that day, so I decided to order the restaurant's namesake, The Plow, which is an all in one dish that consists of two eggs served in any style, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and a choice of pork, bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I asked for my eggs poached and I substituted a salad for the meat options.

The eggs were perfectly poached, but had no seasoning to them otherwise, and the salad was fresh and crispy, but again, bland. The standouts of the dish were the crispy potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes. The potatoes were so expertly seasoned and full of flavor -- they could quite easily be some of the best potatoes I've ever had. And those lemon ricotta pancakes were out of this world! The lemon is very present in the pancakes and is balanced nicely by the ricotta, and the syrup with the pancakes added a nice sweetness that wasn't overbearing. The pancakes were light and fluffy and don't sit heavy in your stomach. I'll definitely be coming back for those pancakes!

Something to keep in mind: Plow is one of the most popular brunch restaurants in SF, so expect a long wait time (at least 1.5 hours) on the weekend. However, if you're a brunch queen like me who's trying to catch 'em all, you are an expert on surviving the brunch hunger pains and boredom of long wait times, and having to wait no longer affects you. 

If you are not on a brunch quest like I am and you are willing to endure the long wait, bring a friend to keep you company, eat something light beforehand, and try to come as close to opening hours as you can, and you'll be brunching down in no time.

There is a lovely cafe across the street called Farley's that has plenty of indoor and outdoor seating and serves tea and light pastries where you can keep yourself from starving as you wait to be called. In general, the neighborhood where The Plow is located is really lovely and has a stunning view of the city skyline, so even if the wait is long, the environment is inviting. 

I'm putting The Plow on my list of brunch places to return to, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an exciting brunch spot!

excerpts: The Plow included two eggs, a choice of meat (bacon/sausage), two lemon ricotta pancakes, and potato.
While most of that dish tasted like any other breakfast place, the pancakes were a surprise to us.
We both really like the pancakes because they were so fluffy and soft and I love the slight lemon taste in them.
We had really wanted to try the Hong Kong style toast but our server told us they didn't have that or the custard
French toast or the prosciutto toast.

zZZzZzzz

two eggs.review:
My friend and I got to Plow at 6:45 in the morning because we thought there were gonna be a lot of people after reading the other Yelp reviews. However, we realized that was WAY too early since there was no one around. We suggest people to come at exactly 7 during the weekdays. The restaurant quickly got busy after it opened and there was a line around 7:25.

For the food, we ordered the Plow ($17) and the Two Egg Breakfast ($15.75). The Plow included two eggs, a choice of meat (bacon/sausage), two lemon ricotta pancakes, and potato. We had really wanted to try the Hong Kong style toast but our server told us they didn't have that or the custard French toast or the prosciutto toast. I guess we must have picked a bad morning.
