She told us it would take 45 min before we were seated (we had 3 people and said we were fine sitting outside). I can imagine the long wait time for being seated since the venue is small, and the outside seating only had a few tables as well. When we checked in to see what our position in line was, it turned out that they already called us (though we missed it), but they told us we were next in line to be seated outside. So in total, our wait time was about an hour. Since it was a bit chilly, they offered blankets while we ate, which was a nice touch. The service was efficient and attentive. My friends really love biscuits so she ordered a biscuit as an appetizer and it was warm and delicious. I ordered The Plow, since it had a little bit of everything. It comes with 2 eggs, a choice of meat (I got the housemade pork sausage, potatoes, and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes. Although the items seemed small on the plate, it filled me up. The eggs were fluffy (I got them scrambled), the meat was a little dry but well seasoned, the potatoes were nice and crispy, and the pancakes were amazing and lemon-y. Overall, the food was amazing, though the wait time is a bit of a downer but there's plenty of places to walk around to while you wait, and if you're in the company of great friends, the wait time is no problem at all!

excerpts:
THE PLOW:
effffinggg AMAZING.
the plow.author: Mae Louise L.
the plow.review:
HOLY SHIT!!! I came here visiting from Los Angeles & let me tell you, Plow was the highlight of our trip! All around BOMB brunch. Everything was amazing. I came at 9 AM on a Friday. (Black Friday to be exact) For a table for 4 we were quoted 1-1.5 hours and we were definitely turned off at first.. but then after failing to find a bar open that early to kill time while we waited, we came back at 9:30 to find out that all the other parties got discouraged by the quote time and left meaning we got sat after only a 30 minute wait! yay~! (So try to stick around despite being quoted a long time AND try to come early!) We got seated outside & it was a bit chilly but they offer blankets for every seat! Kudos.

I forget who our server was, but she was very down to earth and nice despite it being quite busy. NOW on to the important part: THE FOOD.

THE PLOW:
effffinggg AMAZING.

Lemon Ricotta Pancake? Small, but amazing. Fluffy and perfect flavor. Sad that I didn't try the other ones cuz they sounded just as appetizing.

House-made Sausage? Really good (recommended by server.) However, my friend got the apple something chicken sausage and THAT was astronomical. I'd say go for that one cuz that blew our minds.

Fried Potatoes? Best I've ever had, hands down. Perfect thin crisp on the outside. Seasoning just perfect, not overly salted with the perfect amount of rosemary coming through. Inside nice and soft, perfectly boiled. 

Soft Scrambled Eggs? This is how they do their eggs and boy do they do it gooooooood.

We also got the honey butter biscuit which was big and yummy. (though I have had better biscuits) BUT to be fair this was more scone-like and we did thoroughly enjoy them.

My only regret is not getting the other pancakes or the prosciutto and gruyere (because I had another reservation elsewhere for lunch right after.)

Plow, I will be dreaming of you until I get a chance to return.

Cheers to the team at Plow! You deserve more praise!!!

excerpts: Ordered up the Plow (number one seller) with Lemon Ricotta Pancakes
plus I went ahead and added bacon on the side even though the plate comes with sausages and potatoes.
the plow.author: John M.
the plow.review:
Visited her with the girlfriend the other morning for a quick bite before work (around 0800), no wait, plenty of tables, and great service. I was surprised that there was no wait, so if you're looking to beat the crowds I'd say show up early or prepare to sit outside in the cold.

Ordered up the Plow (number one seller) with Lemon Ricotta Pancakes plus I went ahead and added bacon on the side even though the plate comes with sausages and potatoes. Also ordered one of their famous biscuits which I did finish. 

The potatoes from Plow were featured on 7x7's best things/places to eat in San Francisco a few years back and I can understand why. Roasted and cooked to perfection, seasoned just right and the perfect compliment to the pancakes. I enjoyed the meal very much with the potatoes and biscuit being my favorite. It's a large biscuit so if you're not planning on eating it all or sharing, I'd say order it to go.

excerpts: I always end up ordering the Plow in order to grab a bite of their pancakes but also have their house made sausage patties and amazing potatoes.
I've waited a very long time in the past which of course impacts the overall experience here, so I do recommend visiting at a more unusual time if possibly instead of peak weekend brunch hours.
the plow.author: Kellyn W.
the plow.review:
Popped in by myself on a Monday morning ~8:45AM and was able to immediately grab one of the empty counter seats. Service was prompt and friendly with the staff offering a lint brush to me after seeing me absentmindedly brushing off lint from the white napkin in my black pants. 

Food was excellent per usual! I always end up ordering the Plow in order to grab a bite of their pancakes but also have their house made sausage patties and amazing potatoes. I've waited a very long time in the past which of course impacts the overall experience here, so I do recommend visiting at a more unusual time if possibly instead of peak weekend brunch hours.

excerpts: Another preference is that most of my friends preferred the chicken apple sausages over the bacon, if you're ordering the plow, which is what they're named after.
the plow.author: Samantha C.
the plow.review:
A light, delicate, won't leave you feeling stuffed, breakfast place!

Came on a Saturday around 10 and the wait was an hour and a half, but the actual wait was only 45 minutes. 

My friend and I shared the breakfast sandwich, which is two eggs fried soft, aioli, cheddar, Acme bread, frisee and of course we added avocado. The aioli really made the sandwich tasty and they give a lot of avocado! This entree also came with plow potatoes which are fried, so the texture is crispier than most breakfast potatoes. I actually forgot to take a picture of my own food but took pictures of everyone else's food... I must have been too excited to eat. 

I also got to try the chia seed pudding, which was light and delicious! The peaches they used were SUPER sweet and the pudding had a eccentric texture with all those chia seeds incorporated. 

Another preference is that most of my friends preferred the chicken apple sausages over the bacon, if you're ordering the plow, which is what they're named after.

excerpts: I got the plow.
This was your standard full breakfast with some incredibly nice twists.
I chose the bacon, which was very much not standard.
It was incredibly smokey and full of flavor.
Never had this type of bacon before, and it was awesome.
Eggs - standard.
Potatoes were quite good.
Slightly crispy, soft and warm on the inside.
Seasoned with several herbs.
I personally enjoy eating this with the egg yolks, but that is up to you.
They are a bit on the smaller side with ordered with the plow, but that's because you wouldn't be able to finish it all if they were larger.
the plow.author: Bryant C.
the plow.review:
There's a reason there is a 45 minute wait for this place on a weekday for brunch: it's really good. There's coffee while you wait on this corner with nice little benches all over the place.

I got the plow. This was your standard full breakfast with some incredibly nice twists. I chose the bacon, which was very much not standard. It was incredibly smokey and full of flavor. Never had this type of bacon before, and it was awesome. Eggs - standard. Potatoes were quite good. Slightly crispy, soft and warm on the inside. Seasoned with several herbs. I personally enjoy eating this with the egg yolks, but that is up to you. Lemon ricotta pancakes are as good as everyone says they are. Light, fluffy, and flavors everywhere. Lemony to match the fluffiness, and the ricotta there to give it that extra bite. Man these were good. I was also able to taste the almond pancakes which were good, but the lemon ricotta is king. They are a bit on the smaller side with ordered with the plow, but that's because you wouldn't be able to finish it all if they were larger. 

Service is great. We sat outside on this nice day, but it was quite nice. Highly recommend this place. Would come back if I'm in the city early enough to not get too hungry waiting in line.

excerpts: We ended up ordering THE PLOW and the Apple Cinnamon loaf as well as a kids meal.
There was more than enough food for everyone.
the plow.author: Farah M.
the plow.review:
My party arrived about 10 minutes prior to opening on a Saturday morning and whooo-wheee, there was already a line with 8-10 parties ahead of us. I lost count because it seems one person would stand in line and people who arrived later would come in and out. We put our name down and they told us it would be about 45 minutes to an hour wait. 

My group of 3 didn't mind, it was the first time for my SO and munchkin to be in SF so we decided to wander the streets and enjoy the architecture and the quiet of this area before it became a bustling area. Once we arrived back about 30 minutes later, we waited around and chatted with some other families who recommended some places for us to check out as well as dishes to try here at Plow. We ended up ordering THE PLOW and the Apple Cinnamon loaf as well as a kids meal. There was more than enough food for everyone. It was a SOLID breakfast. 

The only reason I'm not giving it a higher review is for the customer service and the wait time for the food on top of the wait time to take a seat. I'm not sure if it's because it's super busy or if they didn't have enough servers, it was difficult to flag someone down for more coffee or even the check. As for the food, we placed our order as soon as we sat down and still waited an additional 20-30 minutes for our food to appear.

excerpts: It's tempting to opt for The Plow and get your classic American breakfast fix, but the rest of the menu is just so good.
the plow.author: Roshni B.
the plow.review:
Totally worth the wait - as long as you order the right things. It's tempting to opt for The Plow and get your classic American breakfast fix, but the rest of the menu is just so good. 

My friend and I arrived at 8:10am on Sunday and waited about an hour for a table inside. They offer blankets if you are ok with sitting outside, but we didn't mind waiting the extra 15 min or so on top of the overall wait time to be warm. Everything on the menu sounded delicious - we decided on the buttermilk biscuit, crab scramble, breakfast sandwich with avocado, lemon ricotta pancakes, a side of bacon and mimosas. 

We couldn't decide which item we liked most because it was all just so good. The biscuit was just perfection and a great item to share as an appetizer. The scramble and sandwich were perfect as entrees and the order of pancakes were a great idea to share so you get both savory and sweet. 

At the end of the meal we both agreed that the wait was worth it. I think you just have to be mentally ready for it and you'll be fine.

excerpts: : The Plow - comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, choice of sausage meats, eggs, and potatoes (I would highly recommend subbing the potatoes for fruit - you get fresh mango, berries, grapefruit super unique for a brunch place), the Chinese breakfast (pork shoulder with some spicy sauce), and others.
the plow.author: Kunal T.
the plow.review:
I felt #basic one day so I walked in wanting to try it with few of my coworkers. I would value this brunch place at a max wait of 45 minutes - usually on weekends it could be a 1.5-2 hour wait.

Things I would recommend: The Plow - comes with lemon ricotta pancakes, choice of sausage meats, eggs, and potatoes (I would highly recommend subbing the potatoes for fruit - you get fresh mango, berries, grapefruit super unique for a brunch place), the Chinese breakfast (pork shoulder with some spicy sauce), and others.

In terms of drinks the grapefruit mimosa has a fresh fruit and is pretty strong (if you're trying to have a turnt up day then go for it). 

Service is good. Comparable to Mission beach cafe, Sweet Maple, and all those other brunch giants.

excerpts:
We ordered a coconut mochi cake, The Plow, breakfast sandwich and French toast. 

The plow had lemon ricotta pancakes which were probably the highlight of that dish.
the plow.author: Rohenne L.
the plow.review:
Good? Yeah sure. Worth the weekend wait? Unfortunately not.

I was super excited to finally come to plow, I plowed myself out of bed at 7am just to make it to plow by 7:55am right before opening. At that point, there was already a long line! Omg, crazy! (It must be amazing for everyone to be lining up like they line up for new iphone releases). We didn't make it to the first seating, so ended up going to a near by coffee shop to wait for 30min, came back and there was an available table for us. Woohoo.

The staff, though super busy was attentive and very friendly. We ordered a coconut mochi cake, The Plow, breakfast sandwich and French toast. 

My favorite was probably the mochi cake and everything else was pretty good but nothing mind blowing. The French toast and breakfast sandwich were both decent but the way it's made feels like you can do it yourself at home. The plow had lemon ricotta pancakes which were probably the highlight of that dish. 

Coffee was subpar :(, id just get coffee next door. 

Overall, good experience and if there weren't a line, I'd definitely go more often since it is that comfort brunch food that you'd want on a Sunday morning. 

I've heard from others that their weekday lunch menu is better and dishes are more special, maybe that's what I'm missing from this review. I'll have to try it again on a weekday.

excerpts: The three of us decided to get the Plow with homemade sausage (recommended by our waitress), dungeness crab scramble and prosciutto gruyere egg toast.
We have also ordered a side of the hk style toast (as a person from hk
the plow.author: Louisa L.
the plow.review:
I finally made it to Plow!

My girl friend had been telling me that I have to try the lemon ricotta pancake at Plow - as a person who's not a fan of pancake, it has to be really good pancake to "wow" me - and Plow did it!

It was a rainy Friday and I got there a little past noon. Because of the rain there was a uniform line waiting outside the door. At first I thought we just line up to get in, but then I figured out you have to tell them your name so you will be on the wait list. Luckily it didn't take me long enough to find out, or else I won't be eating there!

I waited for almost an hour for 3 people. I have to say it's a bit crazy especially it's on a week day. Menu was simple - a variety of brunch items. The three of us decided to get the Plow with homemade sausage (recommended by our waitress), dungeness crab scramble and prosciutto gruyere egg toast. We have also ordered a side of the hk style toast (as a person from hk I felt obligated to order that lol~).

Food came out pretty fast. I got to try everything (except the meat) and everything was so good! Pancake was so good that we ended up ordering an extra side of it. I like how the hk style toast was burnt, which brought out the flavor of the toast and matched perfectly with the condensed milk. And the potatoes! I usually left out the potatoes on brunch dishes but I got to say Plow made some really good potatoes. 

It's hard to say if I ever gonna go back since there are still a lot of brunch places to try out in the city. But if you haven't been to Plow yet, make sure to put them on your to go list!

excerpts: The Plow is famous for their brunch and notorious for the wait, which is usually at least an hour on weekends.
TL;DR is it worth the wait?
The menu is always changing, with some staples such as the plow, the breakfast sandwich, some type of French toast, and the buttermilk biscuit.
It seemed like some of the specialties could be hit-or-miss (I saw someone next to me get something that looked fancy but small.)
I'm also usually a fan of French toast, but in a lot of pictures it was surprisingly burnt here.
The Plow plate is the epitome of perfection on classic brunch items.
In fact, I was almost going to pass on Plow because it seemed so commonplace, yet so professionally crafted.
It seemed as if so much thought had been put into every detail, you could perform mindful eating with your otherwise mundane sausage/bacon, eggs, potatoes, and pancakes.
the plow.author: Edna C.
the plow.review:
Plow sure does plow a hole in my wallet! 

The Plow is famous for their brunch and notorious for the wait, which is usually at least an hour on weekends. TL;DR is it worth the wait? No, it's not worth the horrendous weekend wait; however, it is worth the hassles of going early on a weekday. 

The menu is always changing, with some staples such as the plow, the breakfast sandwich, some type of French toast, and the buttermilk biscuit. It seemed like some of the specialties could be hit-or-miss (I saw someone next to me get something that looked fancy but small.) I'm also usually a fan of French toast, but in a lot of pictures it was surprisingly burnt here. Thus, I went with their signature plow. 

The Plow plate is the epitome of perfection on classic brunch items. In fact, I was almost going to pass on Plow because it seemed so commonplace, yet so professionally crafted. It seemed as if so much thought had been put into every detail, you could perform mindful eating with your otherwise mundane sausage/bacon, eggs, potatoes, and pancakes. My thoughts:

1. Lemon ricotta pancakes - the most memorable! Soft and fluffy (albeit a bit burnt), with a refreshing lemon zest balanced by an attenuated sweetness and a touch of creamy ricotta.
2. House made sausage - a close second. The patties were wonderfully juicy without being too greasy, and I especially liked the extra dimension from the boldly heavy use of pepper and caraway. 
3. Potatoes - quite a bit of hype, but I found it to be just okay. It did have a nice crisp and aromatic tones from the rosemary, though I found the outer crunchy coating too thick, causing the potatoes to be too dry.
4. Eggs - Scrambled eggs pretty on point. The texture, consistency, and taste were all well executed. It used less butter than some of the more indulgent scrambles I've had, making it a lighter version.

I had expected portions to be bigger for the $17 pricetag on the bouge equivalent of a McDonald's big breakfast. If you eat it slowly, you'll enjoy it more and it the portion size turns turns out to lie within the narrow window of satisfaction without a debilitating food coma. Plow was memorable, delicious, and Instagram-worthy, but for a total of over $20 for a breakfasty plate, I don't think it's worthwhile to return after the one-time dining experience to cross it off my bucket list.

I arrived just after 7am on a weekday, and by the time I left around 8am the place was nearly full o_O Sometimes I feel like SF brunch is a encephalopathic pandemic.

excerpts: Ended up sharing the cold-smoked salmon toast & the signature dish here called the Plow.
First impressions here are nothing but positive.
In regards to the cold-smoked salmon toast, the salmon this joint uses is really as tender, yummy, and pleasant to taste as I've ever had.
Never realized how good farm-raised salmon could be ... something for me to remember for next time.
As for the Plow, I loved the potatoes because of the seasoning that the chefs use on it, which is most stellar & left my mouth most happy.
the plow.author: Jack M.
the plow.review: Came here with Mom at a friend's suggestion for brunch. Seating is available both indoors & outdoors, although it will likely be a longer wait for seats indoors. Ended up sharing the cold-smoked salmon toast & the signature dish here called the Plow. First impressions here are nothing but positive. In regards to the cold-smoked salmon toast, the salmon this joint uses is really as tender, yummy, and pleasant to taste as I've ever had. Never realized how good farm-raised salmon could be ... something for me to remember for next time. The combination with farmer's cheese, pickled red onion, caper, dill, Acme levain, and simple green salad served only to complement the dish even better. As for the Plow, I loved the potatoes because of the seasoning that the chefs use on it, which is most stellar & left my mouth most happy. The lemon ricotta pancakes were just as soft, moist, and their tartiness was just perfect & not too overpowering. Eggs & sausage were also done well. Overall, a most pleasant place to come for brunch & I would definitely recommend it to others. Don't be surprised if there is a wait (there usually is).

excerpts: I had the plow, which I think it's perfect because it has the ricotta pancakes, homemade sausage, eggs, and the best effing potatoes I've ever eaten!
the plow.author: Vy T.
the plow.review:
Came early on a Saturday morning and there was a wait but it wasn't too bad. I had the plow, which I think it's perfect because it has the ricotta pancakes, homemade sausage, eggs, and the best effing potatoes I've ever eaten! It's the best plate if you're indecisive  like me. 

The pancakes were fluffy and small, with a zesty lemon flavor. I thought the homemade sausage was kind of dry, but you do have your options of bacon as well. Now to the star of the plate, the crispy potatoes. Not sure what they cook it in, but it was so addicting!! It's hands down the best potatoes I've ever had, and is a must get!

excerpts:
Here is what we ordered: 

the plow  - two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes
The lemon ricotta pancakes here were the highlight here, small and fluffy and just the perfect ratio of lemon flavor mixed it.
The plow potatoes were quite good too, crunchy and complements the rest of the breakfast plate.

Beef Hash Skillet - two eggs, beef hash 
Pretty standard here, had better ones 

Overall the food was as expected it to be
the plow.author: Charlton C.
the plow.review:
Don't think I've ever waited this long for brunch before which was shy of just 2 hours! Was it worth the wait? Find out in my review below. 

This restaurant is located in corner of an intersection. There is a steep hill right next to it, we parked on top of that hill which turned out to be quite the walk.  
Here is what we ordered: 

the plow  - two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes

The lemon ricotta pancakes here were the highlight here, small and fluffy and just the perfect ratio of lemon flavor mixed it. The plow potatoes were quite good too, crunchy and complements the rest of the breakfast plate. Be sure to mix it with the egg yolk for maximum yumminess! 

Beef Hash Skillet - two eggs, beef hash 
Pretty standard here, had better ones 

Overall the food was as expected it to be, I think the reason why the wait times were so long is because the restaurant is so small and cannot accommodate more than let's say 20-30 people at a time. 

The good thing about this place is that parking is easy to find since it is in a neighborhood. All in all, it is a good spot for brunch to cross of the list and onto the next one when I come back to visit!

excerpts: I had the plow.
the plow.author: M T.
the plow.review:
All the food was tasty. If you put your name down, go get a coffee, bring a snack and catch up with friends during the wait, then, the wait doesn't seem horrendous. If I was coming truly just for food because I was hungry, though, it is pretty absurd. I think the best strategy to minimize wait time on a weekend is to go right before 2pm. There will still be a wait, but most people are going to think they are closing. They do a final wait list call at 2pm (so you have to be present), but if you are there, you will be seated. 

Food came out fast once you are seated and order. I had the plow. Love the lemon ricotta pancakes, and potatoes were deliciously prepared. House made sausage was eh...I would get the bacon instead.

excerpts: I often choose the Plow, which is eggs, those devilishly good crispy potatoes, choice of meat (try the new-ish bacon confit, which is basically   a roasted piece of pork belly -- so yummy!), and a couple of those luscious mini lemon ricotta pancakes.
It really is way too much food for one meal, so you might try my trick of eating no more than half of each item and taking the rest with me.

I also love the french toast, which I had on today's visit, along with a side of that irresistible bacon confit (I just have to remember to rescue the remainder from the office fridge later today...).
The dungeness scramble is also very good, with eggs that are cooked just a tolerable bit past runny.
the plow.author: Teresa D.
the plow.review:
Every couple of weeks or so I sneak in here at 7 a.m. for a solo pre-work breakfast feast at the counter, and have never been disappointed with the food. I often choose the Plow, which is eggs, those devilishly good crispy potatoes, choice of meat (try the new-ish bacon confit, which is basically   a roasted piece of pork belly -- so yummy!), and a couple of those luscious mini lemon ricotta pancakes. It really is way too much food for one meal, so you might try my trick of eating no more than half of each item and taking the rest with me. I also love the french toast, which I had on today's visit, along with a side of that irresistible bacon confit (I just have to remember to rescue the remainder from the office fridge later today...). The dungeness scramble is also very good, with eggs that are cooked just a tolerable bit past runny. I'm freaked out by gross undercooked eggs, so this works for me.

The only down side for me is the coffee, which is a very bitter roast. I know that a lot of people seem to favor that over-roasted, super-bitter thing, but I'm not one of them. Give me a bitter cocktail any day (please!), but you can keep the bitter coffee. Really, I don't expect such a small kitchen to keep more than one type of roast on hand, so I do understand they have to pick something that a lot of people like. 

I've found the service to be attentive and oblivious at the same time. I'm pretty sure I was the very first person to put in my order this morning, but I saw a lot of food come out of the kitchen headed to tables that hadn't even settled on the menu before my order went in. When my food finally arrived about 16 minutes later, it didn't include the bacon confit side -- that was another 8 to 10 minutes in coming. None of this is a big deal if the server addresses the delay with a cheerful explanation, showing the customer that they haven't been forgotten. My server didn't say anything about any of it. Pretty disappointing. 

But make no mistake: this is a very good place. I don't think I'd try it on a weekend since I hear the wait is way over the top.

excerpts: although everyone recommended The Plow which comes with eggs, sausage, potatoes, and pancakes, I knew that would be too much food for me
so I just planned on getting them as a side order.
However, my friend said I could just take one of her pancakes
so I did that instead and ordered the Coconut Chia Seed Pudding which came with seasonal fruit, bee pollen, and honey.
The chia pudding was delicious and light and the pancake was probably the best lemon ricotta pancake I've ever tasted.
the plow.author: Jessica N.
the plow.review:
3 words: Lemon Ricotta Pancakes!!

I came here one morning with a friend alll the way from Castro Valley just to try Plow. It's been on my Yelp bookmarks for soo long! The wait was about 30 minutes once I put my name down. The indoor seating is a little limited and crowded; my friend and I were seated outside. Good thing it was a nice day out in SF. Not too cold and or too windy. 

I knew I wanted to order their Lemon Ricotta Pancakes for sure and although everyone recommended The Plow which comes with eggs, sausage, potatoes, and pancakes, I knew that would be too much food for me so I just planned on getting them as a side order. However, my friend said I could just take one of her pancakes so I did that instead and ordered the Coconut Chia Seed Pudding which came with seasonal fruit, bee pollen, and honey. The chia pudding was delicious and light and the pancake was probably the best lemon ricotta pancake I've ever tasted. It was super fluffy and you could actually taste the lemon! 

I would definitely recommend Plow to a friend or anyone looking for a nice brunch place in SF. And I would definitely recommend those pancakes! I'd probably come back just for the pancakes next time!

Was a bit disappointed with that. We had one piece and let the milk soak in to soften up the brioche. My friend had their famous **"The Plow". the plow.author: Zare K.
the plow.review:
It's a chilly late-December morning in the week after Christmas. I have the day off work and so, visions of soft-scrambled eggs and crispy potatoes dancing in my head, I head over to Plow for breakfast. There's a line outside, as there always is, but when I inquire with the hostess about the wait time she says there's a seat opening up at the counter and it should be free in just 10 minutes. Only 10 minutes! Lucky me! I settle in for a short wait.

Understanding that things at a busy restaurant can take longer than expected, I wait some 30 minutes outside with nothing but a newspaper for company (no coffee, no seating)  before poking my head inside again to check on the wait. "Not too much longer," says the hostess. Back outside I go to chill, and I mean that in the sense of being cold. Somewhere in there I watch the hostess walk down the street and step directly in front of a (slowly, thank God) moving bus. Another 15 minutes pass so again, I ask to check on my progress. "Sorry, there's nothing available yet" says the hostess, looking agitated. Perhaps she's grumpy from getting honked at by the bus.

Fifty minutes after I first arrived--yes, that's 50, five with a zero after it, as in 5x the original estimated wait time--the hostess finally gestures for me to come inside. Alas, the seat isn't actually ready so she abandons me to stand in the small front lobby. For 5 minutes I wait awkwardly looking at the sign asking people not to stand in the small front lobby. At some point a busboy tries to shoo me outside.

Finally--oh, miracle of miracles! a place setting is prepared and I sit down at the counter. Frozen and too hungry to think straight, I eagerly accept the server's offer of coffee while I contemplate the menu. A man arrives and is seated next to me. He asks to order a moment later and the server obliges him, taking his food order ahead of mine. When he tries to chat me up later it takes a great deal of my self-restraint not to stab him with my fork.

"Ah, but how was the breakfast?" you ask. The breakfast was fine. Okay, taken on its own merits it was more than fine. The soft-scrambled eggs were creamy and tender with perfectly cooked mushrooms and greens. The Plow potatoes were hot and crispy. Their coffee is nice and strong and served in big hand-warming mugs. No one can dispute that Plow's cooks have their technique down. And just to be clear, I take no issue with Plow's long wait times as such--it was the completely bogus time estimate, along with the sneaking suspicion that I as a solo diner got bumped down the list--that had my hangrily grinding my teeth.

I share the tale of this ordeal with you, dear readers, because it prompted me to make a serious lifestyle change. No more waiting in line for brunch. Don't do it. Cook breakfast at home. You too can learn to make hollandaise sauce. Go out for pho or a bowl of porridge with Chinese doughnuts. Most pho restaurants even have coffee! Anything but the interminable wait accompanied by the gurgling Gastrointestinal Orchestra of hunger. Fellow San Franciscans, look around you and see: The Brunch Emperor wears no clothes.

Finally got to eat here! 
We avoided the ridic long wait by coming on a weekday around 12:30. We were told the wait was 20 minutes and were seated at a communal table in about 15 min.

Food was AMAZING! I don't know if I would wait any longer than 45 min for a meal in SF but this place blows many hyped brunch places out of the water in terms of quality and deliciousness (*cough cough* Zazie). 

I ordered the Plow since I don't know when I'll be here again and it's got a little bit of everything. I was disappointed that they didn't have any of their biscuits (though at $4 each, that was probably a good thing). The best thing on the plate BY FAR were the potatoes. Breakfast potatoes can go so wrong and these were perfectly crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Pale, limp potatoes are such a travesty and Plow has mastered the art of frying/baking this humble vegetable. 

Second best thing were those lemon ricotta pancakes---sooooo good! Flavorful and lite. You don't really need the maple syrup at all on them!

Scrambled eggs and bacon were above average and quality was there. Entire plate was $17 which I thought was fair given the quality of ingredients and the portion size.

Would love to say "I'll be back" but the wait times are just silly so I probably won't be back again unless it's another random time on a weekday.

the plow.author: Pooja M.

I came for brunch and stayed for Kanye.

If you want to feel pumped up and ready to party while you enjoy your delicious brunch, Plow is definitely the place to be in the city. 

The restaurant is small, but the vibe is 'popping' as the staff is all super friendly and fun and the music blasting through the restaurant will get you grooving in your seat (or up and about the restaurant if you're brave enough). 

I was in the mood for a bit of everything that day, so I decided to order the restaurant's namesake, The Plow, which is an all in one dish that consists of two eggs served in any style, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and a choice of pork, bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I asked for my eggs poached and I substituted a salad for the meat options.

The eggs were perfectly poached, but had no seasoning to them otherwise, and the salad was fresh and crispy, but again, bland. The standouts of the dish were the crispy potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes. The potatoes were so expertly seasoned and full of flavor -- they could quite easily be some of the best potatoes I've ever had. And those lemon ricotta pancakes were out of this world! The lemon is very present in the pancakes and is balanced nicely by the ricotta, and the syrup with the pancakes added a nice sweetness that wasn't overbearing. The pancakes were light and fluffy and don't sit heavy in your stomach. I'll definitely be coming back for those pancakes!

Something to keep in mind: Plow is one of the most popular brunch restaurants in SF, so expect a long wait time (at least 1.5 hours) on the weekend. However, if you're a brunch queen like me who's trying to catch 'em all, you are an expert on surviving the brunch hunger pains and boredom of long wait times, and having to wait no longer affects you. 

If you are not on a brunch quest like I am and you are willing to endure the long wait, bring a friend to keep you company, eat something light beforehand, and try to come as close to opening hours as you can, and you'll be brunching down in no time.

There is a lovely cafe across the street called Farley's that has plenty of indoor and outdoor seating and serves tea and light pastries where you can keep yourself from starving as you wait to be called. In general, the neighborhood where The Plow is located is really lovely and has a stunning view of the city skyline, so even if the wait is long, the environment is inviting. 

I'm putting The Plow on my list of brunch places to return to, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an exciting brunch spot!

the plow.review:
My favorite underrated brunch place in SF! I feel like there isn't enough hype around Plow, but there is still always a wait. The wait on weekends can be about an hour; I came on my own on a weekday this time and had to wait ~20 minutes.

I had the dungeness crab scramble a while ago and remember loving it. I was really looking forward to getting more of it this recent time but it wasn't on the menu anymore, so I tried a couple new things instead.

1) Buttermilk biscuit with honey butter (5/5) - AMAZING. The biscuit is large, golden brown on the edges, and fluffy inside. The honey butter is essentially butter mixed lightly with honey, but the balance of the creamy saltiness of butter with the sweet was so good.

2) The plow - Combination plate that allowed me to try a lot of different components. Crispy potatoes (5/5) - YES, so crispy on the outside, really well seasoned, but still buttery on the inside. Two overeasy eggs (4/5) - no complaints on the eggs themselves, wish they could have salted it a bit more though. House-made pork sausage (5/5) - really flavorful, it tasted like they mixed in little pieces of onions and herbs into it. Lemon ricotta pancakes (4/5) - actually not quite what I expected, for all that I hear about these pancakes, I was a little disappointed. The pancakes tasted really good, with just a hint of lemon that wasn't overpowering. However, because of the ricotta, the texture of the pancakes is a lot more dense, and I prefer my pancakes fluffier and airy.

A bit out of the way over in Potrero, but the trek is worth it!

With the glowing reviews on Yelp of Plow, it has been my mission to come here and try this place out. One day, we decided to head here and make that happen. The wait was long - and was to be expected - like similar brunch places in SF, and especially for a place such as Plow. The place itself is very small. When we (finally) got seated, we were lucky enough to get the window seat of the restaurant, but even our waitress had a difficult time coming to our table to give us our menus/take our orders since there was another table REALLY close to us. I decided to get the Plow so I could get a little taste of everything, including the lemon ricotta pancakes I've been dying to try. The food came out at a reasonable time despite how busy the entire place was, and overall it was just...okay. The food tasted average, and the lemon ricotta pancakes I had were just, okay. I've had lemon ricotta pancakes at other restaurants that have wow'd me and made me want to keep eating even when I was extremely full, but this was just...meh. It wasn't terrible, but it also didn't make me want to wait on a busy day to come here either because I honestly don't think it'll be worth it. For the price we payed, the amount of time we waited, and the overall experience, it didn't make me feel this place is as spectacular as the reviews had made it out to be. I'd give this place 3.5 stars. 

Overall, this probably wouldn't be my first choice to get brunch in San Francisco.

The breakfast sandwich was amazingly delicious!
Very filling and not too heavy!
Eggs were cooked perfectly and the bacon added a nice crisp to the sandwich.
The potatoes were cooked to perfection.
It had a rosemary kind of flavor.
Crispy on the outside.
Very delicious.
I also got to try the lemon ricotta pancake.
Oh man, that was soo good!
Fluffy and light with a hint of lemon flavor.
Loved how the lemon flavor wasn't too overwhelming.
Definitely a must order!
Everything that I tried was five stars and definitely want me coming back for more.
the plow.author: Philana C.
the plow.review:
I can't believe it's taken me so long just to finally try Plow! I've definitely been missing out and will be back soon! 

We put our name down around 12PM on a Saturday and got seated at the counter within an hour. Not too bad of a wait as I had heard others had to wait almost two hours especially for a weekend! I think we got lucky. :) 

We were seated at the counter, overlooking the kitchen. Best seats in the house since we were able to watch the cooking process. :) I had the breakfast sandwich, which came with two eggs fried soft, cheddar, aioli, and frisee with added bacon. It also came with the plow potatoes on the side. The breakfast sandwich was amazingly delicious! Very filling and not too heavy! Eggs were cooked perfectly and the bacon added a nice crisp to the sandwich. The potatoes were cooked to perfection. It had a rosemary kind of flavor. Crispy on the outside. Very delicious. I also got to try the lemon ricotta pancake. Oh man, that was soo good! Fluffy and light with a hint of lemon flavor. Loved how the lemon flavor wasn't too overwhelming. Definitely a must order! Everything that I tried was five stars and definitely want me coming back for more. :)

excerpts: We got the Plow ($17.50) and steak + eggs ($20).
Both dishes were very delicious.
The eggs were so fluffy and the potatoes were absolutely great.
The food definitely made the hour wait worth it.
There is not a single thing I didn't like about the food; it was delicious.
I would definitely consider coming back here for brunch again.
Make sure to get a dish with potatoes, they're amazing!
the plow.author: Jen S.
the plow.review:
Plow is an excellent place for brunch! We came here at around 1:30pm on Sunday and had to wait around an hour to be seated. The place "closes" at 2pm, but as long as you are there before 2pm, they will take your name down and you will be seated. Right at 2pm, they do a final call from the waitlist, meaning they call out everyone on their waitlist and see who's there. More than half the people on the list aren't there so whoever they call out at 2pm AND is present is guaranteed a table past 2pm. The place is very tiny so a wait is inevitable. There is also seating outside and they provide blankets for outside tables as the area gets a bit chilly.

Parking: There is ample street parking near the area so parking wasn't a problem for us.

Food: We got the Plow ($17.50) and steak + eggs ($20). Both dishes were very delicious. The eggs were so fluffy and the potatoes were absolutely great. The food definitely made the hour wait worth it. There is not a single thing I didn't like about the food; it was delicious. I would definitely consider coming back here for brunch again. Make sure to get a dish with potatoes, they're amazing! Also, highly recommend scrambled eggs, they're super fluffy and taste amazing.

5/5 for a VERY delicious brunch spot, highly recommend!

excerpts: We had the plow, butcher's steak and pancakes.
All were good
the plow.author: Lindt C.
the plow.review:
We came here on a Friday morning and there was also a queue (although more manageable than weekends). 

We had the plow, butcher's steak and pancakes. All were good but I thought the Butcher's steak was surprisingly excellent. 

Aromatic Equator coffee rounded off the great brunch. 

I would visit more often if not for the long queue!

excerpts: Got "The Plow" w/ bacon, poached eggs, and the other stuff that comes with it, along with a side of Hong Kong toast
the plow.author: Nick O.
the plow.review:
Got "The Plow" w/ bacon, poached eggs, and the other stuff that comes with it, along with a side of Hong Kong toast

This is the best brunch spot I've been to so far, definitely recommend. Thank you

excerpts: The Plow Breakfast is a must!
It can be shared amongst 2 people or 1 FA.
:) I've done both.
The homemade sausage is pretty bomb, the apple chicken sausage is also great.. and can't go wrong with bacon..
(so those are what you get to choose besides how you like yo eggs).
the plow.author: Jenna L.
the plow.review: The Plow Breakfast is a must! It can be shared amongst 2 people or 1 FA.  :) I've done both. The homemade sausage is pretty bomb, the apple chicken sausage is also great.. and can't go wrong with bacon.. (so those are what you get to choose besides how you like yo eggs). And I have repeated dreams about their lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes. I've been here 3 times and it has not disappoint. I love taking new people here to mold them into fans. (: The wait is a bit long, but hey, you can always explore the area. We walked to the Dogpatch area which is about a 10 minute walk. We also went next door to Provender Coffee (:

excerpts: So I have been the The Plow twice before , food is average but the lemon ricotta pancake never fails to disappoint me .
the plow.author: Priscilla F.
the plow.review:
Very disappointing ! So I have been the The Plow twice before , food is average but the lemon ricotta pancake never fails to disappoint me . So I have decide to bring my parents along this time . 

The line system needs works on , very unorganized , as they will wait for the previous people to show up before they can move people up the list . For example , Party A have two people , the receptionist call out party A but no one came up , they will still wait for them to show up until a while later .... 

I have checked in with the receptionist fell very unwelcoming and she is super rude . Since I have came before other party does , I checked in with her again making sure we are still on the list however she is very rude and gave a very bad attitude to me and my mom so we were both very disappointing already hoping the food can make up our disappointment .  
Finally got seated , the food is alll over cooked that my parents and I couldn't finish the dishes . 
Bacon is too over cooked that it became crunchy like chips ..... 
the lemon pancake is still good however considered this time of a super bad experience with the restaurant staff I will not return here anymore .

excerpts: I got the breakfast sandwich with bacon and my wife got the Plow with chicken apple sausage.
The Plow the restaurant's go-to: two eggs, choice of meat, in this case chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and plow potatoes.
Nice snappy sausage with full flavor, the potatoes again were crispy and soft at the same time, but the pancakes def stole the show.
the plow.author: Jurem F.
the plow.review:
If there is any restaurant that can serve as the example for all other restaurants to follow, it's Plow. Yes this place is a fabulous place to get breakfast/brunch, but what amazed me is the service. My wife and I didnt have many needs this afternoon, but our server Andrea got to us quickly and super efficiently, never skipping a beat with greeting us, taking our orders, running our food, and dropping the check. Thanks so much!

But the true unsung hero is the guy without a name on a receipt. You can tell this guy has been here for a long time because of how efficient he is, with clearing plates, setting up tables, seating guests from the waitlist, polishing silverware, and even with the breakdown of the outside patio seating. This dude completely blew me away with how every move he made was calculated and done very swiftly. I wish he worked for me!



ON TO THE FOOD. Mimosas, both grapefruit and OG, were served in wine glasses, which was greatly appreciated lol. I got the breakfast sandwich with bacon and my wife got the Plow with chicken apple sausage. 

The breakfast sandwich is your traditional egg sandwich with frisee, cheddar, and aioli. Done perfect and just what I was looking for. The yolks were runny, which is just bliss, the potatoes were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside, and the acme bun was soft and tasteful. 

The Plow the restaurant's go-to: two eggs, choice of meat, in this case chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and plow potatoes. Nice snappy sausage with full flavor, the potatoes again were crispy and soft at the same time, but the pancakes def stole the show. You NEED THESE in your life!

BOOKMARKED. WILL RETURN FOR MOAR.

excerpts: The Plow.
Of course.
It had everything you could ever want...eggs, meat, pancakes, AND potatoes.
YUM.
I was ready to take on The Plow.
The Plow still looked amazing but on the other hand, the soft scrambled eggs looked heavenly as well.
the plow.author: Ilana B.
the plow.review:
Hmmm what to say about Plow....

Heard amazing things about this place and have been dying to try it! My friend and I finally ventured out to Petrero Hill (10 min car ride from my apt...) to try Plow and boy did it live up to the hype. We had been looking over the menu in the uber ride there and already knew what we wanted...The Plow. Of course. It had everything you could ever want...eggs, meat, pancakes, AND potatoes. YUM. I was ready to take on The Plow. 

We knew the line was going to be long and we'd probably be waiting for over an hour but it would be worth it. The second we walked in, we told the hostess we had two people and she said we can either put you on the list for inside or seat you outside right away. My friend and I both looked at each other and said outside at the same time. We could not believe it! Note: It was a little chilly outside but who cares...we were getting seated RIGHT AWAY! Anyone who lives in SF and eats brunch on a weekend knows how rare this is. So outside it was! They even provided each customer with their own blanket!! Incredible. Is there anything they don't think of?!

As soon as we sat down, I started looking over the menu. The Plow still looked amazing but on the other hand, the soft scrambled eggs looked heavenly as well. I mean...shitake mushrooms and goat cheese in my soft scrambled eggs? I think yes. Plus I've been told they are known for both these dishes. It was going to be a game time decision. As soon as the server came over, I completely scrambled (pun intended) and went with the soft scrambled eggs BUT added an order of the lemon ricotta pancakes on the side. Could I BE any more excited? The answer is no. Plus I also ordered an iced chai. It was so tasty. 

I could not have been happier with my decision to get the soft scrambled eggs. it was everything I could have hoped for and more. Much more. 

Plow, you have my heart.

excerpts: and I both ordered the plow plates.
the plow.author: Stefanie S.
the plow.review:
I've only been here once but it made quite an impression. I went way back when the Giants won the World Series in 2014, thinking that it wouldn't be crowded and I could avoid the long waits. Wrong lol seems like a lot of people had the same idea. 

It was roughly a 30 min wait for two people. It's a pretty small space so it'll be cozy but don't worry, the food will make it all okay. My boyfriend and I both ordered the plow plates. Those lemon ricotta pancakes. Dang. I could eat 50 of those. Everything on the plate was just so well made with great ingredients, and it was easy to see why the waits are constantly long. I will not wait till the Giants win (even year tho heyyy) to come back!

Free street parking, but it's pretty hilly because duh San Francisco. Bring a jacket for the wait outside haha

excerpts: I've ordered "the plow" which is basically a little bit of everything for breakfast.
The sides are also very delicious, and I'm mainly talking about the plow potatoes.
It is not something you can get anywhere!
Come here and try the food!
the plow.author: Jason W.
the plow.review:
Best breakfast in the city for sure! The line is always long but the food is always perfect. Generally if you come on a weekday before 930, the wait is pretty reasonable. Anytime after and you'll be waiting for quite a while. 

I've ordered "the plow" which is basically a little bit of everything for breakfast. Definitely a lot of food!

This time I ordered the pork chop! I wasn't sure if it was the right call but I would definitely recommend it! It was very moist and juicy and cooked perfectly! Give it a shot!

The sides are also very delicious, and I'm mainly talking about the plow potatoes. It is not something you can get anywhere! Come here and try the food!

excerpts: I ordered the plow with a substitution of French toast instead of pancakes.
Every bite on my plate was better than the last.
the plow.author: Heaven R.
the plow.review: This place was recommended by a friend.  I must say that this was the best breakfast I've had in a long time.   I ordered the plow with a substitution of French toast instead of pancakes.   Every bite on my plate was better than the last.

excerpts: The plow breakfast had wonderful potatoes.
the plow.author: Vernon A.
the plow.review: We loved the BLT because it had a beautiful beefsteak tomato and pimiento cheese - both memories from Missouri childhood.  The Hong Kong toast reminded her the pan de sol sandwiches she used to have.  The plow breakfast had wonderful potatoes.

excerpts: We ordered the honey butter biscuit, pudding, the plow, and the sandwich.
Everything was amazing.
Other then the wait we had a very good brunch.
Definitely be back when I'm in town to visit!
the plow.author: Hoa V.
the plow.review: Expect to have a long wait. We put our name on the waiting list and walked down the street to get some coffee. The food was fantastic! It was exactly as what we saw on other yelpers posts. It was a little chilly outside so they handed us a little throw to keep us warm. The service was great! They were attentive and so sweet. Like I said earlier the food was fantastic! We ordered the honey butter biscuit, pudding, the plow, and the sandwich. Everything was amazing. Other then the wait we had a very good brunch. Definitely be back when I'm in town to visit!

excerpts: The Plow: was very good.
It was a big order, can easily be shared between 2 people with big appetite, or 3 people with small appetite.
the plow.author: Anjali A.
the plow.review:
Checked in on May 31st, 2016.

First time to San Francisco, searched on Yelp for breakfast place and found Plow.  Very impressed!
Rating:
1) Food - 5/5
2) Service - 5/5
3) Ambiance - 4/5

We ordered:
1) The Plow: was very good.  It was a big order, can easily be shared between 2 people with big appetite, or 3 people with small appetite.  Comes with 2 eggs, choice of sausage (we took Apple chicken), potatoes and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes.  The pancakes were my favorite.  Everything else was good and perfectly cooked.
2) Mochi: was excellent.  
3) Cold brewed Iced coffee: did not care much for it.

Service was efficient and timely.  I have taken off one star due to the cramped setup.  I would like to see them move to a larger location with more space between 2 tables.

excerpts: I ordered the French toast with strawberries, mascarpone, and pure maple syrup while the mister ordered the Plow breakfast with two eggs, house made pork sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.
No complaints!
All the components on the Plow were nicely cooked and the two fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes truly had a pleasant lemon essence.
All the components on the Plow were nicely cooked and the two fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes truly had a pleasant lemon essence.
the plow.author: Merica S.
the plow.review:
Good food, but not feeling the approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes wait on the weekends. 

I'm not going to lie---the food just wasn't worth the unbearably long wait. Didn't blow my mind. 

I ordered the French toast with strawberries, mascarpone, and pure maple syrup while the mister ordered the Plow breakfast with two eggs, house made pork sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes, and crispy potatoes.  No complaints! All the components on the Plow were nicely cooked and the two fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes truly had a pleasant lemon essence. I thought my French toast appeared relatively burnt, though it didn't taste like it. 

+ Can only accommodate parties of 6 or fewer due to the small size of the venue 
+ No reservations
+ Indoor and outdoor seating

excerpts: Hubby and I split a biscuit (comes with honey butter) - that was sooo good, great texture - and "the plow" which is your choice of eggs, your choice of meat, breakfast potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes.
The plow was soooo delicious but also sooo much food
so I'd def recommend splitting it.

The eggs were phenomenal, the chicken apple sausage and bacon (Hubby requested an extra meat side) were good but greasy, the breakfast potatoes were amazing (especially those small crunchy bits, but the star of the show was the pancakes!
Such great flavor, not too heavy, great texture because of the ricotta.
I just wish I had gotten to eat more of the pancakes
the plow.author: Xenia P.
the plow.review: What a great spot for breakfast! We went on a weekday and it was full, so I can only imagine how packed it gets on the weekend. Hubby and I split a biscuit (comes with honey butter) - that was sooo good, great texture - and "the plow" which is your choice of eggs, your choice of meat, breakfast potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes. The plow was soooo delicious but also sooo much food so I'd def recommend splitting it. The eggs were phenomenal, the chicken apple sausage and bacon (Hubby requested an extra meat side) were good but greasy, the breakfast potatoes were amazing (especially those small crunchy bits, but the star of the show was the pancakes! Such great flavor, not too heavy, great texture because of the ricotta. I just wish I had gotten to eat more of the pancakes

excerpts: Me and my friend both got 'The Plow' which came with 2 eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, homefries and your choice of pork sausage patties (like the kind you get with your sausage mcmuffin), chicken apple sausages (links) or bacon.
Me and my friend decided to get the sausage patties and the chicken apple sausages to share.
Between those two, I would recommend the chicken apple sausages more, but they were both moist and juicy.
The pancakes were fluffy and with the right amount of lemon in it (yums.)
The homefries potatoes were extra crispy (they actually fry them @___@) and seasoned just the right amount.
I was lucky enough to be seated at the bar, meaning I had the pleasure to see the cook season the potatoes
the plow.author: Jenny N.
the plow.review:
I must be on a quest to try every brunch place in the city because that's all I been reviewing lately, and this place happens to win a spot in my list of best brunches in the city. 

I came here on a weekend and for a party of 2, the wait was about 1.5 hours... which is about average in this city. The place seems like a fairly small place and the ambience is pretty fresh and bright because the place was filled with natural sunlight. I took the bus here but parking doesn't seem to be like a big issue in this neighborhood. 

Me and my friend both got 'The Plow' which came with 2 eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, homefries and your choice of pork sausage patties (like the kind you get with your sausage mcmuffin), chicken apple sausages (links) or bacon. Me and my friend decided to get the sausage patties and the chicken apple sausages to share. Between those two, I would recommend the chicken apple sausages more, but they were both moist and juicy. The pancakes were fluffy and with the right amount of lemon in it (yums.) The homefries potatoes were extra crispy (they actually fry them @___@) and seasoned just the right amount. I was lucky enough to be seated at the bar, meaning I had the pleasure to see the cook season the potatoes and she actually tries every batch to make sure they're seasoned enough. 

Overall, I would definitely recommend this place for all brunch lovers.

excerpts: (On a Sunday) We ordered the plow and everything on the dish was unique and tasted great.
The peach upside down cake was heavy, but delicious and was a nice sweet after our breakfast.
the plow.author: Ashley Y.
the plow.review: Worth the wait! (On a Sunday) We ordered the plow and everything on the dish was unique and tasted great. The peach upside down cake was heavy, but delicious and was a nice sweet after our breakfast.

excerpts: Food is not bad (we had the plow which was not mind blowing, but pretty all right), and that's why people wait for a long time.
the plow.author: D J.
the plow.review:
I don't use Yelp to complain about places but this one needs a mention so that people are aware. 

Food is not bad (we had the plow which was not mind blowing, but pretty all right), and that's why people wait for a long time. For us, it was 2 solid hours on a Sunday morning. 

However, the server was EXTREMELY rude. I believe she was agitated with a different customer and vented her stress on us. 

After a 2 hour wait, we got seated and because it was cold outside we wanted to order a hot coffee and asked the server if we could order. She replied "I'm helping a customer here ok? I'll be with you after that". I replied "got it". I understood they were busy and did not hold it against her. When she got back to us I asked for her recommendation and she just replied "Everything is good". Well that doesn't help much and doesn't fix the situation either. The way she took our orders was also very angry, didn't repeat what we ordered, and generally hurt our experience no matter how good the food was (which I mentioned was not exceptional). Oh and she only gave us one side plate for both of us. Really?

With good service I would have given it 3 stars but please, jeep your servers in line and fix your seating situation. There are so many customers complaining about the chaotic seating and ordering situation and it doesn't seem this business gives a damn about it because people still line up. Just a sad situation and a poor experience overall.

excerpts: and I think the Plow breakfast is just overall delicious and awesome.
This is one of my favorites as a SF local!
the plow.author: Laura T.
the plow.review: This place is one of my favorites in the city. If you can swing it, I'd recommend going early during the weekdays, then you really won't get much of a wait. On the other hand, I've come at 10:30 on a Sunday and been told that we won't be seated until 1pm, soooo take that as you will. While the wait is long, I think it can be so worth it though!  The lemon ricotta pancakes are by far my favorite and I think the Plow breakfast is just overall delicious and awesome. This is one of my favorites as a SF local!

excerpts: My friend and I split The Plow, which consists of lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, a meat, and eggs.
We went with the house made sausage and over medium eggs.
I loved the potatoes, which were soft on the inside and super crispy on the outside.
The portions were just big enough that we felt satisfied, not bloated like we usually do after brunch.
the plow.author: Anna H.
the plow.review:
We dropped by last minute on a Friday afternoon and were pleasantly surprised by the relatively quick 20 minute wait. My friend and I split The Plow, which consists of lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, a meat, and eggs. We went with the house made sausage and over medium eggs. I loved the potatoes, which were soft on the inside and super crispy on the outside. The portions were just big enough that we felt satisfied, not bloated like we usually do after brunch. The meal was quite expensive - $17 + tax and tip for a very simple meal, excluding the potatoes (which as I mentioned before, were extraordinary).

Service was attentive and the atmosphere is great. I'm not sure if I would make a trip back just for the potatoes because Plow is definitely on the pricey end but it's worth trying if you're in the area!

excerpts: I ordered the plow breakfast and coffee.
the plow.author: Jaime F.
the plow.review:
Hipster spot. I don't usually go out for brunch, but this place is certainly an experience. 

Got in, the waitress told our party of two the wait was about 30 minutes. They did seem very busy. We went walking around and looked around. We come back after 10 minutes, the waitress seemed to be looking for us. She said the table was almost ready. Sure enough, we were seated after a short wait. 

I ordered the plow breakfast and coffee. It came with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, bacon, sausage. The waiter was very friendly and very attentive to coffee and water refills and kept checking on us.

It's very easy to find parking here. Definitely recommend this spot if you are on Potrero Hill!

excerpts: I got the plow with pork sausage, and soft scrambled eggs.
My plate turned out exactly what i thought it would.
the plow.author: Paulina N.
the plow.review:
Came here in a Monday afternoon, for a group of 5 our wait was about 30-35 minuets. Not too bad because a couple of parties before us didn't show up.
Our servicer was nice she got our orders in as soon as we were ready. 
We ordered 2 buttermilk biscuits to start off our lunch. The butter was sweet and seems like it was house made. 
I got the plow with pork sausage, and soft scrambled eggs. My plate turned out exactly what i thought it would. The lemon ricotta pancakes are supposed to be a huge hit here but I personally didn't favor them. The dense ricotta made it too heavy for me to finish both. But it seems to be exactly what a ricotta pancake should be. 
I would definitely come back next time for brunch again!

excerpts: Ordered the plow
so I could try a little bit of everything.
the plow.author: Steph D.
the plow.review:
I have tried to eat here three times. THREE TIMES. The wait is usually around an hour, and all the people standing outside can be intimidating, but it's absolutely worth it. 

I went at 9am to put our name in for a group of 4, and our table was ready about 45 mins later. Opted for inside seating cause it was cold, but would have been happy to sit outside just to finally be able to eat at this place. Limited seating, so I don't think a party bigger than 5 or 6 would be a good idea.

Ordered the plow so I could try a little bit of everything. The lemon ricotta pancakes. AMAZING. SO GOOD. HOW. WHY. Country style potatoes and eggs. Definitely the perfect hearty size after a late Friday night.

I would suggest ordering the grilled cheese. A friend ordered it and as soon as they brought the food, the entire table was jealous. 

I would eat here every weekend this wasn't San Francisco and I didn't have to wait an hour to sit at a fabulous restaurant.

excerpts: My friend ordered the plow dish, and I ordered the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes with a side of bacon.
the plow.author: Taylor M.
the plow.review:
Pretty good! 

Came here for brunch on a Tuesday morning around 11, and was surprised to see that it was busy! Had to wait less than 10 minutes for a table, and the hostess seated us at a two-top right next to a four-top that was within breathing room of us. It felt awkward being a bit close, so we scooted the table over a bit. 

With that said, Plow is a small restaurant. Be prepared to get comfortable with your table neighbors! 

My friend ordered the plow dish, and I ordered the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes with a side of bacon. 

Our food came out in about 15 minutes, and it was good! My bacon was greasy, fatty, and most importantly, crispy. It added the salt needed to the sweetness of the pancakes. The pancakes were delicious. I could taste the lemon without it being overpowering, and the ricotta was present as well. The blueberry compote that comes along is a great addition, as it adds a bit of tartness to the pancakes. Plus, the purple-blue of the blueberries on top of the lemon pancakes look so colorful and fun! 

My friend seemed enjoyed her dish, she ate the whole thing! 

The service was great. Our server made sure our coffee mugs were filled, and took good care of us. 

I'd recommend this place to a friend for sure. I'll come back in the future and order those pancakes again!

excerpts:
The plow - 5/5
Ginger molasses cake - 3/5
Biscuits and honey butter - 5/5 - Unbelievably good.
Overall, the plow and the biscuits are "as good as it gets.
the plow.author: Mark O.
the plow.review:
Brunch review. Third visit.

Pumpkin pancakes - 3/5
The plow - 5/5
Ginger molasses cake - 3/5
Biscuits and honey butter - 5/5 - Unbelievably good. Best Biscuits in the city. 

Overall, the plow and the biscuits are "as good as it gets."

excerpts: Get the Plow... just do it!
But, don't wait 2 hours for it like I did.
You've got to be strategic when it comes to brunching in SF.
Come early and be among the first group to be seated.
On the plus side, patrons are fairly self-aware and don't linger around after they scarf down their food because yes, you will work up an appetite from all of the waiting.
This single meal lasted me all day.
The carb-protein-fat ratio is just perfect.
A must try when in town!
the plow.author: Julia K.
the plow.review: Get the Plow... just do it! But, don't wait 2 hours for it like I did. You've got to be strategic when it comes to brunching in SF. Come early and be among the first group to be seated. On the plus side, patrons are fairly self-aware and don't linger around after they scarf down their food because yes, you will work up an appetite from all of the waiting. This single meal lasted me all day. The carb-protein-fat ratio is just perfect. A must try when in town!

excerpts: I ordered the Plow, which consists of 2 eggs, 2 lemon riccota pancakes, their house potatoes, and choice of protein-chicken apple sausages, Nueske's bacon, or house pork sausages.
the plow.author: Denzell S.
the plow.review:
I decided to be productive this morning and go to the gym. But of course, considering the time it takes to get ready, drive to the gym, and sit in traffic, I decided instead to plow my face at Plow. They open at 7am but already at 6:50am people are congregated outside their door. Inside has a nice, quaint, homey feel. The server seated me on the counter facing the kitchen, so I had a perfect view of the kitchen. 

I ordered the Plow, which consists of 2 eggs, 2 lemon riccota pancakes, their house potatoes, and choice of protein-chicken apple sausages, Nueske's bacon, or house pork sausages. I opted for the pork sausages based on the server's recommendations and ordered a cup of their Equator coffee to pair off with my meal. I don't know if it's the coffee fiend in me, but their cup of joe was addicting. I may have had a total of 4 cups.

The meal was real hearty leaving me stuffed. The house potatoes were nice and crispy seasoned with what tasted like rosemary. The lemon riccota pancakes were nice and fluffy with just the perfect amount of lemon flavoring. Initially I ordered for over-medium eggs so the yolk doesn't run throughout my plate but instead was served over-easy and a bit salty. I typically refrain from using condiments so I can savor the flavor of the dish, but their pork sausage was a tad dry, overcooked, and overly seasoned with herbs that ketchup helped neutralize the taste.

As I was wrapping up my meal, the chef also pulled out a fresh mochi cake from the oven and of course I couldn't resist, so I decided to order a slice to go. The cake reminded me of a Filipino bibingka cake. It has a spongy and gelatinous texture with a coconut after-taste. Very delicious especially when warm. 

Plow is perfect for splurging on breakfast. Personal advice is to come early because they do get packed and of course for the owners to add bottomless mimosas to their menu- one can only dream.

excerpts: We both ordered The Plow, which comes with eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, and your choice of pork sausage/bacon/chicken apple sausage.

the plow.author: Cheryl N.
the plow.review:
I don't really understand what the hype is all about. 

My friend and I came on a Saturday morning around 10:30am and the wait was 1-1.5 hours for a party of 2. We went for a stroll across the street to grab some coffee and toast while we waited, but I saw others order coffee and mimosas from Plow while waiting. The staff seemed super nice and accommodating, considering how busy it was.

We finally got seated after about an hour and 15 mins. We both ordered The Plow, which comes with eggs, lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes, and your choice of pork sausage/bacon/chicken apple sausage. I went with the classic bacon option while my friend opted for the pork sausage.

Being seated outside, I noticed that we were not given a jug of water that we could use to fill our own glasses, while people sitting inside were. It didn't matter too much because our waitress was pretty good about refilling our waters. Just wish they kept it consistent with the tables, though.

Onto the food... Honestly I was very disappointed. My over medium eggs came with a perfect runny yolk (yay!) but overall were extremely bland. They tasted like they were barely seasoned with any salt or pepper. The bacon was terrible. It was waaay too salty and was not crispy at all. It was actually pretty soggy. The lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes, on the other hand, were the redeeming factors of the dish. The pancakes were fluffy and had a good balance of lemon flavor. The potatoes were pretty good as well, but not remarkable enough for me to say they were amazing. I tried some of my friend's pork sausage and thought it was pretty average. The worst part was when I found a piece of hair at the bottom of my plate. Definitely know it's not my own since it was short and black instead of long and ombré. It's too bad I had already eaten a majority of the plate when I found it...

I also noticed that they printed the menu specific for that day. I'm not sure if they print the menu everyday, but I sure hope not because that would be such a waste of paper.

Overall, Plow was definitely overhyped. It wasn't worth it to me to wait 1+ hour and pay $17 for a mediocre plate of food that had a hair in it... But maybe I just had a bad experience? I'd give it a try again maybe if the wait weren't so long.

May have been the best brunch experience I've had in San Francisco. Arrived at 8:45 on a rainy Saturday and was informed that there was an hour wait for a table for 3, not a problem, found a nearby coffee shop and the hour was over before we knew it. Had the homemade biscuit with honey butter, the plow, the French toast with caramel apples, and the gruyere and prosciutto open face sandwich.

excerpts: I had The Plow, which is their signature breakfast plate.
The kitchen gussied up the pancakes a little more than they did with the other breakfast items in The Plow.
The pancakes featured both lemon and ricotta.
The lemon was nice.
It provided a noticeable lemon flavor as well as a lot of freshness.
I felt though that the ricotta probably hurt the pancake more than it helped it.
The pancakes had a great color and the smell of the pancake was very inviting.

I would definitely go back and give Plow's other dishes a shot.
the plow.author: Anthony N.
the plow.review:
***This neighborhood breakfast spot utilizes high quality ingredients and a well-run kitchen to churn out delicious and satisfying breakfast and brunch dishes***

Plow is located in Dogpatch, an up-and-coming neighborhood that will probably introduce several more destination restaurants in the next few years.  Plow is a weekday and weekend breakfast and brunch eatery.  The restaurant is small and casual though the décor is nicely done featuring homey but still contemporary notes.  The counter is nice and provides an excellent view of the short order counter where the team of chefs here efficiently crank out breakfast dishes like a well-run greasy spoon.

The food at Plow is not greasy spoon staples though.  You will see more upscale ingredients here like prosciutto and frisee as well as some great looking bread from a prestigious San Francisco bakery.  I had The Plow, which is their signature breakfast plate.  It is a hearty plate featuring two eggs, crispy fried potatoes with onions, choice of meat (chicken apple sausage, pork sausage patties or bacon), and two lemon ricotta pancakes.

With the exception of the lemon ricotta pancakes, this breakfast veered more towards fairly classic interpretations.  I had the eggs sunny side up, and they were quite good.  I would have liked the egg yolk a little less done, but the flavor was great.  The crispy potatoes were quite delicious.  The caramelized onions provided a mild sweet flavor while the potatoes combined a satisfying crispy exterior with a hot and soft center.  I also had their bacon, which was Nueske's bacon, a popular Midwestern bacon from Wisconsin.  The bacon had a smoky flavor as well as an appetizing pork flavor from the crispy fat.

The bacon was not as thick as Niman Ranch bacon, but the flavor was definitely memorable.  I also ordered their pork sausage patties, and these were good though I probably did prefer the bacon.  The center of the sausage was moist while the outside was well seared and crispy.  They get a little more adventurous with the seasoning so you get more herb and fennel notes with their sausage than you would experience at most breakfast spots.

The kitchen gussied up the pancakes a little more than they did with the other breakfast items in The Plow.  The pancakes featured both lemon and ricotta.  The lemon was nice.  It provided a noticeable lemon flavor as well as a lot of freshness.  I felt though that the ricotta probably hurt the pancake more than it helped it.  The pancakes had a great color and the smell of the pancake was very inviting.  Unfortunately, the pancake could have been sweeter.  The center was also a tad on the dry side and did not have that light and fluffy cake-like texture you would expect in an excellent pancake.

Service was fairly quick given how busy this restaurant gets (even on weekdays).  Prices are higher than your standard breakfast spot, but the ingredients at Plow are definitely high quality and the portions are surprisingly generous.

I enjoyed The Plow at Plow though I felt the savory items were far superior to the disappointing lemon ricotta pancakes.  Part of me really loved the breakfast here, and, in some ways, Plow would rival my favorite breakfast restaurants--Matt's Big Breakfast in Phoenix or Huckleberry in Santa Monica, which features an excellent fried egg sandwich with bacon.  I would definitely go back and give Plow's other dishes a shot.  If you are a big breakfast fan, Plow is a must visit if you live in San Francisco or are just visiting.

I believe free street parking is available in the nearby residential area though parking spaces are probably hard to find around here.
