We all gobbled all of our food - everyone agreed everything was delicious all around.
My only real complaint is that my salad was very over-dressed.
(Why do restaurants put so much dressing on salads??)
My friend who ordered the biscuits and gravy said the gravy was super (too) buttery and a bit too rich.
the plow.author: Kate W.
the plow.review:
I came here for brunch with friends today & it was great. We did have to wait outside for about 45 minutes for a table (and it was cold out!) but the hostess was super nice. 

I ordered the arugula salad with winter squash, pomegranate, hazelnuts and ricotta salata because I'm off gluten. My friends got the Plow special (eggs, bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes) and the biscuits and gravy. We all gobbled all of our food - everyone agreed everything was delicious all around. My only real complaint is that my salad was very over-dressed. (Why do restaurants put so much dressing on salads??) My friend who ordered the biscuits and gravy said the gravy was super (too) buttery and a bit too rich. But hey, it's sausage gravy.

Also - we didn't order the fruit on the side but we should have when we saw our table neighbors'. They had gala apple and asian pear slices, fuyu persimmon slices, and half of a mango, cubed. It looked AWESOME. 1000% better than the gross melon-pineapple-grape combo with maybe a single strawberry on it that you usually see at a brunch place. 

I'd definitely come back here. The neighborhood around it is super cute as well & parking was really easy at 12:45 on a Saturday.

excerpts: I've been here several times and my best bet is to go with the Plow breakfast - two eggs, sausage or bacon (I prefer the chicken apple sausage), two lemon ricotta pancakes (absolutely delicious and fluffy), and amazing potatoes.
It's worth the wait and definitely worth coming on a weekday when it's less crowded if you can!
the plow.author: Lidia L.
the plow.review: Consistently great quality of food and service.  I've been here several times and my best bet is to go with the Plow breakfast - two eggs, sausage or bacon (I prefer the chicken apple sausage), two lemon ricotta pancakes (absolutely delicious and fluffy), and amazing potatoes.  It's worth the wait and definitely worth coming on a weekday when it's less crowded if you can!

excerpts: I ordered the Plow from the brunch menu.
I LOVE the 2 miniture pancakes made with the cottage cheese!
They tasted really good!
It also comes with your choice of egg style.
I asked for sunny and they were good.
There are also multiple choices of meats you can chose for Plow
and I decided to try their homemade sausage.
That was a bit disappointing.
I like my sausage juicy and tender, but they were dry and too dense to me.
The flavor was delicious.
One last thing worth mentioning is their potatoes.
They are really good!
I'm not a big fan of potatoes, but I finished all the potatoes given on my plate.
They were crispy and flavorful!
Delicious!
the plow.author: Gina W.
the plow.review:
My first experience at Plow was very pleasant.  Starting from the friendly host who seated us to the owner (the husband, the wife is the main chef busy cooking), our waitress, the ambience, the vibrant energy at the restaurant and the food.  It's a great place for breakfast, lunch and brunch!

The menu looked interesting to me.  Immediately the Crispy Pig Ears on the menu caught my eyes.  I rarely see this dish on a western restaurant's menu and was curious about the dish so I ordered it.  I liked it a lot!  It tastes almost like fried pork chops or salt and pepper pork chops except they served this dish with vinegar.  It was tasty.  I would go back just for this dish. But try it only if you are a food adventurer.

Then we ordered an orange scone to savor prior to our brunch.  It's warm therefore tasted good, but for some reason it didn't "wow" me.  My friend on the other hand was crazy in love with it.  

I ordered the Plow from the brunch menu.  I LOVE the 2 miniture pancakes made with the cottage cheese!  They tasted really good!  It also comes with your choice of egg style.  I asked for sunny and they were good.  There are also multiple choices of meats you can chose for Plow and I decided to try their homemade sausage.  That was a bit disappointing.  I like my sausage juicy and tender, but they were dry and too dense to me.  The flavor was delicious.  One last thing worth mentioning is their potatoes.  They are really good!  I'm not a big fan of potatoes, but I finished all the potatoes given on my plate.  They were crispy and flavorful!  Delicious!  I would go back for the potatoes and the pancakes as well!

Then I think we also tried their cremebulee, but can't remember much.  I'm not sure if I was in food coma already that's why I don't remember or it wasn't memorable.  I will have to try it again next time I go to Plow and share with you later.  


Give Plow a try!

excerpts: We ordered The Plow [2 eggs, 2 small lemon ricotta pancakes, bacon (or sausage) and crispy potatoes], as well as an order of the French Toast (mascarpone and strawberries on top).
Both were delicious!
Staff was friendly and street parking was easy that early.
Will be back again soon!
With a pot of tea, I think our total (including tip) was about $45.
the plow.author: L S.
the plow.review: Arrived early (before 8am) on a Friday morning and were seated right away. We ordered The Plow [2 eggs, 2 small lemon ricotta pancakes, bacon (or sausage) and crispy potatoes], as well as an order of the French Toast (mascarpone and strawberries on top). Both were delicious! Staff was friendly and street parking was easy that early. Will be back again soon! With a pot of tea, I think our total (including tip) was about $45.

excerpts: I got "The Plow" which comes with crispy potatoes, two eggs, choice of bacon, pork sausage or chicken sausage and two lemon ricotta pancakes.
The crispy potatoes were also a hit
and I was just disappointed I couldn't manage to finish them all.
The lemon ricotta pancakes were pretty good as well.
Just enough sweetness and a good lemon flavor.
My only complaint is that they were a bit on the dry side and lacked fluffiness.
The freshly squeezed orange juice was also a plus.
The place is very small and it was completely packed when we visited.
Despite this, service was great.
I look forward to visiting the Plow on my next visit to SF.
the plow.author: Gema S.
the plow.review: We were lucky to come across this place on a recent trip to SF because it was close to where we were staying, and it was quite a find! The first time we came here it was about 10:30 and there was an hour wait. We decided not to wait and came back the next day at opening because the pictures of the food looked so good on Yelp. I'm so glad we came back! The next day we had no wait and were seated quickly once the place opened. I got "The Plow" which comes with crispy potatoes, two eggs, choice of bacon, pork sausage or chicken sausage and two lemon ricotta pancakes. I got mine with the nueske bacon and I have to say it was the best bacon I've ever had. Slightly sweet and salty and they were very generous with the portions. The crispy potatoes were also a hit and I was just disappointed I couldn't manage to finish them all. The lemon ricotta pancakes were pretty good as well. Just enough sweetness and a good lemon flavor. My only complaint is that they were a bit on the dry side and lacked fluffiness. The freshly squeezed orange juice was also a plus. The place is very small and it was completely packed when we visited. Despite this, service was great. I look forward to visiting the Plow on my next visit to SF.

excerpts: She ordered the Plow plate: with eggs, lemon pancakes, sausage.
the plow.author: Maria A.
the plow.review:
I came here with a friend before Indie-Mart. She ordered the Plow plate: with eggs, lemon pancakes, sausage. I had the eggs benedict. 

We both thought our food was good but nothing memorable enough to drive from our respective neighborhoods for. If it hadn't been for Indie-Mart being walking distance, we wouldn't have tried this place out. It's a trendy spot and its awesome for the neighborhood because it needs more up and coming restaurants like Plow. But I don't consider it a destination brunch place, like Just for You cafe, or Axis cafe, both in that part of town.

excerpts: I ordered The Plow which consists of two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes.
This was not cheap as the price of admission was $15.75, but it didn't fail to satisfy.
The potatoes were some of the best I've had in the city, super crispy and salty.
The eggs were scrambled to perfection and the pancakes may have been the highlight here.
And the bacon, was well bacon.
You can't really go wrong with bacon.
All in all, the entire experience was enjoyable and the waitress even prevented my from getting a parking ticket as halfway through the meal
she warned me there was street sweeping.
The neighborhood is a little out of the way if you are just visiting, but there is a great view of the skyline from across the street.
Definitely worth checking out if you've got some spare time.
Would highly suggest avoiding this place on the weekends.
#foodcomaking approved.
the plow.author: Food Coma K.
the plow.review: In the past few weeks, Plow has frequently become the main topic of conversation when talking about brunch. Unless you get there around 7am on weekends, you are looking at waiting over two hours which is insane if you ask me. This morning I just so happened to be in the area and drove by to see many open spots inside so I decided to stop and see what all the fuss is about. I was seated immediately and was able to get in and out of the establishment in under a half an hour which was awesome. The food was great. Worth waiting two hours for? Probably not, but then again I'm not sure any food is worth waiting two hours for. I ordered The Plow which consists of two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes. This was not cheap as the price of admission was $15.75, but it didn't fail to satisfy. The potatoes were some of the best I've had in the city, super crispy and salty. The eggs were scrambled to perfection and the pancakes may have been the highlight here. And the bacon, was well bacon. You can't really go wrong with bacon. All in all, the entire experience was enjoyable and the waitress even prevented my from getting a parking ticket as halfway through the meal she warned me there was street sweeping. The neighborhood is a little out of the way if you are just visiting, but there is a great view of the skyline from across the street. Definitely worth checking out if you've got some spare time. Would highly suggest avoiding this place on the weekends. #foodcomaking approved.

excerpts: My wife had "the Plow" breakfast (lemon ricotta pancakes, sausage, crispy potatoes, scrambled eggs) and I ordered the "Scramble" (chanterelles, goat cheese, scallions with salad and acme toast).
the plow.author: J. SOMA S.
the plow.review:
This is a SOLID FOUR STAR establishment.  I had breakfast with my wife this morning and it was wonderful.

My wife had "the Plow" breakfast (lemon ricotta pancakes, sausage, crispy potatoes, scrambled eggs) and I ordered the "Scramble" (chanterelles, goat cheese, scallions with salad and acme toast).

The service was excellent -- and the coffee was hot and strong.

I will be back.  Well done, this is a good new addition to the SF restaurant scene.

excerpts: On top of that, the option I chose, The Plow, was delish!
I LOVE their bacon.
the plow.author: Min M.
the plow.review:
The Food:
1. I am gluten-free and they have options for me. That's ALWAYS a plus. On top of that, the option I chose, The Plow, was delish! I LOVE their bacon.
2. I do wish they would have had a better option for substituting out the pancakes.

The Ambiance:
1. It's a little small but doesn't seem noisy.
2. I like that they tell you up front that they can't seat parties of more than 6.

The Price:
1. Surprisingly, it was priced perfectly. I was impressed by the fact that they are mostly local and organic, and priced so well.

excerpts: I got the plow - pancakes, potatoes, eggs, and choice of meat (pork sausage for me).
The pancakes and potatoes are outstanding.
The pancake is super moist and fluffy and has a great flavor (lemon ricotta).
The potatoes are super crisp.
the plow.author: Piggy S.
the plow.review:
I got the plow - pancakes, potatoes, eggs, and choice of meat (pork sausage for me).  The pancakes and potatoes are outstanding.  The pancake is super moist and fluffy and has a great flavor (lemon ricotta).  The potatoes are super crisp.  Not so into to the pork sausage - would probably do chicken apple sausage next time.  

The wait here is ridiculous though - we waited for an hour.  Parking isn't plentiful, but we were able to find some a block away.

excerpts: We usually order The Plow, which is a short stack of lemon-ricotta pancakes, choice of bacon or sausage, and two eggs.
Now let's talk about the potatoes for a second here.
These are the crowning glory of the place.
They literally make the experience unforgettable.
I'm not a chef, but I do cook some and it seems to me the yukon gold potatoes are fried once, smashed by hand, seasoned with salt, pepper and herbs, and then fried again to a crispy, golden brown.
I am not doing them justice thru my description.
Go ahead, wait an hour on the sidewalk and tell me these don't make you do cartwheels.
They're that crazy good.
The coffee is strong, dark, the juices freshly squeezed, the breads are artisan.
Service is so friendly, so congenial, that if they spilled my potatoes on the floor, I would still give them a warm hug.
the plow.author: Angelo S.
the plow.review:
If not for the long waits, I would give the place 6 stars for best brunch in The City.  We have waited 1+ hours to snag a table here, but it was truly worth it.  Now this husband and wife team used to work at the beloved 42 Degrees, way back when.  Fast forward 15 years, they have taken over a lovely, light-filled space on Potrero Hill.  Nothing fancy, but clean, modern, yet comfortable.  You can't help but smile even after you waited outside for an hour.  It's a cheery spot.  And that's before you take your first bite of food!

We usually order The Plow, which is a short stack of lemon-ricotta pancakes, choice of bacon or sausage, and two eggs.  Now let's talk about the potatoes for a second here.  These are the crowning glory of the place.  They literally make the experience unforgettable.  I'm not a chef, but I do cook some and it seems to me the yukon gold potatoes are fried once, smashed by hand, seasoned with salt, pepper and herbs, and then fried again to a crispy, golden brown.  I am not doing them justice thru my description.  Go ahead, wait an hour on the sidewalk and tell me these don't make you do cartwheels.  They're that crazy good.
The coffee is strong, dark, the juices freshly squeezed, the breads are artisan.  Service is so friendly, so congenial, that if they spilled my potatoes on the floor, I would still give them a warm hug.  Assuming of course, I get a fresh plate of these beauties.

I have yet to venture out and try their fried chicken sandwich, although just sighting it, it looks like it has a strong chance to be a contender against the fried chicken sandwich at Bakesale Bettys or Marlowe's.  

Another unfortunate another minus (along with the wait) is the lack of a full bar.  Sigh.  Can't have it all I suppose.  This comes pretty damn close, I guaran-damn-tee ya.

excerpts: I had the plow which was a great mix of sweet and savory, the lemon ricotta pancakes were like dessert!
My wife had the huevos rancheros and said they were amazing (that's impressive, because she has high standards for mexican food).
If you are ever in SF, you HAVE to check it out.
I promise you will be thanking me.
the plow.author: Josh C.
the plow.review: My wife and I went here a couple months ago while in SF after our friends recommended it to us. One word to describe the breakfast........PHENOMENAL! The array of flavor profiles and the unique menu options set this place apart from many other breakfast spots. I had the plow which was a great mix of sweet and savory, the lemon ricotta pancakes were like dessert! My wife had the huevos rancheros and said they were amazing (that's impressive, because she has high standards for mexican food). If you are ever in SF, you HAVE to check it out. I promise you will be thanking me.

excerpts: Breakfast sandwich, lemon recotta pancakes, and THE PLOW are delicious.
Haven't tried anymore.
Looking forward to the next breakfast there.
Definitely worth stopping by.
the plow.author: Ian P.
the plow.review: Breakfast sandwich, lemon recotta pancakes, and THE PLOW are delicious.  Haven't tried anymore.  Looking forward to the next breakfast there. Definitely worth stopping by.

excerpts: Ordered the plow.
I agree with everything Erica S said.
the plow.author: Alan B.
the plow.review:
Went on a Saturday morning at 8:30 because they open at 8.  The place is tiny, but not packed together and not noisy.  Two big plusses.

It is on a corner and very light filled and airy.  Sort of the hip Potrero crowd.

Sat at the counter and watched all the goings on in the open kitchen.  Ordered the plow.  I agree with everything Erica S said.  The lemon ricotta pancakes are to die for.  Portions just right.

Made my best brunch list.  A real find.  We will definitely go back.

excerpts: I decided to go with "The Plow", which is the restaurants specialty, I guess.

The serving was large enough to fill my gut until late afternoon (I'm 6'0" 160 lbs) and came equipped with 2 eggs, my choice of a meat (unique to other breakfast restaurants), home fries, and the best pancakes I've ever had...
However, they are small if you get them with "The Plow"
the plow.author: Richard H.
the plow.review:
I found Plow by just typing "breakfast/brunch" into the yelp search and this was the first or second listing in the district I was in; figured I'd give it a try.

I most definitely pleased from the moment I walked in.  A small, unassuming, almost modeled after a highway breakfast joint, restaurant with one major visual difference; It's clean!!

The service is quick (I went on a tuesday in the late morning, from other reviews it seems weekends are busier), the restaurant is very quaint, and the servers are very sweet.

The menu, we were there for breakfast, was not overwhelming and each item on the menu was unique in its own way.  I decided to go with "The Plow", which is the restaurants specialty, I guess. The serving was large enough to fill my gut until late afternoon (I'm 6'0" 160 lbs) and came equipped with 2 eggs, my choice of a meat (unique to other breakfast restaurants), home fries, and the best pancakes I've ever had... Lemon Ricotta Pancakes...  My mouth is watering just thinking about them: creamy, rich, moist, with just the right mount of lemon power in them.  However, they are small if you get them with "The Plow", they may be bigger if you order just the cakes.

Overall, my only negative feedback was the price, I'm not disappointed AT ALL but I paid a lunch/dinner price for breakfast.  However, I'm from Florida so I might not be 100% attuned to the California lifestyle just yet.

Most definitely give it a try.... pancakes... /drool

excerpts: If you have never been, get "The Plow" for breakfast.
the plow.author: Louis A.
the plow.review:
The wait can be crazy, but if you go at the right time (between 7-8 in the morning) or at off peak lunch hours, you can usually snag a spot, at least at the counter. 

All of the food is great. I will say that Plow has the best home fries / breakfast potatoes that I have ever had. Fried until crispy, tossed with spices and herbs. They are out of control and go great with everything else Plow brings to the table.

If you have never been, get "The Plow" for breakfast. Comes with one of their lemon ricotta pancakes and house made pork sausage. Also has potatoes, eggs your style and toast. It's big, but if you're hungry, you will not be disappointed by any part of it.

excerpts: I got a call from someone from the Plow and after convincing him that I was not my mother (she lives in Texas???)
he gave me some mealymouthed excuses about how the bug could have only come from inside the clean glass and not the champagne or orange juice.
I just don't believe him, bugs like food not glass.
Anyway, he said they were sorry.
I guess that's taking responsibility nowadays.
I say skip this one and go to anyone of a hundred other places who serve a better, cleaner, bug free and less expensive breakfast.
the plow.author: Mike E.
the plow.review: My son and I went to this restaurant after reading about them on Yelp. We had worked most of the night and decided to treat ourselves. We entered the place and the inside was very nice and seemed clean. We ordered mimosas and eggs, potatoes and DRY toast. The server brought out our drinks and there was a large bug floating in my son's drink. We let the server know and she replaced the drink. Then we got our food, they shorted my son an egg and there was a generous slathering of butter on our toast. We don't eat cow body fluids, they make us sick. Not having much time left before work, we just finished the rest of our breakfast without complaint. I left my son to pay the bill and I walked up the hill to get our car. The bill was $50. Kind of expensive for eggs even with one drink each. Later I started feeling unwell and was wondering (not sure why I did not think of it at the time I was drinking it) if my drink was poured from the same containers as my son's and if there was bug larvae swimming around in my stomach. Those concerns and the expensive bill caused me to e-mail the restaurant and ask. I got a call from someone from the Plow and after convincing him that I was not my mother (she lives in Texas???) he gave me some mealymouthed excuses about how the bug could have only come from inside the clean glass and not the champagne or orange juice. I just don't believe him, bugs like food not glass. Anyway, he said they were sorry. I guess that's taking responsibility nowadays. I say skip this one and go to anyone of a hundred other places who serve a better, cleaner, bug free and less expensive breakfast.

excerpts: I ordered the plow with the house made sausages.
My husband had the plow but with bacon and my friend ordered the Mexican dish (sorry can't remember what it was called but she licked the plate clean).
Oh the ricotta pancakes were really good as everyone has written.
Slight tang and very tasty.
I have to say the meal was tasty and the service was great, but I don't think I would wait longer than 35 min.
Plow is an empirically good restaurant but not extraordinary.
We had a good meal and I'm glad we tried it.
the plow.author: Linda C.
the plow.review: I had read so many amazing reviews about this place that I was afraid my expectations would be too high. We went last Sunday at 8:30 am with baby in tow. Even at 8:30 am we still had to wait about 15 min for a table. I ordered the plow with the house made sausages. My husband had the plow but with bacon and my friend ordered the Mexican dish (sorry can't remember what it was called but she licked the plate clean). Oh the ricotta pancakes were really good as everyone has written. Slight tang and very tasty. I have to say the meal was tasty and the service was great, but I don't think I would wait longer than 35 min. Plow is an empirically good restaurant but not extraordinary. We had a good meal and I'm glad we tried it.

excerpts: I almost always order the Plow with the pork sausage.
the plow.author: Lenny C.
the plow.review: I almost always order the Plow with the pork sausage.  My mom had the Dungeness crab scramble when it was in season and it was good too. The only negative is the wait.  The line can be long on the weekend.  Just ask for a coffee while waiting.

excerpts: I ordered the plow, which I customized to be composed of lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, two fried eggs, and chicken apple sausage.
This was my first time trying lemon ricotta pancakes, which I was little apprehensive about at first, but it has probably become one of my top pancake flavor choices.
I also really enjoyed the potatoes which were seasoned perfectly and had a nice hint of rosemary.
I would have given this place five stars, but my party and I had to constantly keep requesting for more maple syrup and ketchup.
the plow.author: Shannon M.
the plow.review: Probably the best brunch I've ever had in my life. I ordered the plow, which I customized to be composed of lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, two fried eggs, and chicken apple sausage. This was my first time trying lemon ricotta pancakes, which I was little apprehensive about at first, but it has probably become one of my top pancake flavor choices. I also really enjoyed the potatoes which were seasoned perfectly and had a nice hint of rosemary. I would have given this place five stars, but my party and I had to constantly keep requesting for more maple syrup and ketchup.

excerpts: My friend had The Plow, with which she was very pleased.
I'm not a big bacon or egg person, so I ordered the French Toast.
My Gosh.
SOOO GOOD!
The strawberry lavender compote with mascarpone... divine!
It was so much food, I ordered the small and could only finish one.
I took the other slice to go.
The large plate, which has 3 pieces is probably best left to the hungover and those with an insatiable metabolism.
The bacon was amazing and again, I'm not even a bacon person.
The bacon is sourced from a farm in Wisconsin, where the owners are from.
Cute little anecdote.
The ambience is great, the food is amazing, but that wait- damn.
Get up early for an early brunch or do like we did - wait it out.
But highly recommended!
the plow.author: C L.
the plow.review:
This place was great! The downside: we literally waited 1.5 hours to be seated. In that time, my friend and I did a huge circle around Potrero, SOMA and Folsom Street to come back to wait for 30 more minutes. Sunday brunch is only for the strong and brave. 
My friend had The Plow, with which she was very pleased. I'm not a big bacon or egg person, so I ordered the French Toast. My Gosh. SOOO GOOD! The strawberry lavender compote with mascarpone... divine! It was so much food, I ordered the small and could only finish one. I took the other slice to go. The large plate, which has 3 pieces is probably best left to the hungover and those with an insatiable metabolism. The bacon was amazing and again, I'm not even a bacon person. The bacon is sourced from a farm in Wisconsin, where the owners are from. Cute little anecdote. 
The ambience is great, the food is amazing, but that wait- damn. Get up early for an early brunch or do like we did - wait it out. But highly recommended!

excerpts: Our whole party ordered "The Plow" with house made pork sausages and bacon.
The potatoes were so crispy and delicious.
I would totally come back again!
the plow.author: Amy N.
the plow.review: Great place for breakfast! We came here on a Sunday around 9:30am and there was already a one-hour wait. We were about to leave but the hostess convinced us to stay saying that we wouldn't regret it. We filled ourselves up on some coffee and tea and cornbread muffins while we waited outside. We're really happy we stayed! Our whole party ordered "The Plow" with house made pork sausages and bacon. The potatoes were so crispy and delicious. I would totally come back again!

excerpts: I ordered the plow plate and it was a little bit of everything which was perfect!
the plow.author: Hayley P.
the plow.review: Joel and Maxine are the owners of Plow and are amazing people. They are so kind, they have perfected breakfast. Without a doubt this is the best breakfast place I have been too. I ordered the plow plate and it was a little bit of everything which was perfect! I highly recommend getting the almond flour pancakes, delicious!!

excerpts:
I ordered the plow:

Lemon ricotta pancakes - the ricotta gave it an amusing texture

Potatoes - !!!
the plow.author: Amy H.
the plow.review:
For someone who almost never gets excited about or craves breakfast/brunch food. I absolutely loved my meal here. The food made me happy :)

I ordered the plow:

Lemon ricotta pancakes - the ricotta gave it an amusing texture

Potatoes - !!! Best potatoes I've ever had. Hands down. Really crispy and well seasoned. Perfection.

Scrambled eggs - asked for them on the runny side - really fluffy and light - can eggs be ribbon like?

Sausage - they were good but I would want to try the bacon to see how they compare

My bf had the crab scramble which was also really good with fresh crab and well cooked eggs.

I would recommend coming early or you'll end up having to wait 1hr plus :| People were eating outside in the rain - well there was an awning at least.

excerpts: Definitely get the Plow.
It was a good amount of food and delicious.
the plow.author: Bethtina W.
the plow.review: Food was a little posh, expensive, but tasty. Definitely get the Plow. It was a good amount of food and delicious.

excerpts: The PLOW was a standard pancake (it tasted good with a lemony flavor?
the plow.author: Jboogie L.
the plow.review:
Saturday brunch wait around 11am - 30 minutes.  We walked around the neighborhood (Christopher's bookstore, FARLEYS, baked, and some other gift shops around the area)

You have to consistently check in with the host because I noticed that he did not come out of the restaurant to call out tables being available. With that being said, it is a bit irritating because there are plenty of opening and closing the door (there is a wind draft) too. 

We were lucky because we were offered either to sit by the open kitchen or in the back. We opted to sit by the open kitchen. 

I LOVE WATCHING CHEFS IN ACTION. 

DECOR - Modern, simple with metal high chairs and marbled counter tops. It reminds me of being in NYC because of the big sprawling windows as well.  

FOOD - I ordered the Duck Hash with leeks $14. I thought the duck didn't have much flavor. It was chopped up duck and it was prepped ahead of time already. The leek was there but I didn't taste much of the flavor. 
It came with two eggs and two pieces of toast.  The eggs were well made.

The PLOW was a standard pancake (it tasted good with a lemony flavor? i dont remember, a bit fluffy) homemade sausage patties (not too salty which is good), eggs, toast and scrumptious potatoes. 

KITCHEN STAFF - Two Mexican line cooks and probably another two in the back area cleaning the dishes.  

Everything is open so you can see the preparation.   

PARKING - easy street parking in Poterero.

SERVICE - pleasant staff 

I would come back on a less busier day.  THREE STARS FOR FOOD I HAD, FOUR STARS FOR DECOR and SERVICE

excerpts: I ordered The Plow, which is 2 eggs, crispy potatoes, a breakfast meat (I chose bacon), and two lemon ricotta pancakes.
The food was EPIC.
The potatoes were absolutely crispy on the outside, soft on the inside and were made with rosemary and white onions
(I'm sure there were more seasonings, but I don't have the most discerning tongue).
The lemon ricotta pancakes were perfect little clouds of perfection.
They were cooked to perfection with a fantastic lemon taste.
the plow.author: Meranda M.
the plow.review:
Had breakfast at Plow yesterday after reading the reviews on Yelp.  We showed up and the wait was an hour.  This place is teeny tiny, but I will give them credit, they had people moving in and out of there at a decent pace.  We did wait the full hour (maybe a little more), but the wait was worth it.  

I ordered The Plow, which is 2 eggs, crispy potatoes, a breakfast meat (I chose bacon), and two lemon ricotta pancakes.  The food was EPIC.  The potatoes were absolutely crispy on the outside, soft on the inside and were made with rosemary and white onions (I'm sure there were more seasonings, but I don't have the most discerning tongue).  The lemon ricotta pancakes were perfect little clouds of perfection.  They were cooked to perfection with a fantastic lemon taste.  It is my personal mission to learn how to make these.  

My friend had their salmon eggs benedict, which she basically described as the best she has ever had in her life, and that everything was cooked to perfection.  The staff was great, and they even provided free coffee for their customers waiting outside in the rain.  

Worth the wait.

excerpts: I had a dish called The Plow at a place called Plow.
the plow.author: Brevin P.
the plow.review:
The Continuing Case of the Missing Papaya Diamond: By Detective Honeybutter

"An hour wait?!" I scoffed sarcastically, dramatically raising my eyebrows to make it clear to the nearby onlookers in the small eatery that I would have none of this tomfoolery.
"My good man, I missed being knighted by the Queen herself by only three ounces of blood. Had I been conscious I would have been Sir Honeybutter!"
They did not look impressed.
"I have looked into the eyes of the devil himself..." (and then softly to a nearby horrified lady) "... granted in a carnival's haunted house ride where I nearly defecated in my pantaloons..." (and then loudly again so everyone could hear) "...but I have seen things that would make you question your own faith in humanity! I mean, have you SEEN that documentary on the Bieber maiden?" At this point I was escorted out of the building as I yelled on about respect and was asked to wait outside with the others. Whatever happened to respecting a British detective?  
A bloody rut. That's what I was in. The Case of the Missing Papaya Diamond wasn't having a lot of traction. Not for a bloody lack of trying, mind you. Imagine a montage set to a funky bass groove where I kick down doors and chase down perps in dark alleys, screaming at them for answers. And by "chase down perps in dark alleys" I mean "eat a lot of waffles" and by "kick down doors" I mean "take naps". Not sure who I was screaming at outside of the montage, either. No, this was a critical rut. 
It was a Saturday morning stroll that brought me here to Plow. That, and the aroma of bacon. But this common occurrence of having to wait an hour to be seated still baffles me. The fact that most people are fine with this means that I'm either a savage barbarian with no patience or that I'm missing a key vantage point to this observation. So I just stood there in the morning sun, waiting. Thinking about the case. Thinking about little details. Things I might have missed. Overlooked. Suspects. Locations. 
And then it struck me. That eureka moment delegated to only the greatest breakthroughs in modern science and medicine.  
By Toutatis. Of course!
It was here that they called my name and I promptly forgot about my epiphany. Plowed! You may think than an hour goes by quickly when solving mysteries, but my hot tip here is that even though they say it's an hour wait, it probably won't be. Most people don't hang around long enough so you sort of move up the list to get seated. 
I had a dish called The Plow at a place called Plow. It was a decent mix of eggs, amazing bacon (I need to go back and investigate the bacon), magical lemon ricotta pancakes (because it's 2012 and science figured out how to give us this boon to culture) and SWEET MENTAL TIDDLYWINKS THE POTATOES! 
Oh golden crunchy potatoes, wherefor doth thou embrace my taste buds so?
I took my sweet time finishing this meal and will come back soon. It was when I finally waddled away that I remembered the epiphany. 
Game on, Baxter Borneo. Game on.

excerpts: I got an egg sandwich with bacon and Vince w. got the plow.
I'm sure it's their ingredients and the farms they get their produce from because that was one yummy egg sandwich.
The plow order came with some yummy pancakes.
They are dollar pancakes though, but cooked to lemony perfection.
I'm not a pancake fan, but i liked.
the plow.author: Genie S.
the plow.review:
Came here on a weekday.  It was already packed.  We waited about 20 minutes (not bad) and were seated at the counter.  I love their open kitchen and watching the cooks at work.

I got an egg sandwich with bacon and Vince w. got the plow.  I'm sure it's their ingredients and the farms they get their produce from because that was one yummy egg sandwich.  I'm probably so used to eating eggs from hormone injected chickens that I'm used to it!

The plow order came with some yummy pancakes.  They are dollar pancakes though, but cooked to lemony perfection.  I'm not a pancake fan, but i liked. he also got the chicken apple sausage with his order since they ran of the house made pork sausage. boo.  The chicken apple was fine, nothing out of the ordinary.

The potatoes were yum, with just a pinch of salt. 

The service was spotty as I had to get my own ketchup, but then she asked us if we needed water like 5 times. *shrugs*

Go for the eggs!

excerpts: I ordered "The Plow".
Bacon was perfect.
Almond pancakes were also pretty good....a very nice consistency, light and not too cake
-y (often, gluten-free flours yield dense and chewy cakes).
Great service.
Pricey, as the meal with a good tip put me in at $26.
the plow.author: Brian H.
the plow.review: Breakfast Review: went early, 7 am on a weekday. The scene was calm.  Tons of soft morning light was flowing through the massive wall of windows. The coffee is delicious. I ordered "The Plow". Bacon was perfect. Almond pancakes were also pretty good....a very nice consistency, light and not too cake-y (often, gluten-free flours yield dense and chewy cakes). Great service. Pricey, as the meal with a good tip put me in at $26.

excerpts: My husband loves the plow breakfast.
The homefries are among the best I've tasted.
If you get the plow breakfast, trade the home fries for a fruit dish and you won't be sorry.
the plow.author: Brenda B.
the plow.review:
The food is delicious but the service is average. 

I've been twice and both times we had to ask several times for creamer or jam or anything else that did not come on the plate were were served.   No coffee refills offered either.  

If you can get past the service, the food is delicious.  My husband loves the plow breakfast.  The homefries are among the best I've tasted.  Love, love, love the Dungeness Crab scramble.  Toast was too hard.  If you get the plow breakfast, trade the home fries for a fruit dish and you won't be sorry.  Homemade sausage is pretty amazing too.

Go early on a weekday and you won't have to wait :)

excerpts: I got the plow and potatoes were very tasty
(I guess they'd have to be because they're deep fried?), bacon was good, eggs were done to my specification, lemon-ricotta pancakes were small and manageable and tasty....
the plow.author: Easter E.
the plow.review:
Liked this place just fine!  It's a small place and it's popular so you'll have to go expecting quite a wait... especially on weekends... but that's ok... especially on lazy sundays... we waited about 45 minutes...the same they told us the wait would be...  We got a table inside... nice... clean..... host/hostess were very cheery and nice... service was excellent... I always like that at a restaurant.  Food was very good.  I got the plow and potatoes were very tasty (I guess they'd have to be because they're deep fried?), bacon was good, eggs were done to my specification, lemon-ricotta pancakes were small and manageable and tasty.... all in all, a good experience... 

good service always equals the 5th star!

excerpts: I had "the plow" there for $13 -  "two eggs, choice of Nueske bacon, house made pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage, 2 pancakes, and crispy potatoes."
I saw the Chinese sausage there on the menu, and they allowed me to substitute that for my sausage choice.
The food came relatively quick, presented nicely on a white plate.
the plow.author: Leo C.
the plow.review:
Plow offers a clean and relaxed atmosphere to enjoy a fresh and delicious breakfast/brunch.  I came here jet lagged after getting off a trans-pacific flight, looking for a satisfying meal that features fresh ingredients.  Plow did the job for sure.  

I had "the plow" there for $13 -  "two eggs, choice of Nueske bacon, house made pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage, 2 pancakes, and crispy potatoes."  I saw the Chinese sausage there on the menu, and they allowed me to substitute that for my sausage choice.  The food came relatively quick, presented nicely on a white plate.  The server was very attentive and nice while conscious of not being bothersome.  

Overall, Plow is a place that I'd come back to as well as recommend to my friends.  It's not a great value since the price is somewhat premium for what you're getting.  But it's also very fresh and clean, so the price is fair.  Come check it out!

excerpts: The Plow is their "greatest hits" plate and in the past
I know they had blood sausage on the menu, which was wonderfully done!
The setting is also beautiful and intimate, and the service is always spot on.
Every time I've been there, I've seen the husband and wife who own Plow behind the counter, talking to customers, which I think really shows how much they enjoy being involved in the business.
I'll never stop loving this place and I can't wait to go back!
the plow.author: Ava J.
the plow.review: I. LOVE. PLOW. I seriously cannot say enough gushing things about this place without making people think I'm being facetious. The way they do their crispy potatoes reminds me a little bit of Lola in Seattle; smashed and fried so they're crispy on the outside with a fluffy center. In a word, "spectacular!" I always ask for a little of their aioli to go along with it. The Plow is their "greatest hits" plate and in the past I know they had blood sausage on the menu, which was wonderfully done! The setting is also beautiful and intimate, and the service is always spot on. Every time I've been there, I've seen the husband and wife who own Plow behind the counter, talking to customers, which I think really shows how much they enjoy being involved in the business. I'll never stop loving this place and I can't wait to go back!

excerpts: The Plow breakfast is unmatched.
You can really do no better; love this place.
the plow.author: Jesse L.
the plow.review: I get it now. The Plow breakfast is unmatched. You can really do no better; love this place.

excerpts: I had the fried egg sandwich with bacon, the boyfriend had the plow.
Both were a win.
The eggs had the perfect amount of leaky yolk and the bun..omg...
i mean...
how fluffy can a bun get??
I wouldn't mind ordering the same items on my next visit
the plow.author: Mimi N.
the plow.review: Oh my gawd this place is uh-mazingggg.  I had the fried egg sandwich with bacon, the boyfriend had the plow.  Both were a win.  The eggs had the perfect amount of leaky yolk and the bun..omg...i mean... how fluffy can a bun get?? I wouldn't mind ordering the same items on my next visit but I'll probably try the dungeness crab scramble along with 5 orders of lemon ricotta pancakes......

excerpts: Food was good, but portion size of "the plow" was misleading.
the plow.author: Bryan L.
the plow.review: Food was good, but portion size of "the plow" was misleading.  Menu said two eggs, choice of bacon or sausage, crispy potatoes, and two pancakes.  I'm thinking upscale grand slam breakfast at Denny's.  Pancakes were about 2 inch diameter.  Tasty, but not very filling.  Two eggs would be more correctly labeled two small eggs.  Had to grab a sandwich shortly afterward to carry me through to dinner.

excerpts: Max's buttermilk biscuits and gravy, the plow and the eggs Benedict.
the plow.author: Grant T.
the plow.review:
What a great idea for brunch, and when we finally got seated, it was scrumptious.  We were a party of 5, so if you also have a party of 5, be prepared to wait a while as pretty much the only accommodation is at the bench in the back of the place.  It was a freezing cold Sunday morning, and with a very small waiting area, be prepared to wait outside.  What else is new in the city.  Coffee is provided to help temper the masses.  The staff were very friendly and helpful and the food was savory.  We had the donuts, the lemon ricotta pancakes, Max's buttermilk biscuits and gravy, the plow and the eggs Benedict.  All of the ingredients were distinctive and flavorful and their combination's symphonic.  

Although I froze my arse off waiting for a table, the view of downtown and the Bay waterfront was relaxing.  You gotta go experience this place!

excerpts: My husband got the Plow, which is great because you get to try a bit of everything, including the famous lemon ricotta pancakes.
My husband isn't a huge lemon fan, but this was just a slight lemon flavor
so he (and I) really liked them.
the plow.author: Lauren M.
the plow.review:
This place had been on my list for a while but my husband isn't a fan of waiting an hour to eat somewhere so we always avoided it. One sunday we were up early enough that I convinced him to go with me. We got there right at 9am and the timing seemed to be good, got busier after that. There were tables outside that were open but it was pretty cold, so we waited for inside. The wait was about 20 minutes or so, didn't seem too bad. 

I got the dungeness crab scramble which was delish, and as others have said, the potatoes are awesome. My husband got the Plow, which is great because you get to try a bit of everything, including the famous lemon ricotta pancakes. My husband isn't a huge lemon fan, but this was just a slight lemon flavor so he (and I) really liked them. The fresh OJ is great too.

Service once inside was quick and I felt the food was worth it. Not sure we'd make it a regular thing considering the wait, but it is a great spot.

excerpts: ( we both got the plow)
Service was great, they took in a pushy family after they had already closed, would love to go again soon.
the plow.author: John K.
the plow.review: The potatoes are as good as everyone claims. The gluten-free pancakes made my girlfriend cry, literally, because she hasn't had any so good since she got the no-gluten news. The lemon-ricotta ones are fantastic as well, something sweet to balance out the rest of the dish. ( we both got the plow) Service was great, they took in a pushy family after they had already closed, would love to go again soon.

excerpts: I had the Plow which was 2 eggs, potatoes, bacon and two lemon ricotta pancakes.
Everything was very high quality but those pancakes...
wow.
Service was great, everyone was very nice and I can't wait to go back as soon as I get the chance.
the plow.author: Jamie C.
the plow.review: I had one of the best brunches of my life at this place the other day. Their menu had some really interesting choices like a Chinese breakfast with caramelized pork shoulder but they also had some very elevated basics. I had the Plow which was 2 eggs, potatoes, bacon and two lemon ricotta pancakes. Everything was very high quality but those pancakes...wow. Service was great, everyone was very nice and I can't wait to go back as soon as I get the chance.

excerpts: I went for the weekend brunch and ordered The Plow because I like to get a little taste of everything.
Potatoes, sausage, lemon pancakes yum, yum, yum.

I went late in the day so it was beginning to clear out however, the place is pretty tiny so I would imagine it gets packed at prime time.

excerpts: I got "the plow", which came with scrambled eggs, their homemade pork sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes.
The homemade pork sausage was slightly spicy with really good flavor, while the pancakes were super soft and tasty.
I liked how they were mini pancakes and not the huge ones you'd get at like
IHOP/Denny's.
The crispy potatoes were a little too salty for me, but my bf liked them.
I might have been able to eat the whole plate of food if it weren't for the monkey bread, but I did find many couples sharing the plow, if the other person ordered something small.
My bf got the fried egg sandwich that came with two eggs fried, cheddar, frisee, aioli, crispy potatoes  and Nueske bacon.
It looked good, and was an adequate sized sandwich.
I was tempted to order their organic yogurt with granola and mixed fruit, but felt I needed to order something more substancial since it was our first time here.
the plow.author: Joycelyn L.
the plow.review:
Tasty, well-portioned meals, get here before 9am if coming for brunch so you don't have to wait in line.

Came here Sunday morning before 9am and were lucky to get some bar seats in front of all the cooks.  It was neat to see how they cooked everything.  We started off with the monkey bread and it tasted just like cinnamon buns, just not as sweet and without the sugary frosting spread all on it.  I got "the plow", which came with scrambled eggs, their homemade pork sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes.  The homemade pork sausage was slightly spicy with really good flavor, while the pancakes were super soft and tasty.  I liked how they were mini pancakes and not the huge ones you'd get at like IHOP/Denny's.  The crispy potatoes were a little too salty for me, but my bf liked them.  I might have been able to eat the whole plate of food if it weren't for the monkey bread, but I did find many couples sharing the plow, if the other person ordered something small.  My bf got the fried egg sandwich that came with two eggs fried, cheddar, frisee, aioli, crispy potatoes  and Nueske bacon.  It looked good, and was an adequate sized sandwich.  I was tempted to order their organic yogurt with granola and mixed fruit, but felt I needed to order something more substancial since it was our first time here.  Plus, you can make that at home.

Overall, one of the better brunch places I've been to and will surely come back for more.

excerpts: I had the plow, it was ridiculously tasty!
the plow.author: Caroline L.
the plow.review: I had the plow, it was ridiculously tasty! The lemon ricotta pancakes were the fluffiest, most delicious cakes I have ever had.

I had the plow, it was rustic, hearty and packed full of wonderful flavors. The potatoes were so good, perfectly golden crispy and made good for dipping into my over medium eggs. That's how I eat my potatoes. The sausage was absolutely smashing, both patties had a tasty caramelized exterior while the inside was full of dripping goodness. I love the taste of fennel in sausage and it was just the right amount.  The lemon ricotta cakes were a nice touch and added a perfectly sweet balance to compliment such seasonfull meal.  I want more!

excerpts: Everything on the plate ( I had the plow with bacon and scrambled eggs) was perfectly seasoned, I didn't know what to indulge in first!
the plow.author: Kirsty E.
the plow.review: I came here with a friend yesterday and pretty much died and went to food heaven. Hands down one of the best brunches I have ever tasted and I dine out a lot! Everything on the plate ( I had the plow with bacon and scrambled eggs) was perfectly seasoned, I didn't know what to indulge in first! The creamy eggs were so flavorful and no additional salt needed and the lemon ricotta pancakes were heavenly! I was tempted to lick my plate but contained myself! Sure their was a wait but well worth it on the cute benches soaking up the march sun. I've waited longer in line for mediocre brunch at other places and in SF it is to be expected. Pop your name on the list, go grab a coffee and treat yourself to this hidden gem in Potrero hill, you won't regret it :-)

the plow.review:
Came here for brunch on thursday morning and it was still crowded! me plus 4 more didnt have to wait long for a table although they dont seat larger parties of 6 due to the size.  The kitchen is open with a bar like seating in front. i ordered the herloom tomato salad, fruit cup and the side order of crispy potatoes....to the demand of my friend who adamantly raved about their potatoes.  I have to say it was the best crispy potatoes ive ever had and i dont even like potatoes.  They didnt have the overly dipped in oil kinda taste nor was it so starchy you couldnt eat the rest of your meal.  yum. the fruits were not standard fruit cup (thank god), rather i had pears, figs, grapes.  double yum. anddd lastly the heirloom tomatoes which ive been dying to order at a restaurant since their now in season, was sliced, drizzled in olive oil with avocados on top.  Didnt seem like much but it was pretty filling and i was completely satisfied with my mini meals for brunch.  The ambiance was bright and relaxing for a chilly morning.  

if i still ate meat, i would definitely recommend the plow plate:  two eggs, choice of meat, and a side of crispy potatoes and pancake.  I definitely stood out of my table of 4 plow plates and one vegetarian dish. =)

excerpts: The Plow.
the plow.author: Katie W.
the plow.review:
sheer. 

perfection. 

I am tempted to simply leave my review at that, but being a long-winded know-it-all, I simply cannot. 

Sunny, quiet and quite practically perfect in every way was the day. We stepped in at about 9 and were promptly seated in the most quaint and lovely Farmhouse-esque setting. Beautiful wooden tables, great large windows for viewing clean little Potreo Hill. 

Enough about that fluff. The vitals. So gorgeous in it's simplicity, so delicious in literally every bite. The menu is small, but crafted in such a way that anyone could find something to fit their tastes to a tee. For me? The Plow. 

This includes your choice of breakfast meat, 2 eggs any way, potatoes and pancakes. Sounds like a standard from anywhere. But here, that's just not fair nor accurate. Those eggs, so fresh, that bacon - so full of actual ham flavor - but those potatoes. NO ONE does potatoes correctly when eating out. They need to be tender inside, extremely crispy outside and have the right amount of seasoning, no grease and if you're lucky, accompanied by great caramelized onions. I thought only my Mom could make this magic. She must have divulged her secret to the Chefs at Plow. Never were potatoes so right OUTSIDE of my Mother's kitchen. 
Let's not though, forget those pancakes. These are light, airy, moist. These are LEMON. Lemon ricotta pancakes that are so subtle and meek in their own little corner of your plate, you would never expect them to absolutely wow you, as they are certain to do. 

People are funny about their breakfasts, they all know what's the best and where to get said "best," but unless they are speaking of Plow, they are just wrong. 

However, maybe they are smarter than me and telling you other places to go so as not to form a line at Plow... 
shit.

the plow.review:
Not so excited about Plow. I like the idea of it, getting produce and meat from local farms. The simple menu and ambiance are a refreshing change form most overcrowded restaurants and over processed foods. I went on a bright and warm SF morning for brunch. I expected the ait to be long based on the previous reviews I read while I was browsing through on my phone. My part and I were offered coffee during our wait. We were seated about 45 minutes after our arrival. We opted to eat outside on account of the beautiful day. We were handed menu but waited an additional 20-25 minutes until our order was actually taken. I ordered 'The Plow' with bacon and added eggs and denied the toast and pancakes to fit my diet. My friends and I chit chat and it took absolutely forever to actually get our meals. I want to say it was at least 30 minutes, either way it was enough time for me to get borderline 'slap a b**ch I'm so hungry' crazy.

I wasn't crazy about my food. My scrambled eggs were overcooked and I thought I could have at least gotten a few more pieces of bacon. Call me crazy, I'm not asking for a crazy Cheescake Factory amount of food when it's quality but I fell Plow was lacking in Quality. I could have gone on an off day so I will definitely give it another chance.

Other parties of three who were in line behind us for the first seating at 8am were seated at tables that could seat 4.  Why were we discriminated against?  Now for the food.  I ordered the egg scramble with goat cheese, oyster mushroom, and nettles.  The eggs were watery, the nettles and mushrooms were stringy and tough.  There were clumps of goat cheese throughout.  The worst about the eggs was that it was extremely salty.  It was impossible to eat and I left 3/4 of the eggs  on my plate.  My husband ordered the Plow which was edible.  The bacon came out all clumped together as if the cook had just thrown it on the plate.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were heavy.  As you can tell, we will not be back.  So not worth it!!

excerpts: We both ordered the Plow, which is their little-bit-of-everything (2 eggs, meat of your choice, potatoes and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes).
I actually asked to switch the potatoes for a slice of French toast, which I think is somewhat unheard of given the confusion it caused the line cooks (who we were watching the entire time).
The service is top notch, as our waitress caught the cooks on a couple occasions to make sure the plates came out as ordered.
The pancakes were fresh but didn't really taste strongly of lemon and were underwhelming, which made me glad that I had solid-but-not-spectacular french toast to compensate.

The house-made pork sausage was decent but could've used a much heavier hand of sage to make it really like breakfast sausage (for those of you who don't like the flavor of breakfast sausage, then this is perfect for you).
I stole a piece of potato from my friend, which was essentially smashed (as opposed to cut) potatoes thrown into a deep fryer to attain great crispy texture throughout.
Overall the ambience is clean and comfortable, and I wasn't feeling overly greased from the meal (always a good thing).
I'll be back to order other things off the menu next time
(they look like they put a ton of Dungeness crab into their scrambled eggs), but I'm also still on the look-out for a better brunch place in SF.

The house-made pork sausage was decent but could've used a much heavier hand of sage to make it really like breakfast sausage (for those of you who don't like the flavor of breakfast sausage, then this is perfect for you).  I stole a piece of potato from my friend, which was essentially smashed (as opposed to cut) potatoes thrown into a deep fryer to attain great crispy texture throughout.  Overall the ambience is clean and comfortable, and I wasn't feeling overly greased from the meal (always a good thing).  I'll be back to order other things off the menu next time (they look like they put a ton of Dungeness crab into their scrambled eggs), but I'm also still on the look-out for a better brunch place in SF.
