the plow.author: Candace F.
the plow.review: Brunch was the name of the game. I came here on a holiday and it was prime time for brunch/lunch. We scored awesome parking up on the hill. We walked in and put our name on the list and took a nice stroll in the neighborhood. I never get a chance to visit this side of town. After a 35 minute wait, we were seated. We shared the butternut squash soup and the plow. The soup was flavorful, you can taste the spices. The plow came with 2 pancakes, choice of sausage, potato chunks and eggs. I'm just glad we shared the meal, that would be too much food for me.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were to die for. The best I've had, the pancakes were light and fluffy. The equator coffee was a good companion to the brunch, definitely strong. Would come back for more pancakes and crunchy potatoes.

excerpts: I got the Plow and O M G
it was delicious!
The definition of comfort food exactly the way you dream of it!
The fact that it is prepared so carefully with so much attention to detail is so unexpected- sets the bar for breakfast pretty high!
the plow.author: Sasha D.
the plow.review:
Hands down best breakfast i have ever had! I am not a "hipster" as other reviews with 3 stars have said. I just love to f*cking eat! I got the Plow and O M G it was delicious! The definition of comfort food exactly the way you dream of it! The fact that it is prepared so carefully with so much attention to detail is so unexpected- sets the bar for breakfast pretty high! The sign out front should say "heaven this way"

Lemon Ricotta pancakes cannot be missed!!

excerpts: the plow: typical breakfast, but good fresh flavors.
the plow.author: Tea Lyves ..
the plow.review:
french toast: they make it using a baguette rather than toast. topped with roasted peaches and marscapone... different and delicious!

the plow: typical breakfast, but good fresh flavors. their potatoes are different though, super crispy and fresh fluffy potato-goodness inside! 

chicken tinga: good textures with the soft egg and crispy tortilla... reminds me of breakfast in puerto vallarta, but with SF's finest ingredients :)

* corn millet muffin, peach pie, chinese breakfast, and tomato soup was sold out and we got there around 1:30pm.

excerpts: My go-to breakfast item consists of something sweet and savory, so I immediately gravitated towards the plow.
The chicken apple sausages were juicy with a nice sweet counterbalance, but not particularly noteworthy.
The much lauded potatoes were indeed perfectly crispy without being too greasy.
the plow.author: Jeremy C.
the plow.review:
Found a seat at the counter afte a 30 minute wait - cramped without a place to put your jacket, but it does have a front row view of the open kitchen and the bustling chefs.

My go-to breakfast item consists of something sweet and savory, so I immediately gravitated towards the plow.  The chicken apple sausages were juicy with a nice sweet counterbalance, but not particularly noteworthy.  The much lauded potatoes were indeed perfectly crispy without being too greasy.  The highlight, however were the lemon ricotta pancakes - texture-wise it was more like a cake.  Light, tangy, and fluffy - definitely the best pancakes I've had in the bay, and two of them were not enough.

excerpts: And the Plow - is just awesome.

To top it off, when we were done, we asked the waitress where we should walk to try and hail a cab, as the restaurant is in a more residential area, and we were worried that taxis wouldn't be readily available.
She instantly offered to call one for us!
As we were waiting in front while she was on the phone, she noticed one down the street and we were able to hail that one.
It was impressive that she was going out of her way to help us, as she did more than we were expecting!
This is a definite must, and if we lived in the area, would definitely come back many more times!
the plow.author: Bryan F.
the plow.review: While visiting San Francisco, we tried to find places that were not the "tourist traps" of the city for dining.  Plow's great reviews on Yelp lead us to venture to this small, yet excellent restaurant just 10 minutes by taxi from our hotel.  When we got there, we were promptly greeted by the hostess, and got our name on the list.   The wait was about 20 minutes on a Sunday morning around 10.  The service was fantastic, and the food was even better.   What gives their dishes a final "wow" are the crispy potatoes.  Never have I had a potato fried and seasoned quite like theirs.  They were excellent.  The fried egg sandwich, while good - should only be eaten with a knife and fork.  And the Plow - is just awesome.   To top it off, when we were done, we asked the waitress where we should walk to try and hail a cab, as the restaurant is in a more residential area, and we were worried that taxis wouldn't be readily available.  She instantly offered to call one for us!   As we were waiting in front while she was on the phone, she noticed one down the street and we were able to hail that one.  It was impressive that she was going out of her way to help us, as she did more than we were expecting!  This is a definite must, and if we lived in the area, would definitely come back many more times!

excerpts: So I decided on the plow, which was kinda like their combo breakfast with eggs, bacon or sausage, potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes!
Hubby took a bit longer to decide and finally went with the plow as well.
I got the bacon and hubby got the home made sausage patties.
The food took about 15 minutes to come out because the kitchen was so busy.
There were 3 people in the kitchen and they were hustling nonstop.
Finally the food came out and it was worth the wait!
My scrambled eggs were cooked perfectly, nice and delicate.
The bacon was good
but I wish it was a little bit crispier.
The potatoes were awesome.
They were so crispy on the outside but soft on the inside.
They were also perfectly seasoned and mixed with sauteed onions.
With a little bit of ketchup, we were all set.
The lemon ricotta pancakes were delicious, so soft, fluffy, and lemony, and came with a side of maple syrup.
I tried the homemade sausage and loved it.
They were so flavorful with all the herbs and spices.
the plow.author: Kat M.
the plow.review:
We've been wanting to come here for a long time, but I like to sleep in on my weekends and don't really like to wait over an hour for brunch.  Yesterday, we had a full day of activities planned and had to be out and about early anyway, so I thought why not make the most of a Saturday morning and make a trip to Plow for breakfast?

We got there a little before 9:30 and there was already a wait, but the host assured us it would only be a 15-20 minute wait.  In the meantime, he offered us coffee. Such a small and simple gesture, but always appreciated! Exactly 20 minutes later, we were seated at the counter where we could check out all the cooking action in the small, open kitchen.  It made it so hard to decide what to get because everything coming out looked so damn good. 

So I decided on the plow, which was kinda like their combo breakfast with eggs, bacon or sausage, potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes! Hubby took a bit longer to decide and finally went with the plow as well.  I got the bacon and hubby got the home made sausage patties. The food took about 15 minutes to come out because the kitchen was so busy.  There were 3 people in the kitchen and they were hustling nonstop. Finally the food came out and it was worth the wait! My scrambled eggs were cooked perfectly, nice and delicate.  The bacon was good but I wish it was a little bit crispier. The potatoes were awesome.  They were so crispy on the outside but soft on the inside.  They were also perfectly seasoned and mixed with sauteed onions.  With a little bit of ketchup, we were all set.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were delicious, so soft, fluffy, and lemony, and came with a side of maple syrup.  I tried the homemade sausage and loved it.  They were so flavorful with all the herbs and spices.  Next time, I am so getting the sausage patties! 

We had such a good meal here.  Not only was the food so delicious, but everyone there was so friendly and nice.  I loved their decor, so simple and bright with huge windows.  It just felt like a pleasant place to spend your weekend morning.  The great thing about sitting at the counter was that we got to see all the different stuff they had, so we had good ideas about what to order next time.  I was definitely intrigued by the fried pig ears! I know it sounds weird but they looked so good - light and crispy with what looked like a side of jalapeno vinaigrette.  Oh and I must have the chocolate eclair.  So many things to try next time.  I guess I'll need to plan another early morning to go to Plow again!

excerpts: Highlights: the plow (nice to try a little bit of everything), almond flour pancakes, corn + cheddar bun.
Cute neighborhood spot.
the plow.author: Daisy Y.
the plow.review: Came here for weekend brunch with the family.  Arrived around 930a and waited about 25 minutes or so.  Not bad, was expecting a longer wait.  Ordered a bunch of dishes and shared them.  Highlights: the plow (nice to try a little bit of everything), almond flour pancakes, corn + cheddar bun.  Cute neighborhood spot.

excerpts: Got the Plow, and it was just ... mmphhh, so delicious.
I really wish I got to try the eggs benedict or the fried egg sandwich.
My friend got the fried egg sandwich with bacon
and I drooled watching him eat it.
the plow.author: Samantha Sydnie S.
the plow.review: Wait is definitely not the business, but they say Tuesday and Wednesday's aren't as busy. Everything looked so good. Got the Plow, and it was just ... mmphhh, so delicious. I really wish I got to try the eggs benedict or the fried egg sandwich. My friend got the fried egg sandwich with bacon and I drooled watching him eat it.

excerpts: I got the Plow breakfast plate
(I think that was the name) which included eggs, potatoes, and two pancakes.
Even though it's a pretty standard dish it just tasted better than I expected.
The potatoes are crispy on the outside, soft on the inside and tossed with just the right amount of salt and some nice onions too.
The freshness of the ingredients really makes a difference.
I tried my friend's egg benedict with spinach and mushrooms
and it was cooked to perfection.
All our food was seemingly simple but wonderfully delicious and memorable.
The nuances of the fresh ingredients really make all the difference in the flavors in the dishes.
I felt totally satisfied but not overly stuffed nor heavy after my meal at Plow.
I will definitely be back, although only on a day where I have the patience to wait in a ridiculous long line.
I hope they expand soon!
the plow.author: Sherene C.
the plow.review:
I live in the Dogpatch and was very excited to have a new breakfast/brunch spot in the neighborhood. It looked modern but homey and like something definitely worth a try but...that line! On any given weekend morning there will be a crowd of people hanging out outside. I started resenting Plow for taunting me with its newness while shutting me out with it's dreadful long lines. "It's already over-hyped," I secretly thought to myself. Anyway, I finally bit the bullet and tried it out last weekend. The wait time was 45 minutes for a table for three. Ugh. They offer complementary coffee inside to soften the pain of waiting but it runs out quickly and people inside are too busy to keep it replenished. It is probably good business for Farley's, the coffee shop up the street.

Anyway, we finally got seated and I have to say the ambiance is simple but nice. It's going for a clean rustic vibe to go along with it's philosophy of using local, seasonal, farm-fresh ingredients. I works for me. We shared the lemon ricotta pancakes. SUPER DELICIOUS. I got the Plow breakfast plate (I think that was the name) which included eggs, potatoes, and two pancakes. Even though it's a pretty standard dish it just tasted better than I expected. The potatoes are crispy on the outside, soft on the inside and tossed with just the right amount of salt and some nice onions too. The freshness of the ingredients really makes a difference. I tried my friend's egg benedict with spinach and mushrooms and it was cooked to perfection. All our food was seemingly simple but wonderfully delicious and memorable. The nuances of the fresh ingredients really make all the difference in the flavors in the dishes. I felt totally satisfied but not overly stuffed nor heavy after my meal at Plow. I will definitely be back, although only on a day where I have the patience to wait in a ridiculous long line. I hope they expand soon!

excerpts: I ordered "the Plow" (lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and poached eggs).
My bf ordered the "fried egg sandwich" which came with crispy potatoes.
I'm not much of a pancake eater, but my goodness these were absolutely delicious and unique.
The texture was great too--not too fluffy and not flat.
The potatoes were the crispiest I've ever eaten, and my bf agrees.
They are salted to perfection.
I highly recommend this place.
It's nestled away in a residential and hilly area.
Totally worth the price (I believe our bill came out to be ~$40) including a coffee.
Cute shop.
Clean and packed.
the plow.author: D C.
the plow.review: This place is absolutely delicious and the atmosphere is relaxed and cute. We were in line for Mama's for 30 min and moved about one foot before we decided to ditch Mama's and try somewhere else. So glad we did! This place had less than a 10 min wait (late breakfast). The waitress was nice, and the food arrived rather promptly. There were big glass jars of water at each table so we could refill as we liked. I ordered "the Plow" (lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and poached eggs). My bf ordered the "fried egg sandwich" which came with crispy potatoes. I'm not much of a pancake eater, but my goodness these were absolutely delicious and unique. The texture was great too--not too fluffy and not flat. The potatoes were the crispiest I've ever eaten, and my bf agrees. They are salted to perfection. I highly recommend this place. It's nestled away in a residential and hilly area. Totally worth the price (I believe our bill came out to be ~$40) including a coffee. Cute shop. Clean and packed.

excerpts: I had "The Plow" which had probably the best lemon ricotta pancakes I've ever tasted.
Everything was satisfying and was perfect to kick off a lazy Saturday afternoon.
NOTES:
Theres a bit of a bustle inside, so it would be best for a more lively crowd to join you.
The parking is easily found, but the wait can be a bit long.
Try to get there early to potentially avoid a rush.
I noticed people having sidewalk cocktails while waiting, which I'll be sure to remember the next time I wait.
the plow.author: Sun M.
the plow.review: All the press reviews are right-  Plow is a GREAT brunch spot. The ambience has a modern rustic feel- as well as the food.  It's all the staples of the best of brunch food... only kicked up a notch.  I had "The Plow" which had probably the best lemon ricotta pancakes I've ever tasted.  Everything was satisfying and was perfect to kick off a lazy Saturday afternoon.  NOTES: Theres a bit of a bustle inside, so it would be best for a more lively crowd to join you. The parking is easily found, but the wait can be a bit long.  Try to get there early to potentially avoid a rush.  I noticed people having sidewalk cocktails while waiting, which I'll be sure to remember the next time I wait.

excerpts: My friend had the Plow and I tried his pancakes.
They were awesome!
I will have to try his order next time...
the plow.author: Ling L.
the plow.review:
Love the decor - light, bright, and airy.  The potatoes are to die for - probably the best I have had in a LONG LONG time.  I had the fried chicken sandwich, which was very good, but a bit skimpy on the meat.  I like Bakesale Betty's the best still.

My friend had the Plow and I tried his pancakes.  They were awesome!  I will have to try his order next time...

excerpts: A friend got their big breakfast plate "The Plow" which also turned out to be amazing.
the plow.author: Nitta P. B.
the plow.review: I went there for the first time today for brunch, and god, what an amazing food!!!!! LOVE, LOVE, LOVE everything about this place. The service was great, ambience was awesome, and above all, the FOOD!! We were seated on the counter, I got a pot of jasmine tea and it comes in this cutesy little pot, enough for 1 1/2 cup. Then ordered the dungeness crab scramble which turned out to be a little bland on the egg, but the chunks of crab meat was perfect and the egg was not overcooked, so it balanced out. Homefries that comes with the egg was AMAZING. Crunchy, well-seasoned, I mean, it was just perfect. A friend got their big breakfast plate "The Plow" which also turned out to be amazing. Comes with two eggs, freshly made pork sausage, two ricotta cheese pancakes and potatoes. The pork sausage was very nice and the eggs was done to perfection, enough liquid egg yolk to dip your pancake in! YUM! Another friend got smoked trout salad and that was very nice, too. The beetroot gave the salad a little kick and avocado mashed into frisée was nicely done, the trout tastes great. Ended up paying $60 and it was worth every penny. Very filling and satisfying first experience there. I WILL DEFINITELY be back for more! Their baked egg looks amazing and I shall put that on my list to try next time.

excerpts: the first day, i ordered the plow with chicken apple sausage.
everything was great and filling, but i wasn't sold on the sausage.
the plow.author: Ashley F.
the plow.review:
oh goodness.  never has a breakfast joint revitalized my affinity for morning meals (okay, slight exaggeration but who cares).  i've recently given up breakfast out of laziness, but it's amazing what lengths you'll go to for a place like this with good company.  :]  my friends and i came here on fridays for three straight weeks to try out all the dishes that we wanted.  while some things fell flat, i was mostly pleased whenever i left.

first off:  the coffee.  tasty and a nice pick-me-up for my sleepy mornings, especially if you wake up before six just to get some grub.  and can i just gush about their granulated brown sugar?  i think they use ramekins for it as presentation, and it's the cutest thing ever.  however, the last time i was there, they had white sugar cubes instead, and it made the coffee taste a little weird.  :|

second:  i mentioned it briefly, but everything from their containers to their choice of water pitchers (or bottles, in their case) to their napkins - guh, this place is smartly decorated.  first impressions are everything, and they present a good one!  moreover, it helps in my anticipation to try what they have to offer.  nice sense of décor = must be good.  :P  (also, their website makes the minimalist in me extremely happy!  simplicity goes a long way, people.)

the first day, i ordered the plow with chicken apple sausage.  everything was great and filling, but i wasn't sold on the sausage.  same thing happened the second time i was there when i ordered their two eggs and tried the pork instead.  i don't know, i'm just not a big fan of it in general, though it never hurts to try on the off-chance i'm blown away.  the third day i ordered some sides, but it was enough for me.  oh, and on the second day, i had a bite of my friend's lemon ricotta pancakes.

!  so delicious!  i normally stray away from anything cheese-like in my sweet foods, but i was pleasantly surprised by it!  i think i saw another review here that said the size of these pancakes were small ...?    buh.  i don't know, man.  the pancakes were pretty huge.  then again, everyone has their own idea about what a perfect portion is, so no big deal.

lemon ricotta pancakes aside, the food is average breakfast fare that's touched up enough to set it apart.  i just have a tendency to gloss over the tiny details because i'm easily fascinated by little things (pretty sugar in cute ceramic!).

service is a bit hit-or-miss, depending on who's working.  they're nice (i'm reluctant to say this because it's a very distant kind of niceness) enough and attentive, frequently checking up on your table if you need coffee refills and the like (i haven't been there while it was really busy, so i'm not sure if it's any different during a rush) so it's not so much as a complaint as it is an observation for improvement.

better off as a 3.5 establishment, but i'm okay with rounding up for the memorable rush of excitement i had with my friends.  :]

excerpts: I ordered the Plow which features some of the favorites - eggs, choice of meat, crispy potatoes (which were to die for) and lemon ricotta pancakes.
Very pleased with the service, food and ambiance
Wish I lived there
so I could go more often!
the plow.author: Katherine C.
the plow.review: Plow was on my list of places to try while in San Francisco for a while, and on a recent trip to the city I finally got to go! I arrived around 9 am on a Sunday and there was about an hour wait, which was well worth it! They offered coffee for waiting customers which helped on a chilly morning. I ordered the Plow which features some of the favorites - eggs, choice of meat, crispy potatoes (which were to die for) and lemon ricotta pancakes. Very pleased with the service, food and ambiance Wish I lived there so I could go more often!

excerpts: I had the plow, with bacon/scrambled eggs and there was much to savor.
The eggs were ummm, potatoes OUTSTANDING and the bacon, I could have had a whole plate of the bacon by itself.
The space is airy & lightfilled, and the retained Edwardian details add much.
The host (Randall) was solid, on his toes, attentive professional and warm.
the plow.author: Rosa R.
the plow.review: I have been scoping this place out as it is on my way to/from work. Went on my own for brunch and got a seat at the counter right away! (groups, families, couples waiting) Waitress (Danielle) was attentive and sweet, cooks were intense and focused; the synergy between them was intriguing. But the food, ah the food was sublime. I had the plow, with bacon/scrambled eggs and there was much to savor. The eggs were ummm, potatoes OUTSTANDING and the bacon, I could have had a whole plate of the bacon by itself.  The space is airy & lightfilled, and the retained Edwardian details add much.  The host (Randall) was solid, on his toes, attentive professional and warm.

excerpts: so I tried THE PLOW.
the plow.author: Neil A.
the plow.review:
I had one of those Sundays where I didn't want to make breakfast.  I heard great things about this place through a family friend.  I got their at around 11:45 and the host, who was extremely helpful and nice told me it was a 45 min wait.  And boy was I glad that I waited.

I started out with a coffee cake and the english muffin with homemade peanut butter.  Both were fantastic, and had a lot of flavor.  I wanted to get the best of both worlds so I tried THE PLOW.  The Lemon Ricotta Pancakes were to die for, and the sausage patties had so many different flavors it was unbelievable.  The eggs were cooked just like I wanted them and the potatoes were perfectly crispy.  Overall it was a great place.  I will be back for sure.

excerpts: I had the fried egg sandwich, and my husband had the plow breakfast that comes with lemon ricotta pancakes-- yum!
delicate and flavorful.
Will be back!
the plow.author: R N.
the plow.review:
Husb and I checked this out at 1pm today and the line looked intimidating.  We had a very short wait.

The coffee is good (they said they serve Equator coffee)
Food was all good, and high quality.  I had the fried egg sandwich, and my husband had the plow breakfast that comes with lemon ricotta pancakes-- yum!  delicate and flavorful.  Will be back!

excerpts: We split the dungeness crab scramble and the plow
so we got to try a little of everything.
While the freshly fried potatoes were shatteringly crisp and the sausage was well seasoned the star of the show was definitely the ricotta pancakes.
I saved some of the pancakes for last
but I really should have eaten it all when it first came out.
Sitting on the plate, the pancakes lost some of the lightest and airiness from coming directly off the griddle.
The brunch was really simple, well done and satisfying.
Best yet I completely cleaned my plate but did not feel heavy or fall into a food coma.
All in all it was a great way to start off a Sunday.
As we were finishing up our meal a single diner was seated right next to us
and I don't remember him waiting in line
so this might be an even better call if you are dining alone.
the plow.author: Hieu L.
the plow.review: The average wait time was between 45 minutes to an hour for a party of two which is not bad for showing up after 12pm.  The wait was definitely worth it. We split the dungeness crab scramble and the plow so we got to try a little of everything. While the freshly fried potatoes were shatteringly crisp and the sausage was well seasoned the star of the show was definitely the ricotta pancakes. I saved some of the pancakes for last but I really should have eaten it all when it first came out. Sitting on the plate, the pancakes lost some of the lightest and airiness from coming directly off the griddle. The brunch was really simple, well done and satisfying. Best yet I completely cleaned my plate but did not feel heavy or fall into a food coma. All in all it was a great way to start off a Sunday. As we were finishing up our meal a single diner was seated right next to us and I don't remember him waiting in line so this might be an even better call if you are dining alone.

excerpts: We started with the doughnut that had creme filling, I had the Plow which the pancakes, bacon and POTATOES are all amazing.
It is enough food for two people to split if you start with a doughnut or Brioche.
Husband had the biscuits and gravy,  they were very good.
Kind of on the rich side
so if you are used to a more savory gravy you may want to try something else.
All and all the staff were so nice and what you would expect from a neighborhood spot like this one.
Sadly we are moving off the hill
but I will still come back just for Plow.
the plow.author: Brooke K.
the plow.review: We had breakfast here this morning, got there early and still had to sit at the bar.  I wasn't sure what to expect because I had read the food was overrated,  that is just not true.  We started with the doughnut that had creme filling, I had the Plow which the pancakes, bacon and POTATOES are all amazing.  It is enough food for two people to split if you start with a doughnut or Brioche.  Husband had the biscuits and gravy,  they were very good.  Kind of on the rich side so if you are used to a more savory gravy you may want to try something else.  All and all the staff were so nice and what you would expect from a neighborhood spot like this one.  Sadly we are moving off the hill but I will still come back just for Plow.

excerpts: We only got the Plow and the breakfast sandwich but both were delicious.
Will definitely be back!
the plow.author: Victoria K.
the plow.review: Delicious! As I have said in a previous review I consider myself a bit of a brunch expert/ fanatic and I've been to all the "favorite" brunch spots in SF. This is definitely a top 3 for me! We only got the Plow and the breakfast sandwich but both were delicious. Will definitely be back!

excerpts: My hubs had The Plow - a little bit of everything.
the plow.author: Lulu B.
the plow.review: Ok, so this is my 2nd Yelp review ever and the fact that I'm taking the time to review this AWESOME place, what does that say? Hands down, the BEST brunch ever in SF. My hubs & I grew up in the Bay Area & often go to SF for culinary adventures. We had a spontaneous New Years 2day adventure in SF and this was THE highlight. (Hey, we like food.) Hubs found it on Yelp - paying it forward, yes I am - and when we saw/read their website, we knew it was THE brunch place for us. Worth the 20min wait (altho' I can see it being longer at times). I had the egg sandwich (all about that cheese) and a side of 1 lemon ricotta pancake - which also came with those yummy potatos. My hubs had The Plow - a little bit of everything. Their crispy potatoes are phenom. Their lemon ricotta pancakes are to die for. The rest all culminates together - the friendly service, the intimate ambiance, the very nice owners-couple, the other excited patrons, the location, the venue - to make for a perfect way to start off your day. If you live in, near or are planning a trip to SF, I can't recommend this place enough for brekkie, lunch or wkend brunch...Just be patient - grab a coffee down the block - as you may have to wait a few minutes. But I say it again - it's DEF worth the wait. I will be back. Soon, I hope.

excerpts: You can see it in their menu with specialities like Chinese breakfast and Hong Kong Style brick toast.
chinese breakfast.author: Poy W.
chinese breakfast.review:
A delicious place for brunch in SF! It's American with a hint of Chinese influence. You can see it in their menu with specialities like Chinese breakfast and Hong Kong Style brick toast.

I came here on a Wednesday at 10:15 am and the place was already packed for brunch. It's very small - no wonder the wait is over an hour on weekends. Luckily, my group of 4 only waited maybe 15-20 minutes for a table outside. Although it's chilly outside at this time of year, they offer blankets to keep you warm (but no heaters). The waiters are friendly and despite being outside, they came out often to see if we needed anything and to fill our waters. 

THE PLOW 5/5
Their signature plate with 2 eggs, meat (choice of pork sausage patties, bacon, or chicken apple sausage), potatoes, and 2 small but amazing lemon ricotta pancakes! It's a great choice if you're looking for a taste of their famous pancakes but want a heartier breakfast. 

OPEN-FACED PROSCITTO + GRUYERE TOAST 3.5/5
I love anything with proscuitto so this was a must try, but it didn't quite live up to expectations. It's more on the healthy side, with a perfectly runny egg atop lot of frisee, parsley, one slice of proscuitto, and cheese. In my opinion, it could have used more meat to balance out the greens. I would probably pass on this next time. 

HONG KONG STYLE TOAST 1/5
It's $4 for brioche bread covered with condensed milk which just feels like a trap for non-Asian people LOLOL. Just find a dessert place with brick toast next time. 

Overall, the ambiance and food was good. I would come here again!

excerpts: I didn't see Dungeness crab scramble or Chinese Breakfast, which I was hoping to try.
chinese breakfast.author: Karen F.
chinese breakfast.review:
Plow is a pretty good breakfast/brunch breakfast place. It wasn't mind blowing but I would come here again.

We came here on a Friday during lunch time and waited about 45 minutes for a 2 person table. The place is pretty small, so it's pretty understandable. They do have little benches for you to sit on outside as you wait.

For food, we ordered the breakfast sandwich with bacon and the open face gruyere and prosciutto toast. Both of these dishes came with golden roasted potatoes that were crisp on the outside and soft on the inside, though it was a tad bit dry. The breakfast sandwich and open face toast tasted pretty similar so you can't go wrong either.

The place to see, be seen, be seen eating.

I've been having a bit of fun trying to find new places to go in my new found freedom, to no fault of my own.  I've taken the cue from a few other people and tried to get here early.  I arrived before 8:30 am during the week to a nearly empty restaurant, and by the time I was finished less than an hour later all the seats were taken. So get here early.  Time went quickly, as I sat at the counter, dining solo, and enjoyed watching the chefs do their thing.

First time I had The Plow breakfast.  This comes with 2 eggs your way, choice of protein, Plow potatoes,  and 2 lemon ricotta pancakes.  I like my eggs over hard, so that way I know I will get fresh cracked eggs.  I did not notice if the eggs for scrambled eggs or omelets come from a ladle.  I chose chicken apple sausage.  Everything was very good.  The lemon ricotta pancakes do not need any of the accompanying maple syrup and are light, and the lemon brings it together.  The potatoes are first boiled, lightly smashed, then deep fried and tossed with a few herbs and fewer onions that do not overpower.  Quite possibly the best breakfast potatoes I've had.  They pale in comparison to the undercooked potatoes from Crepevine, but that's another review.

The second time I had a simple two egg breakfast with house made pork sausage and a buttermilk biscuit.  This was an equally good choice, but I would choose the pork over both the chicken sausage and bacon, for the simple reason that the pork is house made, the bacon and chicken sausage are not.   Some of the coffee cakes and biscuits are only available until they are all gone, so it's a good idea to grab it while you can.  Same for the Chinese Breakfast,  which I want to try next ... pork shoulder with chili garlic ginger sauce, 2 fried eggs and rice.  It sounds so perfect. 

Service is friendly and efficient.  Sitting at the counter I saw the servers correct the plates several times when the order was incorrect.  

Coffee is provided by Equator, if I recall.  This place is worth getting up early for ... of course I'm up early every day whether I want to or not.  The only negative was the provided hot sauce ... it was not as spicy as I normally like on my eggs.

* ~ * ~ * April 22, 2012 * ~ * ~ * 

Our first beer goggle-free date:

Mr. NSS: "Did you want to go to brunch?"
Me: "Sure, let's try Plow; I've been wanting to go there for a while now."

*Arrives at Plow*

Wait staff: "It's going to be a two hour wait."
Mr. NSS: "Two $@$^&*# hours?!?!...uhh, no thanks."

Mr. NSS: "I would never wait THAT long for food; it's just 'food', let's go somewhere else."
Me *thinking*: "Thanks for speaking for the both of us, you jerk!"

Fast forward nearly a year of dating a food snob. 

* ~ * ~ * April 5, 2013 * ~ * ~ *

Me: "Since we both took a day off, let's try going to Plow again?"
Mr. NSS: "Uhhh, the place with a two hour wait?"

Me: "Or, we can go to Red Door Cafe instead where the owner may molest your bootay while we wait in line?"
Mr. NSS: "Actually, Plow sounds PERFECT!"

*Arrives at Plow at 10:30 am*

Me: "I'll get the Fried Egg Sandwich w/ Bacon and one Lemon Ricotta Pancake please."
Mr. NSS: "I'll have the Dungeness Crab Scramble please."

*Our order arrives after 10 minutes*

Mr. NSS *talking with mouth full*: "Dayaum, I never knew crab and eggs could taste THIS good."

*2 minutes passes and Mr. NSS annihilates his crab scramble*

Mr. NSS *eyeing my sandwich*: "Aren't you going to ask if I want a bite?"
Me *reluctantly hands over sandwich*

Mr. NSS *Kills the rest of the sandwich*
Me: "WTF! That was MY sandwich!!!!"

Mr. NSS: "Sorry, you always give me half of your food."
Me: "UGH! You're sleeping with Ms. Lubriderm tonight!"

*Walking back to the car*

Mr. NSS: "So the next time we come to Plow, let's put our name down then come back two hours later ok?"
Me: "Uhhh, WTF has Plow done to my bf?!?!"

YEUP, it's THAT good folks!

OTHER NOTES:
*Expect a 30+ minute wait on weekdays and up to a 2+ hour wait on weekends. NO reservations. 
*Rockstar staff. The waitresses are very friendly and the very efficient kitchen staff churns out 6-7 plates at a time. Very impressive. 
*Get the Fried Egg Sandwich w/ Bacon ($13.50): http://bit.ly/16ICt9c! Simple but top-notch ingredients that's perfectly prepared = AMAZING: http://bit.ly/Y8xCIJ! The potatoes are f*cking delicious so make sure your order comes with this as a side!
*The Ricotta Lemon Pancake ($5) is also a must order! It's like a Lemon Meringue Pie but in a pancake: http://bit.ly/Y8xFEu. SO good!
*Why is the Chinese Breakfast always sold out or never available? It wasn't available on Friday. =(
*Outdoor seating, indoor seating, and counter seating. Sit at the counter and watch where all the magic happens!
*Loved the low-key casual ambiance with TLC, Destiny's Child and Toni Braxton bumping in the background.
*Fairly easy residential street parking.

chinese breakfast.author: Lisa Q.
chinese breakfast.review:
Plow is one of the hottest glowing epicenters for breakfast on this earth. You can see it from space, glowing and winking--- the smell of their famous potatoes cutting through the atmosphere into your space station and causing every astronaut to salivate and pine for home. 

I'm a longtime eater, first-time writer about the majesty that is this wonderful breakfast place. They have completely captivated the majority of San Francisco and definitely don't need my help, this is just a love letter to their high level of consistency, execution, and creativity.

There has never been a time when a plow classic has thrown me off whether it'd be the lemon ricotta pancakes, egg sandwich, or "The Plow" (eggs, sausage or bacon, lemon ricotta pancakes, potatoes). Each time I've had them they've tasted exactly the same, which is a very good thing. The potatoes are always amazingly flaky and moist on the inside but crispy and herbaceous on the outside. They remind me of Jonathan Waxman's famous potatoes at Barbuto, except I don't have to travel all the way to New York for them.

They also take recipes from great breakfast places all over this nation such as Joanne Chang's Flour in Boston and execute them exceptionally. Their really nailed Joanne's chocolate brioche with pastry cream recipe... I hope they do her sticky buns with goo next!

I also love it when they do their own seasonal riffs of breakfast, my favorite of all time was their "Chinese Breakfast" which had delicious red roasted pork on top of fluffy rice topped off with a fried egg. I will probably scream and jump up and down for joy when they bring it back--- it was one of the yummiest breakfasts I've ever had. *Siiigh* Those tender and aromatic pieces of pork mixed with the unctuousness of an oozing yolk on top of pristine pearly rice, oh god, it's a recipe for love potion.

My only advice is to get here as soon as they crack open their doors. Waiting an hour to eat food is pretty painful and is especially devastating when it's your first meal of the day.

chinese breakfast.author: Dirty D.
chinese breakfast.review:
The quick low down on Plow is...

- Awesome corn millet muffins.
- The granola + yogurt is amazing! The granola is crunchy but not overly so, the yogurt is made fresh in-house and the honey is harvested from within the neighborhood.
- Quite possibly the best B.L.T.A. I have ever had... Perfectly toasted bread, in-season heirlooms, fresh lettuce, creamy avocado, bacon cooked just right (not too crispy, not too limp) and just the right amount of aioli. It also came with a side of perfectly seasoned, perfectly fried potatoes that did not need any ketchup.
- My peach pie was warmed just right, topped with a perfect sized dollop of whipped cream and bursting with fresh peaches.
- Friendly, knowledgeable and attentive waitstaff.

Minor flaws? The coffee should be WAY better considering how good everything else is. Doing to-order drips from either Four Barrel, Ritual or Sightglass would be more appropriate given the quality of the food. Also, please serve your butter at room temperature so that we can actually spread it on your muffins without risk of crumbling them to corn meal - cold butter does not spread well on muffins, no matter how hot they are. And I've never said this before but... get some comfortable chairs. They may look good but I felt like no matter how I was sitting I was uncomfortable.

And while it's not Plow's fault, having to listen to the banal minutia of the lives of the 40 and 50-something yuppies that populate the neighborhood while waiting for a table was pretty obnoxious. This does not factor into my rating, but I include it because it may be a factor for others amongst you.

If you like brunch at Mission Beach Cafe I would definitely check out Plow. I will be back to try their eggs and the Chinese breakfast, which if they are on par with my first experience, might push this place to five stars.

chinese breakfast.author: Kristen T.
chinese breakfast.review:
I enrolled in a Sunday morning Plow class offered by the San Francisco Cooking School and had the wonderful experience of cooking several of Plow's menu items with the owners, Maxine and Joel. I have never been to their restaurant but after reading all the wonderful reviews I thought, "what a great opportunity!" 
 First and for most, the owners of Plow are incredibly nice people.  It's was very obvious while speaking with them that they have a love and passion for what they do: making delicious food, using fresh ingredients, and quality over quantity. 

The class made the following menu items: 
 Pecan streusel muffins
 Lemon ricotta pancakes (and for those who don't know, the ricotta is home made, not store bough...talk about fresh)
 Shirred eggs with tomato and gruyere
 Biscuits and gravy
 Quiche
 Chinese breakfast (caramelized pork shoulder with eggs over rice)
 Plow potatoes 
 Smoked trout salad

 Breakfast is my favorite meal; I love it all and was so impressed with the meal we made! The pork shoulder in the Chinese breakfast was mouthwatering. The tomato sauce for the shirred eggs...so fresh, a taste you would expect from an Italian restaurant. The savory sausage gravy over perfected buttermilk biscuits...amazing! And of course the lemon ricotta pancakes and the plow potatoes that I have read so much about were better than I expected. I am very picky about home fries/hash browns, and often find most restaurants just miss the mark, but Plow's technique of cooking their potatoes ensures every bite is full of flavor. 

I can not say enough about my breakfast experience!! I will soon make a trip to the city with my husband so he can experience the goodness of Plow.

They are located in Potrero Hill so parking is pretty good considering its SF.  It usually doesn't take me longer than 5 minutes to find a spot.

Highly recommend Plow!

chinese breakfast.review:
For a year and a half, I have been hearing my Potrero friends rave about Plow. Actually, I've been hearing raves about Plow from friends, the blogs, and pretty much anybody who had been and weathered the wait for their tasty breakfasts. Truth be told, I am not enamored with Mission Beach Cafe or Boogaloos and didn't think that breakfast at Plow would wow me.

The breakfast wowed me. 

We started with a corn and millet muffin, freshly baked and still warm from the oven. The muffin was crumbly and a bit hard to eat but the crust on the muffin top was crunchy and the millet added crispy bits to the slightly sweet corn muffin. Seriously though, all muffins should be eaten fresh and warm from the oven. 

Next up were a la carte orders of an almond pancake (gluten-free!) and a pumpkin pancake. The pumpkin pancake was fine, similar to what I make at home, but the almond pancake was really interesting. I didn't believe it was actually gluten-free at first b/c the texture was so spot on and it wasn't heavily almond flavored. I dislike marzipan, so I was quite pleased at the neutral flavor profile of the pancake. We asked the server and she informed us that it was made with almond, oat, and coconut flour. An excellent option for the g-f people out there.

The soft scrambled eggs were the turning point for me, where I switched from liking Plow to loving Plow. Of course we've all read about the proper way to slowly scramble eggs, slow and over low heat a la Julia Child or Jacques Pepin, and I thought I had it right before. I was wrong. These eggs were so, so silky. Not runny, but perfectly silky, highlighted by fava greens, chanterelles, and goat cheese. The much lauded crispy potatoes and some levain toast (well buttered with butter you could actually taste) were also there. I don't even like eggs and I kept going back to them, passing over the crispy fried potatoes!

We also tried the Chinese Breakfast whose name manages to simultaneously bring to mind my family and Humphry Slocombe's Secret Breakfast. Anyway, of course you can't go wrong with gingery braised pork shoulder over rice, but the soft scrambled eggs are really where it's at.

All the ingredients used were obviously quality; seasoning levels and ingredient ratios were also well balanced. Loved the clean yet rustic vibe of the naturally sunny dining room. Also loved our server who understood that we were there to sample some different dishes vs eating at a traditional pace. She brought things out at a comfortable rate and was there to answer questions as needed. I can't imagine this perfect vision of what breakfast at Plow is ruined by the hoards on weekends so I guess I'll just save it for an occasional 7am weekday treat.

Very cute neighborhood brunch spot. We waited for about 15 minutes before getting a table outside on a beautiful Sunday. The tables were so close together, that once one person sits, the other person behind you can't move. So, we met our friends here for some lemon ricotta pancakes, dungeness crab scramble, and fried soft shell crab sandwich thing. Originally the waitress said there was no more monkey bread left because we were just inquiring what it is. Then she came out and told us, of course, we snatched it up!! So a monkey bread is basically a cinnamon swirl bread inside out. Um...when it's nice and warm, it's quite amazing. 

So ... I had the scramble. It was pretty good, definitely a good amount of crab. I did order a side of bacon and it was over cooked. Wayyy too crispy.

excerpts: If you want to taste the absolute best picks of fruit from the market get the "market fruit plate".
Flavor explosion.
market fruit.author: Jodie S.
market fruit.review: Always happy to rave about our neighborhood gem. Consistently GREAT food, great service. Here's the skinny on the wait- do not show up in line hungry as heck. The wait midweek will probably be 30 minutes-1hr ish. Put your name down and walk down the street, get a coffee, browse, read a book. If you have a group, have someone show up earlier. They will start lining up 30 minutes prior to opening. All this goes out the window if it's a weekend. (We don't go on a weekend). The people that work here like their job, and it shows. Start with the plow plate and wander from there. If you want to taste the absolute best picks of fruit from the market get the "market fruit plate". Flavor explosion.

excerpts: I ordered the plow, a side of the market fruit & a grapefruit mimosa.
Everything was amazing & the service was very friendly.
My husband & I did have to wait about an hour or more to get a table, but it was well worth it!
Go & wait for a table!
You won't regret it!
market fruit.author: Molly M.
market fruit.review: Hands down the best brunch I have ever had! I ordered the plow, a side of the market fruit & a grapefruit mimosa. Everything was amazing & the service was very friendly. My husband & I did have to wait about an hour or more to get a table, but it was well worth it! Go & wait for a table! You won't regret it!

excerpts: The market fruit platter consists of a tiny portion of grapes and berries and a sliver of a mango for $6; the other items we ordered were on the pricey side but not unreasonable.
market fruit.author: Vijay N.
market fruit.review:
"Good, fresh food, but don't arrive on an empty stomach because you could wait for over one and a half hours for brunch."

Our party of three was seated for Sunday brunch at 12:05 after having given our names in at 10:30.  The line was consistently long the entire time we were in the neighborhood, so unless you come substantially earlier I don't think there's any avoiding the queue.  You can grab a coffee from them (a nice brew) while you're in line, but I would eat something before coming, anticipating that brunch could actually become lunch before you know it.

The food at Plow is very fresh and quite tasty.  I had the lemon ricotta pancakes, which were nice and syrupy, but not sickeningly sweet.  My friends had the soft egg scramble (smelled great) and the 9-grain muffin (toasted perfectly) with homemade peanut butter and honey, which were also both delicious.  The market fruit platter consists of a tiny portion of grapes and berries and a sliver of a mango for $6; the other items we ordered were on the pricey side but not unreasonable.

Overall, I think that eating at Plow could have been a  great experience, but, feeling faint and starving after the long wait, I devoured my food and didn't have a chance to enjoy the flavors or the ambiance.  If you have a scout who can get your name on the list early or want to wander around the pretty Potrero Hill neighborhood for a while on a lazy, sunny Sunday, Plow is a great place to eat.  But I wouldn't recommend taking it in on an empty stomach.

excerpts: the only demerit, and the reason I'm not giving plow 5 stars is because of the side order of "market fruit" that we got.  for $5, you get about a quarter of an apple sliced thin, a quarter of a pear sliced thin and about 8 grapes.
when they brought it to the table, I thought it might be a garnish and not the fruit plate we had ordered.
I asked, and sure enough, our waitress confirmed that was the market fruit.
a minor complaint in light of everything else that was outstanding.
but seriously, if you're going to put a fruit plate on the menu and charge $5 for it, make it a real fruit plate and not something that could be mistaken for a garnish.
we'll be back though!!
market fruit.author: char s.
market fruit.review:
wow, what a great breakfast place!
I had the "plow" which is eggs, bacon or sausage, potatoes and two small lemon ricotta pancakes - all delish.  hubby had the breakfast sandwich which he loved.  excellent coffee.
the only demerit, and the reason I'm not giving plow 5 stars is because of the side order of "market fruit" that we got.  for $5, you get about a quarter of an apple sliced thin, a quarter of a pear sliced thin and about 8 grapes.  when they brought it to the table, I thought it might be a garnish and not the fruit plate we had ordered.  I asked, and sure enough, our waitress confirmed that was the market fruit.  
a minor complaint in light of everything else that was outstanding.  but seriously, if you're going to put a fruit plate on the menu and charge $5 for it, make it a real fruit plate and not something that could be mistaken for a garnish.
we'll be back though!!

excerpts:
fried egg sandwich - two eggs, cheddar, frisee, aioli, crispy potatoes 
house made organic yogurt + granola + market fruit + Potrero Hill honey

seated at the counter facing the workers
watching them mix, chop, flame, plate the magic.
market fruit.author: Anna K.
market fruit.review:
fried egg sandwich - two eggs, cheddar, frisee, aioli, crispy potatoes 
house made organic yogurt + granola + market fruit + Potrero Hill honey

seated at the counter facing the workers
watching them mix, chop, flame, plate the magic.
it's no secret that plow only uses fresh, wholesome ingredients
in every single dish they offer.
sip on coffee or a mimosa during your wait
as they take no reservations in advance.

excerpts: A hearty plate filled with two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, choice of protein (I chose pork sausage patties), and eggs!
crispy potatoes.author: Catherine T.
crispy potatoes.review:
"The Plow" is the obvious go-to brunch meal. A hearty plate filled with two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, choice of protein (I chose pork sausage patties), and eggs! Everything was delicious and service was quick and attentive. 

We waited for two hours and I honestly wouldn't wait again. Looking at the menu it doesn't look like anything else was enticing either. Also sitting at the counter there was this pungent smell that was bothersome.

Luckily we had a pre-snack before eating here so if I was really hangry this rating would've been lower lol.

In concloosh- if you can avoid a long wait time, come here and order The Plow!

excerpts: Eggs, choice of meat (I had chicken apple sausage), crispy potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes.
Their lemon ricotta pancakes are smol, light, and fluffy -- finally, a pancake that doesn't weigh you down!
The sausages were v flavorful and juicy, but not at all greasy -
*praise*.
Best of all the parts were so well proportioned to each other!
crispy potatoes.author: Joyce C.
crispy potatoes.review:
IT'S SO WORTH IT.  Do not doubt, believe and be blessed!  Got here at 8:30am on a Sunday and there was already an hour wait.  We went to a neighboring cafe for some coffee while we waited, but the large mug of black coffee on an empty stomach set me up with raging anxiety and nausea by the time we got back (woohoo! Adventure...)

Even with all the shenanigans besetting my poor bod, this meal is by far the best brunch I've had in a looong time.  I ordered **The Plow ** ($17.50), recommended to me by my breakfast bud as a sampling of Plow's hit items.  Eggs, choice of meat (I had chicken apple sausage), crispy potatoes, and lemon ricotta pancakes.  Sounds standard, but oh my god - they are out of this world.

I identify as a huge tater lover, and I was still intrigued by this hype over their potatoes.  Best way to describe it: you know the crispy skin on peking duck?  These potatoes had that kind of delicate crisp to them!  HNGH.  Nom nom.

Their lemon ricotta pancakes are smol, light, and fluffy -- finally, a pancake that doesn't weigh you down!  The sausages were v flavorful and juicy, but not at all greasy - *praise*.  Best of all the parts were so well proportioned to each other!  AMAZING.

Keep in mind I felt all these lovey dovey things towards the food while having an anxiety-crippled appetite, so the food really is THAT good. @Plow, TAKE MY MONEY.  I'll be back.  And you should try waiting for and eventually eating at this place too :3

excerpts: We each decided to order the Plow Breakfast because it gave a little of everything from eggs, to crispy potatoes, lemon pancakes and a side of meat.
I went with the homemade pork sausage.
It didn't have a ton of fat or flavor.
crispy potatoes.author: Cortney W.
crispy potatoes.review:
Delicious!

Went for breakfast and we waited about 10 minutes for a single table. The restaurant is small and cozy. The waitress came over right away and took out orders. It seemed like a nice place for people to have chats over food and you could tell most people were regulars. 

We each decided to order the Plow Breakfast because it gave a little of everything from eggs, to crispy potatoes, lemon pancakes and a side of meat. I went with the homemade pork sausage. It didn't have a ton of fat or flavor. Tasted mostly like rosemary and herbs. 

The biscuit we ordered was so good!  With the honey butter it was magical. The coffee was flavorful and hot. 

Overall it was a great experience. I would recommend visiting if in the San Fran area!

excerpts: Envision crispy potatoes, perfect lemon ricotta pancakes, and freshly made biscuits, while you are standing in an hour long line.
I got scrambled eggs with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, and chicken apple sausage.
The potatoes were cooked to crispy perfection and I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes!
crispy potatoes.author: Emily T.
crispy potatoes.review:
Envision crispy potatoes, perfect lemon ricotta pancakes, and freshly made biscuits, while you are standing in an hour long line. Its worth the wait. 

Why I was here // I came with two of my buds as we decided to go for a Sunday brunch, we even got there 5 minutes before it opened and there was already a long line down the block. By the time we got our name on the list we were given a 45 minute wait time for the outdoor seats. Sigh....We took a stroll and chit chatted the time away but...tip: sometimes they will call your name early to fit the tables if the party above you is called and not there, I would honestly stick around the restaurant , where you can hear the host because we got called early and missed it. Our wait could have been 20 minutes shorter..

Service // Service is friendly for this bustling restaurant. Since we were sitting in the freezing cold in their outdoor patio area with no heating, they offered us blankets which was nice. 

Food // 
-Buttermilk Biscuit with honey butter // 5.00 // I was so happy I got this magical piece of fluffy goodness. The honey butter was creamy and sweet and meshed well with the light, crispy and warm biscuit
-The Plow // 17.50 // The whole package this one is. I got scrambled eggs with potatoes, lemon ricotta pancakes, and chicken apple sausage. The potatoes were cooked to crispy perfection and I loved the lemon ricotta pancakes! 

Overall // I would definitely come here to this magical palace of brunch. The only issue is that wait time can be pretty bad, so maybe I would try coming on a weekday next time around. 
Also this place is small and doesn't accommodate parties larger than 6, so choose your brunch friends wisely.

excerpts: The crispy potatoes are just as good as everyone says, and the pancakes were delicious.
However, mine felt dense; not as fluffy as others said.
-dungeness
crispy potatoes.author: Michelle N.
crispy potatoes.review:
I haven't had much luck with the brunch scene in the bay area, but I think I found a winner!!! Plow has been on my bookmark list for years, and my fiance and I finally had a chance to try it! We arrived on a Saturday at 8AM and were met with a massive line. There was ~40 min wait (quoted as 25-30 min), as we missed the first seating of the restaurant.

We tried:
-the plow: bacon, scambled eggs, plow potatoes, and 2 mini lemon ricotta pancakes. The crispy potatoes are just as good as everyone says, and the pancakes were delicious. However, mine felt dense; not as fluffy as others said.
-dungeness crab scrambled: I was a bigger fan of this than my fiance was, but we both agreed it was delicious

So glad to have found a favorite brunch place in the bay, and I can't wait to come back!!

excerpts: At the very least, I would come for those fantastically crispy potatoes.
crispy potatoes.author: Gwen W.
crispy potatoes.review:
I feel bad for anyone who waits more than an hour for this place. Considering that we came at 10 a.m. on a Sunday and waited a whopping 15 minutes (seriously, I timed it from the second we got out of our Lyft). Why? Everyone else wandered away to get coffee or check out the few shops down the street. Just stand around and wait a bit, apparently. Or perch on the wooden slabs affixed to the wall.

Foodies and chefs alike have crowned Plow the best brunch in The City. (See: Dzung Duong of Honeysuckle Catering, J. Kenji Lopez-Alt of the Food Lab, critics at Thrillist, Eater SF, SF Gate, Conde Nast...) And holy hell, I used to think that title belonged to Kitchen Story. Nope.

My significant other went for the Plow breakfast, with two over easy eggs and their housemade pork sausage patties, while I ordered the breakfast sandwich with bacon and a cinnamon roll. Everything we had was phenomenal. The crispy roasted potatoes are the stuff of daydreams, and sitting at the breakfast bar watching cooks in the kitchen toss them with herbs and soft, sweet onions made them so much more satisfying to eat. Imagine a skin that shatters the moment it meets your front teeth. I would deep fry the heck out of my home fries the way that the folks at Plow do.

They've also mastered the art of cooking fluffy eggs, complete with crispy edges and runny yolks. Lemon ricotta pancakes? Tart and complemented every bite of potato that came after. The housemade pork patties exploded with juice and delectable flavor, ever so slightly caramelized on the outside by the flattop. The bacon on the sandwich was pliant, but it was clear that finishing it off on the flat-top really did it crispy justice. And wow, I hate frisee in every mixed greens salad I eat, but the bitter vegetable actually went so well with the fluffy Acme bread, meat, and eggs.

The cinnamon roll was a 9/10 on the indie pastry scale. I found it a little bit dry, but it satisfied a month-long craving for gooey cinnamon buns and it was made quite well.

Service is very friendly here, and despite the hustle and bustle, I was impressed by their professionalism and their ability to work with each other in the kitchen. Cue cooks working together to plate a sandwich, with one guy handling all eggs and another one popping the buns right off the flattop. Plus, our water jug never ran low. If the weekend wait is as bad as it seems, I think I'd pop in on a weekday instead. At the very least, I would come for those fantastically crispy potatoes.

excerpts: The crispy potatoes are probably the best potatoes you'll have in the city.
crispy potatoes.author: Julian L.
crispy potatoes.review:
Wait - 1 Hour @ 13:00

Value - $17 / dish.

Dish Size: Medium

The Plow -  Imagine the best Denny's Grand Slam you every had and times that by 1,000,000 - that's how good this dish is. Every component of the dish is amazing in taste and preparation. The crispy potatoes are probably the best potatoes you'll have in the city. The Lemon Ricotta Pancakes are creamy, fluffy, with a subtle lemon flavor. Hands down all pancakes should be made with ricotta. The homemade pork sausage patties are full of flavor. Lastly, the eggs are cooked perfectly and seasoned well. To put simply, this dish is perfect. 


If you love traditional classic breakfast, Plow is the perfect place. Plow isn't trying to reinvent the wheel, what Plow does it takes the classics and makes the best version of it possible. The food is so refined that it's hard to imagine how Plow could improve upon their dishes. I suppose the price could be a bit lower...

The rustic and refined qualities of the food carries all the way through into the space. Although the interior is small, Plow feels spacious with large operable windows allowing natural light and ventilation to flood the entirety of the space. Plow's interior is minimal with warm accents of rustic decor, must notably the angled dark wood floor. With only a handful of tables and counter seating, it's obvious why the wait can reach upwards of an hour. 

Admittedly, deciding to dine at Plow boils down to one question, "Am I willing to wait over an hour for brunch?" I must say that I wavered a bit while waiting but after the meal I can confidently say that it's worth the wait.

excerpts: the wait wouldn't mind doing again just to taste those fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes!
crispy potatoes.author: Sofia V.
crispy potatoes.review: What can I say one of the best breakfast I've ever had. I got the the plow breakfast which comes with two lemon ricotta pancakes, eggs, potatoes, and sausage. I can't wait to come back and have this meal all over again. It's all I ever think about. We went on a Friday and probably got there at 10 we told an hour which was fine and totally worth the wait wouldn't mind doing again just to taste those fluffy lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes!

excerpts: As for our meals themselves, we shared the Plow with the absolutely scrumptious lemon ricotta pancakes (fluffiness for days!), pork sausage, over medium eggs, and their crispy potatoes, as well as the corned beef hash which tasted almost fajita-y and had really tender corned beef.
crispy potatoes.author: Eva C.
crispy potatoes.review:
As an SF transplant, I'm slowly trying to make my way through the city's top brunch spots, and Plow did not disappoint. 

Location - Parking was surprisingly not too difficult to find, with open street spots here and there.

Wait time - Coming on a Saturday morning around 11am, we were quoted a wait of an hour and a half for a party of 2 so we put our names down and went to a nearby store. We came back ~45 minutes later, and to our surprise were shortly called up! 

FOOD! - Delicious! Relatively standard brunch fare in my opinion, but done really well. We started off with a buttermilk biscuit, which I have to say is probably one of the best biscuits I've had. We also ordered grapefruit mimosas, which were refreshing and the acidity paired well with the heaviness of our meal.

As for our meals themselves, we shared the Plow with the absolutely scrumptious lemon ricotta pancakes (fluffiness for days!), pork sausage, over medium eggs, and their crispy potatoes, as well as the corned beef hash which tasted almost fajita-y and had really tender corned beef. 

Service was friendly and welcoming, and after this experience I would definitely visit Plow again!

excerpts: Yay for crispy potatoes!
They were tasty and addicting.
Had the soft scramble with goat cheese, shiitake mushrooms, stinging nettles, yum.
crispy potatoes.author: Mandy D.
crispy potatoes.review:
Yay for crispy potatoes! They were tasty and addicting. Had the soft scramble with goat cheese, shiitake mushrooms, stinging nettles, yum. I enjoyed my dish since it was a good balance between the heavy potatoes and lightness of the eggs.

Tried the mochi butter cake with coconut flakes. It was almost a layered cake of mochi on the bottom, egg tart and toasted coconut flakes. A good dish to share and it was good to try, but will probably not order this again.

Tried a bit of the lemon ricotta pancakes, the texture and flavor was pretty good, but I'm not too sure if I care to go out of my way or this particular specialty.

The wait was about 30-40mins on a rainy President's day at 8:30am. That's determination on my day off.

excerpts: Now to the star of the plate, the crispy potatoes.
Not sure what they cook it in, but it was so addicting!!
It's hands down the best potatoes I've ever had, and is a must get!
crispy potatoes.author: Vy T.
crispy potatoes.review:
Came early on a Saturday morning and there was a wait but it wasn't too bad. I had the plow, which I think it's perfect because it has the ricotta pancakes, homemade sausage, eggs, and the best effing potatoes I've ever eaten! It's the best plate if you're indecisive  like me. 

The pancakes were fluffy and small, with a zesty lemon flavor. I thought the homemade sausage was kind of dry, but you do have your options of bacon as well. Now to the star of the plate, the crispy potatoes. Not sure what they cook it in, but it was so addicting!! It's hands down the best potatoes I've ever had, and is a must get!

excerpts: I often choose the Plow, which is eggs, those devilishly good crispy potatoes, choice of meat (try the new-ish bacon confit, which is basically   a roasted piece of pork belly -- so yummy!), and a couple of those luscious mini lemon ricotta pancakes.
It really is way too much food for one meal, so you might try my trick of eating no more than half of each item and taking the rest with me.

I also love the french toast, which I had on today's visit, along with a side of that irresistible bacon confit (I just have to remember to rescue the remainder from the office fridge later today...).
The dungeness scramble is also very good, with eggs that are cooked just a tolerable bit past runny.
crispy potatoes.author: Teresa D.
crispy potatoes.review:
Every couple of weeks or so I sneak in here at 7 a.m. for a solo pre-work breakfast feast at the counter, and have never been disappointed with the food. I often choose the Plow, which is eggs, those devilishly good crispy potatoes, choice of meat (try the new-ish bacon confit, which is basically   a roasted piece of pork belly -- so yummy!), and a couple of those luscious mini lemon ricotta pancakes. It really is way too much food for one meal, so you might try my trick of eating no more than half of each item and taking the rest with me. I also love the french toast, which I had on today's visit, along with a side of that irresistible bacon confit (I just have to remember to rescue the remainder from the office fridge later today...). The dungeness scramble is also very good, with eggs that are cooked just a tolerable bit past runny. I'm freaked out by gross undercooked eggs, so this works for me.

The only down side for me is the coffee, which is a very bitter roast. I know that a lot of people seem to favor that over-roasted, super-bitter thing, but I'm not one of them. Give me a bitter cocktail any day (please!), but you can keep the bitter coffee. Really, I don't expect such a small kitchen to keep more than one type of roast on hand, so I do understand they have to pick something that a lot of people like. 

I've found the service to be attentive and oblivious at the same time. I'm pretty sure I was the very first person to put in my order this morning, but I saw a lot of food come out of the kitchen headed to tables that hadn't even settled on the menu before my order went in. When my food finally arrived about 16 minutes later, it didn't include the bacon confit side -- that was another 8 to 10 minutes in coming. None of this is a big deal if the server addresses the delay with a cheerful explanation, showing the customer that they haven't been forgotten. My server didn't say anything about any of it. Pretty disappointing. 

But make no mistake: this is a very good place. I don't think I'd try it on a weekend since I hear the wait is way over the top.

excerpts: and so, visions of soft-scrambled eggs and crispy potatoes dancing in my head, I head over to Plow for breakfast.
There's a line outside, as there always is, but when I inquire with the hostess about the wait time she says there's a seat opening up at the counter
and it should be free in just 10 minutes.
Only 10 minutes!
Lucky me!
crispy potatoes.author: Zare K.
crispy potatoes.review:
It's a chilly late-December morning in the week after Christmas. I have the day off work and so, visions of soft-scrambled eggs and crispy potatoes dancing in my head, I head over to Plow for breakfast. There's a line outside, as there always is, but when I inquire with the hostess about the wait time she says there's a seat opening up at the counter and it should be free in just 10 minutes. Only 10 minutes! Lucky me! I settle in for a short wait.

Understanding that things at a busy restaurant can take longer than expected, I wait some 30 minutes outside with nothing but a newspaper for company (no coffee, no seating)  before poking my head inside again to check on the wait. "Not too much longer," says the hostess. Back outside I go to chill, and I mean that in the sense of being cold. Somewhere in there I watch the hostess walk down the street and step directly in front of a (slowly, thank God) moving bus. Another 15 minutes pass so again, I ask to check on my progress. "Sorry, there's nothing available yet" says the hostess, looking agitated. Perhaps she's grumpy from getting honked at by the bus.

Fifty minutes after I first arrived--yes, that's 50, five with a zero after it, as in 5x the original estimated wait time--the hostess finally gestures for me to come inside. Alas, the seat isn't actually ready so she abandons me to stand in the small front lobby. For 5 minutes I wait awkwardly looking at the sign asking people not to stand in the small front lobby. At some point a busboy tries to shoo me outside.

Finally--oh, miracle of miracles! a place setting is prepared and I sit down at the counter. Frozen and too hungry to think straight, I eagerly accept the server's offer of coffee while I contemplate the menu. A man arrives and is seated next to me. He asks to order a moment later and the server obliges him, taking his food order ahead of mine. When he tries to chat me up later it takes a great deal of my self-restraint not to stab him with my fork.

"Ah, but how was the breakfast?" you ask. The breakfast was fine. Okay, taken on its own merits it was more than fine. The soft-scrambled eggs were creamy and tender with perfectly cooked mushrooms and greens. The Plow potatoes were hot and crispy. Their coffee is nice and strong and served in big hand-warming mugs. No one can dispute that Plow's cooks have their technique down. And just to be clear, I take no issue with Plow's long wait times as such--it was the completely bogus time estimate, along with the sneaking suspicion that I as a solo diner got bumped down the list--that had my hangrily grinding my teeth.

I share the tale of this ordeal with you, dear readers, because it prompted me to make a serious lifestyle change. No more waiting in line for brunch. Don't do it. Cook breakfast at home. You too can learn to make hollandaise sauce. Go out for pho or a bowl of porridge with Chinese doughnuts. Most pho restaurants even have coffee! Anything but the interminable wait accompanied by the gurgling Gastrointestinal Orchestra of hunger. Fellow San Franciscans, look around you and see: The Brunch Emperor wears no clothes.

The standouts of the dish were the crispy potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes.
The potatoes were so expertly seasoned and full of flavor -- they could quite easily be some of the best potatoes I've ever had.

And those lemon ricotta pancakes were out of this world!

crispy potatoes.author: Pooja M.
crispy potatoes.review:
I came for brunch and stayed for Kanye.

If you want to feel pumped up and ready to party while you enjoy your delicious brunch, Plow is definitely the place to be in the city. 

The restaurant is small, but the vibe is 'popping' as the staff is all super friendly and fun and the music blasting through the restaurant will get you grooving in your seat (or up and about the restaurant if you're brave enough). 

I was in the mood for a bit of everything that day, so I decided to order the restaurant's namesake, The Plow, which is an all in one dish that consists of two eggs served in any style, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and a choice of pork, bacon, or chicken apple sausage. I asked for my eggs poached and I substituted a salad for the meat options.

The eggs were perfectly poached, but had no seasoning to them otherwise, and the salad was fresh and crispy, but again, bland. The standouts of the dish were the crispy potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes. The potatoes were so expertly seasoned and full of flavor -- they could quite easily be some of the best potatoes I've ever had. And those lemon ricotta pancakes were out of this world! The lemon is very present in the pancakes and is balanced nicely by the ricotta, and the syrup with the pancakes added a nice sweetness that wasn't overbearing. The pancakes were light and fluffy and don't sit heavy in your stomach. I'll definitely be coming back for those pancakes!

Something to keep in mind: Plow is one of the most popular brunch restaurants in SF, so expect a long wait time (at least 1.5 hours) on the weekend. However, if you're a brunch queen like me who's trying to catch 'em all, you are an expert on surviving the brunch hunger pains and boredom of long wait times, and having to wait no longer affects you. 

If you are not on a brunch quest like I am and you are willing to endure the long wait, bring a friend to keep you company, eat something light beforehand, and try to come as close to opening hours as you can, and you'll be brunching down in no time.

There is a lovely cafe across the street called Farley's that has plenty of indoor and outdoor seating and serves tea and light pastries where you can keep yourself from starving as you wait to be called. In general, the neighborhood where The Plow is located is really lovely and has a stunning view of the city skyline, so even if the wait is long, the environment is inviting. 

I'm putting The Plow on my list of brunch places to return to, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an exciting brunch spot!

excerpts: Crispy potatoes (5/5) -
YES, so crispy on the outside, really well seasoned, but still buttery on the inside.

crispy potatoes.author: Tiffany P.
crispy potatoes.review:
My favorite underrated brunch place in SF! I feel like there isn't enough hype around Plow, but there is still always a wait. The wait on weekends can be about an hour; I came on my own on a weekday this time and had to wait ~20 minutes.

I had the dungeness crab scramble a while ago and remember loving it. I was really looking forward to getting more of it this recent time but it wasn't on the menu anymore, so I tried a couple new things instead.

1) Buttermilk biscuit with honey butter (5/5) - AMAZING. The biscuit is large, golden brown on the edges, and fluffy inside. The honey butter is essentially butter mixed lightly with honey, but the balance of the creamy saltiness of butter with the sweet was so good.

2) The plow - Combination plate that allowed me to try a lot of different components. Crispy potatoes (5/5) - YES, so crispy on the outside, really well seasoned, but still buttery on the inside. Two overeasy eggs (4/5) - no complaints on the eggs themselves, wish they could have salted it a bit more though. House-made pork sausage (5/5) - really flavorful, it tasted like they mixed in little pieces of onions and herbs into it. Lemon ricotta pancakes (4/5) - actually not quite what I expected, for all that I hear about these pancakes, I was a little disappointed. The pancakes tasted really good, with just a hint of lemon that wasn't overpowering. However, because of the ricotta, the texture of the pancakes is a lot more dense, and I prefer my pancakes fluffier and airy.

A bit out of the way over in Potrero, but the trek is worth it!

The plow at the plow.

No matter how early you go, the wait is at least an hour. I came with a couple friends at 9:30am on a Saturday, and we weren't seated until 10:30am. Half the times I've waited before for brunch doesn't take that much time, but the brunch game in SF is always on point. Service here was efficient and welcoming, and street parking is everywhere.

TIP: Drop your friends off to get a spot on the waitlist while you find parking.

All 3 of us ordered the Plow, and I also ordered a grapefruit mimosa along with my meal.

The Plow (two eggs, two lemon ricotta pancakes, crispy potatoes, and side of either bacon or sausages) was delicious. How did the potatoes stay so crispy the whole time, I will never know. They were well seasoned too. I expected the pancakes to be the highlight piece on my plate, as I've had them before. Sadly, these pancakes weren't as good as I remembered when I came here last. Yes, the sweet lemon and honey taste was there, but the flavors just wasn't as packed this time around. The grapefruit mimosa was alright. Nothing too special and isn't worth $10.5 a glass. I'd rather go to Radish for their unlimited grapefruit mimosas ($15/person).

I'd come back just for the pancakes.
