nueske bacon.review: This joint is well worth the 2 hr wait. Advice: go to Blooms across the street and get totally tanked first.. And override the ham on the Benedict w/ Nueske bacon. Huge upgrade you'll thank me latr. Best brunch ever

excerpts: I got mine with the nueske bacon and I have to say it was the best bacon I've ever had.
Slightly sweet and salty
and they were very generous with the portions.
nueske bacon.author: Gema S.
nueske bacon.review: We were lucky to come across this place on a recent trip to SF because it was close to where we were staying, and it was quite a find! The first time we came here it was about 10:30 and there was an hour wait. We decided not to wait and came back the next day at opening because the pictures of the food looked so good on Yelp. I'm so glad we came back! The next day we had no wait and were seated quickly once the place opened. I got "The Plow" which comes with crispy potatoes, two eggs, choice of bacon, pork sausage or chicken sausage and two lemon ricotta pancakes. I got mine with the nueske bacon and I have to say it was the best bacon I've ever had. Slightly sweet and salty and they were very generous with the portions. The crispy potatoes were also a hit and I was just disappointed I couldn't manage to finish them all. The lemon ricotta pancakes were pretty good as well. Just enough sweetness and a good lemon flavor. My only complaint is that they were a bit on the dry side and lacked fluffiness. The freshly squeezed orange juice was also a plus. The place is very small and it was completely packed when we visited. Despite this, service was great. I look forward to visiting the Plow on my next visit to SF.

excerpts: I ordered The Plow which consists of two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes.
This was not cheap as the price of admission was $15.75, but it didn't fail to satisfy.
The potatoes were some of the best I've had in the city, super crispy and salty.
The eggs were scrambled to perfection and the pancakes may have been the highlight here.
And the bacon, was well bacon.
You can't really go wrong with bacon.
All in all, the entire experience was enjoyable and the waitress even prevented my from getting a parking ticket as halfway through the meal
she warned me there was street sweeping.
The neighborhood is a little out of the way if you are just visiting, but there is a great view of the skyline from across the street.
Definitely worth checking out if you've got some spare time.
Would highly suggest avoiding this place on the weekends.
#foodcomaking approved.
nueske bacon.author: Food Coma K.
nueske bacon.review: In the past few weeks, Plow has frequently become the main topic of conversation when talking about brunch. Unless you get there around 7am on weekends, you are looking at waiting over two hours which is insane if you ask me. This morning I just so happened to be in the area and drove by to see many open spots inside so I decided to stop and see what all the fuss is about. I was seated immediately and was able to get in and out of the establishment in under a half an hour which was awesome. The food was great. Worth waiting two hours for? Probably not, but then again I'm not sure any food is worth waiting two hours for. I ordered The Plow which consists of two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes. This was not cheap as the price of admission was $15.75, but it didn't fail to satisfy. The potatoes were some of the best I've had in the city, super crispy and salty. The eggs were scrambled to perfection and the pancakes may have been the highlight here. And the bacon, was well bacon. You can't really go wrong with bacon. All in all, the entire experience was enjoyable and the waitress even prevented my from getting a parking ticket as halfway through the meal she warned me there was street sweeping. The neighborhood is a little out of the way if you are just visiting, but there is a great view of the skyline from across the street. Definitely worth checking out if you've got some spare time. Would highly suggest avoiding this place on the weekends. #foodcomaking approved.

excerpts: I had "the plow" there for $13 -  "two eggs, choice of Nueske bacon, house made pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage, 2 pancakes, and crispy potatoes."
I saw the Chinese sausage there on the menu, and they allowed me to substitute that for my sausage choice.
The food came relatively quick, presented nicely on a white plate.
nueske bacon.author: Leo C.
nueske bacon.review:
Plow offers a clean and relaxed atmosphere to enjoy a fresh and delicious breakfast/brunch.  I came here jet lagged after getting off a trans-pacific flight, looking for a satisfying meal that features fresh ingredients.  Plow did the job for sure.  

I had "the plow" there for $13 -  "two eggs, choice of Nueske bacon, house made pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage, 2 pancakes, and crispy potatoes."  I saw the Chinese sausage there on the menu, and they allowed me to substitute that for my sausage choice.  The food came relatively quick, presented nicely on a white plate.  The server was very attentive and nice while conscious of not being bothersome.  

Overall, Plow is a place that I'd come back to as well as recommend to my friends.  It's not a great value since the price is somewhat premium for what you're getting.  But it's also very fresh and clean, so the price is fair.  Come check it out!

excerpts: My bf got the fried egg sandwich that came with two eggs fried, cheddar, frisee, aioli, crispy potatoes  and Nueske bacon.
It looked good, and was an adequate sized sandwich.
I was tempted to order their organic yogurt with granola and mixed fruit, but felt I needed to order something more substancial since it was our first time here.
nueske bacon.author: Joycelyn L.
nueske bacon.review:
Tasty, well-portioned meals, get here before 9am if coming for brunch so you don't have to wait in line.

Came here Sunday morning before 9am and were lucky to get some bar seats in front of all the cooks.  It was neat to see how they cooked everything.  We started off with the monkey bread and it tasted just like cinnamon buns, just not as sweet and without the sugary frosting spread all on it.  I got "the plow", which came with scrambled eggs, their homemade pork sausage, lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes.  The homemade pork sausage was slightly spicy with really good flavor, while the pancakes were super soft and tasty.  I liked how they were mini pancakes and not the huge ones you'd get at like IHOP/Denny's.  The crispy potatoes were a little too salty for me, but my bf liked them.  I might have been able to eat the whole plate of food if it weren't for the monkey bread, but I did find many couples sharing the plow, if the other person ordered something small.  My bf got the fried egg sandwich that came with two eggs fried, cheddar, frisee, aioli, crispy potatoes  and Nueske bacon.  It looked good, and was an adequate sized sandwich.  I was tempted to order their organic yogurt with granola and mixed fruit, but felt I needed to order something more substancial since it was our first time here.  Plus, you can make that at home.

Overall, one of the better brunch places I've been to and will surely come back for more.

excerpts: The combination with farmer's cheese, pickled red onion, caper, dill, Acme levain, and simple green salad served only to complement the dish even better.
simple green salad.author: Jack M.
simple green salad.review: Came here with Mom at a friend's suggestion for brunch. Seating is available both indoors & outdoors, although it will likely be a longer wait for seats indoors. Ended up sharing the cold-smoked salmon toast & the signature dish here called the Plow. First impressions here are nothing but positive. In regards to the cold-smoked salmon toast, the salmon this joint uses is really as tender, yummy, and pleasant to taste as I've ever had. Never realized how good farm-raised salmon could be ... something for me to remember for next time. The combination with farmer's cheese, pickled red onion, caper, dill, Acme levain, and simple green salad served only to complement the dish even better. As for the Plow, I loved the potatoes because of the seasoning that the chefs use on it, which is most stellar & left my mouth most happy. The lemon ricotta pancakes were just as soft, moist, and their tartiness was just perfect & not too overpowering. Eggs & sausage were also done well. Overall, a most pleasant place to come for brunch & I would definitely recommend it to others. Don't be surprised if there is a wait (there usually is).

excerpts: I paid $26 for the plow - which included 3 pieces of bacon, 2 small lemon ricotta pancakes with a teeny tiny bit of syrup, half a plate full of potatoes (which tasted quite bland), and egg whites (charged an extra $3 for the egg whites), and a pot of mint tea.
About a 25 minute wait to sit at the bar.
You definitely feel like you hae to eat and run because there are so many people waiting for your seat and the waiters
/waitresses can't wait to whisk your plate away.
egg whites.author: Camille H.
egg whites.review: I paid $26 for the plow - which included 3 pieces of bacon, 2 small lemon ricotta pancakes with a teeny tiny bit of syrup, half a plate full of potatoes (which tasted quite bland), and egg whites (charged an extra $3 for the egg whites), and a pot of mint tea. About a 25 minute wait to sit at the bar. You definitely feel like you hae to eat and run because there are so many people waiting for your seat and the waiters/waitresses can't wait to whisk your plate away.

excerpts: I opted for "The Plow" which came with two lemon ricotta pancakes/maple syrup (so good), two eggs (got mine just pure egg whites which were perfectly prepared), bacon (it wasn't the best, I should've just got the chicken apple sausage), and potatoes (which were the highlight of my meal --
egg whites.author: Jorel C.
egg whites.review:
Plow is located in a convenient spot off of 280 in Potrero Hill.  There was easily found street parking nearby when I went so I think parking shouldn't be much of a problem.  

Keep in mind I did not dine in for my meal during this visit to Plow, just a simple takeout request since I was alone.  

I opted for "The Plow" which came with two lemon ricotta pancakes/maple syrup (so good), two eggs (got mine just pure egg whites which were perfectly prepared), bacon (it wasn't the best, I should've just got the chicken apple sausage), and potatoes (which were the highlight of my meal -- I wish I ordered more because they were made to absolute perfection, crispy and all with just the right touch of rosemary).  

If you're in the area this place is so worth trying out despite the wait I've heard it has.  They've got some top-quality eats and excellent/friendly service even though my experience was brief inside the restaurant since I was just claiming my takeout order.  Definitely plan on returning soon!

excerpts: I had the plow with sausage, extra bacon, egg whites and a French toast
and I loved every bit of is!
Their toast is a must have as well!
This place made my last day here one to remember!
egg whites.author: Ismael L.
egg whites.review: Dood this place is amazing! Stayed in San Fran this weekend on vacation and tried a lot of good places to eat but this place here just blows every other place out of the water! The music they place is great, the food is amazing, and the employees are friendly and helpful. Definitely will be making this a must have every time I'm out here in San Fran! I 110% recommend this place! I had the plow with sausage, extra bacon, egg whites and a French toast and I loved every bit of is! Their toast is a must have as well! This place made my last day here one to remember!

excerpts: However, his eggs were undercooked (to the point that the egg whites were slightly runny) and his chicken apple sausage was dry (it was seasoned well though).
egg whites.author: Ally W.
egg whites.review:
Plow is a great place for breakfast...as evidenced by the long line of people waiting outside even at ridiculous times like 8 AM on a Saturday morning.  What a bunch of crazies -- Saturdays are for sleeping in.

I got their French Toast - 3 thick and fluffy eggy bread slices with strawberry and lavender jam, mascarpone, and maple syrup. I have more of a savory tooth for brunch, but enjoyed this sweet dish a lot.

My husband got The Plow, which is a combo of lemon ricotta pancakes, bacon or sausage, eggs, and crispy potatoes. This is a good dish to order if you are new to Plow and want to sample different items.  However, his eggs were undercooked (to the point that the egg whites were slightly runny) and his chicken apple sausage was dry (it was seasoned well though).

I like the lemon ricotta pancakes and crispy potatoes a lot.  I may even want to make them at home, you know, at like 11 AM on a Saturday morning.

1 star off: I do not like dried sausage in my mouth. Get your mind out of the gutter. Read my review above.

excerpts: They're making a dense batter (anything with that much ricotta has to be dense), and then lightening it with whipped egg whites like you're supposed to do for waffles.
Gives you a lighter texture, but still plenty of structure and a crispy exterior.
Plus, waffles reheat poorly, and so did my leftover pancake.
Now I could be totally off the mark, and no one but me could care about my little theory, but I like to know how things work.
egg whites.author: Amanda S.
egg whites.review:
You know how most lazy restaurants and home cooks use pancake batter to make their waffles, even though if you think about it, great pancakes and waffles have nothing texturally in common? Well, I think Plow is doing just the opposite for their lemon ricotta pancakes. They're making a dense batter (anything with that much ricotta has to be dense), and then lightening it with whipped egg whites like you're supposed to do for waffles. Gives you a lighter texture, but still plenty of structure and a crispy exterior. Plus, waffles reheat poorly, and so did my leftover pancake. Now I could be totally off the mark, and no one but me could care about my little theory, but I like to know how things work. Especially yummy things.

The lemon ricotta pancakes were super delicious, but I wish something had been served alongside.

I also wish I had gotten some of those potatoes. I was full and getting ready to leave when the lady next to me's food came out, but the smell of the potatoes was intoxicating.

All in all, a very respectable brunch, I just recommend going on a weekday.

excerpts: Egg whites for $5.50 is cray.
The food is good but on the expensive side.
The homemade sausage patty was delicious.
egg whites.author: Fatty A.
egg whites.review: Solid brunch spot.  The wait here is cray.  Egg whites for $5.50 is cray.  The food is good but on the expensive side.  The homemade sausage patty was delicious.  I was expecting the lemon ricotta pancakes to blow me away.  They were just good.  The chicken tinga was also pretty good.  It looks heavy but was actually pretty light with soft scrambled eggs.  Thank you for not charging SF health tax.  I would go back.

excerpts: I ordered egg whites with toast, chicken apple sausage and potatoes.
egg whites.author: Elaine S.
egg whites.review:
Arrived around 10:30 on a Sunday, yeah, not the ideal time to arrive for Sunday brunch at a place that doesn't take reservations. The host said we would be in by 11, unfortunately we were not seated until 11:15, ouch. Luckily the food made it worth while!

I loved the decor, modern/country/homey all at the same time maybe it was, because we had been standing outside in the cold and it was raining...who knows. 

Our server was super friendly and told us about the daily specials.

We ordered the bakery basket to split between four of us, which came with a scone, a corn muffin, a biscuit, butter, jam & honey. I love scones, but enjoyed everything in the "basket", which turned out to be served on a plate.

The lemon ricotta pancakes were freaking delicious, small, but I would definitely recommend them!

The French toast looked awesome, but my brother finished it before I got a chance to try it; it must have been good.

The daily quiche special was fig, leek and egg custard, which was savory and sweet and totally delicious.

I ordered egg whites with toast, chicken apple sausage and potatoes. Everything was wonderful, like your traditional breakfast, but everything tasted fresh and natural.

Loved the food & atmosphere, not so much the wait, but I'm sure I'll be back!

excerpts: I had the egg sandwich, I changed it to egg whites, and it was still amazing.
Three of us ate and we were all amazed and could not wait to go back.
The street it is on is reaally cute too.
We walked around and shopped before and after in the surrounding blocks and had a great morning.
Everyone should try this place....a different menu printed up everyday.
The owners should be very proud.
egg whites.author: Barbara L.
egg whites.review: WOW! I almost am afraid to yelp this because we had to wait for an hour for our table. It was an hour well spent. It was the most delious, clean, fabulous breakfast Ive ever had. I had the egg sandwich, I changed it to egg whites, and it was still amazing. Three of us ate and we were all amazed and could not wait to go back. The street it is on is reaally cute too. We walked around and shopped before and after in the surrounding blocks and had a great morning. Everyone should try this place....a different menu printed up everyday. The owners should be very proud.

excerpts: I had the scramble with egg whites.
Perfect mix of spinach, jalapenos, chives and goat cheese in the scramble.
Potatoes are seasoned deliciously and perfectly crisp.
egg whites.author: Latte Queen W.
egg whites.review:
THE PERFECT BRUNCH PLACE.

On Saturday we arrived at 11am for brunch. We waited over an hour for a group of 3. The wait was TOTALLY worth it. 

Ambience is definitely perfect - just like the reviewer prior said, it's like a big kitchen you want to spend a lot of time in, with big beautiful windows and generous sunlight. 

And the food...ohhh the food. I had the scramble with egg whites. Perfect mix of spinach, jalapenos, chives and goat cheese in the scramble. Potatoes are seasoned deliciously and perfectly crisp. Tasted my friend's lemon ricotta pancakes - pretty good. The toast was prebuttered and yummy as well.

Friendly and fun service. 

I can't wait to go back!

excerpts: The Equator coffee was decent too, and overall the prices and service weren't bad.
equator coffee.author: Vincent L.
equator coffee.review:
A decent spot for weekend brunch that gets incredibly crowded because it's one of the few good options in the neighborhood. The fried egg sandwich with cheddar, aioli, frisee, and extra avocado was a satisfying choice, in the comforting way that having eggs in the morning is for many people. The Equator coffee was decent too, and overall the prices and service weren't bad. 

Is it worth an insane wait on the weekends when there are so many brunch places that are at least as good in the West Bay? If you're from the neighborhood and don't want to saunter elsewhere on weekend mornings, perhaps yes. If you're making a special trek out here, perhaps no. In my opinion, it might be a better option if you're free on a weekday morning and it's less crowded. YMMV.

excerpts: They have a special plow blend that they serve from Equator Coffee and
if the smell of eggs and toast doesn't wake you up, the coffee sure will.
equator coffee.author: Vasiliy M.
equator coffee.review:
I couldn't decide between 4 and 5 stars and was going back and forth, but opted to give credit where credit is due. Plow creates a unique brunch experience, and while not everything on the menu is exceptional, certain menu options will change the way you think about "typical" breakfast meals. 

First off, the wait can be horrendous if you get here at not the right time. The best move is to arrive at 7:45am and you're most likely guaranteed to get seated with the first group. 15 min wait is worth the early rise. And the food (as well as the endless coffee) will remove any other doubts you had about not sleeping in.

Let's revisit the coffee though. They have a special plow blend that they serve from Equator Coffee and if the smell of eggs and toast doesn't wake you up, the coffee sure will. It only costs $3.50 and they keep it coming the entire time you're there.

Next, I ordered the gruyere and prosciutto toast and, to satisfy my sweet tooth, I order one ricotta lemon pancake. The toast was great, but not anything special. Sure the soft and warm yolk of fried egg on top of the toast slowly dripping onto the prosciutto and soaking in to the toast makes it irresistible, but this toast did not change my life. In fact, I am confident that I can recreate this at home. Additionally, the potatoes were solid, but I've had much better potatoes in the past. At this point I was leaning towards 4 stars.

...then I tasted the pancake...

And, for the first time in my life, I understood what a perfect pancake feels and tastes like. The pancake itself was an oxymoron: fluffy, but compact; light, but rich in flavor; strong lemon flavor, but hidden sweetness. It was so good, I forced my friend (who was full at that point) to try some. Hands down, the best pancake I've ever had. There is no comparison. None.

The most striking thing about Plow is the fact that the space is so simple and unsuspecting. And that's what gives it character. You come in with high expectations given the favorable reviews, but somehow Plow still manages to make you feel comfortable and catches you off guard. 

I didn't fully believe the hype before I ate here, but after experiencing it for myself I can truly say I'm sold. Plow, you earned 5 stars and then some. Thanks for everything.

excerpts: Equator coffee was good.
Overall- a good standard brunch, very very very long lines
so if you are in no hurry at all enjoy a leisurely wait here.
equator coffee.author: Vivian D.
equator coffee.review: Came on a Sun very close to closing and still had to wait maybe 45 min. Pretty standard brunch cuisine, but a cozy nice place to spend your weekend brunch. I got The Plow which was decent. Really enjoyed the homemade pork sausage- delicious. The ricotta lemon pancakes are actually quite small and dense. I  also tried a bit of the crab scramble which was tasty with the creme fraiche on top. Equator coffee was good. Overall- a good standard brunch, very very very long lines so if you are in no hurry at all enjoy a leisurely wait here.

excerpts: *Equator coffee $3.75.
Unlimited refills.
We started with their **Hong Kong style toast  buttered brioche + sweetened condensed milk.
I was super excited because its been forever since I had condensed milk.
The brioche we had was super dry.
Was a bit disappointed with that.
We had one piece and let the milk soak in to soften up the brioche.
My friend had their famous *
equator coffee.author: Sandy B.
equator coffee.review:
Finally got my seat at plow this passed Saturday. Been waiting to come here for awhile. The week before I got to plow at 11:30am and it was a 2.5 hour wait for a party of 3. We couldn't wait because we were hungry. Came back this Saturday at 10:30am and it was 1.5 - 2 hour wait for a party of 2. WOW!!! I know, the wait is crazy long. Instead of just waiting outside, my friend and I decided to get coffee 2 blocks away to kill time. Also you can order coffee, drinks and baked goods from Plow as you wait for your table. 

It was slightly over 1.5 hour wait and got a seat at the counter. We ordered **Equator coffee $3.75. Unlimited refills. We started with their **Hong Kong style toast  buttered brioche + sweetened condensed milk. I was super excited because its been forever since I had condensed milk. The brioche we had was super dry. Was a bit disappointed with that. We had one piece and let the milk soak in to soften up the brioche. My friend had their famous **"The Plow". Comes with everything, two eggs, choice of protein, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes + plow potatoes. She got the house made pork sausage patties. I thought it was super yummy. I got to try everything she had. I really like their triple fried plow potatoes. Must have!! I got their special **Cornbeef hash on poached eggs. I really like it. Wasn't too heavy. This dish is smaller in portion size but I thought it was perfect for me. 

Not my favorite in the city but it has became my TOP 5 BRUNCH in SF. Service was good, staff was friendly, especially the chefs.

excerpts: Aromatic Equator coffee rounded off the great brunch.
equator coffee.author: Lindt C.
equator coffee.review:
We came here on a Friday morning and there was also a queue (although more manageable than weekends). 

We had the plow, butcher's steak and pancakes. All were good but I thought the Butcher's steak was surprisingly excellent. 

Aromatic Equator coffee rounded off the great brunch. 

I would visit more often if not for the long queue!

excerpts: I opted for the pork sausages based on the server's recommendations and ordered a cup of their Equator coffee to pair off with my meal.
I don't know if it's the coffee fiend in me, but their cup of joe was addicting.
equator coffee.author: Denzell S.
equator coffee.review:
I decided to be productive this morning and go to the gym. But of course, considering the time it takes to get ready, drive to the gym, and sit in traffic, I decided instead to plow my face at Plow. They open at 7am but already at 6:50am people are congregated outside their door. Inside has a nice, quaint, homey feel. The server seated me on the counter facing the kitchen, so I had a perfect view of the kitchen. 

I ordered the Plow, which consists of 2 eggs, 2 lemon riccota pancakes, their house potatoes, and choice of protein-chicken apple sausages, Nueske's bacon, or house pork sausages. I opted for the pork sausages based on the server's recommendations and ordered a cup of their Equator coffee to pair off with my meal. I don't know if it's the coffee fiend in me, but their cup of joe was addicting. I may have had a total of 4 cups.

The meal was real hearty leaving me stuffed. The house potatoes were nice and crispy seasoned with what tasted like rosemary. The lemon riccota pancakes were nice and fluffy with just the perfect amount of lemon flavoring. Initially I ordered for over-medium eggs so the yolk doesn't run throughout my plate but instead was served over-easy and a bit salty. I typically refrain from using condiments so I can savor the flavor of the dish, but their pork sausage was a tad dry, overcooked, and overly seasoned with herbs that ketchup helped neutralize the taste.

As I was wrapping up my meal, the chef also pulled out a fresh mochi cake from the oven and of course I couldn't resist, so I decided to order a slice to go. The cake reminded me of a Filipino bibingka cake. It has a spongy and gelatinous texture with a coconut after-taste. Very delicious especially when warm. 

Plow is perfect for splurging on breakfast. Personal advice is to come early because they do get packed and of course for the owners to add bottomless mimosas to their menu- one can only dream.

excerpts: it's Equator coffee.
Definitely recommend this place, only downside is that I wish that the avocado toast included 2, other than that great service, great food and nice area.
Found parking easily which is a big plus anywhere near the SF area.
equator coffee.author: Esmeralda Q.
equator coffee.review: Came here today on a Wednesday and there was no wait. It was still pretty busy and got even more packed 20 mins after ver arrived, closer to 11 am. We sat outside, it was a cool breezy day but they have blankets that you can use to keep warm which I think is a really nice touch. My husband ordered The Plow and I ordered the avocado toast with a side of sausage. My husband devoured his breakfast, and said everything was delicious. The lemon ricotta pancakes are yummy, sweet and fluffy. The avocado toast was lemony, tangy and the bread crispy and flavorful. They have homemade salsa which wasn't spicy but added a burst of flavor. The coffee was good it's Equator coffee. Definitely recommend this place, only downside is that I wish that the avocado toast included 2, other than that great service, great food and nice area. Found parking easily which is a big plus anywhere near the SF area.

excerpts: Ruben started with a cup of Equator Coffee ($3.50) and we shared a Cinnamon Brioche ($4).
It was a delicious rendition of a cinnamon roll and the center was perfectly gooey and flavorful.
equator coffee.author: Amelinda L.
equator coffee.review:
We walked here from the 16th St BART Station. Not a good idea. I didn't think to check the distance (1.6 miles); it seemed so close on the map. It's not that a 32-minute walk wasn't good for me (I totally earned my breakfast, not), it's the unsavory characters that you encounter. So, don't do what I did. However, the meal was worth the trouble!

We arrived around 9:30 on a Tuesday and it was much busier than I expected. Fortunately not busy enough that we had to wait because thankfully, there were two seats available at the bar. Some helpful notes: they will not seat you unless your entire party is present. Even if it is just one other person. No exceptions. Also, there's only 6-7 seats at the bar and roughly seven tables (very small space). There are a couple tables for outside dining as well.

Owner/Chef Maxine Siu was directly in front of us busily preparing dishes in their small partially-open kitchen. She was careful not to make eye contact with any patrons. Totally understandable, but it would have been so much fun to talk food. 

Ruben started with a cup of Equator Coffee ($3.50) and we shared a Cinnamon Brioche ($4). It was a delicious rendition of a cinnamon roll and the center was perfectly gooey and flavorful. I selected The Plow ($16) with sunny side-up eggs, housemade pork sausage, two Lemon Ricotta Pancakes, and crispy potatoes. The sausage was nice, but dry. Not my favorite sausage. Though the crispy potatoes were lovely and the Lemon Ricotta Pancakes were perfect! Ruben had the Fried Egg Sandwich with Nueske Bacon ($13.50), two soft fried eggs, aioli, cheddar, and frisée on an Acme bun. This was also tasty with the addition of the "Food's Best Friend Lucky Dog" hot fire-roasted pepper sauce.

Our server was really friendly and everyone was very pleasant. We didn't loiter much since there were several people waiting, but it's a nice setting to hang out and catch up with friends. The decor is fun with many pigs around! Oh, the important question - would I wait for 1+ hour(s) for a table? No, but that is why you plan ahead!

excerpts: From the Equator coffee, to the ridiculously crispy/soft potatoes, to their homemade sausage and fantastic buttermilk biscuits, Plow consistently outperforms its competitors when it comes to SF brunch fare.
They do the basics well, which is surprisingly hard to come by these days, and have creative/interesting twists on them (the prosciutto/melon salad is one of the best things I've ever eaten).
I would put this up against any of the Eater SF contenders.
equator coffee.author: Sheila E.
equator coffee.review:
This is as good as it gets for me. From the Equator coffee, to the ridiculously crispy/soft potatoes, to their homemade sausage and fantastic buttermilk biscuits, Plow consistently outperforms its competitors when it comes to SF brunch fare. They do the basics well, which is surprisingly hard to come by these days, and have creative/interesting twists on them (the prosciutto/melon salad is one of the best things I've ever eaten). I would put this up against any of the Eater SF contenders. To top it off, Plow's friendly wait-staff make you feel like you're eating at your best friend's house (the one who effortlessly is cool/casual and who may have an appreciation for Toms and all things succulents). 

If waiting in line for a table bothers you, walk around the quaintness that is Potrero Hill (shout out to Farley's and Gaelan's Boutique). Or try it out by yourself and sit at their chef's counter and have a front row seat to all the action. Some things are worth waiting for and this is certainly one of them. 

Thank you Plow for being my happy place!

excerpts: Oh-- and a cup of Equator coffee to wash it all down.
equator coffee.author: Melody W.
equator coffee.review:
I came here with a gal pal on a Thursday lunch break (~12:15pm). Parking was easy (say what the what? It's never easy in SF). Since I was in great company, the wait wasn't long at all--probably 10-15 minutes max for first available seating. We got seated outside, which was fine. The weather was amazing, so we didn't mind. 

She ordered a side of scrambled eggs with the Almond Flour Pancakes. I got the Plow breakfast (hey-- when in Rome, right?) which came with two eggs (over-easy for me), 4 things of chicken apple sausage, 2 lemon ricotta pancakes (yes! and yes!), and a big hoppin' load of crispy potato chunks (it's a bit ginger-y, so be advised). Oh-- and a cup of Equator coffee to wash it all down. I loved The Plow (get yer mind outta the gutter...lol). I believe the gal pal loved her pancakes too. I only wish my lemon ricotta pancakes had some blueberry compote (sp?) like the ones in the regular lemon ricotta pancake entree. And, I think the crispy potatoes were a little over-powering with ginger taste. All in all, I loved the dish and the experience. 

This place is worth a visit in my book.

excerpts: +Coffee: San Raf's finest, Equator coffee.
equator coffee.author: Adena B.
equator coffee.review:
"Hour and a half wait," says Randall.

"No worries, we'll wait it out," I told him. He smiled and handed me some coffee to pass the time. He also pointed down the street and shared a tip: "Rico makes some killer Bloody Marys. In case you're interested."

Of COURSE I'm interested, Randall. We wasted a good 45 minutes at Blooms Saloon, (http://www.yelp.com/biz/blooms-saloon-san-francisco#hrid:g60JAte3LvIB4-uJ8CCUXw) then headed back to wait out the remainder of the time. 

EATS
+The Plow: two eggs, choice of house made pork sausage, Nueske bacon, or chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes with pure maple syrup, and some crispy potatoes. The boy got his with the sugar pie pumpkin pancakes (instead of the lemon ricotta) and they were just as heavenly--if not better. We both opted for the bacon--and it was just OK; kinda smokey.

DRANKS
+Mimosas: watered down and not that great; especially not after that spicy Bloody Mary.
+Coffee: San Raf's finest, Equator coffee. Excellent.

Service was good, Randall made it great. Will I be back? Probably not, but happy to have tested it out to see what the hype was all about.

excerpts: For instance, they have lemon ricotta pancakes, super crispy (and well-seasoned) potatoes, and Equator coffee.
equator coffee.author: Sarah G.
equator coffee.review:
Plow is such a cute little neighborhood spot. 

It's a great breakfast/brunch place that has a lot of familiar breakfast foods done a little bit better. For instance, they have lemon ricotta pancakes, super crispy (and well-seasoned) potatoes, and Equator coffee. Overall, the food was very well-executed here, and is delicious. 

I also enjoyed sitting at the bar during my meal. I was watching the cooking staff, and they were dancing and seemed really happy. Some were even saying thanks to the customers as they left. I definitely enjoyed this happy vibe. 

The only disclaimer is that this place is super busy, so be prepared to wait. Don't come starving (and expecting to eat as soon as you arrive). Otherwise, you'll be very unhappy to hear your wait time.

excerpts: Equator coffee was earthy and was happily light roasted.
equator coffee.author: T L.
equator coffee.review:
(See pics) Review #1192. Great all local purveyors ingredients brunch that brightens up any gloomy day or energizes a sunny day.

The day we visited, they were out of monkey bread so we opted for corn millet muffin which was good.

The Plow with the two eggs, Nueske bacon, chicken apple sausage, two lemon ricotta pancakes and potatoes was a total brunch that had everything you need and desire. The bacon and sausage were good salty, sweet and meaty, while the pancakes definitely were the highlight. Eggs were prepared perfectly to my likeness.

As mentioned many times in my other reviews, I love locally roasted beans. Equator coffee was earthy and was happily light roasted.

My friend had the fried egg on Acme bun that was hearty and freshly tasted.

Mimosa was nice but more orange juice than sparkling wine.

Many had wondered about the San Francisco style long wait and yes even on a rainy weekend we we visited. However, the server was extremely helpful and actually told us not to go get coffee up the street because there would be a table coming up shortly and if those who were not there while called, they would lose the spot. Amazing enough, we only waited for 10 minutes. While the place was completely packed, service was super friendly and perky, we were never rushed to finish, though we were considerate to not hold up the tables.

Do wish they were closer to public transit stops.

excerpts: Its expected though, and they serve Equator coffee which is my favorite brand.
So def a plus!
They have outside seating which is also a plus.
Oh and they have some sitting area outside for you to sit at while you wait too.
equator coffee.author: Jefferson Y.
equator coffee.review:
GODDAMN THIS PLACE IS EXPENSIVE.

Its expected though, and they serve Equator coffee which is my favorite brand. So def a plus! They have outside seating which is also a plus. Oh and they have some sitting area outside for you to sit at while you wait too. Service was very good.

I got "The Plow". LEMON RICCOTTA PANCAKES= BOMB. Perfectly cooked over easy egg and crispy potatoes. I got the chicken apple sausages which were meh, were they packaged or something? Because there are "homemade pork sausages", that I wish I tried instead but will next time. Overall, sweet spot I would definitely come again.

excerpts:
Items selected:

Equator Coffee
Blueberry Streusel Muffin
Lemon Ricotta Pancake
French Toast with Strawberries, Mascarpone, Maple Syrup

Another day led to another breakfast near Potrero Hill, this time at Plow where Maxine Siu and a small team of four embracing the theme of "Midwest country boy meets San Francisco China girl" churned out a an eclectic list of early morning classics to a constantly packed dining room of locals and tourists alike.
equator coffee.author: Michael U.
equator coffee.review:
Items selected:

Equator Coffee
Blueberry Streusel Muffin
Lemon Ricotta Pancake
French Toast with Strawberries, Mascarpone, Maple Syrup

Another day led to another breakfast near Potrero Hill, this time at Plow where Maxine Siu and a small team of four embracing the theme of "Midwest country boy meets San Francisco China girl" churned out a an eclectic list of early morning classics to a constantly packed dining room of locals and tourists alike.  With friendly service from a young woman named Kirby and a seat at the bar allowing me to watch the kitchen at work the duration of my stay was bookended with copious refills of rich Mocha Java from Equator with three plates between, the first a dense blueberry muffin stuffed with fresh berries and the latter two single orders of the restaurant's highly praised ricotta pancakes and custard soaked French Toast.  Rich and decadent, particularly after the addition of pure maple syrup, it would be a tough call as to whether the French Toast was quite as good as that at nopa but no matter which side of the fence one falls on both are in the upper echelon of their genre and unlike nopa Plow offers their breakfast all week.

excerpts: Plow is also one of the few places that serve Equator coffee in SF (especially now that La Boulange is being acquired by Starbucks) -
while expensive at $3.75 / cup (unlimited refills), it complements a meal perfectly.
equator coffee.author: Rishi N.
equator coffee.review:
Plow is probably my favorite brunch spot in SF.  The location itself is pretty small and very homely / cozy, with huge windows that allow sunlight to pour in (especially valuable for those who don't enjoy as much sunlight due to living elsewhere in SF...).  If only I could park myself here on weekdays and read a book / eat breakfast every day... (and if only I had unlimited monetary resources...)

The food itself is delightful.  During my last visit, I ordered the almond flour pancakes, which are perfectly fluffy on the inside, with the right amount of almond flavor so as to deliver a rich taste without being overwhelming.  I've also ordered the french toast with strawberry compote, mascarpone, and syrup, which was tremendous.  I'm a vegetarian so I can't comment on meat dishes, but friends whom I have gone to Plow with all rave about the dishes they've gotten (everything from The Plow to the Nicoise salad).  Plow is also one of the few places that serve Equator coffee in SF (especially now that La Boulange is being acquired by Starbucks) - while expensive at $3.75 / cup (unlimited refills), it complements a meal perfectly.  Service is great given how hectic things seem to be every time I visit (which has always been on weekends), as the staff is very friendly.

The main negative aspect, as other folks have noted here, is the wait - it can be absolutely brutal at 1-2 hours on weekends.  That wait will get you a single table for 2 if you're lucky, or perhaps a seat at a table of 4 (typically shared with other people if your party is fewer than 4 people) or at the bar.  If you show up after 10:30am on a weekend, be prepared to wait a while ... with limited breakfast / brunch options nearby if you decide that you can't stand the wait.  Plow is also quite pricey for brunch (even by SF standards) - in my opinion, it's worth it, but coupled with the long wait it's something to keep in mind.

All in all, Plow is definitely worth visiting - and if you can make it work, visit on a weekday to avoid the brutal lines (note that they're closed on Mondays).

excerpts: I started with the Equator coffee (GREAT), and ordered the Plow for brunch.
equator coffee.author: C T.
equator coffee.review:
Loved the ambience here. Super cute brunch spot, good for small groups and catching up with friends on the weekends.

I started with the Equator coffee (GREAT), and ordered the Plow for brunch.  I really enjoyed the home-made sausage, the over-easy eggs (not your average supermarket eggs) and crispy potatoes!!! The lemon ricotta pancakes were good, but not amazing.  If I ever come back, I'd probably order the chicken tinga.  I pretty much forced the dude to hand over his plate midway through our meal. YOINK.

Warning: be prepared to wait longer than the quoted time. We were told it would be a 35 minute wait, but ended up getting seated an hour and 15 minutes later.

excerpts: Lemon ricotta pancakes and Equator coffee.
Other stuff is good but the pancakes are what you go for.
Honorable mention-
their bread and butter is somehow amazing.
I don't find their egg breakfast items to be over the top but a main staple
equator coffee.author: Sigorney S.
equator coffee.review: Lemon ricotta pancakes and Equator coffee. Other stuff is good but the pancakes are what you go for. Honorable mention- their bread and butter is somehow amazing. I don't find their egg breakfast items to be over the top but a main staple

excerpts: I did have their equator coffee and it was pretty good.
equator coffee.author: Mika D.
equator coffee.review:
Finally, I stopped in today for a quick brunch. Table for 1 please! =) 
I really don't mind eating by myself. Alisa seated me and took my order. I had the mini lemon ricotta pancakes and they were perfect! I also ordered a side of crispy bacon and a side of their country potatoes. I swear, these are the best potatoes I've had for brunch...EVER! I asked how they were prepared and she answered my question with so much love. I mean, I was sold after she told me. And now, I'm going to share with you what the secret was! They boil and roast the potatoes with salt, pepper, olive oil and thyme and caramelized onions then they deep fry them! OMG they came out so crispy, crunchy and moist when you bite into them. *automatic drool*

I love this restaurant at first sight. I think this is one of my top 5 brunch spots in the City. I didn't have to wait for a table at 10:15 am today. There were a few customers who dined in. I did have their equator coffee and it was pretty good. 

Oh man, I can't wait to go back. Next time, I'm ordering the same exact thing but with extra butter for my pancakes. They're THAT good. Trust me.

excerpts: I also really enjoyed Plow's Equator coffee while I waited for our table.
And that wait was long!
We came in at 11:30 am and had to wait an hour until we were seated.
equator coffee.author: Tiffany M.
equator coffee.review:
I'm not one to vouch for restaurants that often, but in Plow's case, I guarantee that you'll like it... in fact, you'll LOVE it. I should also note that I almost never rate a place 5 stars based on a first time visit, but Plow was so freakin' good, that I feel confident in giving them 5 shiny stars.

Everything at Plow tasted just as good as it looked.

Standouts included:
+Lemon Ricotta Pancakes (house made ricotta, lemon zest, pure maple syrup) 
+Tinga (chicken in tomato chipotle sauce, two crispy corn tortillas, avocado, creme fraiche, cilantro)
+Crispy Potatoes

Mid-conversation, my friend let out a big 'MMMM!!!!" when he bit into his pancakes. I couldn't have agreed more! 

I like the fact that they work w/ local purveyors such as Frog Hollow Farms, Cowgirl Creamery, Monterey Fish Co, Acme Bread & Tcho Chocolate. When you see that they work w/ such local all-stars, you know you're in for a treat. I also really enjoyed Plow's Equator coffee while I waited for our table. And that wait was long! We came in at 11:30 am and had to wait an hour until we were seated. Normally I'd shoot for a much earlier brunch time to avoid the wait, but given that I was prepared for a leisurely Sunday brunch, the wait was pretty painless.

I love the ambiance of this place. It's small, but w/ their high ceilings and all the light that shines in from their big windows, they're able to make the space work; especially decorated in its rustic, modern, simplistic fashion. I love their signage, logo and menu- all well done. They also have stool seating where you can watch the chefs work their magic (like we did!)

The host was cool and our server efficient. Parking was ample (not surprising for Portrero Hill ) and diners seemed to be all SF locals. 

Looking forward to coming back to Plow ASAP to try their Fried Egg Sandwich, The Plow (two eggs, choice of Nueske bacon, house made pork sausage, or chicken apple sausage, two pancakes & crispy potatoes), and/or a Chocolate Eclair.

This place makes me thankful for SF's amazing food scene!

excerpts: Equator coffee:
equator coffee.author: Ben T.
equator coffee.review:
Delicious food, all the way around.

Equator coffee: outstanding

Coffee cake: warm, fresh, light, and delicious

Scramble: fluffy, flavorful, nice ingredient mix, tasty

Potatoes: great texture, yummy

Lemon pancakes: fantastic

Nice atmosphere, kind people, good value for an SF brunch

excerpts: Friendly service with Equator coffee.
equator coffee.author: John K.
equator coffee.review: Small, but brightly lit neighborhood place on Potrero Hill that features locally produced yummy food. Nice feel with the open kitchen.   Everyone starts to line up 30 mins before opening and the taxis begin dropping people off from all around the City.  Must have the house made breakfast sausage.  THE PLOW is the breakfast combo that features 2 eggs, choice of meat, potatoes and the lemon ricotta pancakes.  Everything is truly outstanding.  Friendly service with Equator coffee.

excerpts: The Equator coffee was strong to my liking, and you can even sip on it while you're waiting in line outside.
We tried the cinnamon sugar donuts (not on the menu currently), which reminded me of freshly fried beignets.
SO GOOD.
I'm bummed
I won't get to try these again anytime soon.
I had the eggs benedict with mushroom/spinach and ham (the two add-ons), which was delicious.
equator coffee.author: Jen T.
equator coffee.review:
plow has quickly been rising in the ranks as a staple brunch place in SF, so I can't believe it's taken me this long to remember to review it.
This place is GOOD. It's in a somewhat random location for me (meaning, when we walked around after our meal, there were only other restaurants to look at.. e.g. Chez Papa Bistrot down the block), but the upside of this is that the parking is SO much better than the rest of the city. 
Our friend came an hour early before our meeting time for the wait on a Saturday morning, so that tells you how poppin' this place is. The place overall is quaint and airy, with a handful of tables and a counter facing the open kitchen, with very modern decor.
The Equator coffee was strong to my liking, and you can even sip on it while you're waiting in line outside.
We tried the cinnamon sugar donuts (not on the menu currently), which reminded me of freshly fried beignets. SO GOOD. I'm bummed I won't get to try these again anytime soon.
I had the eggs benedict with mushroom/spinach and ham (the two add-ons), which was delicious. The eggs were cooked to perfection, and the crispy potatoes lived up to their name.
Overall, a great brunch place to add to my list of go-to's. I will mos def be back!

excerpts: The equator coffee was a good companion to the brunch, definitely strong.
Would come back for more pancakes and crunchy potatoes.
equator coffee.author: Candace F.
equator coffee.review: Brunch was the name of the game. I came here on a holiday and it was prime time for brunch/lunch. We scored awesome parking up on the hill. We walked in and put our name on the list and took a nice stroll in the neighborhood. I never get a chance to visit this side of town. After a 35 minute wait, we were seated. We shared the butternut squash soup and the plow. The soup was flavorful, you can taste the spices. The plow came with 2 pancakes, choice of sausage, potato chunks and eggs. I'm just glad we shared the meal, that would be too much food for me.  The lemon ricotta pancakes were to die for. The best I've had, the pancakes were light and fluffy. The equator coffee was a good companion to the brunch, definitely strong. Would come back for more pancakes and crunchy potatoes.

excerpts: Our coffee cups were never empty with Equator coffee, the service was phenomenal!
We are definitely going back!
equator coffee.author: Dr B.
equator coffee.review: We read about this place on Yelp and decided to try it since it was a short walk from my sister's condo where we were staying.  We were skeptical when we arrived around 11am and saw a big line of people outside but put our names on the list anyway.  We were only a party of 2 and after 5 minutes we were seated!  My girlfriend had the Scramble and I had the Two Eggs, both of which were generous portions and were excellent.  Our coffee cups were never empty with Equator coffee, the service was phenomenal!  We are definitely going back!

excerpts: The coffee is good (they said they serve Equator coffee)
Food was all good, and high quality.
equator coffee.author: R N.
equator coffee.review:
Husb and I checked this out at 1pm today and the line looked intimidating.  We had a very short wait.

The coffee is good (they said they serve Equator coffee)
Food was all good, and high quality.  I had the fried egg sandwich, and my husband had the plow breakfast that comes with lemon ricotta pancakes-- yum!  delicate and flavorful.  Will be back!

excerpts: Thanks for rekindling opportunities to savor Equator Coffee while anticipating another outstanding meal (lunch too) before launching back into our City.
equator coffee.author: Geo G.
equator coffee.review: Plow is, by far, the best spot in San Francisco to enjoy breakfast. It's actually converted me into a breakfast fan after years of false promises or inconsistencies elsewhere. From the outstanding epicurean delights (lemon ricotta pancakes...!) to genuinely convivial and efficient service to warm, open, and clean ambience, your senses will awaken happily here. If you're going solo, enjoy the counter and triptych windows framing the oak tree; groups can enjoy comfortable tables with abundant indirect light. Thanks for rekindling opportunities to savor Equator Coffee while anticipating another outstanding meal (lunch too) before launching back into our City.

excerpts: One of them also ordered fresh grapefruit juice and a warm buttermilk biscuit with honey butter (omg).
grapefruit juice.author: Brittany D.
grapefruit juice.review:
This is definitely one of the more upscale brunch joints with average meals $15+, but to be fair, the food is excellent! They deserve to be paid top dollar for the eclectic menu. 

FOOD. My goodness, what I would give for another open-faced prosciutto and gruyere toast this morning?! This magical combo with chili, garlic egg fried up, frisee (a type of endive) and parsley atop a toasted Acme brioche ($15) was heavenly. With a side of plow potatoes, this meal leans on the carb-heavy side of the breakfast food spectrum, but I cannot complain because it was simply amazing. *I do have to warn you, however, that the egg is super runny, so consume with extreme caution* They also serve Equator drip coffee! Although not a seasoned coffee drinker myself, I do appreciate this particular brand of coffee ever since my first tasting at its home base location in Marin County. My two other classmates each ordered the plow signature dish, a tasting platter, if you will, and a good first-timer dish according to the waitress. It included two eggs with your choice of house made pork sausage patties, Nueske's bacon, or chicken apple sausage, and two (mini) lemon ricotta pancakes with a side of yet again those delicious plow potatoes ($17.50). One of them also ordered fresh grapefruit juice and a warm buttermilk biscuit with honey butter (omg). 

SERVICE. 5 stars. The waitress even knew how to use an instax mini 9. She deserved bonus points for this. Tuesday morning around 10am is also the best time to come if you can. We were seated almost instantly upon arrival-- it took longer for my instax camera to produce an image on the Polaroid film. She was also very accommodating and gave great recommendations. We got pretty good seats by the window, but do be aware that since space is tight, the tables feel communal even though they're separate from each other. So if you're okay with sitting right next to the table next to you, then it should be fine. Get friendly.

I will reiterate: excellent food, excellent service. Can't wait to be back to try the other items on the menu!

excerpts: The potatoes were delicious, grapefruit juice was fresh, and they even had blankets for us since we were sitting outside and it was a bit chilly that morning.
The lemon ricotta pancake was amazing.
Don't miss this place!
grapefruit juice.author: Laleh J.
grapefruit juice.review: Wow this place was really excellent.  A friend and I came here for brunch on a Saturday morning- we waited for around 30 minutes but the wait was well worth it!  The vegetarian scrambled eggs were perfect.  The potatoes were delicious, grapefruit juice was fresh, and they even had blankets for us since we were sitting outside and it was a bit chilly that morning.  The lemon ricotta pancake was amazing.  Don't miss this place!

excerpts: I had fresh grapefruit juice and it was a nice addition to my morning.
Overall we really enjoyed Plow.
grapefruit juice.author: Evelia T.
grapefruit juice.review:
Breakfast is my favorite meal of the day so while visiting the bay area, my bf and I HAD  to find a good breakfast spot. This place opens up at 8am on Sunday and we got there a couple minutes past 8 and there was a huge line already. That was a good sign of a great breakfast to come. We waited like an hour but it didn't bother us because you can people watch and sip complimentary coffee while you wait. 

Finally I hear my name being called and personally I think we got the best seats in the place, counter seats. We were in awe at how fast the cooks made everything. We both ordered the Plow and loved it! The potatoes could of used a bit more seasoning but were still great. I had fresh grapefruit juice and it was a nice addition to my morning. Overall we really enjoyed Plow.

excerpts: Coffee, grapefruit juice, and the ginger beer are all great pairs with their dishes.
grapefruit juice.author: Veronica L.
grapefruit juice.review:
Plow is the epitome of what it means to be a brunch spot. I wish I could stop coming here but their food really gets me every time. 

I usually opt for THE PLOW when I come here. The LEMON RICOTTA PANCAKES are the perfect blend of zest and depth for a pancake, this is definitely a must try! The NUESKE'S BACON and HOUSE MADE PORK SAUSAGE are both delicious, but I wouldn't recommend the Chicken-Apple. The potatoes are always fresh and crispy and eggs how you like 'em. The FRENCH TOAST w/ bananas is a great way to end brunch on a sweet note. Coffee, grapefruit juice, and the ginger beer are all great pairs with their dishes.

Things to keep in mind: The wait is going to be long. I was lucky to come by here when the wait was 15-20 minutes, but I know the wait can be up to 1.5-2 hours depending on the day and time you come by. You won't miss this place because of the large crowd standing at the corner of the block waiting to eat at this place.

Service is always great and friendly. Food doesn't take long despite the popularity and seating is both indoor and outdoor.

excerpts: I got the grapefruit juice.
grapefruit juice.author: Jules L.
grapefruit juice.review:
came on a Tuesday around 11am, there were about 5 parties ahead of us. ask them to put your name on the list. some people tried to just sit themselves onto open tables. it is not open seatings. they have little benches for you to sit on as you wait. they will ask if you prefer outdoor or inside seatings or whichever is first available. around after 12, the crowd dies down and not much of a wait. they are open till 2pm though and closed on Mondays. took around 20 mins to be seated. 

ordered the plow: 2 lemon ricotta pancakes, 2 eggs any style, crispy potatoes, and choice of home made pork sausage patties, bacon, or chicken sausage. I got sunny side up and bacon. the plate was a lot of for me and I couldn't finish. LB got the fried egg sandwich with added avocado, side order of pancakes and the pork sausage. he can eat and was not able to finish too. 

food was pretty good. not mind blowing. some of the potatoes are extra crispy like potato chips, egg yolks was small, bacon had a smokey taste, pancakes was alright. I made the mistake of eating that last and it has gotten cold. I do taste the hint of lemon. 

service was good. LB's coffee got refilled 3 times. they asked if you want water also, but we declined. When food arrives, waiter will ask if you need anything else like ketchup or hot sauce. they did not check up on us afterward. the food took a bit to come out, around 25 mins. so don't go hungry. 

a little pricey breakfast, but you're paying for the quality of the ingredients. their juices are not freshly squeezed though, came from bottled jugs. I got the grapefruit juice. Comes in small or large. 

plenty of parking around the neighbor. not metered. nice view as you wait. right off the 280 freeway.

excerpts: The grapefruit juice squeezed fresh, the dungeness scramble AMAZING!
The brined pork chop cooked to perfection and the potatoes just RAD!
grapefruit juice.author: Rob L.
grapefruit juice.review:
OK, let's get that bad stuff out of the way.  The wait. Ok, that's it for the bad.

The good? Well, everything. From the service, the ambiance to especially the food! The gluten free almond flour pancake was AWESOME!!! The bacon was cooked to a extra crispy perfection! The grapefruit juice squeezed fresh, the dungeness scramble AMAZING! The brined pork chop cooked to perfection and the potatoes just RAD! I don't know if you could tell, but I'm a fan!

Oh yeah, careful with gravity when you sit outside on the sloping side of the street, just sayin'....

excerpts: grapefruit juice wasn't too sweet.
grapefruit juice.author: beverly l.
grapefruit juice.review:
had the plow and my friend had the chinese breakfast.  everything was delish!  the pork sausage was house made and it showed.  the rosemary infused potatoes seemed almost deep fried in a good way.  it felt like eating kettle chips at some parts and home fries at others.  the lemon pancakes were tiny, but fluffy, moist and packed with sweet (meyer?) lemon flavor.  the fatty pork in the chinese breakfast had the perfect blend of sugar, acidity, and saltiness.

grapefruit juice wasn't too sweet.  the selection of teas and other drinks seemed thoughtful sourced and made.

this has definitely made it to my favorite brunch places in sf list.  just watch out for the wait.  there was a sizable line even on a friday morning..

excerpts: On a side note, I'll also mention that their house made lemonade is bombsy!
As far as the service goes, it's definitely adequate.
It's not bad by any means, but it's nothing over the top.
If you frequent busy breakfast spots in the city, you should probably already know not to expect outstanding service... but good service.
And good service at an all day busy establishment is good enough for me!
Shoutout to that beautiful hostess who was able to squeeze me in at the counter!
house made lemonade.author: Shayla B.
house made lemonade.review:
So... are YOU ready to plow into some total and utter goodness?! Get them forks and and knives ready people! On your mark... geeeeeet set... aaaand PLOOOW!

Ugh. You know, I don't often put on the stank face. But THIS meal that I had at Plow... yeah, that made me do it. Food was so damn good that I had to put on my stanky face. Like ooooh mah GAAAAWD! Why oh WHYYY was this food just so flippin' GOOD?! Mm, mm, mm! I couldn't tell ya... Naw, naw, naaaaw... now wait. I CAN tell you, and I will. 

First things first; YOU my dear... you need to wait. Yep. Just do it. Keep yourself occupied with the Yelp to make the time go by faster. I'll tell you a little secret though... if you come solo, you won't have to wait as long. I know people don't really like to dine by themselves, but if time is a major issue, then this is a major option. If you don't wanna do that, you'll be looking at wait times of up to 2 hours long! But don't fret... that's what your waiting buddy is for, right? It's worth it. It IS... WORTH... the WAIT! 

So, now you've finally been sat and you're wondering what to get? Welp, their entire menu looks exceptionally good. BUT... if it's your first time dining here... PLOW! Get the PLOW BREAKFAST PLATE! Like... don't even think twice about it. Just say "plow" and hand your server the menu so that those chefs can get to makin' some real magic in that kitchen! But why, you ask? Because it's their signature dish and it's damn delicious... DUH! So, shall I elaborate for you? Mmkay... 

On the Plow breakfast plate:

-Lemon ricotta pancakes: GEE-ZUS! Need I say more?! I personally don't even really like pancakes, but I looooved these! Warm, fluffy, buttery, with a delicious lemon ricotta flavor that bursts into your mouth with each bite. 

-Plow potatoes: The most crispiest and delicious stinkin' 'tatoes that you might ever taste in yo' life-ah! YAS! These carbs are just so damn GOOD! Oh yeah, and no salt needed for these babies. Perfectly seasoned. Thank you!

-House made pork sausage: So, you actually have a choice of meat to choose from. But if you're asking ME... I say, get the pork sausage because it's house made and it's just... GOOD! I know, I know. Repetitive, but hopefully you catch my drift. 

-Yummy eggs: I'mma give you a free for all on this one. I like my eggs scrambled and I must admit that they do them well. However, can have your eggs anyway that you'd like.

And, there you have it; the perfect breakfast! On a side note, I'll also mention that their house made lemonade is bombsy! As far as the service goes, it's definitely adequate. It's not bad by any means, but it's nothing over the top. If you frequent busy breakfast spots in the city, you should probably already know not to expect outstanding service... but good service. And good service at an all day busy establishment is good enough for me! Shoutout to that beautiful hostess who was able to squeeze me in at the counter! Appreciate 'cha!

If you remember nothing else from this review, please please pleeease just remember "Plow" as in the breakfast plate. I promise you won't ever forget it after you've had it. Now, go ahead and get ready to plow into that plate of heaven!

excerpts: Abita root beer was refreshing...
Small place.
We waited 20 minutes on a Wednesday at 1:00.
abita root beer.author: Bleep S.
abita root beer.review: Plow offers high quality,delicious food.Lemon ricotta pancakes were more puddingish than cakey.Smoked trout salad was tossed with the most flavorful olive oil,lemon,garlic dressing in recent memory. Fantastically delicious salad with salty smoked trout, avocado and frisee. Crispy potatoes were very nice. Mushroom and point Reyes cheese sandwich on an acme roll was outstanding. Abita root beer was refreshing...Small place.We waited 20 minutes on a Wednesday at 1:00.
